webTitle: Gattuso stuns new England

fields.headline: Gattuso stuns new England
fields.standfirst:
David Lacey sees Taylor's men fall at the first
Gattuso 57
fields.trailText: David Lacey sees Taylor's men fall at the first hurdle courtesy of Ivan Gattuso snap shot off the bar.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor's lads army remembered enough of their rifle drill to give a tidy performance in losing narrowly to Italy in the Stadio delle Alpi here last night. A pity they were not provided with a few live rounds to make better use of David Beckham's astute creative play in central midfield.

Yet after enduring an impressive opening burst from the Euro 2000 runners-up England played well enough to achieve something approaching parity with the Italians and were starting to suggest that their attack might contain some firepower after all when Gennaro Gattuso beat David James with a snap shot off the bar just before the hour.

Last night England sat their mocks. It was not so much a matter of passing an exam as discovering if a team of largely inexperienced players had the calibre to meet challenges of a more competitive kind later on.

On paper the contest looked one of the grosser mismatches. The best part of the side Italy hope will progress to the World Cup in two years' time faced an England team deliberately selected for its youthful promise - and a promise some way short of fulfilment at that.

Peter Taylor's experiment lacked nothing in balance or ambition but to make it worthwhile he needed a particularly strong performance from Beck- ham, for whom the evening was more a trial of character and judgment than ability.

One of the starker realities of football is that the best-laid schemes stand little chance of success if possession is hard to gain and maintain. England kicked off and for a while thereafter this was the most they saw of the ball.

As for Beckham, he found the stocky, bearded Gattuso keeping him close company from the outset, while Ray Parlour, operating wide on the right, soon came under pressure from the advancing Francesco Coco.

Beckham wasted little time playing the ball up to Emile Heskey in a manner most likely to exploit the Liverpool's striker's power and athleticism. Just past the quarter-hour Beckham did just that, enabling Heskey successfully to take on Fabio Cannavaro for pace before skimming the bar with his shot.

Yet Beckham's natural inclination to drift right and use his more powerful foot meant that on the other flank Gareth Barry and Kieron Dyer saw spasmodic action while Nick Barmby, playing off Heskey in the middle, was often bypassed. And when Barry did get space to use the ball he suffered a series of miscues.

Meanwhile Italy continued to find the weight and angle of pass to penetrate Taylor's back three. In the space of two minutes Marco Delvecchio and Filippo Inzaghi were set up by Stefano Fiore and Coco. Both missed but in any case had been pulled up for a foul and offside respectively.

By tradition the approach of Italian teams to friendly games is equivocal and towards half-time Giovanni Trapattoni's players started to grow lackadaisical. Their passing had lost its earlier snap and crackle, Beckham was beginning to dominate the play between the penalty areas and Heskey was causing genuine concern to Cannavaro and Alessandro Nesta, the best defenders of Euro 2000.

Neverthless Gianluigi Buffon remained relatively unemployed until Beckham tested him with a 25-yard shot after 33 minutes. James was equally idle since the Italians' finishing was rarely commensurate with the incisiveness of their approach. Like all peacetime manouevres this was more about tactical nuances than live ammunition.

Trapattoni's experimental intentions were confirmed early in the second half when the 23-year-old Damiano Zenoni came on for his first taste of international football, replacing Demetrio Albertini while Di Livio gave way to Luigi Di Biagio. A procession of other substitutions followed.

England immediately fell behind to an excellent piece of opportunism by Gattuso, who might nevertheless have been in serious trouble a moment earlier. Apparently objecting to Beckham's claims for a penalty the midfielder thrust a hand into the England captain's face.

In the next instant Gattuso had produced a shot from 25 yards that beat James off the underside of the bar. A few minutes earlier England might have gone ahead when Barmby's run set up Heskey for a low cross that Parlour, running in the from the right, failed to hit the target. And within five minutes of the goal Barry missed his shot after Dyer had pulled the ball back from the byline.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Nice ordered to examine high-profile illnesses

fields.headline: Nice ordered to examine high-profile illnesses
fields.trailText: The national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) has been ordered to advise the NHS on the best and most cost-effective ways to treat high-profile conditions including heart failure, eating disorders and diabetes.
fields.body:
The national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) has been ordered to advise the NHS on the best and most cost-effective ways to treat high-profile conditions including heart failure, eating disorders and diabetes.

The guidance was issued by health minister John Denham today as part of the government's attempts to tackle what it regards as unacceptable UK-wide variations in access to and the quality of NHS care in a number of key areas.

Nice will advise on the cost and clinical effectiveness of eight new health technologies, including drugs for arthritis, schizophrenia and people who want to give up smoking.

The institute will ultimately decide which new drugs and technologies are to be used by the NHS to treat these conditions. Its latest programme is expected to take at least a year to complete.

Nice has already issued guidance on 15 technology appraisals, including controverisal decisions to "ban" the flu drug relenza and fund taxanes cancer drugs.

The programme announced today is as follows:

Smoking cessation: The Nice appraisal will provide GPs with cost and clinical effectiveness evidence for the use of the smoking cessation aids NRT and bupropion (Zyban) in primary care. It will play a significant role in the government's aim of reducing cancer, heart disease and smoking rates in the population.

Schizophrenia: Last year, the Department of Health (DoH) commissioned the Royal College of Psychiatrists and the British Psychological Society to develop guidelines on the management of schizophrenia. Preliminary work was undertaken to look at the evidence concerning the so-called "new" anti-psychotic drugs. This made it clear that a thorough examination was needed of the evidence for all the drugs relevant in the management of schizophrenia, including the traditional drugs. Nice will ensure that a thorough, independent review of the evidence is carried out.

Rhesus disease: The DoH welcomed publication of the guidance on prevention of Rhesus disease from the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists. This guidance included a new recommendation that routine antenatal prophylaxis - an injection of immunogobulin - should be offered to all Rhesus negative women in pregnancy to make a rare cause of neonatal deaths rarer still. Nice will advise on the clinical and cost effectiveness of this treatment as a routine prophylaxis.

Crohn's Disease: Crohn's disease is distressing for sufferers, and it is believed the numbers affected are growing. The Nice appraisal will look at the use of the drug Infliximab, in line with licensed indications, after conventional treatments have failed, and Nice will advise on extended and repeated use as well as single dose.

Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis affects about 5% of women and 2% of men. Nice has been asked to appraise two new treatments, Etanercept and Infliximab, which are used if anti-rheumatic drugs are no longer effective.

Asthma in older children: There is high use of asthma inhalers in childhood and considerable variation in treatment regimes and differences in the range of inhalers available. This increases the difficulty in providing a quality package of care, improving the control of asthma and lessening the effect on children who suffer from this common condition. A more considered and evidence based approach to the treatment of asthma in childhood is needed. Nice will consider and advise.

Asthma care: New evidence-based national guidelines are needed for the management of asthma in adults and children in both primary and secondary care. These will help reduce the number of asthma attacks. Current guidelines are not evidence-based.

Heart failure: Heart failure affects a growing number of people, particularly the elderly. It can be difficult to diagnose and the quality of treatment offered is extremely variable. Patients are subject to frequent acute hospital readmissions due to poor symptom control and often suffer a poor quality of life, particularly during the latter stages of their illness. These clinical guidelines will help doctors and other medical staff in both primary and secondary care deliver more effective diagnosis and treatment for these patients and improve their quality of life.

Eating disorders: Expertise and services are not equally distributed around the country. Not everyone who needs treatment is able to access it easily or quickly. These points are made in the national service framework for mental health. The guidelines will cover the full range of treatments normally available as part of healthcare for people judged to need help. Inpatient treatment is the "established" approach for severe cases of anorexia with extremely low body weight, but outpatient treatment is appropriate for less severe, more common cases and for people with bulimia. Treatment usually involves a form of psychological therapy and advice and guidance on nutrition. In young people, families are commonly involved in treatment as well.

Depression: Depression will affect nearly half of all women and a quarter of all men in the UK before the age of 70 and, at any one time, the prevalence of major depression in the general population is about 5%. Severe depression also carries a raised risk of death by suicide and this is now the second most common cause of death in those under the age of 35. Depression is a common condition, with the vast majority of cases managed in primary care, but services for people with depression are of variable quality, and services are sometimes difficult to access.

Caesarean section: The Government is concerned about the variation in caesarean section rates between hospitals and has a programme in hand to address this and the reasons for the rise in caesarean section rate overall. The national sentinel audit will establish the reasons behind caesarean sections. Nice will use information from this survey to produce evidence-based guidelines for when a caesarean section is necessary.

Common medical emergencies: The work will produce a series of guidelines covering a range of situations where immediate action needs to be taken either to deal with an acute emergency or to prevent an emergency taking place. They will be up-to-date and evidence based and will be continuously updated. Guidelines on healthcare associated infection Healthcare associated infection is a serious problem for the NHS. It can be life-threatening and uses considerable NHS resources. The guidelines will help promote sound infection control in both primary and community care. They will also provide clear statements of good practice for all staff.

Head injuries: Initial assessment, management and referral. The major concern in the management of head-injured patients is to detect damage and impairment early and minimise secondary brain and spinal cord injuries. Prompt and effective initial management can limit the number of patients left with significant behavioural, cognitive, emotional and physical disabilities. Development of clinical guidelines will support the implementation of the health secretary's priorities for modernisation strategies, in accident & emergency, care of critically ill adults, strategy on paediatric intensive care, caring for vulnerable people including children.

Diabetes: The management of type one diabetes has a significant impact on health, including the likelihood of developing long term complications. People with type one diabetes have a life expectancy 25% lower than people without diabetes. Yet there are marked variations around the country in current practice as well as in the outcomes of care. The development by Nice of clinical guidelines for type one diabetes will contribute to the implementation of the diabetes national service framework, which is to be published in 2001 for implementation in the NHS from 2002.

Under consideration for referral to Nice:

Ramipril for patients with heart disease: Recent trial evidence suggests that the drug Ramipril may significantly reduce the risk of death, heart attack and stroke for many patients with or at risk of heart disease, and in particular patients with diabetes. The appraisal by Nice of Ramipril will support consistent and effectively targeted prescribing of the drug for these patients.

Growth hormone replacement: Growth hormone has been used for many years to promote growth in childhood, essentially where there is an absence of naturally produced hormone. However this treatment has sometimes been used to promote growth where there is little evidence of benefit or hormonal deficiency. There is also a lack of sufficient information on the long term results of growth hormone treatment in children of short stature. The highly demanding nature and high costs of this treatment require an optimised prescription, and this remains to be determined. Nice will consider this. This appraisal will also be extended to adult use, subject to further consultation.

webTitle: Livingstone reveals blueprint to tackle housing crisis

fields.headline: Livingstone reveals blueprint to tackle housing crisis
fields.trailText: London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, today announced a dramatic increase in the level of "social housing" as his blueprint for tackling the housing crisis.
fields.body:
London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, today announced a dramatic increase in the level of "social housing" as his blueprint for tackling the housing crisis.

Unveiling a report by the Greater London Authority Housing Commission, he announced that London's economic future is being jeopardised by the lack of affordable housing for vital workers who cannot afford to live in the capital.

The report says that at least 280,000 of the new homes built in London over the next decade must be earmarked for low income workers such as nurses, teachers and police to help maintain decent services. It comes in the wake of the publication of the government's urban white paper, and today's Commons statement by environment secretary John Prescott.

Researchers estimate that London's population will grow to more than 8m people by 2016, creating a need for approximately 318,000 new homes in the social housing sector to be built over the next 10 years. Another 11,200 are needed to deal with the backlog of homelessness, overcrowding and poor housing conditions.

"What we have arrived at is a vision of London as a thriving, inclusive world city in which all its inhabitants have a decent and affordable home in neighbourhoods where they want to live, within reasonable reach of their work and with high quality public services," said Chris Holmes, chairman of the Housing Commission and director of the homeless charity Shelter.

However, Conservative regeneration spokesman Tim Loughton said that such levels of increased "social housing" would endanger urban regeneration in the capital and inappropriately take control of housing away from London boroughs. "Livingstone is still living in the 1970s, trying to recreate a mythical socialist utopia. A left-wing municipal housing policy will be a recipe for continued deprivation and decay in London," he said.

webTitle: Explained: The Middle East peace process

fields.headline: The Middle East peace process
fields.standfirst: The situation in Israel and the Palestinian territories is frighteningly close to war. It is a savage irony that this threat comes after recent remarkable progress towards a comprehensive settlement. Derek Brown, Mark Tran, Julian Glover and Simon Jeffery explain the crisis
fields.trailText: The situation in Israel and the Palestinian territories is frighteningly close to war. It is a savage irony that this threat comes after recent remarkable progress towards a comprehensive settlement. We explain the crisis.
fields.byline: Derek Brown, Mark Tran, Julian Glover and Simon Jeffery
fields.body:
Is the peace process dead?
It looks like it. The crisis began at the end of September with rioting on the Palestinian West Bank. Palestinian fury, first provoked by a provocative visit by Israeli opposition leader Ariel Sharon to an Islamic holy site in Jerusalem, was heightened by the savagery of Israel's response to the riots and other attacks.

What has happened since then?
To date, over 200 people have died, overwhelmingly Palestinians. The crisis on the streets could have been contained, but the key problem for the peacemakers is that the issue has moved on to become a conflict between rival states. Stone-throwing protests by Palestinian youths are giving way to carefully calculated attacks on Israeli troops and the 200,000 Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza. In addition, Israel has repeatedly used helicopter gunships to attack key Palestinian sites, including Yasser Arafat's headquarters. Mr Arafat calls the conflict a "war".

Why do the Palestinians attack?
Specifically, they want Israel to retreat to its pre-1967 borders and give the West Bank, Gaza Strip and Jerusalem to the Palestinians. More generally, many resent what they consider to be an Israeli military occupation and the increasing number of Jewish settlers.

Why does Israel attack?
Israel says it will revenge the death of its citizens and, without fail, uses its army to strike against the organisations and individuals it believes are behind the attacks. Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak says he supports peace but public opinion says the army is not being tough enough.

But wasn't the peace process dead in the water anyway?
The last serious attempt to negotiate a permanent settlement was made at the Camp David summit in July. It ended in failure after 15 days, but not before the two sides had come tantalisingly close to wrapping up a deal.

What progress was made?
Leaks from Camp David suggested that agreement was within reach on the issues of refugees and the boundaries of a future Palestinian state. But deep differences remain over Jerusalem.

What are the remaining sticking points?
Land. Mr Arafat wants Israel to return all Palestinian territory occupied since the 1967 war, including the West Bank, where the Palestinian authority has full sovereignty over only 40% of the land. Israel appears willing to cede 92%. Discussion on territory is hugely complicated by some 145 Jewish settlements dotted throughout the West Bank occupied by some 200,000 Israelis. As many as 40,000 settlers may have to move to Israel proper, or live under Palestinian rule. Smaller settlements would go, particularly in the Jordan Valley, but three large blocs would stay.

What about refugees?
There are some 3.6m registered Palestinian refugees in Jordan, driven out when Israel was created in 1948. Israel has so far refused the Palestinians' right to return, endorsed by UN resolutions, or to accept moral and legal responsibility for their expulsion and consequent hardships. There are proposals that Japan, the US and Europe contribute to a fund to help the Palestinian authority handle those who want to return or compensate those who do not want to come back.

If talks resume will Jerusalem be the most contentious issue?
This could be the deal breaker. Both sides consider Jerusalem as their own holy capital and Mr Barak refuses to contemplate its division. The Palestinians have a sliver of the city in Abu Dis, the village straddling the city boundaries where a Palestinian parliament is being built. Despite Israel's tough public line, leaks suggest that Mr Barak might cede two Palestinian neighbourhoods in the north, Shuafat and Beit Hanina. Jerusalem is such an emotional and difficult issue, it might be shelved for later.

Are there any prospects for negotiations to resume?
In the short term, hope lies with international leaders - especially Bill Clinton who is keen to broker a deal before he leaves office in January. Mr Clinton regularly speaks to Mr Arafat and Mr Barak but the best he can hope for is maybe to prevent all out war. The Israelis say they will not resume talks until shooting attacks against on their army stop but senior Palestinians say the confrontations will continue through future talks.

When will it end?
No one knows. However, Israel has a non-military strategy to put pressure on the Palestinians to meet their demands. The West Bank and Gaza are small disjointed territories and Israel is taking advantage of their vunerability with a blockade of the towns and villages that is crippling the local economy. Unemployment is already high among the Palestinians since the one-sixth of the workforce employed in Israel has been barred from going to the country and, by extension, their jobs. Mr Barak has also blocked the tax revenues that Israel collects for the Palestinians. He may bring the Palestinians to the negotiating table but true peace is a distant prospect.

More generally, many resent what they consider to be an Israeli military occupation and the increasing number of Jewish settlers. Why does Israel attack? Israel says it will revenge the death of its citizens and, without fail, uses its army to strike against the organisations and individuals it believes are behind the attacks. Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak says he supports peace but public opinion says the army is not being tough enough. But wasn't the peace process dead in the water anyway? The last serious attempt to negotiate a permanent settlement was made at the Camp David summit in July. It ended in failure after 15 days, but not before the two sides had come tantalisingly close to wrapping up a deal. What progress was made? Leaks from Camp David suggested that agreement was within reach on the issues of refugees and the boundaries of a future Palestinian state. But deep differences remain over Jerusalem. What are the remaining sticking points? Land. Mr Arafat wants Israel to return all Palestinian territory occupied since the 1967 war, including the West Bank, where the Palestinian authority has full sovereignty over only 40% of the land. Israel appears willing to cede 92%. Discussion on territory is hugely complicated by some 145 Jewish settlements dotted throughout the West Bank occupied by some 200,000 Israelis. As many as 40,000 settlers may have to move to Israel proper, or live under Palestinian rule. Smaller settlements would go, particularly in the Jordan Valley, but three large blocs would stay. What about refugees? There are some 3.6m registered Palestinian refugees in Jordan, driven out when Israel was created in 1948. Israel has so far refused the Palestinians' right to return, endorsed by UN resolutions, or to accept moral and legal responsibility for their expulsion and consequent hardships. There are proposals that Japan, the US and Europe contribute to a fund to help the Palestinian authority handle those who want to return or compensate those who do not want to come back. If talks resume will Jerusalem be the most contentious issue? This could be the deal breaker. Both sides consider Jerusalem as their own holy capital and Mr Barak refuses to contemplate its division. The Palestinians have a sliver of the city in Abu Dis, the village straddling the city boundaries where a Palestinian parliament is being built. Despite Israel's tough public line, leaks suggest that Mr Barak might cede two Palestinian neighbourhoods in the north, Shuafat and Beit Hanina. Jerusalem is such an emotional and difficult issue, it might be shelved for later. Are there any prospects for negotiations to resume? In the short term, hope lies with international leaders - especially Bill Clinton who is keen to broker a deal before he leaves office in January. Mr Clinton regularly speaks to Mr Arafat and Mr Barak but the best he can hope for is maybe to prevent all out war. The Israelis say they will not resume talks until shooting attacks against on their army stop but senior Palestinians say the confrontations will continue through future talks. When will it end? No one knows. However, Israel has a non-military strategy to put pressure on the Palestinians to meet their demands. The West Bank and Gaza are small disjointed territories and Israel is taking advantage of their vunerability with a blockade of the towns and villages that is crippling the local economy. Unemployment is already high among the Palestinians since the one-sixth of the workforce employed in Israel has been barred from going to the country and, by extension, their jobs. Mr Barak has also blocked the tax revenues that Israel collects for the Palestinians. He may bring the Palestinians to the negotiating table but true peace is a distant prospect. webTitle: Battered woman stars in ad

fields.headline: Battered woman stars in ad
fields.trailText: The face of a severely battered woman fronts a shocking charity advertising campaign launched this week. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
The face of a severely battered woman fronts a shocking charity advertising campaign launched this week. The advertisement depicts a woman sharing make-up tips on how she covers facial injuries from domestic violence.

A women's human rights and development charity, Womankind Worldwide, aims to raise awareness of domestic violence following a recent report by the University of London that revealed that the police receives over 1000 calls a day from female victims of domestic violence.

Maggie Baxter, executive director of the charity said: "Domestic violence harms women both physically and emotionally. Many hide their pain rather than reveal their personal suffering. This advert aims to break the silence, and prompt debate."

The advert will appear in women's magazines this month and on poster sites across England. A radio advert featuring the actress, Juliet Stevenson, will also go out next week.

Womankind Worldwide is campaigning against violence in the run up to its white ribbon day on November 25. The charity asks people to wear a white ribbon as a symbol of hope for a world where women and girls can live free from the fear of violence. Celebrities including Dawn French, Jerry Hall and Kate Adie are also backing the campaign.

 To get your white ribbon call 020 7588 6099.

webTitle: Nightingale flies to top

fields.headline: Nightingale flies to top
fields.trailText: 5pm:Mary Nightingale, long a favourite of ITV bosses, has finally made it on to the grade A roster at ITN, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
Mary Nightingale, long a favourite of ITV bosses, has finally made it on to the grade A roster at ITN.

The TV presenter will cover for Kirsty Young when she goes on maternity leave in January.

Ms Nightingale first made her name as Alastair Stewart's co-presenter on the regional news programme London Tonight.

But she has been being groomed for bigger things ever since joining Carlton TV as the presenter of ITV's holiday programme Wish You Were Here.

And she hit the headlines earlier this year when TV star Barrymore picked her up at an awards ceremony, exposing her underwear.

Ms Nightingale said: "I'm really looking forward to getting back into the newscaster's chair."

Her arrival at ITN raises questions about the future of newsreader Katie Derham, who currently doubles up as weekend news anchor and media and arts correspondent.

webTitle: State funding for children's hospices is too low

fields.headline: State funding for children's hospices is too low
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lee, fellow in fundraising at South Bank university, says children's hospices need more than just words of support from the government
fields.trailText: Stephen Lee, fellow in fundraising at South Bank university, says children's hospices need more than just words of support from the government
fields.body:
There are few worthier causes within the voluntary sector than children's hospices. With the biggest growth rate in the sector, the hospice movement remains one of the great unsung success stories of the past twenty years. So why are children's hospices in crisis?

Twenty years ago it was nearly impossible to raise funds for hospices. Fears born out of ignorance prevented people from making contributions. Hospices were seen as places to die and people steered clear of talking about them.

Now, however, hospices are respected and loved by their communities and are a godsend to governments of all persuasions. Childrens' hospices are leaders in fundraising excellence, grounded in community action and sustained by impressive volunteer networks.

Yet hospice wards are closed at weekends, beds are empty and highly skilled and committed clinical staff have been let go - all in the face of an increased number of urgent patient referrals.

Charities and voluntary organisations exist because we want them to. They flourish through the sustained commitment of their communities. But income through donations is not enough - the state must make a contribution.

In this brave new world of compacts, the government claims it is encouraging the creativity and innovation of the voluntary sector. Yet it has responded to the urgent financial need in hospices by offering £50m to support the entire movement - less than £125,000 for each one.

Frankly, this is madness. Most hospices need well over a million pounds each year in voluntary contributions just to survive and many already fundraise beyond the norm. When hospices so clearly benefit the health service and their communities, £50m is nothing short of an insult.

As a result, selection criteria will be further narrowed and children and their families excluded from the care and expertise that is available but not achievable, all for the want of a proper partnership between the state and the voluntary sector.

If the voluntary sector compact with government is to offer anything practical to our beneficiaries, we need money and action from government, not just the supportive words that we hear at the moment.

 Stephen Lee will be online to answer questions on fundraising on 22 November at 3pm.

webTitle: Mayor plans to challenge ministers over new homes

fields.headline: Mayor plans to challenge ministers over new homes
fields.standfirst: Report warns that housebuilding in capital "must double" over next decade
fields.trailText: London mayor Ken Livingstone is preparing to challenge ministers by using his new planning powers to demand tens of thousands of affordable homes in the capital for people on average incomes unable to qualify for mortgages.
fields.byline: Peter Hetherington, regional affairs correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
London mayor Ken Livingstone is preparing to challenge ministers by using his new planning powers to demand tens of thousands of affordable homes in the capital for people on average incomes unable to qualify for mortgages.

The mayor will signal his determination to address a growing housing crisis after receiving a report today which warns that house building in London needs to more than double over the next 10 years to prevent rising homlessness.

It says that 43,000 new homes annually are needed until 2011, at least half for rent or subsidised and shared ownership.

With teachers and nurses priced out of the capital's booming housing market, the report from a housing commission - launched by Mr Livingstone shortly after taking office in May - warns that "the unequal distribution of the benefits of the capital's booming economy may mean that London is sowing the seeds of its own social and economic decline".

The commission, chaired by the director of Shelter, Chris Holmes, says urgent action is needed with the prospect of the number of households in London rising by 500,000 to 3.6 million by 2016.

webTitle: Oxford heart centre:management arrogance denounced

fields.headline: Oxford heart centre:management arrogance denounced
fields.standfirst: Chaos, feuding and cronyism at leading heart centre
fields.trailText: The future for heart surgery in Oxford, which was seen as a centre of excellence 10 years ago, is bleak unless its cardiac centre's five surgeons learn to work as a team, says NHS report.
fields.body:
The future for heart surgery in Oxford, which was seen as a centre of excellence 10 years ago, is bleak unless its cardiac centre's five surgeons learn to work as a team, a report commissioned by the NHS executive has said.

It denounced the "chaotic"' arrangements for operations, which included antagonism between surgeons, overbooked lists, apparent emphasis on putting private patients before NHS ones and failure to prioritise by clinical need.

The investigation concluded that the Oxford heart centre at John Radcliffe hospital had developed a culture in which there was a risk of cronyism.

Robust procedures for some aspects of patient care did not exist, the local NHS trust had failed to respond appropriately to nurses' concerns and management had not monitored arrangements to address weaknesses at the centre. "As a consequence, cardiac surgery levels are at their lowest for a decade, and robust clinical audit is still an aspiration rather than a reality," the report said.

In four years the number of adult open-heart operations carried out in Oxford fell from more than 1,400 to 800. In the past year alone, the number of operations cancelled on the day of admission rose by 20% to 130. The waiting list rose by 30% to 270, with those waiting for more than nine months up from 21 to 51.

Staff interviewed during the investigation divided into two camps - one still believing Oxford to be a world leader in various medical fields, with many of the problems down to lack of money and poor management, the other believing an "Oxford complacency, even arrogance" was hampering development.

The report noted that Stephen Westaby, the driving force behind cardiac surgery at the John Radcliffe, had "tended to isolate himself from others in the unit", building up his own research team for a separately funded, artificial heart programme.

The results of disciplinary investigations into the alleged behaviour of a surgeon at the centre, Ravi Pillai, are expected to be published soon. Oxford coroner Nicholas Gardiner is investigating the death of a two-year-old Aylesbury girl Safeena Begum in August last year.

webTitle: Women drinking more

fields.headline: Drink and be merry
fields.standfirst: New research suggests women are drinking more to relieve stress. Or is it just because they like it, asks novelist  Laura Hird
fields.trailText: New research suggests women are drinking more to relieve stress. Or is it just because they like it, asks novelist Laura Hird.
fields.body:
Recent figures published by Alcohol Concern suggest that one in five women drinks more than the recommended daily limit. Stress and increased spending power are seen as major factors. But this overlooks the fact that we also drink because it is utterly enjoyable, a wonderful way to unwind and to counteract shyness.

It's a fast escape, a short holiday. Women's lives are so consumed by juggling work and family that they need quick thrills to squeeze into limited free time. Alcohol fits the bill perfectly.

Even in the company of pregnant friends, or those who have just given birth, the real pain of childbirth seems nowadays to be having to stop getting drunk for nine months. Breastfeeding is replaced by the bottle as soon as possible, to make way for the other bottle.

Why do we drink so much? It could be that it's impossible to get away from alcohol: the last aisle in the supermarket, after a stressful shop with the kids, heaves with shelves of wine to get past on the way to the check-out. They smile out from behind the counter of every corner shop. You can go for a meal, the cinema, theatre, even the zoo to try to avoid it, but it is there as well. Everywhere you look, there are neon Budweiser signs; off licences within practically every group of shops.

And pubs are forever developing new ways to attract more women. Pub quizzes, live music, karaoke (you can't do karaoke sober, for God's sake) and, of course, drinks promotions. Do you notice, the majority of drinks promotions are for those trendy bottled spirits with alluring names to which women are drawn? Is offering two for one, or three for two the right way to encourage women to drink less?

Women want to be in pubs without needing to be enticed. Pubs fulfil our need for a sense of community. Not that it's just the drink companies that are trying to get us all addicted to their product. We do it to each other. My friends do it to me and, I confess, I do it to them. I am a pusher.

When I have guests round, I feel I have failed as a hostess if, at any point, someone is left sitting with an empty glass, or heaven forbid, we run out of drink altogether.

To drink in company is to exert a silent pressure on the people you are with to do the same. I have a friend who, a year ago, was allergic to alcohol, but now drinks like a fish. Every time she visits, I offer alcohol. I am to blame. The only people I know who don't drink are alcoholics. If I meet someone who doesn't drink, I assume they must have a drink problem.

The peer pressure is enormous and we are all culpable, at all ages. "Oh, you can just have one, surely." Why? Because when people are drinking, they like the people they are with to be drinking too, so they feel less guilty. Drinking with heavy drinkers is ideal as it gives you the impression that you are drinking less.

People who have stopped drinking don't get invited out so much for this reason and because they remind people of their real fear about drinking: that one day they, too, will reach the stage where they may have to stop drinking completely.

Research also suggests that 41% of women have one-night stands when they are drunk. It doesn't mention that they also have better sex with partners who no longer manage to turn them on when sober. What is wrong with one-night stands anyway? Are they bad for you? Or are they bad for men's chances of having a relationship, since that is what they appear to want these days.

Women's desire for sex without commitment threatens this. It's bad for men. Not for women. One-night stands are said to illustrate a lack of self-respect. If they do, that lack is there before the woman gets drunk.

Drink also helps to start a lot of relationships. It makes the tentative building of the early days a lot easier. At work, you don't really bond with people until you've seen each other pissed. Couldn't they just increase the recommended units we can drink, then fewer women would be drinking too much? Twenty-one units a week? Don't French children drink more than that with dinner?

Everyone knows what the health risks are. They are also part of the attraction. Drinking is a quick and easy way to live dangerously and defy death. We are addicted to being addicted to things. Moderation is for bores. Cheers.

 Born Free, nominated for the Whitbread Prize, is published by Canongate, £6.99.

webTitle: Gore sweats on Florida recount ruling

fields.headline: Gore sweats on Florida recount ruling
fields.standfirst:
 Bush rejects Gore impasse solution
 At least 24 court cases in action
 Clinton suggests voting reform

Special report: US election race
fields.trailText:
 Bush rejects Gore impasse solution
 At least 24 court cases in action
 Clinton suggests voting reform
Special report: US election race
fields.body:
In the latest legal attempt to win the contested US presidency, Al Gore asked a Florida judge today to force the state to count disputed presidential ballots being hand tallied after a deadline had passed.

Mr Gore, who trails George W Bush by 300 votes in Florida, asked the judge to reverse a Republican state official's decision to reject vote counts still going on in some counties.

The Democrats want final vote certification in Florida delayed until all those totals are in.

On Tuesday, the same circuit judge, Terry Lewis, had upheld that day's state deadline for submitting results of recounts to the state elections board. But he also had said the secretary of state for Florida, Katherine Harris, had flexibility in deciding whether to accept late filings.

Four counties - three of them heavily Democratic - asked for an extension. Ms Harris turned them down late last night. Judge Lewis scheduled a hearing for 1700GMT today.

There was no immediate response from Ms Harris in court. It was not clear how much authority the state court had to intervene, and the case could pass quickly to the state supreme court, where other election-related cases are pending.

There are over 20 court cases pending today and countywide hand recounts are still in dispute.

Meanwhile, Mr Gore and Mr Bush's PR battle has moved into a new phase. Vice president, Mr Gore, said last night: "I don't know what the final results will show." He suggested a state-wide hand recount of Florida's 6m votes as a way to achieve a "fair and final" result without further legal manoeuvring.

Mr Bush, the Texas governor, countered that a few hours later in rejecting the vice president's suggestions. "The outcome of this election will not be the result of deals or efforts to mould public opinion,"

Hand recounting, which Gore wants, "introduces human error and politics into the vote-counting process," said Mr Bush.

Democrats also filed papers arguing against the Bush campaign before a federal appeals court in Atlanta. Mr Bush is also in that court trying to overturn a federal ruling in Florida that let the recount continue.

"This case is simply not appropriate for federal court intervention of any kind at this point in the proceeding," Mr Gore's lawyers argued in a brief filed this morning with the 11th US circuit court of appeals in Atlanta.

Mr Bush's team, in arguments to the same court seeking to stop hand recounts in the four Democratic Florida counties, warned that Americans are witnessing the "disintegration" of the way they elect presidents. The Bush camp complains hand counts are prone to error.

Mr Bush's lawyers said in their submission: "Eight days after Florida's presidential vote, the entire nation is witnessing the disintegration of a process that was designed to elect America's president.

"The Florida manual recount process is being used to eliminate any possibility of an orderly, rational and final end to the election."

The federal court's unusually rapid decision to get involved could launch the controversy toward the US supreme court.

The winner in the stalemated Florida vote will claim the state's decisive 25 electoral votes and almost certainly the White House. Mr Gore is hoping to pick up enough votes in the recounts to overtake Mr Bush's narrow lead.

Ms Harris announced last night she saw no reason to accept late vote filings. Only absentee ballots from overseas, due in by midnight Friday, will be rolled into the totals, she said.

Democrats have sharply criticised Ms Harris, who supported Mr Bush's campaign, as a partisan Republican and suggested her actions have been motivated by her politics. But a lawyer retained by her office, Joseph Klock, defended her today.

He said: "More than half the lawyers who have been working on this for the secretary are Democrats and I bet probably half of them voted for Gore."

The US president, Bill Clinton, in Brunei for the Asia-Pacific Economic Co-operation summit, said that the Florida controversy will likely spur election reforms. "I think there will be a lot of pressure to improve the form of ballots and the methods of voting and have more clear standards around the country," Mr Clinton said as photographers took pictures of him and the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin.

Mr Gore spoke again today on radio saying he would "fight all the way" to ensure every vote is counted."The choice is whether the voters are going to win this election by having every vote count," the Democrat said.

"If I'm successful I will certainly fight all the way for the principles that need to be defended," Mr Gore said, adding that he would at the same time try to "reach out to the people who disagree with me."

Asked if Republicans were trying to steal the election, Mr Gore cautioned, "I would discourage the use of that word because, again, however it comes out we're going to come behind the winner and please understand there are high emotions on the other side."

He spoke shortly after his running mate, Joseph Lieberman, warned that an unjust election will cause American to "go into the new century divided with a president who does not have legitimacy."

Mr Gore and Mr Bush made separate television appearances last night, the vice president at his official residence in Washington, the Texan at the governor's mansion in Texas. Both men strove for a statesmanlike presentation, and manoeuvred for maximum TV exposure.

webTitle: US post-election campaign exposes financial loophole

fields.headline: US post-election campaign exposes financial loophole
fields.standfirst:
As the race for the White House shows no sign of ending, Jane Martinson in New York looks at the legal loopholes being exploited in the unprecedented demand for post-election finance
Audio: Mike Ellison in Florida (2mins 26)
fields.trailText: As the race for the White House shows no sign of ending, Jane Martinson looks at the legal loopholes being exploited in the unprecedented demand for post-election finance
fields.body:
As armies of lawyers, teams of chad counters and former secretaries of state slugged it out in Florida, the campaign website for George W Bush offered some clarity yesterday.

There, in large capital letters, was the most urgent communication of this post-election morass. "YOU CAN CONTRIBUTE!" was the message delivered to anyone seeking guidance on one of the closest US presidential elections in history.

Never mind the issues of fairness and democracy, "show me the money" has been a rallying cry for this election and its unprecedented final chapter.

After a record-breaking fundraising effort by both the Republicans and Democrats in this year's election, campaign financiers had hoped it might all be over on November 7. The unprecedented recount effort has instead prompted demands for unheard-of amounts of post-election finance.

Within 24 hours of the they-love-you-they-love-you-not night in Florida, campaigners had raised $3m (£2.15m) for the Al Gore recount effort. They were helped by the fact that some 200 favourite, ie most generous, donors had turned up in Nashville on the morning of the November 8 for what was meant to be a celebratory party. Instead of being offered some plum ambassadorship with Georgian house attached, they were asked to open up their purses.

The Bush campaign team were too busy framing early editions of the nation's newspapers - the ones that shrieked "BUSH WINS!!" - to build up their own recount fund until the weekend. They were therefore forced to post the stark message on Bush2000.com yesterday. Their fundraising efforts started in earnest with an urgent e-mail sent out over the weekend to all supporters asking for cheques for up to $5,000 to be sent to Texas ASAP.

Advocates of campaign finance reform are less worried about the amounts raised by these efforts than by the apparent disclosure loopholes they highlight. After all, both campaigns are understood to have spent between $20m and $30m (between £14.4m and £21.5m) in a television advertising blitz during the final week.

What really worries campaigners is that the candidates appear to be able to solicit as much money as possible from undisclosed sources to pay for their post-election battles.

This is because, according to clauses 107.B20 and 108.B20 of the Federal Elections Commission Act, money raised for a recount is not officially a "contribution" to a particular candidate's campaign. The reasons for this are somewhat arcane and seem to depend on the fact that the campaigns officially end when the election does.

The only types of donation outlawed under these little-used clauses are those from unions, corporations or foreign sources. However, individuals or the political action committees organised by American workers can give unlimited amounts for the recount. These donations are also not subject to the FEC's public disclosure requirement.

The Center for Public Integrity is one of several non-partisan reform groups to have voiced their concerns about this apparent loophole in the law. Peter Eisner, managing director of the Center, says, "What's worrying is the genuine concern about interest groups providing money in return for ingratiating themselves with the candidates. It also creates a system in which the public can be left out."

He does believe, however, that the intense scrutiny awarded to this phase of the election will make both candidates act on their voluntary promises to disclose the identity of their donors.

So far, the Bush campaign has promised to post the names of donors on its website and to voluntarily restrict the amount given by individuals. As of Wednesday it had failed to do so.

The Gore campaign has promised to reveal its donors "to the appropriate authority". The Center expects this to be the Inland Revenue Service, or US tax authority.

Official reports like these usually take about 90 days to appear in public, which means that the identity of donors to the Gore recount effort will not be known until January, when the vice president may or may not be moving into the Oval Office.

By then, every vote will hopefully have been counted in this election. Not to mention every dollar.

webTitle: Blunkett announces £978m package for academics

fields.headline: Blunkett announces £978m package for academics
fields.trailText: Education secretary, David Blunkett, today announced £330m of new money over the next three years to boost pay for academics and university support staff.
fields.body:
Education secretary, David Blunkett, today announced £330m of new money over the next three years to boost pay for academics and university support staff.

The extra funds are part of an overall package unveiled by Blunkett for English universities, which will see funding increase by £978m - up nearly 10% in real terms over the next three years.

According to the Department for Education and Employment, funding will increase overall by £412m in 2001-02. There are also planned increases of £268m in 2002-03 and £298m in 2003-04. Details have not been released, but the increases include fees from public funding and from students, earmarked capital funding, and funding for widening participation made available through universities. They apply to grants to the Higher Education Funding Council for England and the Teacher Training Agency.

For academic and non academic pay, universities will receive an extra £50m in 2001-02, an extra £110m in 2002-03, and an extra £170m 2003-04. Universities will need to submit plans detailing how they will use funding to "enhance quality and modernise management of the sector", particularly addressing equal opportunities issues. Academic leaders have warned that under-funding over the last 20 years is forcing many senior academics to leave UK universities for better paid positions in other professions or more wealthy US academic institutions.

Universities currently face industrial action by staff after academic unions rejected a 3 per cent increase in pay offered by administrators.

University heads welcomed the news, but are awaiting detailed funding figures from the government. "Universities will obviously be interested to see the details behind these headline figures, particularly the government's specific targets on additional student numbers for future years," said Diana Warwick, Chief Executive of the Committee of Vice-chancellors and Principals.

David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, said: At first sight the extra resources for pay look very welcome but we will be examining the detail. I shall be writing to university vice-chancellors asking for urgent meetings to discuss the best ways to spend this much-needed boost for the sector."

The government says that universities and colleges will be able to recruit an additional 45,000 students next year. Over the next two years, £10m has been set aside to develop the new two year foundation degrees, which will be available from August 2001. Further expansion is planned in the following two years to meet the government's aim that, by the age of 30, half of all young people will have benefited from higher education.

The new funding package includes £60m over three years from the government's new 'Excellence Challenge' package to improve access for students from low-income families.

Officials at the Department for Education and Employment say that funding for English universities by 2003-4 will be £6.4bn - a 10% increase in real terms.

Next week the research councils will also announce details of extra £250m over three years for research into the priority areas of genomics, e-science and basic technology. A further £80m will be available to support university-business links over the three years.

In July, the government and the Wellcome Trust also announced £1bn in funding for improvements in the research infrastructure which will be available to institutions in 2002-03 and 2003-04.

webTitle: Head salutes 100% exam success rate

fields.headline: Head salutes 100% exam success rate
fields.standfirst: Top class
fields.trailText: Kevin Satchwell, headteacher of Thomas Telford school in Shropshire, yesterday declared himself the luckiest head in the country after his school became the first comprehensive to chalk up a 100% success rate at GCSE.
fields.body:
Kevin Satchwell, headteacher of Thomas Telford school in Shropshire, yesterday declared himself the luckiest head in the country after his school became the first comprehensive to chalk up a 100% success rate at GCSE.

Every GCSE entrant at the school gained at least five grade A*-C passes - more than twice the national average in the state sector - making it the top comprehensive in the country in the government league tables published today.

Thomas Telford opened in 1991 as one of 15 city technology colleges launched by the Tories as part of a programme to raise school standards through innovation.

The colleges have been encouraged to use ground-breaking learning and teaching methods relevant to the 21st century and boosted by extra financial resources from the private sector.

Pupils at Thomas Telford work a 35-hour week - one-third more than the state school average - and take home 10 detailed teaching reports to their parents every year. The day begins at 7.30am and can last until 7pm. Lessons last three hours.

Competition for places is so keen that the school now attracts more than 1,000 applications every year for just 168 first year places.

Staff also work a longer week, but are rewarded with performance-related pay and receive extra payment for covering classes and running school clubs and societies.

What the tables do not show is that all the pupils achieved at least six passes at the higher grades, while 91% gained 10 or more top grades.

Mr Satchwell, who has been head since the school opened, said yesterday: "No one should underestimate how hard we have worked to achieve 100%. Everyone connected with these fantastic results should be congratulated for their contribution. I am probably the luckiest headteacher in the country to have had the privilege of leading Thomas Telford school to this record breaking position."

He said it was important the school shared "what is working effectively here with other schools who want to work with us". Significant progress had already been made with more than 500 schools around the country using some of its online teaching and learning materials, he said.

webTitle: Community values beat the band

fields.headline: Community values beat the band
fields.standfirst: Improving
fields.trailText: Anyone looking for excellence at Brighouse high school, in Yorkshire's textile heartland, only has to slide open a window and cock an ear.
fields.body:
Anyone looking for excellence at Brighouse high school, in Yorkshire's textile heartland, only has to slide open a window and cock an ear.

Just inside the hilltop grounds, the rehearsal hall of the Brighouse and Rastrick brass band thumps and toots out the message, twice a week, that it is perfectly possible to be world famous if you come from round here.

Like the band, whose Floral Dance record topped the charts and paid for the hall, Brighouse is basking in league table glory today. Its status as the highest comprehensive in the "most improving school" category will join another recent trophy on the foyer noticeboard: a newspaper headline saying Brighouse 1 Eton 0.

"That was when we won BP's Build A Car competition, beat ing Eton's team which apparently included a few friends of Prince William," said headteacher Graham Soles. A fixture at the school since East Calderdale went comprehensive in 1985 - initially as deputy, then as head for the last eight years - he also recalls the winning Brighouse hovercraft of 1995.

This year's record results, he said, came in a particularly interesting context; a corner of British education where everyone seems to be winning. Although there are three state grammar schools within five miles, plus a flourishing independent sector, all three comprehensives in Brighouse, Rastrick and Heckmondwike are successful and over-subscribed.

"It owes something to a local, historically working class culture of valuing education," said Mr Soles, translating Brighouse town's Latin motto as "knowledge and hard work". Both he and his deputy, Jane Pickerill, come from similar backgrounds just down the M62, the former mining towns of Normanton and Castleford.

Knowing a bit of Latin is part of the deal: Brighouse runs an after-school Latin GCSE as a tempter for academic students - with an added incentive for those who attend. Mr Soles said: "We usually employ the top GCSE student to take the next year's class, when they're in the sixth form, paying them a proper wage."

Brighouse is a genuine comprehensive, however - happy about the GCSE league table success (61.2% with five grade A-Cs, 96% with five Gs or above, 98% with at least one G or above). The school also saw a record A-level pass rate of 90.5%.

But staff emphasised that special needs got exceptional targeting, including a new visually impaired unit and the adapting of the whole junior campus for a blind student, due to arrive later this year. "One of the results which gave us greatest pleasure this year was a special needs pupil who got 11 GCSEs," said Mr Soles. His own daughter Jenny is meanwhile in the sixth form, picking "Dad's school" rather than "Mum's" - Graham's wife Doreen is deputy head at Heckmondwike.

Friendly local competition is part of the recipe for improvement, along with very strong links to the town of Brighouse - 35,000 people who consider the school to be "theirs."

And do not forget the violet walls, inspiring keywords on ceilings and walls, and music in art classes for girls. The school is trying out an "accelerated learning scheme" which ordains these things - including the theory that girls but not boys can do two things at once, such as drawing and listening to music.

"It seems to be working," said Mr Soles. But if it does not, you can rely on Brighouse to chuck it out.

Although there are three state grammar schools within five miles, plus a flourishing independent sector, all three comprehensives in Brighouse, Rastrick and Heckmondwike are successful and over-subscribed. "It owes something to a local, historically working class culture of valuing education," said Mr Soles, translating Brighouse town's Latin motto as "knowledge and hard work". Both he and his deputy, Jane Pickerill, come from similar backgrounds just down the M62, the former mining towns of Normanton and Castleford. Knowing a bit of Latin is part of the deal: Brighouse runs an after-school Latin GCSE as a tempter for academic students - with an added incentive for those who attend. Mr Soles said: "We usually employ the top GCSE student to take the next year's class, when they're in the sixth form, paying them a proper wage." Brighouse is a genuine comprehensive, however - happy about the GCSE league table success (61.2% with five grade A-Cs, 96% with five Gs or above, 98% with at least one G or above). The school also saw a record A-level pass rate of 90.5%. But staff emphasised that special needs got exceptional targeting, including a new visually impaired unit and the adapting of the whole junior campus for a blind student, due to arrive later this year. "One of the results which gave us greatest pleasure this year was a special needs pupil who got 11 GCSEs," said Mr Soles. His own daughter Jenny is meanwhile in the sixth form, picking "Dad's school" rather than "Mum's" - Graham's wife Doreen is deputy head at Heckmondwike. Friendly local competition is part of the recipe for improvement, along with very strong links to the town of Brighouse - 35,000 people who consider the school to be "theirs." And do not forget the violet walls, inspiring keywords on ceilings and walls, and music in art classes for girls. The school is trying out an "accelerated learning scheme" which ordains these things - including the theory that girls but not boys can do two things at once, such as drawing and listening to music. "It seems to be working," said Mr Soles. But if it does not, you can rely on Brighouse to chuck it out.

webTitle: Blunkett hails success of targeting

fields.headline: Blunkett hails success of targeting
fields.standfirst: Unions say improved results in specialist colleges and deprived areas demonstrate only that all schools need more money
fields.trailText: Improved exam results in specialist state schools and deprived areas targeted by the government are hailed today by the education secretary, David Blunkett.
fields.body:
Improved exam results in specialist state schools and deprived areas targeted by the government are hailed today by the education secretary, David Blunkett.

But teaching unions insisted that the school performance league tables for England, published in the Guardian, showed only that money bred success.

Across more than 5,000 schools, 49.2% of pupils achieved five or more A*-Cs at GCSE, up 1.3 points on last year. But the rate of improvement was better - 2.3 points - in the 450 schools covered by the Excellence in Cities programme. Fourteen programmes in Sheffield, Liverpool, Birmingham and parts of inner London improved, although Islington still performed poorly.

Four of the five most improved schools at GCSE were government backed specialist arts or technology schools, and Mr Blunkett singled out for congratulations Thomas Telford, a city technology college launched by the Tories in Telford, Shropshire, which became the first comprehensive to have 100% of pupils achieving five or more A*-Cs at GCSE. It made history after appealing to exam boards on behalf of one pupil who had three of four D grades upgraded to Cs. Emmanuel city technology college in Gateshead missed out on 100% because three children got four A*-Cs.

"These results show how our policies, particularly those targeted at young people from more deprived areas, are working, " said Mr Blunkett. "Today's results show just what can be achieved by committed teachers and pupils, supported by effective, national strategies."

But amid health warnings about the value of performance tables, John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "The faster rate of improvement of specialist col leges and Excellence in Cities schools demonstrates the link between additional funding and higher achievement."

Margaret Tulloch, chairman of the Campaign for State Education, said: "If more money means schools and children do better, then all schools need more money."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "League tables still remain as damaging and distorting as ever. Who would not expect Manchester United to do better than their neighbours Oldham Athletic?"

Alan Seiber, head teacher of Tarporley in Cheshire, the sec ond-best comprehensive performer at A-level, urged the government to move quickly on introducing value added measurements, which it piloted this year. "These tables aren't fair. There must be thousands of teachers in schools that have got particularly difficult circumstances to work in, who do a cracking good job and never get any attention."

Measured on points score per pupil at GCSE, Thomas Telford and Emmanuel would make a countrywide top 12. However, dozens of grammar and independent schools had 100% of pupils gaining five or more A*-Cs, helping to reinforce parent prejudice against the comprehensives.

But an adviser to Mr Blunkett said: "If a grammar school is not getting 100% five A-Cs then frankly you have to ask some questions. The issue is whether we are able to ensure that the most able comprehensive pupils are able to do as well if not better than those at grammar schools."

St. Marylebone Church of England school, a performing arts school in central London, is the most improved school by GCSE results, jumping from 39% of pupils with five good passes in 1997 to 89% now. In England the number of pupils achieving no passes at all has fallen to 5.6% this year.

There are no surprises in the map of school performance by local education authority. More than 60% of GCSE students get five or more good passes in the Isles of Scilly, the outer London boroughs of Sutton and Kingston, and in Buckinghamshire and Rutland. But in Hull, Knowsley on Merseyside, Islington and Nottingham, less than 30% do.

In Hull, where fewer than one in four pupils gain five A*-Cs, assistant director of education Andy Swallow painted a complex picture. Though standards of teaching were recognised as high by government officials, and key stage one and two results were improving, "what we have got in the city is a culture still that does not value education". About 240 Hull primary school pupils moved out of the borough for secondary school, mostly to the East Riding of Yorkshire. Of those, three-quarters achieved level four or above in key stage tests. Among the brightest children that remained, up to 11% of those who achieved level five at key stage three at 14 were playing truant.

Gillingham community college in Kent, the school with the worst GCSE results for an English comprehensive - only 3% achieving five A*-Cs - is to close.

webTitle: TheStreet.com pulls plug on UK site

fields.headline: TheStreet.com pulls plug on UK site
fields.trailText: Amateur investors' website TheStreet.co.uk has closed, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Amateur investors' website TheStreet.co.uk has closed.

The online financial news and share tipping site emailed its subscribers this afternoon with the news that its US parent company, TheStreet.com, had decided to pull the plug.

It is the latest dotcom venture to take the high road, but in an email to all 180,000 subscribers it promised not to vanish with other people's money.

The email said: "It is another internet collapse - but one with a difference. TheStreet.co.uk hit all its financial targets during its brief life, including cashflow. It will be an orderly wind down."

The company's farewell email added: "This is the last email you will receive from TheStreet.co.uk. We are closing down today.

"TheStreet.com, which today took full control of TheStreet.co.uk, took the decision to close the site in order to cut its costs. All the staff here are being made redundant."

Reports of a monthly burn rate of £500,000 and rock-bottom staff morale put off any rescue attempt from investors, only nine months after the site launched.

TheStreet.com is also teetering on the brink, having appointed advisors for a possible sale of the company or a joint venture.

webTitle: Working the web a conscience online

fields.headline: Working the web a conscience online
fields.standfirst:
Now you need not sacrifice your ethics when you surf, writes Gideon Burrows
Net news
fields.trailText: Now you need not sacrifice your ethics when you surf, writes Gideon Burrows
fields.body:
Thanks to the web, living a socially conscious life at home need no longer mean commandeering the kitchen to paint CND placards, or ripping up the patio to plant organic veg.

An obvious way to begin is to type www.conscienceonline.org.uk into your browser. (Notice that magic .org? Most ethical sites avoid anything so capitalist as a .com, or .co.uk.) The address takes us to the Peace Tax Campaign - supporting those withholding the 10% of their taxes that pays for the armed forces. That may be a little hard-core for a beginner. Signing the online petition to end third world debt at www.jubilee2000uk.org/petition.html may be a gentler place to start. Or perhaps a little ethical shopping?

Fair traded goods are no longer the stuff only of church fetes and trestle tables outside the library. Oxfam runs an online charity shop at www.oxfam.org.uk/shop selling ethically produced goods ranging from coffee and chocolate to clothing and jewellery. You can also donate goods to the charity, which are auctioned online.

www.oneworld.net/shop also brings you gifts, holidays and music with an ethical edge. The oneworld.net site is an internet portal and news site for those interested in human rights, development and the environment.

www.getethical.com, to be launched on November 28 by the Big Issue and left-green magazine RedPepper is another online ethical shop - but with in-depth analysis and news.

Information is power for the surfer with a conscience. www.ethical-junction.com has a huge directory ethical businesses and organisations - including, strangely enough, a huge list of ethical caterers.

When buying from mainstream outlets, how do you know the items have not helped to destroy the environment, or been sewn in a sweatshop? www.ethicalconsumer.org looks at the environmental and social records of the companies behind the brand names. It has a huge searchable business ethics database, and you can check products against their constantly updated boycotts list.

If you are concerned about big business, the more radical www.corporatewatch.org takes a direct activists' perspective against all that is wrong with multinational corporations. "The Earth is not dying it is being killed," it says. "And those who are killing it have names and addresses."

But enough about what "they" are doing to the planet and its people. What is your effect? Take a quick click to www.americanforests.org/climate/amforcalc.html and calculate the "carbon debt" created by your use of transport and fossil fuels. The site tells you how many trees to plant each year to offset your CO2 emissions. Those lacking green fingers could reduce their tree planting obligations by buying electricity from one of the "green electricity" suppliers listed at www.est.co.uk/together/tog_whofuture.html

You could try your hand at being an eco-warrior at www.greenpeace.org.uk/HardCodedPages/ arcticaction_win.htm, where you can play Bears of Despair, a little Shockwave game where you try to stop BP drilling for oil in the Arctic.

Money makes the world go round. www.co-operativebank.co.uk is the site for the well known socially responsible bank and its internet based sister is at www.smile.co.uk Both have strict investment policies - excluding, for example, countries that abuse human rights, and companies which sell them arms. (For more on the arms trade, click to www.caat.org.uk).

Triodos Bank allows customers to open savings accounts which lend money to specific social projects like housing and energy-conservation - you can even open an account which benefits the Western Buddhist Order.

Appeals through the post may soon become junk-mail of the past. Charities have made it easy to part with cash via your credit card and a secure net connection.

The Charities Aid Foundation at www.giveasyouearn.org allows you to give regularly, tax free, to any registered charity by completing an online donor form.

Another charity focused website www.care4free.net has a limited database of charities you can donate to via the site.

But why spend your money, when you can spend someone else's? Most of the money bouncing around the net is from advertising revenue - and www.thehungersite.com has turned this to the advantage of world's starving. For every click, a cup of staple food is donated to a hungry person in the developing world, paid for by companies whose banner adverts pepper the site.

Windows and Internet Explorer users might feel a little guilty browsing with tools produced by the ultra-capitalist multi-national Microsoft. Repentance is just a click away at www.microsoft-sucks.com, which not only has a huge list of anti-microsoft links (with sites ranging from the well argued, to the frankly ludicrous), but also posts photos of the great man himself on the sticky side of a custard pie lobbed by protesters. The Biotic Baking Brigade's own site is worth a final click at www.asis.com/~bbb.

 Gideon Burrows is a writer on human rights, peace and the environment. Visit him at www.gidstar.freeserve.co.uk
gideon@foundationspa.co.uk
