webTitle: 'Florida election mess could harm president'

fields.headline: 'Florida election mess could harm president'
fields.standfirst: Many US commentators are looking beyond the current imbroglio in Florida to the likely long-term effect of the candidates' actions. Derek Brown senses a mood of pessimism
fields.trailText: Many US commentators are looking beyond the current imbroglio in Florida to the likely long-term effect of the candidates' actions. Derek Brown senses their pessimism.
fields.body:
Many commentators are looking beyond the presidential election saga to the likely long-term effect on the nation's political life. There is a widespread view that the epic legal wrangle in Florida will embitter relations between the two big parties for years to come.

The Chicago Tribune homes in on the blatantly political nature of the courtroom dramas: "Setting the stage for a legal showdown, Florida Secretary of State Katherine Harris on Wednesday rejected requests by three heavily Democratic counties that she certify their hand-recounted ballots in the presidential election, giving Texas Gov. George W. Bush a potential advantage immediately challenged by Vice President Al Gore. Harris, a prominent local Republican who served as co-chairwoman of the Bush campaign in Florida, said she would not accept revised vote totals from Palm Beach, Broward and Miami-Dade Counties because they failed to meet the legal criteria for extending the state's Tuesday deadline for certification of votes."

The Houston Chronicle focuses on the latest mini-drama to form part of the presidential epic, tomorrow's deadline for the receipt of postal ballots. The paper wisely refrains from forecasting the likely impact: "Their history would seem to favor Bush, the Republican candidate, over Democrat Al Gore. The 1996 absentee voters gave GOP candidate Bob Dole 54 percent of their vote, when he received just 43 percent of the statewide ballot against President Clinton. But if anything has been been learned from this year's squeaker in Florida, it is that the art of prediction is, at best, inexact."

The prize for the day's most understated headline must go to the Honolulu Star-Bulletin editorial column's "Florida election mess could harm president". Underneath is a shrewd analysis of the likely pattern of partisan rivalry in coming years, whoever gets to the White House: "Whichever candidate survives Florida will be handed a damaged presidency, shaken with partisan animosity and facing a Congress that is as divided as it can be. The historical pattern of gains by the party out of power in off-year elections makes it probable that the next president will face an opposition Congress in two years. The level of ferocity in Florida may signal worse times ahead."

The Miami Herald, in its latest breathless update of the state elections, gives George W. Bush an unofficial lead of 286 over Al Gore, out of nearly six million votes cast. In an intriguing sidebar story, the paper recalls that a 1988 report recommended the abolition of the punchcard ballot system which is at the centre of the current imbroglio: "A federal report issued 12 years ago recommended abandoning the controversial punch card ballots widely used in Florida, citing inaccuracies and uncertainties in their tallies, and delivered a clear warning of the 'hanging chad' problem that has vexed this year's presidential race. The National Bureau of Standards report, conducted because of concerns over 'inaccuracy or fraud in computerized vote-tallying,' chronicled instances of election confusion across the country caused by punch card technology, including a 1984 election in Palm Beach County, now the epicenter of the presidential election controversy."

The New York Times is scathingly critical of Bush's rejection of Gore's latest suggestion, that both candidates abide by the results of a full recount in Florida. The paper also savages the partisan rulings of Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris: "So far, the Bush campaign's attempts to block the manual recount have failed to win favor in both state and federal court. Moreover, Mr Gore's proposal for a binding resolution put in a bad light Governor Bush's insistence on blocking an authoritative recount. The governor is depending on Ms Harris, a Bush campaign official, to pre-emptively certify the results in Mr Bush's favor once all the overseas votes are counted on Saturday. Ms Harris, who served as co-chairwoman of the Bush campaign in Florida this year, announced last evening that she would accept no further manual vote counts. That is an abuse of her public duty and an irresponsible act at this sensitive moment in the nation's political life. She is doing grievous damage to Mr Bush's reputation, and potentially to his presidency."

Over in California, the Sacramento Bee politely differs from the widespread view that Americans are deeply and bitterly divided over the presidency: "Indeed, the campaign itself often seemed to demonstrate just the opposite. One problem with Al Gore and George W. Bush as candidates was that they failed to inspire deep loyalty, particularly among voters who weren't already wedded to a political party. The wild swings reported in opinion polls before the voting may well have represented actual shifts among voters as they switched allegiances again and again -- hardly evidence of deep and abiding convictions. That lack of attachment also might explain another apparent anomaly: Despite round-the-clock coverage on CNN and solemn pronouncements of crisis from the campaigns, most Americans don't seem nearly as exercised as their would-be leaders."

The paper concludes that US citizens have behaved with remarkable aplomb, and urges: "One of the men engaged in the high-stakes Florida faceoff will shortly become president of the United States - the only one we've got. He will face a fractured electorate, a divided Congress and an uncertain future. He will need a steady hand and patient demeanor to win through - and he could look to the behavior of the voters, thus far, as an example."

The paper concludes that US citizens have behaved with remarkable aplomb, and urges: "One of the men engaged in the high-stakes Florida faceoff will shortly become president of the United States - the only one we've got. He will face a fractured electorate, a divided Congress and an uncertain future. He will need a steady hand and patient demeanor to win through - and he could look to the behavior of the voters, thus far, as an example."

webTitle: How John Lennon's murder changed the Beatles' lives

fields.headline: How John Lennon's murder changed the Beatles' lives
fields.trailText: When John Lennon was struck by four bullets fired by a deranged fan outside his New York apartment on December 8 1980, the lives of the three remaining Beatles changed forever.
fields.body:
When John Lennon was struck by four bullets fired by a deranged fan outside his New York apartment on December 8 1980, the lives of the three remaining Beatles changed forever.

Not only did they have to deal with the emotional turmoil of losing a friend, but the days when the only danger they seemed to face was being accosted by screaming teenage girls were also snatched away.

The notoriety Mark Chapman gained after killing the most charismatic of the Fab Four meant that the remaining Beatles could never be certain there were no "crazies" - as Sir Paul McCartney dubbed them - waiting for one of them.

The murder prompted the band's surviving members to take elaborate security precautions. George Harrison was reported to have spent more than £1m protecting from intruders the Oxfordshire mansion he has lived in since 1971. He was given local council permission to place razor wire along the perimeter of the 34 acre property. Infra-red sensors, security lighting, CCTV and electronic gates were installed. The cameras connected to a control room in the 15 bed room property and the alarm system linked to a nearby police station.

But Henley-on-Thames residents said fences were sometimes in disrepair, while the thick shrubbery surrounding the estate offered cover to intruders.

Sir Paul's 160 acre Sussex estate was dubbed "Paulditz" by locals because of the elaborate security measures.

His regard for security has not been without foundation. In November 1984 police uncovered a plot to kidnap the star's late wife, Linda, for a £10m ransom.

In 1996 Harrison called in detectives after a series of death threats.

webTitle: Minister issues directions to Lambeth social services

fields.headline: Minister issues directions to Lambeth social services
fields.trailText: Health minister John Hutton today took drastic action to improve children's services in Lambeth, issuing the council with statutory directions.
fields.body:
Health minister John Hutton today took drastic action to improve children's services in Lambeth, issuing the council with statutory directions.

Mr Hutton's instructions follow two highly critical reports - one by the Social Services Inspectorate, and another which the council commissioned from independent consultant John Barratt.

The reports aired serious concerns about looked-after children, those on the child protection register and family placement services in the south London borough. The department has until 31 August - a period of nine months - to meet all the minister's demands.

Lambeth has to put right failings which include:

 the 9% of children on the at-risk register and 11% of looked-after children without a social worker;
 the 11% who have been on the register for more than two years; and
 the 42% at risk whose cases are not reviewed regularly enough.

The social services department must ensure that reviews take place of the "significant number" of looked-after children who are not being visited often enough and catch up on the 28% of looked-after case reviews that are overdue.

The minister has directed the council to carry out annual reviews and police checks on foster carers. Lambeth has to speed up adoptions, ensure smooth transfers from the looked-after service to the young adults service, and make a priority of processing new cases. It must also review the 135 cases where relatives and other informal carers are being paid to look after children.

"There is clear evidence that children's social services in Lambeth are not meeting the required standards," said Mr Hutton. "I have taken these steps to protect the needs of vulnerable children. Their needs are paramount. I understand that the council is working constructively with the SSI to take the necessary action to turn their services around and bring them up to the standard we expect."

Lambeth social services is already on the list of local authorities being monitored by the SSI. Lambeth and Hackney are the only two monitored authorities to have been given directions.

Lisa Christensen, Lambeth social services director, said she was confident that the department would meet its targets. Since its SSI inspection in the summer, it had already begun to make changes. The council was "fundamentally restructuring" its children and families service, had recently recruited a highly experienced management team, had outsourced foster care recruitment, implemented police checks on staff and carers and allocated social workers to all the children on the at-risk register.

"We welcome and confirm the minister's confidence that we will work constructively with our colleagues in the SSI to build on the progress that has already been made," said Ms Christensen. "We take seriously our statutory obligations and we believe wholeheartedly that safeguarding the needs of children is paramount."

The inspectorate's London social care region and the new adoption taskforce are working with the department to improve services. A follow-up SSI inspection will take place in September to ensure that the directions have been met. Directions are issued under the Local Authority Social Services Act 1970.

webTitle: Super projects fall short in dam commission report

fields.headline: Super projects fall short in dam commission report
fields.standfirst: The report of the World Commission on Dams has revealed the terrible damage done by big dams to people and the environment, writes Paul Brown
fields.trailText: The report of the World Commission on Dams has revealed the terrible damage done by big dams to people and the environment, writes Paul Brown
fields.body:
Dam critics have challenged the funders of big dams, the World Bank and the export credit agencies, to halt all support for new projects until the recommendations in today's report by the World Commission on Dams have been implemented.

But nowhere in the Commission's 400-page report was such an idea expressed, so careful were the members not to upset each other and so reach their goal of all being able to sign a unanimous report.

However, what is clear from the recommendations is that many of the 42,000 big dams already built in the world would not have existed had proper planning taken place, and many of the most controversial currently on the stocks should be abandoned.

Many dams have been examined by the Commission. Very few lived up to claims made for them in the planning stage: they almost always took longer to build and cost far more than the original estimates.

People affected by the dams, usually the poorest and indigenous groups without a voice, always came off worst, got little or no compensation and had their lives ruined.

Those that benefited were the rich and the dam builders who were usually contractors from the developed world backed by the World Bank and export credit agencies with no rules about human rights or proper evaluation of economics.

In a sense there were no surprises - this is what the campaigners have been telling us for ages, but often without the proper research data to back it up. Now it is official - big dams have done terrible damage to people, the environment and better alternatives have generally not even been considered.

On the other hand Nelson Mandela, who launched the report at Canary Wharf in London, reminded everyone that the picture is not all bleak and that dams had brought great benefits too. Although millions have suffered, millions more have made great gains in terms of water and electricity not available before.

"The problem is not the dams," he said. "It is the hunger. It is the thirst. It is the darkness of a township. It is the townships and rural huts without running water, lights or sanitation."

The point he was making is that dams have often been built for the wrong people and for the wrong reasons.

If the people who benefit from dams are the poor who would not otherwise have water to drink and grow crops, or electricity for their homes, then there is a case for them.

If the environment is safeguarded as much as possible, and those displaced are properly consulted, compensated and found alternative ways of earning a living, then there is still a case for them. There can be no absolutes, each case must be dealt with on its merits.

If the report was backed by authority, governments would never again be able to back projects on the basis that it will provide jobs because home country contractors could do with the work.

The UK, which is currently "minded to back" the controversial Ilisu Dam project in Turkey, needs to read the report carefully before putting up £200m of export guarantees. The Ilisu would flood the Kurd homelands, destroy archeological sites of international importance, and give the Turks control over the water to the downstream states of Syria and Iraq - both of which object.

The project fails to meet any of the conditions the commission demands as vital to any dam project. The locals have not been consulted, no plan exists for proper compensation or resettlement, alternatives have not been considered, and the downstream states have not been satisfied.

In fact, typical of the disastrous past projects detailed in the report.

webTitle: Ministers unveil urban white paper

fields.headline: Ministers unveil urban white paper
fields.trailText: Ministers today unveiled a raft of policies designed to make town and city centres magnets for business investment and better places to live.
fields.body:
Ministers today unveiled a raft of policies designed to make town and city centres magnets for business investment and better places to live.

While the government's urban white paper stops short of a total ban on out-of-town developments, it does say that new developments should be built as close to town centres as possible.

Developments at the edge of cities undermine "the viability of many town centres and encourage increased use of car travel," the paper says.

The white paper aims to ensure that brownfield land is reused before new land is developed and says that, if urban areas cannot be built in, the planned extension of cities is better than greenfield development. This formula is intended to help ministers meet their target of ensuring that 60% of new developments take place on brownfield land by 2008.

The white paper promises a focus on regenerating the country's most run-down areas. A total of 12 new urban regeneration companies are proposed, with a brief to co-ordinate redevelopment work. The companies could win tax breaks for the areas they cover to stimulate investment.

The white paper, the first for 23 years, brings together a range of government policies developed over the last three years. It provides more details on the £1bn package of financial incentives to increase inner city investment announced by chancellor Gordon Brown in his pre-budget statement last week.

New measures announced in the white paper include:

&#149: A £250m fund, made up of public and private money, to be spent on large-scale redevelopment in areas that have undergone major economic and social change.
 A greater emphasis on the area of skills training for regional development agencies.
 A national green flags scheme to encourage and reward excellence in managing parks and green spaces.
 A dedicated fund for parks and green spaces made up of £96m from the government's New Opportunities Fund and £225m from the Heritage Lottery Fund.

The government intends its white paper to bring together and co-ordinate those policies, and to give local people the chance to play a role in regenerating their neighbourhoods.

Launching the policy package, deputy prime minister John Prescott said: "A clear message from regeneration projects over the last 20 years is that local people must be fully engaged from the outset. All too often this has not been the case."

webTitle: Late In The Day, Alright, and Caught By The Fuzz

fields.headline: Late In The Day, Alright, and Caught By The Fuzz
fields.trailText: WE'VE SEEN THE FUTURE
fields.body:
WE'VE SEEN THE FUTURE

After watching the highlights of Italy v England last night, the Fiver gave Queen Elizabeth II a lingering goodnight kiss - the 1p piece does have its uses after all - and crawled into its red-and-white coloured bed. Then we started to dream of England and what a fantastic dream it was! We saw young David Beckham scampering and young Michael Owen scoring against a team wearing red, blue and yellow. "Ah, this must be a premonition of England's friendly against Spain in February," the Fiver thought - we must be the second coming of Nostradamus.

Then we had a peek at the England bench and discovered that boxing promoter Frank Warren was managing the team. Immediately we woke up, convinced our once-mighty psychic powers had somehow deserted us. But had they? Because earlier this afternoon, Charlton revealed they had given the FA permission to speak to Alan Curbishley (a dead-ringer for Mr Warren in a certain light - the darker the better, obviously) about joining the England coaching set-up.

"We have given Adam Crozier of the FA formal permission for Howard Wilkinson to speak to Alan about any role that he might want him to play," Charlton chief executive Peter Varney revealed convolutedly. But what's this brewing in the tea-leaves? It's Peter Taylor - and he's indicated that he would be happy to stay on as caretaker England boss for the friendly against Spain in February if asked by the FA. "I've enjoyed the three days and, as long as it doesn't affect Leicester, I'm happy to help out," he says. Which could mean there is conflict ahead. Or - as we're hedging our bets - maybe not. Now where did we put the 2001 edition of Old Moore's Almanac again?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SILLY SAUSAGE

It's always worth having a nose around the German football scene, because you never know what (or who) will come up. For example, the Fiver hadn't had a sniff of a story about former Germany coach-in-waiting Christoph Daum for ages - until today, that is, when we digested a few lines in Bild explaining how Daum has taken a second drug test and this time he's clean!

"The result was a foregone conclusion for me because I knew the first test did not apply to me," cracked a happy Daum this morning, waving the results of a test he took in the American Medical Laboratory on November 6. "The result is clearly negative," insisted his lawyer Rolf Stankewitz. "This test rehabilitates Herr Daum." Sadly, the new findings cut no powder with Professor Herbert Kaferstein, who oversaw the initial test in Germany, for which Daum tested positive. "I am absolutely sure that our results are correct," he said. "We looked closely at three different hair samples and we found clear evidence of cocaine in all of them."

But despite uncertainty, the Fiver expects Daum to be in ecstasy tonight - because one of the prime movers in his downfall is in a spot of legal bother himself. Bavarian authorities are following up an anonymous tip-off that Bayern Munich's Uli Hoeness has been employing workers illegally at the sausage factory he runs in Nuremberg. "My collaborators have been instructed not to recruit workers without permits and nothing will come out of the investigation, which will be completed next week," claimed a wide-eyed Hoeness today. You couldn't make this up if you were flying off your noggin.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"At West Ham, we're used to his comments. We know him well: we know that one day he can be very angry about something and the next day he'll have forgotten all about it" - Frederic Kanoute puts paid to the rumours that Paolo Di Canio is as mad as a lump of lemonade.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

YOU, THE CRIMINAL

So you're up in court for shoplifting. The fuzz have got you bang to rights, and a life (or at least six months) of press-ups and sexual subjugation awaits. What do you do? Do you make a run for it through the courtroom busting off shots from the .45 hidden in your sock? Do you burst into tears and try to will yourself back into the womb? Or do you claim to be a Second Division footballer?

If you took the last option, then congratulations! You have a high chance of avoiding a prison sentence at Horseferry Road court, London. At least, that was what happened to lucky Uchenna Nwanokwu, 19, who missed out on a bout of incarceration on shoplifting charges by telling the court that since the offence, he had become a Cambridge United player on £1,500-a-week. In fact, not only was Uchenna a U, but he also had a match to go to - so if the judge didn't mind summing up sharpish, it would be much appreciated.

And so, district judge Eleri Rees quickly proceeded to fine Nwanokwu for leaving Sainsbury's with £124.66 worth of goods up his jumper. "The fact that you have now turned over a new leaf and have a promising career as a footballer which I wouldn't wish to interrupt," she said, "means I propose to hit you in the pocket." Nwanokwu, who is not a Cambridge player - "We've never even heard of this man!" was the club's official response - was fined £250 for shoplifting with £50 costs and another £150 fine for jumping bail three times. He may never even have been to Cambridge for all we know.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea are prepared to bid an astounding £18m for Real Madrid's injury-plagued striker Fernando Morientes, reports Planet Football.

Tottenham have joined the hunt for £5m-rated Benfica defender Carlos Marchena, according to reports. However, they face stiff competition from Barcelona, who have also registered an interested in the 21-year-old after his superb performances in the Olympics. "I am a star at Benfica but Barcelona is Barcelona," Marchena admitted.

Aston Villa are chasing two strikers in the shape of Daniel Fonseca and Hakan Sukur. Uruguay international Fonseca looks the more likely target - he is well down the pecking order at Juventus, and might be tempted to join Villa on loan for the rest of the season. But John Gregory is keeping his options open - he was at last night's Turkey v France match to watch the unsettled Sukur.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Alan Stubbs has been admitted to hospital after a routine check-up found that the cancer which affected him last July had returned. The 29-year-old had to have a testicle removed after a routine drugs test revealed he had a cancerous growth. Stubbs got the all-clear but he will now be forced to undergo further chemotherapy.

Troubled Everton defender Abel Xavier must have a knee operation that will rule him out for a month. The utility defender will have the operation tomorrow and is unlikely to play again until Christmas.

Norwich and Blackpool have been fined by the FA's disciplinary committee for failing to control their players after a confrontation during a Worthington Cup second round first leg tie at Carrow Road on September 19. Norwich have been fined £30,000 and Blackpool £6,000.

Portsmouth have reduced the price of tickets for their uncovered Milton End to just £5. Tickets for the roofless stand, usually reserved for away fans, will be reduced for the December visits of Huddersfield and Sheffield United.

Aberdeen are to abandon attempts to sign Colin Hendry from Coventry due to the Scottish international's wage demands. Aberdeen spokesman Dave Macdermid admitted: "We have made an enquiry about the player, but certainly wage-wise we are not at the races."

Manchester City will not be pursuing their interest in Rangers striker Sebastian Rozental, after the Chilean international completed a four-day trial at Maine Road.

Artur Numan could make a return to the Rangers first team this weekend after recovering from a hamstring injury.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (3.15am) It's a game of a round globe.

Channel 4: Gazzetta Football Italia (3.25am) Can't sleep? No job to get up for? Feel that your life is going nowhere? Then it's possibly best if you don't see pictures of a well-dressed man sitting in an Italian cafe with nothing pressing to do except chat about sport.

Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.05am) No, you'll feel much better about yourself if you watch this get instead.

Dutch Football (12.35am) Stick with it. It's a slow burner but it'll take effect.

Argentinian Football (2.15am) Are you Scottish? Just how much do you love Diego Maradona? Email the.boss@theguardian.com with your songs of love.

Major League Soccer 2000 US Major League Soccer Cup Final (3.55am) Snappy title. Like it. Well done.

Sky Sports 1: A United City - Manchester Football Special (6.30pm, 12.30am) Clever title. Like it. Well done.

Fifa TV (7.30pm) This week: how to dodge taxes.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3.30am) More from McCaff's Ducky Project: "We have three yellow ducklings and three darker coloured ones. Madame Hachey's class named the ducklings. Their names were Lucky, Skrawney, Joey, Rodney, Junior and Donald." Hold on a minute one of the McCaff ducks is called Rodney?

Australian Soccer League (11pm) "Sorry I missed that open goal, Bruce, but I've drunk too many tinnies." Sky Sports 3: Football League Review (5pm, 3am SS2) How many Third Division goals have the cameramen missed this week? We reckon two.

Spanish Football (10pm) No coke, no sausages. Where's the fun in this?

British Eurosport: The Road To The World Cup (9pm) runs through many expensive restaurants, fancy hotels and the odd "massage parlour".

Radio 5 Live: Any Sporting Questions (7.30pm) What can we do to make Alan Green love us?

"I am absolutely sure that our results are correct," he said. "We looked closely at three different hair samples and we found clear evidence of cocaine in all of them." But despite uncertainty, the Fiver expects Daum to be in ecstasy tonight - because one of the prime movers in his downfall is in a spot of legal bother himself. Bavarian authorities are following up an anonymous tip-off that Bayern Munich's Uli Hoeness has been employing workers illegally at the sausage factory he runs in Nuremberg. "My collaborators have been instructed not to recruit workers without permits and nothing will come out of the investigation, which will be completed next week," claimed a wide-eyed Hoeness today. You couldn't make this up if you were flying off your noggin. * * * * * * * * * * * * * QUOTE OF THE DAY "At West Ham, we're used to his comments. We know him well: we know that one day he can be very angry about something and the next day he'll have forgotten all about it" - Frederic Kanoute puts paid to the rumours that Paolo Di Canio is as mad as a lump of lemonade. * * * * * * * * * * * * * YOU, THE CRIMINAL So you're up in court for shoplifting. The fuzz have got you bang to rights, and a life (or at least six months) of press-ups and sexual subjugation awaits. What do you do? Do you make a run for it through the courtroom busting off shots from the .45 hidden in your sock? Do you burst into tears and try to will yourself back into the womb? Or do you claim to be a Second Division footballer? If you took the last option, then congratulations! You have a high chance of avoiding a prison sentence at Horseferry Road court, London. At least, that was what happened to lucky Uchenna Nwanokwu, 19, who missed out on a bout of incarceration on shoplifting charges by telling the court that since the offence, he had become a Cambridge United player on £1,500-a-week. In fact, not only was Uchenna a U, but he also had a match to go to - so if the judge didn't mind summing up sharpish, it would be much appreciated. And so, district judge Eleri Rees quickly proceeded to fine Nwanokwu for leaving Sainsbury's with £124.66 worth of goods up his jumper. "The fact that you have now turned over a new leaf and have a promising career as a footballer which I wouldn't wish to interrupt," she said, "means I propose to hit you in the pocket." Nwanokwu, who is not a Cambridge player - "We've never even heard of this man!" was the club's official response - was fined £250 for shoplifting with £50 costs and another £150 fine for jumping bail three times. He may never even have been to Cambridge for all we know. * * * * * * * * * * * * * THE RUMOUR MILL Chelsea are prepared to bid an astounding £18m for Real Madrid's injury-plagued striker Fernando Morientes, reports Planet Football. Tottenham have joined the hunt for £5m-rated Benfica defender Carlos Marchena, according to reports. However, they face stiff competition from Barcelona, who have also registered an interested in the 21-year-old after his superb performances in the Olympics. "I am a star at Benfica but Barcelona is Barcelona," Marchena admitted. Aston Villa are chasing two strikers in the shape of Daniel Fonseca and Hakan Sukur. Uruguay international Fonseca looks the more likely target - he is well down the pecking order at Juventus, and might be tempted to join Villa on loan for the rest of the season. But John Gregory is keeping his options open - he was at last night's Turkey v France match to watch the unsettled Sukur. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Alan Stubbs has been admitted to hospital after a routine check-up found that the cancer which affected him last July had returned. The 29-year-old had to have a testicle removed after a routine drugs test revealed he had a cancerous growth. Stubbs got the all-clear but he will now be forced to undergo further chemotherapy. Troubled Everton defender Abel Xavier must have a knee operation that will rule him out for a month. The utility defender will have the operation tomorrow and is unlikely to play again until Christmas. Norwich and Blackpool have been fined by the FA's disciplinary committee for failing to control their players after a confrontation during a Worthington Cup second round first leg tie at Carrow Road on September 19. Norwich have been fined £30,000 and Blackpool £6,000. Portsmouth have reduced the price of tickets for their uncovered Milton End to just £5. Tickets for the roofless stand, usually reserved for away fans, will be reduced for the December visits of Huddersfield and Sheffield United. Aberdeen are to abandon attempts to sign Colin Hendry from Coventry due to the Scottish international's wage demands. Aberdeen spokesman Dave Macdermid admitted: "We have made an enquiry about the player, but certainly wage-wise we are not at the races." Manchester City will not be pursuing their interest in Rangers striker Sebastian Rozental, after the Chilean international completed a four-day trial at Maine Road. Artur Numan could make a return to the Rangers first team this weekend after recovering from a hamstring injury. * * * * * * * * * * * * * TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: World Football (3.15am) It's a game of a round globe. Channel 4: Gazzetta Football Italia (3.25am) Can't sleep? No job to get up for? Feel that your life is going nowhere? Then it's possibly best if you don't see pictures of a well-dressed man sitting in an Italian cafe with nothing pressing to do except chat about sport. Channel 5: Jonathan Pearce's Football Night (12.05am) No, you'll feel much better about yourself if you watch this get instead. Dutch Football (12.35am) Stick with it. It's a slow burner but it'll take effect. Argentinian Football (2.15am) Are you Scottish? Just how much do you love Diego Maradona? Email the.boss@theguardian.com with your songs of love. Major League Soccer 2000 US Major League Soccer Cup Final (3.55am) Snappy title. Like it. Well done. Sky Sports 1: A United City - Manchester Football Special (6.30pm, 12.30am) Clever title. Like it. Well done. Fifa TV (7.30pm) This week: how to dodge taxes. You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 3.30am) More from McCaff's Ducky Project: "We have three yellow ducklings and three darker coloured ones. Madame Hachey's class named the ducklings. Their names were Lucky, Skrawney, Joey, Rodney, Junior and Donald." Hold on a minute one of the McCaff ducks is called Rodney? Australian Soccer League (11pm) "Sorry I missed that open goal, Bruce, but I've drunk too many tinnies." Sky Sports 3: Football League Review (5pm, 3am SS2) How many Third Division goals have the cameramen missed this week? We reckon two. Spanish Football (10pm) No coke, no sausages. Where's the fun in this? British Eurosport: The Road To The World Cup (9pm) runs through many expensive restaurants, fancy hotels and the odd "massage parlour". Radio 5 Live: Any Sporting Questions (7.30pm) What can we do to make Alan Green love us?

webTitle: Fascists in prison service face sack

fields.headline: Fascists in prison service face sack
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Priso  n officers found to be members of far right groups such as the British National party will be automatically expelled from the service under reforms to employment practice to be introduced by Martin Narey, director general of the prison service.
fields.body:
Priso n officers found to be members of far right groups such as the British National party will be automatically expelled from the service under reforms to employment practice to be introduced by Martin Narey, director general of the prison service.

Speaking at the annual conference of prison race relations liaison officers, Mr Narey said that he would be willing to face any challenge to his reforms at employment tribunals.

"We have to own up that racism is a big problem for the prison service as recent events at Feltham and Brixton have shown," he said. "This is one of a raft of measures needed to get it right."

The Prison Officers Association backed the measure. "We believe that the eradication of racist behaviour should be at the forefront of the prison service," said Colin Moses, the only black member of the POA's national executive committee.

The director general also announced that he would be abolishing drill from prison officers' basic training with immediate effect and filling the time saved with mental health and race relations instruction.

Mr Narey's announcements come as the commission for racial equality confirmed it would be announcing an investigation into the prison service shortly.

The prisons minister, Paul Boateng, asked the CRE to look into the issue of racism in the service earlier this year following a damning internal report into conditions at Brixton prison.

The remit of the CRE investigation has not been formally determined but is expected to focus on three institutions - Brixton, Feltham young offenders' institution, and one other.

An internal investigation into Feltham revealed by the Guardian following the murder of an Asian prisoner, Zahid Mubarek, by his racist cellmate found evidence of many failings.

webTitle: US rates left on hold amid uncertainties

fields.headline: US rates left on hold amid uncertainties
fields.trailText: The US Federal Reserve left key American borrowing rates unchanged last night but said it was still watching closely for signs of rising inflation.
fields.body:
The US Federal Reserve left key American borrowing rates unchanged last night but said it was still watching closely for signs of rising inflation.

Amid continuing uncertainty over the outcome of the presidential election, the federal open market committee (FOMC) left the base interest rate at 6.5%, where it has been since mid-May.

Recent data suggesting a cooling of the mighty US economy had led some analysts to predict that the committee would downgrade the possible risks of inflation.

But in its statement, the FOMC warned that record lows in unemployment and sky-high oil prices still posed a threat to prices.

"The utilisation of the pool of available workers remains at an unusually high level, and the increase in energy prices, though having limited effect on core measures of prices to date, still harbours the possibility of raising inflation expectations," the FOMC said.

The hawkish tone of the comments unnerved investors, causing US stock markets to give up much of the ground made before the announcement. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index, both up 100 points before the decision, instantly shed most of their gains.

Investors had hoped for a more positive outlook on inflation, given the signs of a slowdown and the sharp decline in the stock markets over the past few months.

webTitle: Children in Need telethon starts tonight

fields.headline: Children in Need telethon starts tonight
fields.trailText: Terry Wogan, Gaby Roslin and Pudsey Bear will strut their stuff for charity tonight as part of the 21st Children in Need telethon. Events taking place across the country include appearances by Big Brother contestants Anna and Tom in Northern Ireland, and the celebrity chef Jamie Oliver is to be flown by the RAF to one caller's home to cook their dinner.
fields.body:
Terry Wogan, Gaby Roslin and Pudsey Bear will strut their stuff for charity tonight as part of the 21st Children in Need telethon. Events taking place across the country include appearances by Big Brother contestants Anna and Tom in Northern Ireland, and the celebrity chef Jamie Oliver is to be flown by the RAF to one caller's home to cook their dinner.

The BBC charity Children in Need awards grants to registered charities, voluntary organisations and self-help groups. Last year the fundraising night raised £18,803,85 which was distributed to 1,900 successful applicants.

Charities can download an application form from Children in Need's website. Awards are given to children who are disadvantaged by mental, physical or sensory disabilities; behavioural or psychological problems; children who are living in poverty or deprivation; or children suffering from illness, distress, abuse or neglect.

The website advises applicants to be thoughtful and honest in their applications and present a carefully prepared budget: "Give us relevant facts and figures, please don't use jargon, and don't be vague," it says. "You don't need to promise the moon, just tell us what you can realistically achieve."

The next deadline for grant applications is November 30. Grants are allocated twice a year but organisations can only make one application a year. The first deadline next year is April 30.

webTitle: Trapattoni: England impressed me

fields.headline: Trapattoni: England impressed me
fields.trailText: Italy coach Giovanni Trapattoni was full of praise for Peter Taylor's young England side - despite their narrow 1-0 defeat at the Stadio Delle Alpi last night.
fields.body:
Italy coach Giovanni Trapattoni was full of praise for Peter Taylor's young England side - despite their narrow 1-0 defeat at the Stadio Delle Alpi last night.

And the Italy coach believes that Sven-Goran Eriksson will have plenty of talent to work with when he takes over as England manager.

"They were an attractive team and I think Eriksson will take over a squad with many interesting elements to it. I am sure that he will do an excellent job with them," admitted Trapattoni.

And his words where echoed by Italy's goalscorer Gennaro Gattuso, who also praised England's performance: "I think England played very well, they were aggressive and showed they have good young players for the future," he said.

Meanwhile, England caretaker coach Peter Taylor today revealed he met with Eriksson after the game. "I saw Sven very briefly at the end. He was in a hurry to get off, but I will speak to him at length at some stage over the phone," he said.

Taylor, who returned to training at Leicester after only four-and-a-half hours' sleep, was in buoyant mood despite the result.

"It was a most enjoyable experience for me," he admitted. "Most people got things out of the game, although I felt we should have had a penalty. Perhaps if it had been a qualifier, not a friendly, it might have been. But overall it was a marvellous experience.

"I was sitting there during the game thinking to myself, 'I can't believe this. I am manager of England'."

webTitle: The urban white paper in brief

fields.headline: The urban white paper in brief
fields.trailText: Deputy prime minister John Prescott this afternoon announced a raft of tax incentives aimed at persuading business to invest in Britain's cities.
fields.body:
Deputy prime minister John Prescott this afternoon announced a raft of tax incentives aimed at persuading business to invest in Britain's cities.

The urban white paper he unveiled draws heavily on Lord Rogers's urban task force report which called for better design in cities and the provision of affordable homes.

Key measures in the urban white paper:

 An exemption from stamp duty for all property transactions in disadvantaged communities;
 Accelerated payable tax credits for cleaning up contaminated land;
 100% capital allowances for creating "flats over shops" for letting;
 Package of VAT reforms to encourage additional conversions of properties for residential use;
 Proposals for town improvement schemes and for a local tax reinvestment programme;
 Planning policy guidance putting urban renaissance at the heart of the planning system; and a drive to implement planning policy on housing;
 Promoting a culture of innovation and enterprise across society through the Small Businesses Service and programmes like the Phoenix Fund, and the Higher Education Innovation Fund;
 Creating the conditions for e-commerce to thrive, for example through launching the UK Online initiative;
 Providing employment opportunities for all through an enhancement of New Deal programmes and tax and benefit reforms to make work pay.
 Equipping people with skills through the Department for Education and Employment's £6bn Learning and Skills Councils - which become fully operational from next April;
 Investing £180bn in a 10 year plan for transport to modernise and up-grade our transport needs.

Additional points:

 Expansion of Excellence in Cities education programme and Sure Start;
 New Deal for Schools and free early education for 66% of 3-year-olds in areas of greatest need;
 Forty new action teams for jobs;
 Major investment to deliver the proposals in the housing green paper - Quality and Choice: a Decent Home for All  including starter homes for key workers;
 Cutting crime through an enhanced crime reduction programme and crime reduction partnerships;
 Promoting culture, leisure and sporting activity through new creative partnerships for schools and by putting in place the Spaces for Sports and Arts Scheme;
 Supporting individuals and communities to take their ideas forward;
 A Neighbourhood Renewal Fund of £800m over 3 years;
 A New Opportunities Fund initiative to enable communities to fund their ideas for improving the local environment.

webTitle: Mischievous Mercury's US election trickery

fields.headline: Mischievous Mercury's US election trickery
fields.standfirst: Maggie Hyde explains how Mercury's backward loop sent the US media reeling in the face of last week's election fiasco.
fields.trailText: Maggie Hyde explains how Mercury's backward loop sent the US media reeling in the face of last week's election fiasco.
fields.body:
Three times a year, for three weeks at a time, the planet Mercury appears to go retrograde, making a backward loop through the zodiac. At the beginning and end of this loop it stands still and is said to be on its station.

This unexciting astronomy becomes the stuff of imagination for astrologers who insist that things on earth connected with Mercury - like communication, media, trade and transport - go wonky on these tricky movements.

The US election shambles seems to prove the point. Mercury's retrograde arc began on October 18 and ended on the night of the election.

CBS called for Gore just after 8pm EST. Mischievous Mercury turned on its station at 9:29pm and within half an hour, the networks turned, too.

At 10pm the election was declared too close to call.

Then at 2:17am, the networks gave it to Bush, and Gore phoned to concede. By 3:30am it was undecided yet again and Gore withdrew his concession.

This see-saw situation, as the vote hung in the balance, is reflected in Mercury's placing in the last minutes of the last degree of Libra the Scales.

Mercury had moved into Libra on the morning of the election and it entered Scorpio next day, heading for a square of confusing Neptune a week later (November 15).

The American astrologer Caroline W Casey has pioneered astrology as 'Mythic News', and the election has shown that the old god Hermes is alive and well, living as the media monkey in the modern age.

In mythology, Mercury is the Greek Hermes, the messenger of the gods who is a thief and wheeler-dealer, a trickster and a liar. He is the god of numbers and language, associated with the Gemini Twins, and he is duplex, androgynous and amoral.

In the spirit of entertainment, the networks jump the gun on exit polls and the election becomes the media's call.

Its fake calls are a sign of fake authority, symptomatic of the wider problem that for the media, the race matters more than the issues.

As Todd Gitlin observes, most of the absurd Bush claims about his Texas record, and his scary lack of understanding of international affairs, went unquestioned and unanalysed.

His frequent gaffes and malapropisms - signs of Dubya's own suspect Mercury - were more fun than the yawning ignorance they covered.

So what happens next? With Mercury moving into fixed and power-hungry Scorpio, a bitter entrenchment has begun and the world awaits some higher authority to sort out the mess.

In mythology, it is Zeus, king of the gods and the law itself, who silences Hermes with a nod of his head.

The horoscopes of the main players point to a Bush win but there are sure to be more legal wrangles in the coming months.

The American horoscope suggests electoral reform, but the media, the major culprit of the fiasco, will slip away unscathed.

webTitle: Work in progress: Shane O'Sullivan, film director

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: Shane O'Sullivan, film director
fields.trailText: Shane O'Sullivan, film director
fields.body:
Second Generation, my first feature, opens in London tomorrow at the ABC Piccadilly - the first independent film digitally released in the West End. When I first wrote the script I didn't think I'd be distributing it as well, but digital projection now makes it possible for guerilla filmmakers to be guerilla distributors as well.

Second Generation follows a young Japanese detective in his search for a missing Chinese girl among the curry houses of London's Brick Lane. It's an offbeat detective story exploring the humour and melancholy of late-night multi-cultural life there.

I wrote the script three years ago when I moved to the East End after a spell teaching English in Japan. It was developed by an established producer but a proper budget never materialised. So I raised a £25,000 shooting budget from three "business angels", a post-production house deferred £15,000 of editing time, and we shot for 19 days in Brick Lane last summer on Digital Betacam.

For missing Chinese girl Lili, we cast junior geisha-turned-Japanese pop-star Hanayo - a Björk-like chameleon who now lives in Berlin and collaborates with the Digital Hardcore label. Saeed Jaffrey signed on for a cameo and was mobbed by Bengali kids in a Halal Fried Chicken shop.

We finshed the film to tape and waited for a UK distributor to pick it up. It's difficult when you have a small, quirky film with no major stars which may only work as a small arthouse release. Who's going to pay £5,000 for a tube poster campaign or £20,000 to blow up to 35mm film?

The answer is: stay digital and release it yourself. We secured the ABC Piccadilly for a week, helped by the ready-made Japanese audience at the neighbouring Japan Centre, curious to see Hanayo's film debut. Barco Digital Cinema came on board to sponsor the release with one of their state-of-the-art projectors, we got a 15 certificate (mild swearing, £900) - and here we are.

So if you'd like a fresh vision of multi-cultural London and are curious about the possibilities of Digital Cinema, come check it out.

So I raised a £25,000 shooting budget from three "business angels", a post-production house deferred £15,000 of editing time, and we shot for 19 days in Brick Lane last summer on Digital Betacam. For missing Chinese girl Lili, we cast junior geisha-turned-Japanese pop-star Hanayo - a Björk-like chameleon who now lives in Berlin and collaborates with the Digital Hardcore label. Saeed Jaffrey signed on for a cameo and was mobbed by Bengali kids in a Halal Fried Chicken shop. We finshed the film to tape and waited for a UK distributor to pick it up. It's difficult when you have a small, quirky film with no major stars which may only work as a small arthouse release. Who's going to pay £5,000 for a tube poster campaign or £20,000 to blow up to 35mm film? The answer is: stay digital and release it yourself. We secured the ABC Piccadilly for a week, helped by the ready-made Japanese audience at the neighbouring Japan Centre, curious to see Hanayo's film debut. Barco Digital Cinema came on board to sponsor the release with one of their state-of-the-art projectors, we got a 15 certificate (mild swearing, £900) - and here we are. So if you'd like a fresh vision of multi-cultural London and are curious about the possibilities of Digital Cinema, come check it out.

webTitle: Watch this

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Late Spring | The Negotiator | Last Tango In Paris | Mad Dog And Glory
fields.body:
Late Spring

(Yasujiro Ozu, 1949)

6pm, FilmFour

This focuses on the relationship between altruistic professor Somiya and his loving daughter Noriko. She wants to stay at home and look after him; he thinks it's time she was married, and arranges various suitors, knowing he'll have to live alone. A lyrical, harmonious portrait of postwar Japanese society.

The Negotiator

(F Gary Gray, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Samuel L Jackson's ace hostage negotiator is framed for murder and embezzlement; he reacts by taking his main accuser and a bunch of admin staff hostage, demanding that a negotiator from another district (Kevin Spacey) investigates the crisis. The pair are soon working together to root out top-level corruption. The face-off between two of US cinema's most charismatic leads provides Gray's drama with a powerful charge - pity that the pair share so little time on screen.

Last Tango In Paris

(Bernardo Bertolucci, 1972)

12midnight, FilmFour

A glowering Brando meets kittenish Maria Schneider while viewing a Paris apartment. Within minutes they're shagging madly, prelude to an obsessive, increasingly sado-masochistic affair. The film's fairly explicit sex scenes - a knob of butter and all that - caused an is-it-art storm, but it's really all about Brando's extraordinary performance - his depressed ex-pat, traumatised by his wife's infidelity and suicide, is mesmerising.

Mad Dog And Glory

(John McNaughton, 1993)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Mad Dog is the ironic nickname of Robert De Niro's lonely, inhibited police photographer; Uma Thurman's Glory is the shopgirl "given" to him for a week as a reward for saving the life of mobster Milo (Bill Murray) during an armed raid. An intriguing set-up, blending thriller, romance and comedy - and the quality cast makes it surprisingly touching.

webTitle: Who will play the lead in the Grease sequel?

fields.headline: The price is right
fields.standfirst: Who will play the lead in the Grease sequel?
fields.trailText: Who will play the lead in the Grease sequel?
fields.body:
Britney Spears 1-2

Christina Aguilera 2-1

Debbie Gibson 25-1

Geri Halliwell 33-1

Following the 20th anniversary re-release of Grease, there are now rumours of a second sequel to the 1978 musical. So who could be up for the female lead?

"The choice depends on how close the producers want to make the part of Sandy to the original", says Andy Clifton, entertainment odds compiler at Ladbrokes. "The problem might be trying to convince some movie-goers that an innocent teenager still exists today", he adds. Britney Spears is keen to branch out into movies, but will the producers see it as a smart move, with her provocative dancing and revealing outfits? "Spears is part of a tightknit Baptist family, but she's played on the naughty girl side to her nature", says Andy. "That's a minor detail, though, when you consider her huge popularity among both sexes. If she wants it, she can have it."

It'd be good publicity to pitch Christina Aguilera against Spears for this part. "She might make a better job of it, but she's less likely to put bums on seats", says Andy. With numerous TV appearances to her credit, it's not surprising that Aguilera has been approached by a number of directors for roles in films. "She stands a good chance if Spears doesn't want it."

Debbie Gibson is a flash from the 80s past - perfect for the retro Grease feel? She's also worked in various musical productions, including a stage version of Grease, and is still releasing music. "She has talent, particularly as a songwriter," says Andy, "but I think she was a bit of a figure of fun in the 80s, and though she's still churning out stuff, it's a long time since she was well-known."

Geri Halliwell is rumoured to have a part in a film, Therapy, as well as contributing to the soundtrack, but is she big enough in America? Andy's not convinced. "There's more chance of Britney Spears covering up her navel in her next video than Ginger getting this gig."

webTitle: TV and Radio: Were the 60s filthy?

fields.headline: Love, peace and mud
fields.standfirst: They say that if you remember the 60s, you weren't there. But Jenny Fabian doesn't agree. And a new BBC series on some seminal moments from the era of love leaves her with just one question: were we all really that filthy?
fields.trailText: They say that if you remember the 60s, you weren't there. But Jenny Fabian doesn't agree. And a new BBC series on some seminal moments from the era of love leaves her with just one question: were we all really that filthy?
fields.body:
They arrived in the post - three defining moments of the 60s. Videos of the Isle of Wight Festival, the Grosvenor Square demo and the Albert Hall Poetry Reading. These trips down the memory lane of the counter-culture are scheduled to be shown in reverse chronological order, and I settled down to see what I had missed out on. I'd been at the Albert Hall, but stayed away from the demo and I'm sure there was a good reason for not going to the festival.

In the first Days In The Life programme, the 1970 Isle of Wight festival, hordes of half-dressed hippies wander across my screen. Were we really so matted and bedraggled? Where had all the beautiful crushed velvet people gone? Probably hobnobbing backstage with rock royalty, who, oblivious to the mud and lavatorial conditions out front, won't play until they get their money. A young protester sticks his head through the fence. He sees Roger Daltrey of The Who. "Music should be free!" he declaims. "Fuck you!" says Daltrey, and whacks him on the head.

The Marcusons, once big in the underground press and still looking cool in their softly lit sitting room, reminisce about packing their picnic baskets, getting high and being arrested by undercover police dressed in wigs, beads and tie-dye T-shirts. The acid must have been good, because police cells, full of tripped-out freaks, morphed into space ships spinning through the universe.

Back on earth in "the psychedelic concentration camp", the good vibes are wobbling. Anarchists torch the hamburger stalls, and the power-to-the-people mob are battering down the perimeter fence.

The odious promoter, trying to disguise himself in a fringed jacket, loses his cool and shouts over the PA: "If you don't want to pay three quid to listen to the music, don't fucking well come!" You can feel the hip free spirit being pol luted by the dreaded consumerism. If I couldn't remember why I didn't go then, I certainly can now. The flower party was over, declares the Blessed Caroline Coon, once the patron saint of stoned hippies.

The only flowers at the Grosvenor Square demo in '68 were those that got trampled underfoot by Trots, radicals and midget miners armed with chains "to slash the coppers with". Revolution was in the air, the Masters of War were killing humans in Vietnam, and the underground politicos were going to occupy the American Embassy.

In our South Kensington flat the great preparation of banners was taking place. The resident phone phreak, who could direct calls half way round the world by whistling at the right frequency, had put in a call to George Brown, who was probably pissed anyway, at the Foreign Office. The poet Spike Hawkins, a brilliant mimic, put on the voice of Harold Wilson and alerted Brown to the fact that society was about to collapse and there was a submarine at Skegness on standby.

I never made it to the demo, and judging from the footage, I'm glad I didn't. It seemed that from trying to find the solution, we had become the problem. Gone were the days of the orderly CND marches of the 50s. Now it's The Charge of The Fright Brigade starring Tariq Ali as Omar Sharif. People shouting Sieg Heils, throwing darts in horses' necks, bobbies' pointed helmets being treated with disrespect, and officers on horseback clubbing everyone in sight to the ground. I'm not surprised to hear two fuzz who were there on the day say it was good fun, and they'd be volunteering for the next demo. There were rumours of marines inside the embassy armed with rifles and tear gas, and someone said Mick Jagger was there being inspired to write Street Fighting Man. Why doesn't anybody get pissed off like that when we drop bombs on Kosovo?

In the final episode, The Gathering Of The Tribes, I look for nostalgic glimpses of faces I once knew, including my own. It's '65, and Moses, aka Allen Ginsberg, was in town. A big event was needed to do him justice, and not really knowing the enormity of what they were doing, a group of hipsters got it together to put on the Albert Hall Poetry Reading. "We were going to fill that bastion of reaction with love and flowers and beauty and energy and Blakean sunshine, and the revolution would stop all the wars and stupidity", extols Michael Horovitz, still amazingly free with his limbs for a man his age. But nobody expected so many from so far would flock to pay homage to the prophets of beat philosophy.

"Allen, do you think we should bring our spikes out on stage?" asks Alex Trocchi, king of the British junkie writers, who MCs the event with no idea of time. Poets on acid, poets on mescaline, pissed poets who couldn't get on stage, and, the final sacrilege, two naked poets covered in paint with books strapped to their heads, found in Sir Malcolm Sargent's private bathroom. But out front, in the warm buzz of a hall swollen with the initiated, the sensational vibe comes flooding back, and I think I see me gazing up into the eyes of a legendary poet. To hear again, 35 years later, Adrian Mitchell recite Tell Me Lies About Vietnam, "about all those stupid, cruel, futile wars that we carry out, still, at our age", I wish the world was ruled by poets and we could start all over again.

 Days In The Life, Saturday, 9pm, BBC2.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Hear this

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Crossing Continents | The Material World
fields.body:
Fritz Markuse spent 50 years living in Russia, but has returned to his native land for his 90th birthday. He is one of thousands forming the world's fastest-growing Jewish community. As Olenka Frankiel discovers in Crossing Continents (11.0am, Radio 4), Fritz was born in Berlin and has had no hesitation about returning to the nation where so many of his co-religionists perished. The city's Jewish population has doubled in the past decade, a steady expansion which shows no sign of slackening.

With the government's energy policy in a constant state of ebb and flow, it's a good moment to get Professor Stephen Salter and Dr William Beattie into the studio for The Material World (4.30pm, Radio 4). For some 30 years they have been involved in assessing the potential of wave power. Though the idea of harnessing the sea's perpetual movements has been around for centuries, modern technology is making it look a more viable proposition.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Last Night's TV

fields.headline: Code of silence
fields.trailText: Inspector Morse: The Remorseful Day | State Of The Planet
fields.body:
I am not surprised that the heart unit at the John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford was castigated so severely yesterday. It was the very day Morse died there from a heart attack. Almost holding hands for comfort, Chief Superintendent Strange and Sergeant Lewis reassured each other that Morse couldn't be in a better place.

I suggest that the front row of the chorus at the Folies Bergères would have been a better place. The surgeon was a sexual sadist. The nurse died during a bondage session, battered to death by a doctor with an NHS crutch. Which, I may add, was not returned to the hospital.

Who, you ask, is in charge of the clattering train?

In Colin Dexter's book, Morse died murmuring "Please, thank Lewis for me" to a nurse who didn't catch what he said. It was very characteristic of Morse, who had never thanked Lewis for anything in his life, to do so too low and too late. In Inspector Morse: The Remorseful Day (ITV) Morse said it with bell-like clarity to Strange. Which was strange, I thought.

The plot is one that you can hardly repeat with a straight face. The strength of this beautifully produced series was the unspoken affection between Morse (John Thaw) and Lewis (Kevin Whately). Like sweet and sour, they mingled extraordinarily well. Like father and son, they could barely communicate.

"What does Lewis think?" asked Strange. "Lewis!" exclaimed Morse, who probably thought Lewis's head was there to stop his ears banging together. Lewis invariably looked on the bright side. "Cheer up, sir. It's a lovely evening!" Morse replied with one of Housman's more stricken stanzas:

Ensanguining the skies How heavily it dies Into the west away... How hopeless underground. Falls the remorseful day.

You quite see it would be difficult to sustain a conversation in such circumstances.

AE Housman, whom Morse resembles in several curious particulars, was brilliant, reclusive, pedantic, sarcastic, melancholic and, probably, heartbroken by his unrequited love for a fellow undergraduate at Oxford. He said that his poetry, lyrical, almost liquid, oozed from him like gum from a tree while taking a long walk after drinking beer. Morse told Lewis, "I drink to think." If it were anyone but Morse, you would laugh.

He called Lewis "Robbie" once in 13 years. Lewis called him "sir" to the day he died and, indeed, afterwards. "Goodbye, sir", he said in the mortuary, and kissed the cold forehead.

Unlike the local stud's rather jolly funeral, which was packed with loose ladies in large hats (one of whom was called Debbie Repp because, I bet, it was a play on demirep), Morse's, you know, will be sparsely attended. You also know that Lewis will be there.

As the demirep put it to Morse, this series has been "A bit of class, darling..."

About the time Lewis was staring stricken at Morse's body, Sir David Attenborough was gazing with benign sorrow at a stuffed dodo. Both dead, no doubt about that. The dodo proverbially so. It was Exhibit A in State Of The Planet (BBC1), a three-part series about the future of life on earth. If any.

"This", he said, "is a kind of giant ground-living pigeon discovered by Portuguese sailors in the 16th century on Mauritius. They called it fat and lazy and stupid, but that didn't stop them clubbing it over the head in vast numbers and eating its flesh. They introduced pigs and monkeys, which ate its eggs. A few dodos were shipped back to Europe as curiosities. Most of them died on the way. How long the last dodo survived alone, we don't know." He looked at it with visible pity. The dodo gazed back with an air of mild, maidenly amazement.

You wondered if, perhaps. it wasn't a handsomer bird in the flesh. Few of us look our best skinned. Like the marsupial mahogany glider, known only from a 100-year-old skin, which reappeared recently in Queensland as a glorious little thing, which flew like a kite.

It was a narrow squeak for the mahogany glider. You felt, like the prodigal's father, "This, my son, was dead, and is alive again. He was lost and is found." Of course, he then rather lost the plot and killed a fatted calf.

The passing bell is sounding for the mass extinction of species. Sir David is, rather gallantly, hanging on the clapper.

webTitle: 60 Minutes producer slams top US news anchors

fields.headline: 60 Minutes producer slams top US news anchors
fields.trailText: 4pm: The executive producer of American current affairs show 60 Minutes has hit out at the country's top news anchors, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The executive producer of America's most prestigious current affairs show, 60 Minutes, has hit out at the country's top news anchors.

Don Hewitt said that the three big anchors - Dan Rather at CBS, Peter Jennings at ABC and NBC's Tom Brokaw - were now so similar that they should work together.

"If you were locked in a room and forced to watch only Peter Jennings, Tom Brokaw or Dan Rather, you wouldn't miss anything the others had," he said.

And he told MediaGuardian.co.uk that news anchors should go back to being "journalists rather than presenters - I'm sick of presenters".

In his controversial new book, Tell Me a Story, the veteran journalist will recommend that the three networks merge their news operations and syndicate a service to the networks for a fee, rather than working as competing commercial services.

Mr Hewitt told an audience of senior journalists and TV executives at Newsworld in Barcelona that competition between the networks had eroded the differences in their coverage.

At the same time, he said it was essential that journalists should tell a story and have "a bit of theatricality".

He said: "You want to find journalists who look like actors playing journalists."

Mr Hewitt was talking to the British journalist Nik Gowing and Michael Rosenblum a US-based current affairs producer, about the difference between traditional and new current affairs.

Delegates noted that magazine shows like 60 Minutes are very successful - 60 Minutes still pulls in $2bn for the network and commands budgets of up to $500,000 per hour - in stark contrast to most US magazine programmes.

webTitle: Top ten tips for campaigning on the net

fields.headline: Top ten tips for campaigning on the net
fields.standfirst: Nick Buxton, communications and networks executive of Jubilee 2000, suggests ways to create an attention-grabbing campaign website
fields.trailText:
1. Accuracy is crucial
Internet users can take their pick from a vast amount of information so they will only visit sites they know are reliable. Be very careful about the information you upload as inaccuracies reflect an unprofessional site.
fields.body:
1. Accuracy is crucial
Internet users can take their pick from a vast amount of information so they will only visit sites they know are reliable. Be very careful about the information you upload as inaccuracies reflect an unprofessional site.

2. Keep information up to the minute
Your campaign website needs to be as current on key developments in your field as news sites so you can make known your perspective on breaking news.

3. Keep information simple and clear
Activists are much more likely to react promptly to information on the net if they can absorbe it quickly.

4. Make it easy to navigate
Design your website so that visitors can move about without getting lost. Don't be afraid to copy sites that you admire and find easy to use.

5. Layer the information
Write simple summaries, then add more detailed links.

6. Maximise interactivity
Encourage campaigners to interact with your information and with other activists by using discussion boards, listservs and guest books.

7. Spend time on promotion
Advertise your site in the key search engines, other websites, sympathetic organisations and in your offline publications.

8. Provide links
Link to other campaign sites and arrange for them to link to you.

9. Install a good statistic engine
This will tell you everything from how many people visit your site to which region of the world your users are based. Use these statistics to improve your site.

10. Don't rely solely on the net for campaigning
The net is only one vehicle for getting your message across and millions of people do not have access to it. Tried and tested techniques such as public meetings, petitions, street stalls all involve contact with the public which is crucial for successful campaigning.

webTitle: NTL joins Go Racing team in battle for TV rights

fields.headline: NTL joins Go Racing team in battle for TV rights
fields.standfirst: Oct 12: Sky/C4 saddle up for race bid
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: Cable giant NTL has joined forces with BSkyB, Channel 4 and Arena Leisure in in the battle for TV horseracing rights. By Claire Cozens.
Oct 12: Sky/C4 saddle up for race bid
fields.body:
Cable giant NTL has joined forces with BSkyB, Channel 4 and Arena Leisure as the battle for the right to broadcast British horseracing intensifies.

The news strengthens their Go Racing consortium's claim to the prized media rights to Britain's 59 racecourses.

If the consortium's bid is successful, NTL will carry the planned Go Racing channel on its interactive TV service, allowing viewers to place bets and receive up-to-the-minute form guides.

Geoffrey Hamilton-Fairley, chief executive of Premium TV, a subsidiary of NTL, said: "We have analysed the racing sector carefully and believe that Go Racing is the best option for the racing business and racing fans alike.

"In particular, we are keen to unlock the potential of horseracing within the interactive TV environment."

Go Racing is competing against Carlton Communications for the global media rights to UK horseracing. The racecourse owners are due to meet next week to discuss the rival bids.

It is thought the bigger racecourses favour Go's bid, while the smaller provincial tracks believe they would benefit from Carlton's regional coverage.

webTitle: Anger at plan to name paedophiles on web

fields.headline: Anger at plan to name paedophiles on web
fields.standfirst: Special report: Child protection
fields.trailText: Plans to launch a website identifying paedophiles across the UK have been condemned by police and human rights organisations.
fields.body:
Plans to launch a website identifying paedophiles across the UK have been condemned by police and human rights organisations.

Stuart Carnie, an anti-paedophile campaigner from Aberdeen, aims to have the first details of sex offenders and their whereabouts posted on the internet next week.

Mr Carnie, who runs an organisation called Freedom for Children, said he will use court records, media reports and information from the public to draw up his profiles.

He said that he had already been inundated with offers of help and requests for information.

"We have decided to go down this route because we feel that people do have a right to know if there is someone in their area and to give the widest possible coverage we decided to go via the internet," he said. "Our fight is about the fact that we have a system in this country which would rather protect dangerous sex offenders who are killing our children. These people are getting more money, help and sympathy than their victims have ever had."

But the development has been condemned as dangerous and counterproductive by police, children's charities, and human rights groups.

"We have worked very, very hard to minimise the risk of harm to the public and I think we have accomplished that, but you would only need to get something like this wrong once," said Inspector Harry Thorburn, of Grampian police.

"I don't subscribe to the notion that this high media profile, very loud, very strident, clamouring for 'cleaning up a neighbourhood' is effective."

Mr Carnie said information would be checked before being posted on the site but said he would take full responsiblity for any mistakes.

A father of five, Mr Carnie regularly films people in his area whom he believes are paedophiles. He has dismissed suggestions that his website may incite violence.

"I won't ask people to commit acts of violence," he said. "What I would prefer to see them do is say, 'We now know what you are and who you are. We're not going to drive you away, but if we see you approaching our children may your god be near you because you are going to need him'."

A Glasgow-based human rights lawyer, Allan Miller, described the website as a "sinister development", which had the potential to put families at risk. "It is not going to provide better protection for families and children, it's going to place families and children in more danger because those who are going to be exposed in this way will go underground."

The creation of the website follows a summer of protests against paedophiles after the murder of Sarah Payne. The News of the World, which launched a name and shame campaign to identify padeophiles, was forced to bow to criticism and end the project.

Ray Wyre, who has studied sex offenders, said people needed to have a better understanding of the nature of sexual abuse, the majority of which was not carried out by strangers but occurred within the family.

The key to limiting abuse was working with offenders, not driving them away.

webTitle: Mayor plans to challenge ministers over new homes

fields.headline: Mayor plans to challenge ministers over new homes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone is preparing to challenge ministers by using his new planning powers to demand tens of thousands of affordable homes in London for people on average incomes unable to qualify for mortgages. The mayor will   signal his determination to address a growing housing crisis after receiving a report today which warns that house building in London needs to more than double over the next 10 years to prevent rising homlessness.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone is preparing to challenge ministers by using his new planning powers to demand tens of thousands of affordable homes in London for people on average incomes unable to qualify for mortgages. The mayor will signal his determination to address a growing housing crisis after receiving a report today which warns that house building in London needs to more than double over the next 10 years to prevent rising homlessness.

It says that 43,000 new homes annually are needed until 2011, at least half for rent or subsidised and shared ownership.

With teachers and nurses priced out of the capital's booming housing market, the report from a housing commission - launched by Mr Livingstone shortly after taking office in May - warns that "the unequal distribution of the benefits of the capital's booming economy may mean that London is sowing the seeds of its own social and economic decline".

The commission, chaired by the director of Shelter, Chris Holmes, says urgent action is needed with the prospect of the number of households in London rising by 500,000 to 3.6 million by 2016.
