webTitle: German man killed in renewed Israeli assault

fields.headline: German man killed in renewed Israeli assault
fields.trailText: A German man has become the first foreigner to be killed on the West Bank since the current conflict began seven weeks ago.
fields.body:
A German man has become the first foreigner to be killed on the West Bank since the current conflict began seven weeks ago.

Harald Fischer, 68, who moved to Beit Jala on the West Bank in 1981, was killed outside his home during an Israeli attack against Palestinian gunmen.

A wall near the spot where Fischer died was pocked with .50 caliber machine gun bullets. His left leg was severed and his upper body riddled with bullets.

His Palestinian wife, Norma, said the house had come under intense fire during the night but Fischer had braved the assault to help wounded neighbours.

German foreign minister Joschka Fischer said he was "shocked and horrified" by the shooting. He spoke to his Israeli counterpart at the Euro-Mediterranean foreign ministers meeting today and demanded an investigation.

The attacks are part of a renewed Israeli assault on the Palestinians following the deaths of four of its citizens on Monday. The offices of Yasser Arafat's Fatah movement in the West Bank towns of Salfit, Tulkarm and Hebron were hit in overnight helicopter strikes that left 10 Palestinians injured.

In addition, Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak announced that he has stopped the transfer of millions of dollars in tax revenue that Israel collects for the Palestinians.

Mr Barak brushed off criticism at home that the army's response to Palestinian shooting attacks was not strong enough. "If we thought that instead of 200 Palestinian fatalities, 2,000 dead would put an end to the fighting at a stroke, we would use much more force," he told Israeli radio.

Despite the violence, diplomatic efforts continue. Dennis Ross, the United States' outgoing Middle East envoy, met Mr Arafat for nearly two hours in Gaza today. Mr Arafat said Bill Clinton, who leaves office in January, is "insisting to achieve something before his departure."

The Israeli position is that Palestinian stone and shooting attacks must end before peace talks resume. However, senior Palestinian officials have said confrontations with Israel will continue, even if talks resume.

webTitle: ONdigital comes clean over pay-TV launch

fields.headline: ONdigital comes clean over pay-TV launch
fields.standfirst:
Company chief admits making false claims as former operations director sues for unfair dismissal

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Company chief admits making false claims as former operations director sues for unfair dismissal.
fields.body:
ONdigital was forced yesterday to admit that it had made false claims about the success of the launch of its pay television service.

The embarrassing admission, made by chief executive Stuart Prebble at an employment tribunal hearing in Croydon, came as part of the company's response to a claim of unfair dismissal by former director of operations John Egan.

Mr Egan, 40, who left the company last September, claimed he was entitled to £100,000 in bonuses, much of which was tied to the success of the launch almost two years ago. Despite publicly painting a favourable picture of the launch at the time, Mr Prebble yesterday conceded that this was at least in part a misleading impression.

"It was a commercial success and a public success, but it was not a success internally in terms of managing the situation," he said. "Any commercial enterprise will describe its launch as a success. It is not surprising that we did not share details of a range of issues with the public. It would be naive to think otherwise."

Mr Prebble cited problems with the supply of set-top boxes and difficulties with the company's call centre as areas where the launch had been troublesome. "There is no doubt that John worked very hard," Mr Prebble said. "He was a key member of the management team who had an understanding of operational aspects of the business that nobody else had."

But Mr Prebble added that the decision not to pay Mr Egan's launch bonus had been taken by a de-facto sub-committee of the ONdigital board.

The powerful sub-committee comprised the main directors of ONdigital's parent companies - Michael Green, and Stephen Cain, the chairman and former chief executive of Carlton Communications, and Charles Allen, chairman of Granada Media.

Earlier in the proceedings both Stephen Grabiner, a former chief executive of ONdigital, and Carlton deputy chief executive Nigel Walmsley confirmed that the launch had not been trouble-free but both were of the opinion it broadly had been a success.

Mr Walmsley said: "My view was that the launch bonus should have been paid. I acknowledge the amount of work that had to be done in the run-up to the launch - in the round, there was a case for the bonus to be paid in full."

Mr Egan had received £50,000, which the company claimed was an ex-gratia payment and not part of his launch bonus. Mr Egan said he felt "very let down" by ONdigital.

As well as the launch bonus Mr Egan is making claims concerning a loyalty bonus and alleged unfair dismissal.

Mr Egan left ONdigital to start the interactive TV firm Situp.com with Ashley Faull, another former ONdigital director.

Four of the five ONdigital directors at the launch have pursued claims against their employer. Judgment in Mr Egan's case was reserved.

ONdigital, which went on air two years ago, has signed up around 900,000 customers and is on track for its target of 1m subscribers by year-end.

webTitle: Arts: French modern art

fields.headline: Young, gifted and French
fields.standfirst: Across the Channel, Britart is regarded as vulgar and smug. So how do they do things over there? As a new show of contemporary French art opens in Scotland - the first in the UK for 10 years - Stuart Jeffries finds out
fields.trailText: Across the Channel, Britart is regarded as vulgar and smug. So how do they do things over there? As a new show of contemporary French art opens in Scotland - the first in the UK for 10 years - Stuart Jeffries finds out.
fields.body:
In Bilbao earlier this year, the French artist Matthieu Laurette bought a car worth just over 1m pesetas. Then he gave it away on a TV game show called The Big Exchange. That's what happens when a conceptual artist gets his hands on a TV programme's production budget.

The game show worked like this: the caller who offered the most expensive new gift in exchange for the car would drive the car home. In the first week, a Bilbao family won by offering a multimedia PC plus printer worth a quarter of the price of the car. The following week, the PC was exchanged for a widescreen TV. The week after, the TV was exchanged for a fridge-freezer. The fridge-freezer was traded for a juicer. It went on like this for two and a half months: in the last week the prize was so crummy that nobody bothered to phone up.

Yes, yes, but why is this art? Matthieu Laurette, who is one of 21 French artists taking part in the Vivre Sa Vie season in Edinburgh and Glasgow during November and December, looks across the cafe table and says: "It's an artistic project because what I'm laying bare is the nature of money, the nature of interest, the value of consumption and the consumption of value. I was recycling money back to the people and showing clearly how it was done. It was quite a laugh, too."

He's an impish cuss, is Laurette - a little like Chris Morris in his devotion to tearing the media apart, but less sinister. This Sunday, for example, the Pompidou Centre in Paris has a private view for a new exhibition called Beyond the Spectacle. Laurette has a video installation in the show, but more interestingly, he has come up with a project for the pre-show schmooze.

Lots of celebrities and journalists are expected to attend, so Laurette arranged for a host of lookalikes to wander round among them. What sort of lookalikes? "Well, that would give the game away," says Laurette. "But I'm pretty sure Elton John will be there, and the French singer Eddie Mitchell. Not the real ones, you understand." But, again, why is this art? "Because we are in the middle of the society of the spectacle and, if you're an artist, the only thing to do is to pull it apart. It's a great game."

Laurette, 30, has become a media personality in France thanks to this kind of playful deconstruction of the media, celebrity and consumer culture. For four years, he washed, shaved and ate for free by using only materials that came with offers such as "satisfaction or your money back" or "first purchase refunded". I don't believe you, I tell him. "It is absolutely true," he replies. "There are a great deal of these deals in France," he adds, showing me the packaging for a Reach toothbrush.

"I'm hoping that when I get to Scotland they will have some of these deals, too, because even though I don't live entirely off them nowadays, I have for the past nine years subsisted mostly off these goods." He shows me a package for a Weight Watchers yoghurts special offer that someone brought him from Britain: "I might have to live off these," he says.

This artistic project thrust Laurette into the limelight in France. He appeared regularly on TV shows during the 90s, explaining how to get not only a free lunch, but a free shave, too. His expertise as the consumer's friend was widely courted.

Laurette recalls his stardom with a grin: "The project had everything. In France people are obsessed with food, with money, and above all with money-saving scams. What really interested me was another economics - the economics of the artist. Every time I mentioned that I was an artist, ratings fell. If I just kept talking about how to get things for free, people stayed tuned in.

"My celebrity took an identity of its own. I couldn't entirely control it, and that has always been the case with my work: when they write about me in Le Monde, or in your Express newspaper, I am something other than I am. I like that. And it's important for me to present myself to different media outlets in different ways." An intellectual art terrorist for the broadsheets, a clued-up shopper for the tabloids? "That's the general idea."

Isn't his work just an application of the situationist philosophy of Guy Debord? "I get that question all the time from journalists. What amazes me is that media people all seem to know their Debord and even their Andy Warhol. They know they are working in a world of spectacle and celebrity, but they carry on anyway - perhaps with a certain amount of cynicism. My role as an artist is to engage with this society of the spectacle and expose its workings."

He won't tell me what he's planning to do as part of the Vivre Sa Vie season in Edinburgh - "It isn't finished yet. I'm not sure." But his appearances will be worth experiencing, not least because French contemporary art rarely gets shown in Britain.

The last such major retrospective was Le Cinq, held at the Tramway in Glasgow nearly 10 years ago. Why isn't French contemporary art very well known or in much demand in Britain? Laurette has a theory. "In Britain, the artist has become the star, just like movie stars and music stars. They consume the media and are consumed in return. It's a very interesting economy. But that isn't the case in France. How can we compete in that economy?"

Indeed, throughout much of France, one has the feeling that French artists are sniffing smelling salts in response to the vulgar displays across the Channel. Only last month, the French philosopher Paul Virilio published a tirade against contemporary art called La Procédure Silence in which he argued not only that contemporary art was bad, but that it was evil. Citing Theodor Adorno's dictum about the impossibility of writing a poem after Auschwitz, Virilio railed against "the conformism of abjection" of the Britart Sensation! exhibition.

Why was contemporary art evil? Virilio quoted from an interview with an Auschwitz survivor who visited the death camp's museum and recorded her impressions. She had just seen glass cabinets filled with suitcases, prostheses, children's games: "I wasn't overwhelmed as I was when I was at the camp. No, in the museum, I suddenly had the impression of being in a contemporary art museum. And I said: 'They have won!'"

Though Virilio's analysis has been widely attacked in France, it is suggestive about why French contemporary art isn't as vulgarly virulent as its British counterpart. It is not merely a question of there being no Charles Saatchi to buy the stuff and thus give it exposure.

Rather, French contemporary art seems less smugly wounded, more playful; more intellectual, certainly, and less egocentric. Laurette is only an extreme example of this. Another is Pierre Joseph, also showing at Vivre Sa Vie, an artist who has made books, videos and installations that often mistranslate maps, diagrams and educational books.

Much of the most exciting French contemporary art is video- or internet-based. This is probably because French art schools are so suffocatingly dominated by old-schoolers that the only way young artists can establish autonomy is by working in new media.

That is not to say that French contemporary sculpture, for example, is not interesting: Claude Leveque's intriguing work, which can be seen at the Glasgow Project Room from Saturday onwards, is particularly exciting since it uses neon light installations to produce an uncanny and very contemporary beauty.

What is appealing about Vivre Sa Vie is the lack of a unifying theme. Tanya Leighton, director of the season, writes in her programme notes that the season is named after Jean-Luc Godard's 1962 film which told its story through 12 apparently unconnected episodes. This is striking: while Britart can and has been packaged so readily and sold so easily, French art can only be exported across the Channel by reference to its variety. The tyranny of British abjection, the ubiquity of its vulgarity, is going to get a French lesson.

 Matthieu Laurette gives a talk at noon today at Edinburgh College of Art. His event for Vivre Sa Vie will take place on December 7 at the Edinburgh College of Art. Information on the season at www.vivre-sa-vie.co.uk or on 0141-576 6182.

New Life: the full Vivre Sa Vie line-up

Pierre Huyghe and Philippe Parreno

The two new stars of French contemporary art have been commissioned to create a new large-scale installation at the Tramway. Huyghe, who will represent France at the Venice Biennale next year, often works in video in the manner of British artists such as Douglas Gordon and Gillian Wearing. Parreno's installations often deal with the production and organisation of space and identity.

Nicolas Pages

This artist, born in 1970, will present a written work during Vivre Sa Vie entitled I Eat an Egg, which will be available from participating venues. The following is an extract: "I roll a joint, I don't know what to do with myself, I open a bottle of red wine, I pour myself a glass, I wait, I watch TV."

Thomas Hirschorn

A sculptor who specialises in making altars from cardboard, tinfoil, Perspex and wood, Hirschorn's project for Vivre Sa Vie is called Raymond Carver Altar and will be on show in a public space in Glasgow from tomorrow until December 2.

Claude Closky

This internationally recognised multimedia artist, who loves to distort the mass media, has been commissioned to create a new internet work. From Saturday it will be at www.mediascot.org/closky.

Marine Hugonnier

Hugonnier's film and video works include Highlights, Moorgate Station, 17.08.99, 5.35 and Highlights, London Bridge, 13.10.99, 6.15, which have brought her international critical acclaim.

Born in 1944, Bortanski is one of the old guard, whose primary focus has been death in general and the Holocaust in particular. I was recycling money back to the people and showing clearly how it was done. It was quite a laugh, too." He's an impish cuss, is Laurette - a little like Chris Morris in his devotion to tearing the media apart, but less sinister. This Sunday, for example, the Pompidou Centre in Paris has a private view for a new exhibition called Beyond the Spectacle. Laurette has a video installation in the show, but more interestingly, he has come up with a project for the pre-show schmooze. Lots of celebrities and journalists are expected to attend, so Laurette arranged for a host of lookalikes to wander round among them. What sort of lookalikes? "Well, that would give the game away," says Laurette. "But I'm pretty sure Elton John will be there, and the French singer Eddie Mitchell. Not the real ones, you understand." But, again, why is this art? "Because we are in the middle of the society of the spectacle and, if you're an artist, the only thing to do is to pull it apart. It's a great game." For four years, he washed, shaved and ate for free by using only materials that came with offers such as "satisfaction or your money back" or "first purchase refunded". I don't believe you, I tell him. "It is absolutely true," he replies. "There are a great deal of these deals in France," he adds, showing me the packaging for a Reach toothbrush. webTitle: Arts: Javier de Frutos on Las Vegas

fields.headline: Bring on the showgirls
fields.standfirst: Choreographer Javier De Frutos sought grit and glitter for his new dance. He found it on a trip to Las Vegas
fields.trailText: Choreographer Javier De Frutos sought grit and glitter for his new dance. He found it on a trip to Las Vegas.
fields.body:
I first visited Las Vegas in 1988. In the heat of the desert city, I was holed up in the Convention Centre for a week, modelling fur coats. In its own way, my brief sojourn was a reflection of the contradictions that make Las Vegas what it is - a city where Siberian fur is modelled in 90 degrees of heat and where gay bars exist alongside shops selling Catholic iconography. It's a city of plunging necklines and rhinestone crucifixes, where night becomes day in 24-hour casinos and where clocks are rarer than a sunny day in London.

When Christopher Bruce recently asked me to choreograph a piece for Rambert Dance Company, of which he is artistic director, my travels in Vegas came back to haunt me. America has been a constant theme in my work over the past few years and I have been particularly inspired by the lyrical writings of Tennessee Williams. I was keen to see if the universal human truths that Williams addresses in his work had found a place in arguably America's most manufactured and made-over city.

And so, Vegas found its way into The Celebrated Soubrette - my new piece for Rambert. In Michael Daugherty's clever, witty score, Le Tombeau de Liberace, I found a voice for my musings.

I wanted to choreograph something unapologetically grand and at times tragic. Daugherty's music, and the man it was inspired by - a one-man walking Las Vegas - fitted the bill perfectly. One image seemed to stick in my mind: what would the atmosphere have been like if Williams had actually met Liberace?

This potentially disastrous chemical cocktail became the starting point for The Celebrated Soubrette. Las Vegas provided the heat which would bring the mixture to the boil. In an attempt to capture the essence of the city and inject this fantasy with some stark reality, I made a two-day visit to Las Vegas earlier this year.

Day 1

Much has changed in Las Vegas over the past 10 years. On my first visit, I landed in the desert. Today, the airport is just off Vegas's central strip. A huge shimmering pyramid rises into the sky. This is my hotel.

4am: I'm jet-lagged. I look out of my window. To my left are replicas of the Empire State and Chrysler buildings. Straight ahead is a pastel recreation of Camelot. The Eiffel Tower is just around the corner.

6am: Breakfast. The Luxor is probably the only hotel in the world where you breakfast in the midst of a full-scale archaeological excavation (although the "artefacts" bear an uncanny, if fractured, resemblance to the kitsch "Egyptian" statues in the casino). "Hi, I'm Linda. What can I dig for you?" asks my waitress.

8am: I meet up with James P Reza, editor of the Time Out Guide to Las Vegas and that rare breed in the city - a native Las Vegan. Our first stop is the Glass Pool Inn, one of Vegas's few remaining 1950s buildings. It's a style of architecture that I am particularly drawn to.

Much of my work relates to the creation and destruction of geometric shapes. Similar themes run through the carved curves of these elegant, strangely futuristic edifices. Over the past 10 years, the original 1950s Las Vegas casinos have largely been "imploded", and only a small number of motels and even fewer original bars remain. I ask James why this is. "They don't make money," he replies. In their place now stand modern buildings masquerading as ancient or classical architecture (but with added fairy lights and a shorter shelf life).

Lunchtime: I'm at the Liberace Museum. "Do you like my costume? You should. You paid for it." Liberace knew which side his bread was buttered and a visit to his museum only confirms that while he knew what money could buy, he never forgot who put it in his pocket. Diamond jewels are displayed side-by-side with small throw-away china dogs; a gold encrusted piano shares the stage with one made by a fan from 200,000 toothpicks.

I spot a photograph of a poster advertising an early show starring Liberace and the "voice of Barbra Streisand". Liberace supposedly said of her that "what she hadn't discovered about showbusiness was the value of glamour. It almost seems as if she'd never even heard the word." I find myself warming to the man even more. We are met by the new curator of the Liberace Museum, 25-year-old anthropologist Brian Paco Alvarez. Paco (whose motto is "It's not just a label, it's an idea") shows us behind the scenes. Paco's enthusiasm for Liberace is purely personal - he used to see him shopping as a child and Liberace always said "Hi". His mother couldn't be more pleased if Paco had become President.

But, all is not well at the Liberace Museum. Brian's predecessor has left things in quite a state. Some of Liberace's precious costumes are stored in the bathroom. I take an exclusive pee in Liberace's personal toilet and note that clearly his love of candelabras was not just a stage act. On my way out, I buy a moving-image pen. Liberace floats in a dream car between two candelabras as I write.

Evening: Like the 50s architecture, old-fashioned Las Vegas showgirls are a dying breed. Those still working look like they've been at it a long time. I decide to head for Bally's Casino to see Jubilee! There are two shows each evening: the midnight show is topless; at 9.30pm, the girls tie a bit of sparkly ribbon across their top half.

I decide to be daring and go for the late show. And, what a show. The sinking of the Titanic, complete with rictus smiles, lingerie and a high-kicking American Pie finale has the woman next to me in tears. The effects are fantastic, but beneath the sparkles, you can see that for these women, its just a job. I wonder what will happen to them when Jubilee's lights go out forever?

Day 2

3am: Time to get up. The same people are in the same position in the timeless casino.

10am: We head out for the desert, which puts Vegas into sharp focus. Tennessee Williams said: "We are all of us sentenced to solitary confinement inside our own skin, for life!" I realise that this could apply as strongly to Vegas itself - a floating island in a sea of dust - as to any living person.

Lunchtime: Shopping at The Forum mall at Caesar's Palace. At the Gucci roman temple, I'm short on cash and time. "Don't worry," says the shop assistant, "everything will still be here when you come back from the casino." Money talks in Vegas, but I suppose it's consoling to know that if you don't have any, your fortune could just be a slot machine away.

Evening: I meet up with James P Reza and his girlfriend Stacey. I'd given up hope of finding anything of Williams's spirit in Vegas, and then in walks Stacey. She used to be stripper, but is now setting up as a hairdresser. She stripped because she loved it and recently fulfilled her adolescent fantasy of stripping on New Orleans' Bourbon Street. The name of her chosen bar? Big Daddy's (after Brick's father in Cat on a Hot Tin Roof).

Stacey is smart, sexy, seemingly frail but tough as nails - the quintessential Williams heroine - and she's sitting opposite me. This is what I've been looking for. She's my celebrated soubrette, and I'm dying to tell the Rambert dancers. Time to go home.

 Rambert Dance Company's The Celebrated Soubrette is at Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020 7863 8000) from November 21-25 and the Plymouth Theatre Royal (01752 267 222) from November 29 to December 2. A documentary by Matthew Springford on the making of The Celebrated Soubrette will be shown on Artsworld - a new digital channel - on Christmas Eve

webTitle: Web watch

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Planetproject.com | Unbeatable.co.uk
fields.body:
All human life
An ambitious survey has just kicked off to find out "what it is like to be a human being at the start of the 21st century".

The Planet Project, sponsored by tech company 3Com, says it wants to hold up a "digital mirror for a glimpse of the human condition" over the next three days, and is inviting millions of people - online and offline - to contribute to the survey.

It will also provide a useful platform to showcase technologies that combine lots of statistical input from across the world in eight different languages. Questions will be divided into eight modules covering everything from religion to dating and sex.

As users complete each module they will be able to compare instantly their answers with the results from around the world. In an attempt to bridge the digital divide 3Com says thouands of pollsters equipped with laptops, handhelds and portable transmitters will take off into the more remote cornersof the globe. See www.planetproject.com.

Shop here Shopping in the high street for gadgets increasingly looks like throwing money away, such are the bargains to be had online. I bought a new digital camcorder at Unbeatable that was fully £150 cheaper than the best "bricks and mortar" price (and almost £200 less than the biggest high street names). The website has recently been redesigned to give it a much slicker look. Fulfillment - at least in my experience - is excellent too.

We've yet to try the Helpful Home Shopping Company, but with the prices they are advertising (impressive discounts on white goods especially, it seems) it could only be a matter of time. See www.unbeatable.co.uk and www.helpful.co.uk.

Movie Times
The BBC might be upsetting various dot.coms by moving into new areas on the web, but its latest efforts show they're not being put off. Under the Radio Times brand the BBC has unveiled a new site dedicated to films - on both small and silver screens - drawing on its extensive database of reviews. A nice touch is the highlighting of films that are appearing on TV this week, as well as those showing at your local fleapit. See www.radiotimes.com/film.

Small screen
Staying with television, both MTV and Channel 4 have revamped their websites. Channel 4 wants to make it easier to navigate your way through its sprawling online empire. To that end, the clean-looking front page sports an A-Z index and a guide to what's on the channel today, while celebrity chat, user forums and Shockwave games are gathered together in "talk" and "play" sections.

MTV wants to expand its online offering, and introduce what it calls a "bold new graphic look and feel". That new look is pretty hideous, but should you persevere past all the winking graphics and impossible-to-read text you'll find lots of cool features like six online radio stations, animations, cartoon clips and an archive of the channel's amusing promos.

New force
While some entertainment companies continue to try to shut down the legions of websites devoted to their TV shows and programmes, it is heartening to see that LucasFilm is doing exactly the opposite. The company is asking amateur directors to submit their short films based on the Star Wars series, so they can be showcased on the website of multimedia specialists Atom Films.

Going even further, LucasFilm is even making assorted audio clips from the films available for would-be directors to cut in to their efforts, so they too can have authentic Darth-style heavy breathing and the distinctive "bufthzzzz" sound of a lightsaber duel.

Uri plans to complete the book on November 15, 2001, 50 chapters later, with readers being asked about the book along the way.

United Utilities is reviewing its financial PR and public affairs accounts in the wake of the appointment of a new group director of communications.

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter has poached JP Morgan's vice-president of media relations, Alexander Northcott.

The intimate details of lobbying contracts involving members of the House of Lords are to be laid bare under proposals made by Lord Neill.

Financial Dynamics chief executive Nick Miles is to head a new global investor relations and corporate communications brand, launched this week by parent company Cordiant Communications Group.

Sally Osman has been appointed to the top dedicated PR post at the BBC.

The general public believes public relations officers to be more trustworthy than journalists.

Clark's, the high street shoe retailer, has ditched its two retained corporate and fashion PR agencies as part of a communications overhaul.

Charlotte Church, the Welsh teenage soprano, has hired Henry's House to handle personality PR.

The Tobacco Manufacturers Association is looking for a new PR agency after Edelman PR Worldwide decided not to repitch for the account.

Corporate and financial agency Citigate Dewe Rogerson has denied industry rumours that its deputy chairman and international MD are leaving to launch a rival agency.

The communications industry has reacted strongly to the New Economics Foundation's claims that social reporting is corporate spin.

Rising numbers of public relations officers are leaving staff jobs to go freelance.

Former Clinton PR guru Dick Morris has denied accusations of making £1.1m for advising the Argentinian government during an eight-month period.

webTitle: Twists and u-turns over manual recount

fields.headline: Twists and u-turns over manual recount
fields.standfirst:
Florida Switches plus legal ruling signal good news for Gore
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: One of the three Florida counties that hold the key to the identity of the next US president performed a u-turn yesterday and said it would hold a manual recount after all.
fields.byline: Michael Ellison  in Tallahassee and Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
One of the three Florida counties that hold the key to the identity of the next US president performed a u-turn yesterday and said it would hold a manual recount after all.

Meanwhile in West Palm Beach, the centre of attempts to re-examine last week's election, Democrats who said they were confused by a new ballot design into voting against vice-president Al Gore won a ruling that could lead to a wider recount of votes than expected.

Broward county, between Miami and Palm Beach county, said it would reassess 564,000 ballots in the overwhelmingly Democratic area. "We're in uncharted waters, in a legal perspective," said Sam Goren, a lawyer advising the elections supervisor Jane Carroll.

The switch, which is good news for Mr Gore - officially 300 votes behind George W Bush - was made in the face of a lawsuit filed by the Democratic party.

The recount, if it goes ahead, is expected to take at least a week. Broward's canvassing board met the Tuesday evening deadline, in common with Florida's other 66 counties, but only after a partial recount that gave Mr Gore another seven votes. This was ascertained by taking another look at 3,892 ballots in three precincts.

On Monday officials decided this suggested a county-wide recount would be of little value and so ruled it out, on Tuesday they talked about reconsidering, and yesterday they decided to go for the manual recount.

Meanwhile Mr Gore edged another step forward in his efforts to gather enough votes to defeat Mr Bush in Florida when the judge in West Palm Beach said election officials in Palm Beach county could include the celebrated "dimpled chad" voting papers in their recounts.

Judge Jorge Labarga said officials should not automatically throw out all ballot papers in which the hole next to a voter's presidential choice was not completely punched through. Instead, officials could decide whether to accept a ballot paper in which the box next to the candidate's name was clearly indented, even though no hole had been made - the so-called "dimpled chads".

"No vote is to be declared invalid or void if there was a clear intention of the voter," Judge Labarga ruled after a 90-minute hearing.

The ruling means several thousand previously rejected ballot papers may now be included in any manual recount of the 462,000 votes cast in the presidential ballot in Palm Beach county.

The Palm Beach hand recount had been scheduled to begin at 7am yesterday, but it was suspended while the county's election board members went to court for the judge's ruling.

"We decided we would wait because we need clear direction on what to do," said Charles Burton, chairman of the local canvassing board which supervises elections in the county. "On the one hand we're trying to move forward, on the other it almost seems to be musical courts. We're going from the next courtroom to the next courtroom to the next courtroom."

Democrats had also hoped that a hand count in Florida's largest county, Miami-Dade, would give Mr Gore a clear lead in the state but this looked yesterday to be where there was least likely to be any movement.

Officials ran a manual recount there of 5,871 ballots in three heavily pro-Democratic precincts and found another six votes for Mr Gore. This, the Miami-Dade canvassing board decided by a two-one vote, did not justify a hand count across the county.

"I don't believe the changes I saw in the votes warrant us going any further," said David Leahy, the county elections supervisor. Democrats were still considering a legal challenge to the decision. "We think they're wrong," said Kendall Coffey, a lawyer for the party.

There was no immediate legal dispute about the clarity of the ballots in Miami-Dade but still about 17,000 cards had more than one punch for president and another 10,000 had none.

In another development, it emerged yesterday that 16 of the 67 counties that submitted certified recount figures to Tallahassee by Tuesday evening's deadline did not recount every vote. Democrats claimed the 16 counties merely rechecked their computer arithmetic rather than running a full mechanised recount.

As if this was not enough, an extreme conservative legal pressure group said it had been given permission by 32 of the state's counties to review all the ballots.

"We're assembling volunteers, we're getting organised," said Larry Klayman, chairman of the Washington-based Judicial Watch.

No US legal conflict of recent years has been complete without the fanatically anti-Clinton Mr Klayman trying - often successfully - to get his foot in the legal door. Somehow it was inevitable he would show up in Florida sooner or later.

webTitle: The Lion's main attraction

fields.headline: The Lion's main attraction
fields.standfirst: Meteor watchers are ready for a celestial spectacular, writes  Duncan Steel
fields.trailText: Meteor watchers are ready for a celestial spectacular, writes Duncan Steel
fields.body:
If two Scottish astronomers are correct, our skies will blaze with shooting stars at 03:44 on Saturday morning. Their prediction is based not merely on computer modelling of the dynamics of the solar system, but also on ancient records of meteor showers dating back to AD 902, a remarkable mix of the old and the new.

David Asher (Armagh Observatory) and Rob McNaught (Australian National University) met seven years ago when both were essential parts of the small team I directed at the Anglo-Australian Observatory in New South Wales, looking for Earth-approaching asteroids.

To predict whether an asteroid might hit the Earth in the future, we would follow its trajectory forward by computer, accommodating all the gravitational tugs of the planets. Even the best measurements always leave some uncertainty. If the asteroid has been observed only for a few weeks, one cannot be sure where it will wander. Predicting an impact requires precise observations over perhaps several years.

This has been evident in reports over the past fortnight. Based on initial observations, an asteroid discovered at the end of September, catalogued as 2000 SG344, seemed to be a possible Earth-impactor in 2030. The formally calculated probability of a hit was one in 500. Soon, though, observations of the position of SG344 in April 1999 were identified in sky-scan archives. With data spread over 18 months it was found that the 499 in 500 chance - that the asteroid will miss us - was the reality.

To derive such probabilities, astronomers run computer programs that ask, in essence, a lot of "what if?" questions. This process is similar to considering the asteroid to be split into billions of hypothetical particles, the software following each of them along their slightly different paths in space, and then identifying which ones end up hitting the Earth. If you start with a billion, and a thousand intercept our planet (at least in your computer's memory), then the chance of the real asteroid slamming home might be estimated as one in a million. Meteor showers allow astronomers to run the experiment in the real solar system.

Meteor showers occur when the Earth ploughs through concentrations of small meteoroids spawned by a comet. The nucleus of a comet is composed largely of ice, plus other frozen but easily-evaporated materials (ammonia, carbon dioxide, and various organic chemicals like methane, ethane, and even alcohol). Each orbit, solar heating causes a layer of these ices to evaporate.

The cometary vapour cloud carries with it a multitude of flecks of rock, plus heavier organic chemicals (like tar) that do not evaporate easily. Typically these are only the size of sand grains or peas. They gradually disperse, moving along much the same path as their parent comet.

If the Earth eventually traverses that complex, a meteor shower occurs, the tiny meteoroids burning up in the high atmosphere as they arrive at hypervelocity. In their death throes, they produce the familiar zips of light we call shooting stars. A comet with a trajectory passing very close by can produce a spectacular but brief shower, perhaps even what astronomers call a storm (more than 1,000 shooting stars an hour), because there is a greater concentration of particles trailing right behind.

For 11 centuries a comet named Tempel-Tuttle has generated a meteor shower called the Leonids (because the streaks appear to emanate from the constellation Leo). When the Leonids return, the lion figuratively roars. The comet takes about 33 years to circuit the sun on its elongated orbit, and storms have been recorded throughout mediaeval times. In 1799 the Leonids were phenomenal. A good display in 1832 was followed by a corker in 1833, seen over the eastern USA. In 1866 the sky over Britain lit up. This led to widespread predictions in the newspapers that 1899 would see a fine display, but it fizzled, as did 1900. In 1933 there were a few meteors, but nothing to get too excited about. As a result, in 1966 astronomers in the western USA were caught unawares by a huge outburst; the count rate was estimated at more than 100,000 per hour. Ten or 50 shooting stars could be seen at any instant.

This is where Asher and McNaught enter the story. They reasoned that the comet loses meteoroids predominantly in clumps at the times when it passes nearest the Sun on its 33-year cycle, but each time it returns, the comet has a slightly different path because it too has been perturbed by the planets, Jupiter in particular. In principle, the Earth should pass through separated clumps of different ages at slightly different times on November 17 and 18.

They tested their idea first by comparing its results with what had been seen in previous years. They made a firm prediction for 1999. They said that at 02:08 Universal Time on November 18 there should be an outburst, produced solely by meteoroids released by the comet in 1899.

Leo does not rise until about 02:00 local time, and so Asher and McNaught advised observers to go east. They met up themselves in Jordan. Nasa flew two telescope-equipped planes out of Israel. They were not disappointed. An 80-minute period of high meteor count rate was obvious, centred on 02:04. The prediction was out by just four minutes. And the count rate, which Asher and McNaught had estimated to peak at about 1,000 per hour ahead of time, actually reached 4,000.

What about this year? The prediction is for a lower rate, only a hundred per hour, but some should be visible from the U.K. If this modelling is correct, there will be a peak at 07:53 on the 17th, and another at 07:51 on the 18th, but that's after sunrise here so you'd need to be in the Americas to see them. In between should be another peak at 03:44 am, and that one may be seen from Britain, clouds allowing. Asher and McNaught pinpoint 1733 as the year the comet released those particles, to light up our night sky 267 years later.

The main interest is in validating the theoretical model producing the predictions. If it works as well this year as it did in 1999, meteor enthusiasts will be keenly anticipating 2001 and 2002, when Asher and McNaught expect the Leonids to produce tens of thousands of meteors. The Leonids provide a real, cosmic test of the sort of software we need for predicting asteroid impacts years ahead of time. Although they pose a danger to astronauts and satellites, meteor showers are mostly fun. There's nothing funny about asteroid impacts.

 Duncan Steel works at the University of Salford. His book Target Earth (Time Life) will be published shortly.

webTitle: Science update

fields.headline: Science update
fields.trailText: Trying over spilt milk | Ice machine in the sky
fields.body:
Trying over spilt milk
Did Iron Age man run cattle for beef or for cheese? Seven scientists from five British institutions report in Nature today that they have sorted out one thing: in Scotland, they were into dairying. The researchers from Newcastle, Bradford, Oxford and two places in Sheffield managed to detect a protein only found in cow's milk trapped in shards of coarseware cooking pots used 2,500 years ago at South Uist in the Outer Hebrides. "Dairying is a high-input, high-output, high-risk operation indicative of an intensive, sophisticated economy," they say, "but this practice is notoriously difficult to demonstrate in the archaeological record."

Ice machine in the sky
Huge hailstones (Science, May 4) in Spain - lumps of ice weighing up to 2kg -may have a natural explanation, according to a Spanish team reporting to the American Geological Institute's journal Geotimes. There were 50 such falls from January 8- 31. Were they from aeroplane toilets? Were they comet ice? "On January 5, a thin jet of ozone depression passed through all the areas in Spain where the ice falls took place. It is commonly posited that global warming and ozone depression are linked. Despite the fact that the greenhouse effect leads to an increase in the global mean surface temperature, it leads to cooling in the stratosphere," they say. The ice began to nucleate around dust at very high altitudes. "There, where humidity is more abundant, they start growing, evidencing that the greenhouse effect is beginning to show."

It wasn't a boson
Scientists at Cern in Geneva have switched off LEP, the large electron positron collider, after a fruitful 11-year run. This machine, which consumes the power supply of a small nation, and which has done the job it was built for, was left running (Science September 21) for an extra month because of last minute hints that it might be detecting traces of the Higgs boson, the so-called "God particle." Alas, there was no further sign, and LEP is now silent.

"On January 5, a thin jet of ozone depression passed through all the areas in Spain where the ice falls took place. It is commonly posited that global warming and ozone depression are linked. Despite the fact that the greenhouse effect leads to an increase in the global mean surface temperature, it leads to cooling in the stratosphere," they say. The ice began to nucleate around dust at very high altitudes. "There, where humidity is more abundant, they start growing, evidencing that the greenhouse effect is beginning to show." It wasn't a boson Scientists at Cern in Geneva have switched off LEP, the large electron positron collider, after a fruitful 11-year run. This machine, which consumes the power supply of a small nation, and which has done the job it was built for, was left running (Science September 21) for an extra month because of last minute hints that it might be detecting traces of the Higgs boson, the so-called "God particle." Alas, there was no further sign, and LEP is now silent.

webTitle: Sail the boiling seas

fields.headline: Sail the boiling seas
fields.standfirst: A revolutionary design may take yachts through an invisible barrier.  Chris Cheers  reports
fields.trailText: A revolutionary design may take yachts through an invisible barrier. Chris Cheers reports
fields.body:
It is sailing's equivalent of the sound barrier. The boat is doing about 40 knots and still accelerating when suddenly it goes out of control.

The British windsurfer Erik Beale, who took the sailing speed record past 40 knots in 1988, sometimes spun out at such speeds. The spindly tripod designs of the Australian Lindsay Cunningham set the current record of 46.52 knots in 1993 but have gone no faster, despite refinements. Boats simple or sophisticated face the same problem: boiling water - boiling, but not hot.

Even cold water boils if the pressure is low enough; likewise lukewarm kettles on Everest. And it boiled on the low-pressure side of the windsurfer's fin and the tripods' foils at extreme speeds. Such fins and foils - in effect wings striking down into the water - have the essential function of balancing the horizontal thrust of the sail. And most of their thrust - called "lift", though not in the sense of lifting the boat out of the water - is lost when the water boils. The phenomenon, called cavitation, can be postponed by using a larger and therefore less heavily loaded foil, and by careful choice of foil section.

But a few knots on, the problem will still appear. The high-pressure side of the foil continues to provide some lift but it is not enough; if any other water surface continues to afford side-force - another foil, say, even if merely intended as a stabiliser to the main foil - the boat yaws. The stabiliser becomes a destabiliser.

A British inventor appears to have the answer. Jon Howes is building a boat designed not merely to push back the cavitation barrier but to smash right through it. Its key feature is a single water foil, which is enough; for example a dinghy without a rudder can be sailed, even to windward, by backing the jib to turn it into a stabiliser.

Mr Howes's boat has a more conventional wing and tailplane acting as a sail, attached to the foil by a long crossbeam from which is suspended the hull carrying the lone pilot. The hull is designed to plane, but at 43 knots it is lifted clear of the water. Above 40 knots there will still be cavitation but lift will not be lost, because the "low-pressure" side of the foil will not generate significant low pressure at any speed.

That means it will not generate lift either, of course; only the concave high-pressure side of the foil will provide lift. Like high-speed boat propellers, this foil is basically wedge-shaped, with a sharp leading edge. But such a foil can produce excessive drag at sub-cavitation speeds.

Howes, an aeronautical engineer, appropriately lets air into the problem. Surface air, rushing down the suction side of the foil. Ventilation, it is called, and for most sailors it is a dirty word even more than cavitation because it too destroys lift and it occurs at much lower speeds. But Mr Howes lets it happen.

The fences that the current generation of fast sailing boats rely on to keep ventilation at bay would be merely a drag on this boat. The foil is not as efficient at low speeds as foils with a conventional section and fences, but there is likely to be no further loss of lift when it reaches the cavitation zone. The foil still loses all its lift on occasions, notably when it clears the water in a wave trough, but then it simply skips sideways and is rolled into a subsequent wave.

So this boat, like the wind surfers, can survive in waves and a blow, one criterion for record-breaking. However, it belongs emphatically in a different category of boats, those designed to break records because high lift/low drag enables them to go several times faster than the wind.

That being so, there is a fundamental question: can a boat with such a foil, producing three times as much drag for the same lift as a conventional foil, possibly achieve the lift-drag ratio it needs?

Howes's mathematical modelling and tow-tests suggest it can, because of clean air shape and minimal underwater surfaces; and he has built small models, with a 30-inch wingsail, which have done twice the speed of the wind despite scale effects, notably the relative immensity of waves. Mr Howes is expecting much better than that from the boat that will carry him across Portland Harbour's measured course next September; he is building it strong enough to withstand 100 knots (yes, 115mph).

H e does not say it will go that fast. "I would only claim that the speed you get is as fast as it will go; there are simply too many variables to be absolutely confident." But, unlike some sheer-speed boats, it can sail on either tack, and it may be suitable for the wide oceans.

"Although I did not originally believe that this boat would be any more than a sprinter for record attempts on sheltered water, it is is becoming increasingly clear that it is very stable and has a very high tolerance to waves, even before the hull flies," he says.

"I now believe that it could be built larger and be perfectly capable of racing on the open sea with probably better seaworthiness than some current multihulls."

But, given that well-sponsored British designers have recently produced far more conventional boats that have proved to be turkeys - can't swim, can't fly - why should we believe this still unsponsored effort is different?

After all, any gathering of speed sailing enthusiasts will feature numerous eccentric amateurs with their world-beaters, many of which do not even get into the water. But Mr Howes, 41, is a professional. No, not a boat-design professional; he works as a structures and aerodynamics specialist for the Civil Aviation Authority at Gatwick, where he is head of loads and dynamics. However, the fastest boat of the future will be bird not fish. As he says of his invention: "Think slow aircraft, not fast boat."

webTitle: Doing the locomotion

fields.headline: Doing the locomotion
fields.standfirst: The plesiosaur flew through the Mesozoic seas - but probably on two wings rather than four, writes  Theagarten Lingham-Soliar
fields.trailText: The plesiosaur flew through the Mesozoic seas - but probably on two wings rather than four, writes Theagarten Lingham-Soliar
fields.body:
Four hundred million years ago back-boned animals hauled themselves out of the water and made the first bold steps onto land. One of the many problems that these pioneers had to contend with was turning flexible fishy fins into robust legs to cope with a new problem - gravity. Ironically, 200 million years later some of the descendents of these early colonisers returned to the sea.

These included three major groups of marine reptiles of the Mesozoic era, the ichthyosaurs, mosasaurs and plesiosaurs. Reptilian legs gradually changed into fins or paddles for steering and balance in the water. The tail was readapted to locomotion -with the exception of plesiosaurs.

Plesiosaurs included members such as pliosaurs, among the largest carnivores ever. They reached lengths of at least 15m and weights in excess of 50 tons. The limbs became greatly elongated, compressed and tapered. In contrast to ichthyosaurs and mosasaurs, the tail was highly reduced, making how they swam a puzzle.

By the mid-1920s, however, palaeontologists believed they had cracked plesiosaur locomotion. The short stubby tail was clearly ineffective as a propeller. Instead, the two pairs of flippers were moved back and forth like oars. This view prevailed for three decades until British palaeontologist Beverly Halstead proposed a startling new theory: the anterior limbs were beaten up and down as a bird uses its wings to fly.

Flight depends on lift, the same principle that helps propel birds in air and penguins, marine turtles and sea lions in water. Lift is gained from the natural aerofoil shape of the wing: long, broad but tapering at the end. In cross-section the wing is cambered above and concave below.

The air/water travelling along the wing's upper surface has to follow a longer path to the trailing edge than that travelling along the lower surface. The faster the fluid travels, the lower the pressure. So the flow below the wing exerts a greater pressure on the wing than the flow above, producing lift.

Numerous studies reinforced the theme of plesiosaurs as underwater fliers. All four limbs were considered flight organs. This fueled the image of the grace and beauty of plesiosaurs. What pterosaurs were to the skies and dinosaurs to land in the Mesozoic, plesiosaurs were to the oceans.

But the theory of four-winged flight has been dogged by the clearly inadequate musculature for the upward recovery stroke of the posterior limbs, resulting in complex hydrodynamic proposals. In a paper in the international journal Neues Jahrbuch (July 2000), which has published a number of key studies on plesiosaur locomotion, I consider the problem of four-wing flight. Flapping flight demands considerable energy. Recent experiments have shown that the humble budgerigar can muster 200 watts of flapping power per kilogram. Humans manage a mere 10 watts per kg.

Staying afloat in water, because of buoyancy, requires less energy than in air. Nevertheless it is still a serious problem among large marine vertebrates. Tuna have to swim continuously, sharks need enormous low-density livers, and large air-breathing ichthyosaurs have hydrofoils. What of the plesiosaurs?

Traditionally all four plesiosaur limbs have been treated as identical structures. This is far from so. The anterior limbs are swept back as in swallow's wings - the posterior ones are relatively straighter. Research has shown that the swept-back or crescent shape is dynamically more efficient than the straight wing for flight. There is no elbow or wrist-joint in plesiosaur limbs. So the ability to make delicate changes in pitch, direction etc, was limited.

O f further significance is the way in which marine animals such as sharks and ichthyosaurs rise or descend in the water by elevating or lowering the leading edge of the paddles. However, lift in a hydrofoil works best when it is inclined at a precise angle to the water flow - known as the angle of attack. Hence, the wing's capacity to act simultaneously as a rudder and flight organ is impractical.

For a pursuit predator chasing elusive prey, this would be disastrous. The solution? Sharing flight func tions between the anterior and posterior limbs.

Think of plesiosaurs as using a front-wheeled drive engine (thrust and lift) with the steering and a number of other functions at the back (ideal for rotating and manoeuvring because of their greater distance from the centre of balance). This is precisely how other underwater fliers such as penguins and sea lions rapidly orientate their bodies during pursuit of prey. At other times the hind limbs could also be used in rowing - the predominantly ventral musculature would allow this.

Why have the posterior limbs in plesiosaurs been connected with active flight? Simply, they look like flight organs (hydrofoils) and not oars. Oars are lifted out of the water in the recovery stroke, avoiding drag. This is not possible in an underwater flier - hence a tapered limb may cause less drag. More important, the posterior hydrofoils prevented the animal from sinking (functioning as aircraft wings) during slow swimming.

Attempts to provide sophisticated hydrodynamic solutions for the recovery stroke of the posterior limbs despite a dismally weak upper musculature is like taking a sledgehammer to crack a nut. While the glamorous notion of plesiosaurs as four rather than two-winged fliers is appealing, reality suggests a very effective division of functions between the anterior and posterior limbs, necessitated by mechanical and anatomical limitations, but every bit as unique.

 Theagarten Lingham-Soliar is visiting professor at the palaeontological institute, Russian Academy of Sciences.

webTitle: Five lessons for Sven

fields.headline: Five lessons for Sven
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor may have had to head off sharpish after last night's friendly defeat in Turin, but the caretaker England manager will have wanted to make a few points to make to coach-in-waiting Sven Goran Eriksson, an onlooker in the stands, before he left. Below, Football Unlimited has a guess at what they might have been.
fields.body:
Peter Taylor may have had to head off sharpish after last night's friendly defeat in Turin, but the caretaker England manager will have wanted to make a few points to make to coach-in-waiting Sven Goran Eriksson, an onlooker in the stands, before he left. Below, Football Unlimited has a guess at what they might have been.

1. Stick to 3-5-2

Strictly speaking, England didn't actually play 3-5-2 last night, with Kieron Dyer playing in a very similar position to Nick Barmby behind sole striker Emile Heskey. But the mobility of this pair helped to reinforce the extra flexibility that comes with abandoning a flat back-four. Wingbacks can move in and out of defence or midfield, the central three have licence to move wide or stay narrow, and there are also extra options from the back.

2. Stick with Emile Heskey

Not much of an observation this, as it was obvious to everyone that Heskey was the best player in white last night. It is unlikely that he scared Maldini, Nesta et al too much, but he certainly made them work for their clean sheet with a performance packed with strength, pace, intelligence and no little skill. What's more, he proved he could do it on his own.

3. Stick with the youngsters

When England take on Finland next March, the average age of the side is unlikely to be 25, as it was in Stadio Delle Alpi last night. But on last night's performance, there would be little to be gained by choosing Ray Parlour over Kieron Dyer at wing-back, or dumping Paul Ince back into a holding midfield role at the expense of the improving Jamie Carragher. Experience isn't everything.

4. Stick Beckham in the middle

He's the best crosser of the ball in the world and all that, but Becks ain't half bad at passing it either. He found lots of space in the centre (again thanks to the formation England played) and his distribution was, on occasions, jaw-dropping - in the first half, he picked Heskey out in the Italian box from 40 yards. Beckham is also intelligent enough (yes, we all know the jokes) to move out wide when the opportunity arises.

5. Stick a rocket up Rio

Taking the ball off an Inzaghi by flicking it over your head with your heel is one thing, but frequently standing off your man and not concentrating on simple passes is another. A mixed night for Rio merely confirmed what everyone already knows: he's got talent, but lacks application. England need Eriksson to drill it into him.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Election glossary

fields.headline: Election glossary
fields.standfirst:
The perplexities of the US presidential saga are magnified, for outsiders, by the opaqueness of the electoral jargon being used. Here is a quick guide to some of the new circumlocutary psephological lexicography...
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText:
Chad: The tiny square section of a ballot card which is, ideally, punched out to indicate the voter's preference. The presence or otherwise of chad, in those states which use the punchcard ballot system, is a key factor in the current legal disputes over recounting. There are a whole family of chads:
Dimpled chad: The chad is visibly pushed through, but not pierced.
Pregnant chad: A chad which is bulging or pierced, but still attached to the ballot card at four corners.
Hanging chad: A chad still attached by one corner.
Swinging-door chad: A chad attached by two corners.
Tri chad: A chad attached by three corners.
fields.body:
Chad: The tiny square section of a ballot card which is, ideally, punched out to indicate the voter's preference. The presence or otherwise of chad, in those states which use the punchcard ballot system, is a key factor in the current legal disputes over recounting. There are a whole family of chads:
Dimpled chad: The chad is visibly pushed through, but not pierced.
Pregnant chad: A chad which is bulging or pierced, but still attached to the ballot card at four corners.
Hanging chad: A chad still attached by one corner.
Swinging-door chad: A chad attached by two corners.
Tri chad: A chad attached by three corners.

Recuse: A US official who withdraws from his or her duties on grounds of conflict of interest is said to recuse him or herself. Thus, Governor Jeb Bush has recused himself from the Florida election process on the grounds that George W Bush is his brother. On the other hand, the Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris, a prominent Republican, hasn't. The nearest use of the word in British English is recusant, applied to Roman Catholics who refused to attend Church of England services after the Reformation.

Hand recount: Manual recount.

Certification: The process by which counties and states put their formal seal of approval on the final result. Or, in some cases, the almost final result.

County canvassing board: The local committee which decides whether to recount the votes, and by which means; mechanical or manual.

Concession: The message of the losing candidate to the winner, gracefully acknowledging the latter's victory. Usually lasts for four years, but can be valid for as little as 84 minutes

Certification: The process by which counties and states put their formal seal of approval on the final result. Or, in some cases, the almost final result. County canvassing board: The local committee which decides whether to recount the votes, and by which means; mechanical or manual. Concession: The message of the losing candidate to the winner, gracefully acknowledging the latter's victory. webTitle: Mir mortal: space station chronology

fields.headline: Mir mortal: space station chronology
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: 1986: The Soviet Union launches the core module of the Mir on February 20, predicting the station will last three to five years. The first crew takes off for the station on March 13.
fields.body:
1986: The Soviet Union launches the core module of the Mir on February 20, predicting the station will last three to five years. The first crew takes off for the station on March 13.

1987: The station's second component, called Kvant 1 (Quantum 1), arrives at the Mir but has trouble docking. Crew members find refuse stuck on the docking port.

1990: A Japanese cosmonaut reporter, Toyohiro Akiyama, visits the space station.

1991: A cargo ship loses control during its final approach to the station, nearly colliding with the Mir. The chaos and financial troubles accompanying the collapse of the Soviet Union force the Mir's crew to stay in orbit several months longer than scheduled.

1993: Russian cosmonaut Valery Polyakov returns from a 438-day mission, the longest human spaceflight. Norman Thagard becomes the first American astronaut to visit the Mir.

1997: A series of dramatic troubles begins on February 23, when an oxygen-generating canister bursts into flames, nearly forcing the crew - including British Nasa astronaut Michael Foale - to abandon the space station. On June 25, a cargo ship rams the station during a docking test, piercing a laboratory module and causing pressure inside the Mir to fall. Two days later, a computer crashes. In July, a cosmonaut disconnects a power plug prematurely, setting the station adrift. A month later, the main computer fails during a cargo ship docking, setting the station adrift again.

1999: Russia announces the Mir will be taken out of orbit in 2000 unless new funds can be found and a crew that is widely expected to be the station's last returns to Earth on August 27.

2000: The Netherlands-based MirCorp, backed by private investors, reaches agreement to lease Mir. On April 4, a Russian crew takes off for mission to rehabilitate Mir in preparation for future private missions. The crew returns June 16 and MirCorp announces American businessman Dennis Tito is to go to station as "space tourist."

November 16: The Russian space agency, claiming MirCorp has not upheld its obligations, announces Mir will be plunged into the Pacific ocean in late February 2001.

webTitle: 2001: End of a space odyssey

fields.headline: 2001: End of a space odyssey
fields.standfirst:
Russia makes a painful break from the past and condemns the Mir space station to a spectacular death
Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The 14-year-old Mir space station will be ditched in February in a controlled descent that will send it hurtling into a remote area of the Pacific Ocean, Russia's cabinet has decided.
fields.body:
The 14-year-old Mir space station will be ditched in February in a controlled descent that will send it hurtling into a remote area of the Pacific Ocean, Russia's cabinet has decided.

"Nothing can last for eternity, even the Mir," Russian space agency chief Yuri Koptev told reporters, warning that it would be unsafe to keep the rattling, corroding Mir aloft in its current state.

The decision came after months of wrestling over what to do with the Mir, which Moscow can no longer afford to maintain. The Mir was once a symbol of Soviet space glory and is by far history's longest-serving space station, and Russians have been reluctant to let it go.

The Cabinet approved a plan to crash the Mir into the Pacific 900 to 1,200 miles east of Australia on February 27-28 2001, after private investors failed to fund it, Koptev said.

Officials said Russia should concentrate its funds on the international space station instead of the Mir - something the US space agency Nasa has been urging for years. Nasa is leading the 16-nation international project, which had suffered repeated delays because of Russian funding woes.

To keep the Mir aloft would require tests and procedures ensuring it is fit to orbit - which have not been done, Koptev said. "Any of Mir's systems may now fail," he added.

The Russian government had decided to abandon the Mir earlier this year, but extended its lifetime after the private Netherlands-based MirCorp leased time on Mir and promised to pay for its operation. While MirCorp financed a mission to Mir earlier this year, it has failed to meet other commitments, forcing the government to divert funds allocated to the new international station to maintain the Mir, Koptev said.

"We cannot continue this game... which I call Russian roulette. We simply don't have the right to do that, because we are a government agency responsible for the safety of the Mir," he said.

MirCorp representatives couldn't be immediately reached for comment.

American businessman Dennis Tito, who had hoped to travel to the Mir as a tourist under a deal with MirCorp, and who has already spent $1 million in training, will not be sent to the station, Koptev said.

The Mir was hailed as revolutionary when it went up in 1986, and has far outlasted the three to five years it was expected to live. But critics say it has also outlived its usefulness.

Abandoning the Mir was an excruciating decision for the Russian space program, a force that put the first satellite in the cosmos, as well as the first man and first woman - and now has no cash and no new projects entirely its own.

Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov told Thursday's Cabinet meeting that he considers safely discarding the Mir an international commitment undertaken by the Russian government. In calling for careful preparation for de-orbiting the Mir, Koptev on Wednesday recalled a Soviet satellite that crashed into northern Canada in 1978.

Nobody was hurt but radioactive fragments were scattered over the wilderness.

The unoccupied US space station Skylab fell to Earth in 1979 when its orbit deteriorated faster than anticipated, scattering debris over western Australia. No one was hurt.

Koptev said an unmanned cargo ship would be sent to Mir in January and in February the cargo ship would fire its rockets to push the station quickly into the atmosphere. In case something goes awry, a crew of two Russian cosmonauts will be on hand to blast to the station and prepare its descent.

The Mir cluster of six modules, bristling with solar panels and antennas, has far outlived engineers' original expectations. The inside is scarred by a 1997 fire and one module, Spektr, is sealed off after a collision that year with a small craft ferrying away the station's garbage.

webTitle: Games reviews

fields.headline: Games reviews
fields.trailText: Sudden Strike | Creatures Playground | Ready to Rumble Boxing: Round 2
fields.byline: Greg Howson, Jack Schofield and   Andy Bodle
fields.body:
Sudden Strike PC CD-Rom £29.99 CDV Software
War: what it is good for? Well, not quite absolutely nothing, because armed conflict has served as the backdrop to many a cracking game.

The latest is Sudden Strike, a real-time strategy (RTS) title based on the second world war. While neither of these facts suggests any great innovation, Sudden Strike does at least offer one novel option: you can play as the Germans.

Of course, with the game being developed in Russia it may not be wholly surprising, but for gamers looking for something a little different, the chance to play as the Nazis is appealing.

But whatever you decide, there are three main campaigns to test your battle tactics on, including some tricky Eastern Front combat. In a similar manner to Command and Conquer, you direct proceedings from up high by clicking your mouse and trusting your troops to follow orders.

The graphics present everything clearly, although it can get fiddly to manoeuvre your men at times. Luckily, though, the speed of the game means you do not need to panic too much. Everything proceeds at a snail's pace - more slothful than sudden - that is handy in battle, but not so when you merely want to move supplies from A to B. Also, the amateurish nature of the mission briefings reminds you that you are sitting at your PC and not shivering in a Stalingrad shellhole.

Still, Sudden Strike does deserve some sort of medal. By utilising a splendidly accurate second world war setting and banishing resource management (ammo excepted) the developer has created an intriguing, if rather plodding, strategy game. (GH)

Creatures Playground PC £14.99 Creature Labs/Havas
It is easy to think of Louise as a daughter, even though she is grotesquely deformed, has green hair that would look better on a mop, and popped out of an egg only a week ago.

Louise is a norn: an artificial life form who is born, grows up, ages and dies according to the rules laid down by Creature Labs' software.

Norns, created by Steve Grand, were a pretty serious artificial life experiment a couple of years ago, although of course they were distributed through the Creatures series of games.

But Creatures Playground is from the award-winning Creatures Village range of software, aimed at the sort of four-to-eight your olds who might enjoy on-screen Catz, Dogz, and similar "virtual pets".

Creatures Playground provides a sort of theme park for norns to enjoy. It has a rollercoaster, a big wheel, a haunted house and a space ship, plus a number of mini-games such as Whack-a-mole.

The graphics and sound are extremely good, though the fat, cartoony style of the images can sometimes be hard to read.

The game is great value but it does require a lot of space to run. Even when you have cleared more than half a gigabyte for the installation (516Mb, in my case) it still wants 75Mb free on C: and 32Mb on the drive where it has been installed. It also wants a grown-up processor and memory: 233MHz and 16Mb is the stated minimum, but 450MHz and 64Mb is more like it.

Parents should make sure they install the game first, and spend an hour or two with the manual figuring out how it works, before even mentioning the game to their non-digital offspring. (JS)

Ready to Rumble Boxing: Round 2 Midway Dreamcast £39.99
With the swiftness and inevitability of death, another decent game begets a sequel. All the usual rules apply: if you've got the original, don't bother; if you were thinking of getting the original, get this instead.

Improvements are tangible but slight: more boxers to choose from; a more sophisticated training system in the single-player championship mode; more punches and combos; and a tweak to the first game's "rumble" system, so that there are now three levels of power-up.

You can also, apparently, invoke cameo appearances from Shaquille O'Neal and Michael Jackson. Well, there's an incentive.

But if some things change, more things stay the same. The graphics, intros and music - all admittedly impressive - remain untouched by developer hands. The fighters' chants are still incomprehensible, the boxers still imbalanced (Jet "Iron" Chin rules the ring once more), and the novelty still wears off rather sooner than expected.

I have a dream. A dream that, one day, games makers will bite the bullet and offer discounts on upgrades masquerading as sequels. "Hand in your copy of Ready to Rumble 1 and get Ready to Rumble 2 for half price!"

If that dream should ever come true, who knows? Games with 2 in the title might even start getting good reviews. (AB)
