webTitle: Online letters

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst:
Send letters to online.feedback@guardian.co.uk
Please include a full postal address and telephone number. Short letters stand a better chance of being published. No attachments, please
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
Office theft
I am amazed that the Guardian supports some of the advice given by Richard Adams (Working the web, November 9). Some of it seems to encourage people to be dishonest when it comes to dealing with their employer.

I work in the public sector and surfing the internet for porn and displaying it in the office does not sit comfortably with standards of behaviour expected from staff.
David Wyatt
d.wyatt@btinternet.com

"How dull office life would be without Solitaire and Minesweeper," twitters Richard Adams. Maybe life in the Guardian office is so insufferably dreary that you need mindless distractions, but in that case you should look for a more stimulating job. I'm sick of Online's repeated (and repetitious) articles supporting employees who steal time and resources from their companies. If you are paid to get on with a job, but you fart about playing games on the computer, sending infantile emails and downloading porn, you are robbing your employer and cheating your workmates, who will have to cover the work that you are too idle to do.
Dermod Quirke
dermond@dircon.co.uk

I am aghast at the tone of the "10 steps to reduce paranoia at work".

Apart from his first two points, Richard Adams is condoning and encouraging illegality; and exposing the user to potentially greater sanctions when and if they are discovered. How about transposing the article to one on shopping? Suggesting how to switch price stickers to get something cheaper? Getting a crowd of people to obstruct a sales assistant's view of things? Placing a plastic bag over the CCTV cameras to prevent them observing an attempt at theft?
Jon Finegold
Keyline Consultancy jon@key-line-consultancy.co.uk

Prole position
Allen Ives (OnlineNovember 9) says he ran a hi-tech company, and took money off employees' wages if they abused his computer equipment.

He may have paid 25% more in wages, but how can this ex-member of the boss class claim to have remained a Marxist while presumably still seeking to make a profit from the unpaid physical and mental labour of his workers?

As for Robert Lawrence's letter whining about employees wasting money by using business internet resources for anything other than work, I suggest that we untrustworthy working class scum end such bourgeois concerns about misusing assets (manufactured, installed, operated and maintained by us proles) by voting to own these ourselves through real socialism.
Max Hess
max@truesocialism.freeserve.co.uk

Code it
It is not "techy propaganda" that states that the only way you will ever build a proper website is using HTML (Home page that Mac built, November 9). It's a simple fact.

HTML editors insert huge chunks of absolute gibberish into otherwise simple pages, as one of your own screenshots amply demonstrates. Furthermore, are you going to avoid using JavaScript forever, just because you don't know how to incorporate it into your code?

To extend your own analogy, you may not want to know how your car works. However, be prepared to sit on the hard-shoulder of the Information Superhighway, waiting for the AA to come and change your flat tyre.
Chris Gibson
chris.gibson@naedus.com

Viva Vaio
I've just read Jack Schofield's review of the Vaio PCGC1 laptop (Online, November 9). You're wrong to say Sony must have an odd idea of what travelling business professionals do for a living if this machine is aimed at them.

I'm a "travelling business professional". I've been using a PCG-C1F all over the world for 12 months. And it's absolutely brilliant.

You say that it is let down by not having an inbuilt CD-rom or floppy drive, or net working, and the half size screen is a disadvantage.

Rubbish. They may not suit a computer buff, but they suit a normal user down to the ground. By having external floppy and CD drives, I have the choice of whether to lug the things round with me or not. For me, travelling incessantly, the joy of having a fully fledged computer that I can slip inside a coat pocket is wonderful. Try walking round a few European or Chinese exhbition halls for three days and you'll soon get the picture.

The screen is just fine. There is no serious disadvantage whatsoever that I know of. The fact that you can physically see less text is hardly ever a serious problem. In the end, it is a compromise worth having in order to have a small machine.

The little camera is good too. Mediocre quality perhaps, but superb for taking instant snaps of a sample in a meeting. An inspired gadget.

The only complaint I have is low battery life, requiring spares. But I've had that problem with every laptop I ever owned. I've had Thinkpads for seven grand, Toshibas, Compaq, the lot. For sheer practicality for a travelling businessman, the PCG leaves them all standing.
Peter Hardwick
h@pardwick.demon.co.uk

Records
I note that Matt Luxon (Online, November 9) says Elan Technologies "is going to make electronic patient records available internationally through the web".

Does this mean that I can expect my medical records to be put online for the delectation of medical-records buffs in Japan and Brazil? And how about my bank accounts? Are they to be similarly broadcast throughout the world?

Whatever happened to confidentiality?
Ellie Weld
eweld@gn.apc.org

British idea
Jack Schofield is only partly right when he says in his interview with Vint Cerf (Online, November 9) that Paul Baran invented Packet Switching. It was a Briton, Donald Davies.

Thus, not only was the software architecture of the web invented by a Brit, Tim Berners Lee, but also the telecoms backbone of the internet. Not a fact widely known.
Richard Sarson
rsarson@cix.co.uk

webTitle: Rumours Unlimited

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's transfer gossip spends £293,000 on flowers
fields.trailText: Chelsea are prepared to bid an astounding £18m for Real Madrid's injury-plagued striker Fernando Morientes, according to Planet Football.
fields.body:
Chelsea are prepared to bid an astounding £18m for Real Madrid's injury-plagued striker Fernando Morientes, according to Planet Football.

Tottenham are interested in £5m rated Benfica defender Carlos Marchena, Planet Football reports. However they face stiff competition from Barcelona, who have also registered an interested in the 21-year-old after his superb performances in the Olympics. "I am a star at Benfica but Barcelona is Barcelona," Marchena admitted, without adding: "And Spurs are Spurs."

Aston Villa are chasing two strikers, in the shape of Daniel Fonseca and Hakan Sukur, reports Planet Football. Uruguay international Fonseca looks the more likely target - he is well down the pecking order at Juventus, and might be tempted to join Villa on loan for the rest of the season. But John Gregory is keeping his options open - he was at last night's Turkey v France match to watch the unsettled Sukur too.

Tenerife centre back Pablo Paz is set to join Newcastle after the Spanish club lowered their asking price from £2.5m to £1.5m.

Sheffield United have turned down Crystal Palace's £2.5m bid for striker Marcus Bent. Palace manager Alan Smith had offered £1.5m cash plus the £1m rated Clinton Morrison, but Neil Warnock insisted: "Marcus doesn't want to go back to Selhurst Park and Morrison doesn't fit what we require."

Trevor Francis is hoping to sign Manchester City's Richard Edghill - who is currently on loan at Birmingham - on a permanent deal. "If he does well I would like to consider the chance of it being made permanent," admitted Francis. "That ultimately comes down to finance. I have spoken to Joe Royle, and I don't think he would stand in the players way if he did well while he was here."

Middlesbrough have refused Barnsley's bid for Neil Maddison. Manager Brian Robson said: "Neil has gone on loan to Barnsley to get games but I don't want to lose him. He has a great attitude and I want that around this club."

webTitle: November 15 ratings

fields.headline: ITV's Morse kills off BBC1 Attenborough epic
fields.trailText: 11.45am: TV overnights The BBC's decision to schedule Sir David Attenborough's State of the Planet against the demise of Inspector Morse last night proved a ratings disaster. By Lisa O'Carroll
fields.body:
The BBC's decision to schedule Sir David Attenborough's latest epic production against the final episode of Inspector Morse last night proved a ratings disaster.

State of the Planet, the £2m millennium special that has been two years in the making, was watched by just 4m viewers - 16% of the audience.

As expected, the final ever episode of Inspector Morse was the night's number one show.

The spectacle of the increasingly curmudgeonly policeman expiring just as he is about crack a crime had the nation enthralled, pulling in 12.6m - one in two viewers.

The hype surrounding Morse's death left the BBC with one of its worst ever peak-time shares. Throughout the night it barely managed to muster more than 4m viewers.

Tomorrow's World in Venice at 7pm pulled in 4.3m, followed by Car Wars, which got 4.2m.

Lowri Turner managed to lose 100,000 of the audience with her DIY SOS show but they returned to BBC1 by the time the lottery came on at 8.30pm.

At this point, the time Inspector Morse began on ITV, the BBC didn't lose a single viewer. But it didn't gain any either.

The lottery got 4.2m viewers as did a repeat of Only Fools and Horses. The 10 O'Clock News fared worst with just 3.6m viewers.

That BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey scheduled Sir David's much-anticipated three-part series against one of ITV's biggest ever drama series has surprised many.

However, Ms Heggessey defended her channel's performance, saying: "BBC1 is always going to have important, landmark series like State of the Planet which are there for their public purpose, not for ratings.

"We are thrilled the programme did so well."

Nevertheless ITV must be relishing the prospect of another ratings battle in two weeks' time when State of the Planet will face one of the network's biggest nights of the year - Coronation Street followed by a David Beckham documentary, Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and the TV premiere of The Full Monty.

webTitle: Matthew Norman's Diary

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • After our disastrous run of story-less columns packed with sloppy mistakes and puerile bad taste, The Column You Know You Can Ignore seeks redemption with a serious suggestion.
fields.body:
 After our disastrous run of story-less columns packed with sloppy mistakes and puerile bad taste, The Column You Know You Can Ignore seeks redemption with a serious suggestion.

Ken Livingstone wants the statues of Sir Charles Napier and Sir Henry Havelock out of Trafalgar Square, and the Victorian generals' descendants say they won't mind, if they go somewhere appropriate. Where could be more appropriate than the New Zealand towns of Napier and Havelock North?

When my colleague Richard Adams calls his homeland to do the deal, the signs are mixed. "The mayor, Alan Dick, is looking into it at the moment," says his PA Sandra Svendsen in Napier (pop 55,000). "I just phoned the British high commission to get the name of the new lord mayor of London."

Over at Havelock North, regional mayor Jeremy Dwyer takes a more Livingstonian line. "I am not particularly interested," he says, perhaps reckoning that Havelock's involvement of the brutal suppression the Indian mutiny in 1857 makes him the sort of colonial oppressor New Zealand is loath to commemorate. Never mind, if we can get old Napier off on the boat, that's a start.

 To hear Stephen Pound, the cheeky chappie MP for Ealing and arch Mr Tony loyalist, rabbiting away ("rabbit, rabbit, rabbit, rabbit" as Chas and Dave put it, "rabbit, rabbit, rabbit") on the radio, you'd think he was born in the backroom of a pie and mash shop down Lambeth way.

Would you believe it, though, it seems the brogue may be misleading. It certainly wasn't picked up from his father, the splendidly named Pelham Pound, whom acquaintances remember as more Alvar Liddell than Jamie Oliver.

A fringe player in the Profumo scandal (he was Steven Ward's "agent") Pelham died not long ago after spending his final years as a journalist with BBC radio. Which is where we heard Steve on Friday night. Such symmetry.

 A most intriguing document reaches us. It is on the headed notepaper of Bernard Matthews plc (head office: Great Witchingham Hall, Norwich). "To whom it may concern," it begins. "This letter is to confirm that the above individual is an employee of Bernard Matthews plc."

After explaining that the firm's business is poultry rearing and distribution, it goes on: "Accordingly this employee should be entitled to claim fuel as a priority user." It almost seems shame now that there won't be any trouble at the pumps, just for the pleasure of seeing men and women waving live turkeys around and shouting "essential national business" as they tried in vain to jump the queue.

 Sue Thorne writes from Piccadilly inviting us to an event tonight. "The directors of the Prudential are pleased to announce a celebratory switching on of the Christmas lights in Burlington Arcade, by Boris Johnson, the editor of the Spectator."

Well strike me. When we call Boris, his phone is answered by an Arthur Mullard sound-alike. What's all this about your guv'nor turning on the lights? "If I were you, pal, I'd be more worried about the guv'nor turning yer lights out," says the man, chortling. "Now be a good boy, run along and stop pulling me bell end."

 A court in the South African capital Pretoria heard that marriage guidance counsellor Dr Cedric Wayne, who had been treating an embattled couple, became so furious with the wife's continual nagging that he leapt out of his chair and helped the husband beat her up.

After Tanya MacCauley was taken to hospital with concussion, a broken collarbone and fractured ribs, he and Bill MacCauley face assault charges. "She's the most annoying woman I've ever met and no husband should be subjected to nagging like that," Dr Wayne told police. "A counsellor isn't supposed to take sides, but she drove me crazy. I have no regrets."

webTitle: Marketeers hit out at Gordon Brown

fields.headline: Marketeers turn on 'cheap' chancellor
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Marketeers have branded as 'cheap and thoughtless' a speech by chancellor Gordon Brown in which he said that toy advertising was unfair to the poor. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The marketing industry has hit back at chancellor of the exchequer Gordon Brown after he said toy advertising was unfair to the poor.

They branded his speech a "cheap, thoughtless side-swipe".

Ian Twinn, a director of the Incorporated Society of British Advertisers, said he was horrified that the man in charge of Britain's economy could make such damaging comments about one of the country's biggest industries.

"It's just not the sort of thing the chancellor can go around saying," said Mr Twinn. "He has jumped on this passing bandwagon and is trying to make political capital out of it."

Mr Brown made his controversial comments at the launch of a new fund to help children from disadvantaged backgrounds.

The chancellor said he was struck by how unfair it was that thousands of children got the Christmas presents they wanted while others watched TV ads knowing they could never afford the products advertised.

But Mr Twinn said that advertising played a crucial role in encouraging young people to set their aspirations high.

He added: "It shows it is worth studying and working hard for the things you want."

webTitle: Letter: Scotch that old myth

fields.headline: Scotch that old myth
fields.trailText: It is strange that the Guardian gives credence to the theories of Dr Robert Lomas about ancient Egyptians needing neolithic Orcadian know-how to help them build the pyramids (Scots solution to riddle of the pyramids, November 14).
fields.body:
It is strange that the Guardian gives credence to the theories of Dr Robert Lomas about ancient Egyptians needing neolithic Orcadian know-how to help them build the pyramids (Scots solution to riddle of the pyramids, November 14). Lomas admits in the Prologue to Uriel's Machine (written with Christopher Knight) that, in receipt of a pre-publication copy, "The Guardian dismissed the entire book... assuming that it must all be rubbish". You were right the first time.

Lomas has no connection with our department, where much internationally recognised research on the archaeology of the northern isles is conducted, but lectures in the university management centre, which has other strengths. Lomas's smoking gun, leading him from Scotland to the Nile, is the so-called "megalithic yard", the non-existence of which was demonstrated back in 1976. As for the rest of his free-form, freemasonic fantasy, we are sure that the public can make up its own mind.
Drs Timothy Taylor, Julie Bond, Carl Heron, Prof AM Pollard, Steve Dockrill
Department of archaeological sciences
University of Bradford

So ancient Egyptians learnt building techniques from Orcadians? Your writer does not do justice to Robert Lomas and Christopher Knight. They also discovered the Dead Sea Scrolls contain a history of megalithic Europe; our neolithic predecessors populated China with giants; a large comet hit the earth, and only ancient Scottish science allowed Enoch to save the planet from inundation.

Or you could listen to archaeology, which does not patronise our ancestors with fictional twaddle but reveals their story in all its rich, human glory.
Mike Pitts
Marlborough
Wilts

webTitle: The Way You See It

fields.headline: The Way You See It
fields.trailText: ENGLAND V ITALY: YOUR VERDICT
fields.body:
ENGLAND V ITALY: YOUR VERDICT

Take away the 500 or so sarcastic emails reminding us that Emile Heskey plays for Liverpool (and not Leicester as Richard Williams' article erroneously claimed) and an almost equal number from outraged Aussies ("How dare Graham Spiers undervalue our momentous victory," etc., etc.) and you're left with surprisingly few comments on England's performance against Italy last night.

Those of you who do write in are generally positive about Taylor's first game in charge, although not everybody is convinced. "Let's not start heralding another false dawn," claims Nick Triani. "The Italian team weren't bothered with the game, and judging by the amount of substitutions they made, it was as much an experiment for Trappatoni as it was for Taylor."

Meanwhile, Richard Clayton, while more positive about England's performance, reckons there needs to be a change of tactics to bring the best out of David Beckham. "One of the problems of playing 3-5-2 when you don't have a confident centre-back consistently able to bring the ball out of defence is that the most creative central midfielder tends to drop too deep. Beckham seemed to fall into this trap. The situation was compounded by neither Barry nor Parlour being quick enough to operate as really attacking wing-backs.

"While 3-5-2 is probably the best interim formation when you look at the players available," he continues, "my own longer-term preference is for a flexible 4-5-1 in defence/4-2-3-1 in attack (like Portugal and France generally use). This would allow Beckham to play in a sort of advanced inside-right position, where I believe he is often most effective."

RACISM: SHOULD WE LOOK CLOSER TO HOME?

Richard Williams's column on the persistent booing of Emile Heskey during last night's game has provoked a mixed reaction.

"Having been to a couple of club matches on the continent this year I have to say it is a major problem," says Jusin Toland. "I was so sickened by the chanting of VFB Stuttgart fans at a game against Wolfsburg that I wrote the club a letter of complaint. I feel Uefa ought to make more of an effort to penalise club and international sides whose 'supporters' engage in such moronic behaviour."

However, several of you reckon Mr Williams should look closer to home. "I have close friends that play in the Premier League," says Eden Ballah, "and while they don't have to endure what John Barnes went through, the abuse they get is still appalling. We need to stop patting ourselves on the back that things are getting better," he continues. "Because they ain't."

Meanwhile, Anna from Udine wants us to know that we shouldn't tar all Italians with the same brush: "To be an Italian supporter does not mean automatically to be a racist as to be an English supporter does not always mean to be an hooligan."

AUSSIE, AUSSIE, AUSSIEOI, OI, OI

A barrel load of Australian readers have written in to praise their side's victory against Scotland. Here are some of the best letters.

"Scotland looked and played as miserable as the Glasgow weather. Sadly your correspondent doesn't give the Aussies as much credit as they really deserve," reckons Frank Pangallo. "First, this wasn't Frank Farina's strongest squad by a long shot. Lucky for the Scots, there was no Viduka, Kewell or Vidmar.

"Secondly, this team was very much under-prepared and cobbled together at the last moment. Unlike Scotland, Australia's national soccer team suffers from the tyranny of distance and recalcitrant club managers in the UK and Europe."

And John Miner agrees: "Graham Spiers's comment that the Australians are 'not exactly household names' says more about British households than it does about the quality of Australian footballers. A side that can beat Scotland 2-0 without Kewell and Viduka in the front line should be worth getting to know."

Even expatriate Scot Duncan McNab is with the Aussies on this one: "I was disappointed to note that Graham Spiers' first adjective when describing the Socceroos was 'muscular' and that he could muster no better description than 'cohesive' about their performance. Scotland played so badly because they were made to do so by a team which had great flair, purpose and organisation. Tactically, the Australians were far superior and deserve greater credit than Mr Spiers afforded them."

After beating the Scots, Greg Szudrich has set his sights on the Poms. "Although I am a little bit biased, I would have to say that at if Australia was full strength (the Leeds boys up front, and the Rangers boys at the back) we would give England a run for their money."

However, Scotland fans like Steven Connolly are left praying that last night's performance was a one-off - and pleading that a certain goalkeeper never gets picked again: "Let's hope it was just an experiment. As a long-suffering Celtic supporter I have had the dubious pleasure of observing Jonathan Gould's clueless goal-keeping style for what seems like centuries. Often he has so little to do that perhaps he sets himself improbable tasks to maintain interest in the game.

"All I know is that every corner is a cause for anxiety and that harmless crosses from the touch-line sometimes find their way into the net. Maybe he should just stay at Hampden and see if anyone is interested in collecting him. He's the worst keeper in top-flight football."

fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 17.

fields.body:
Loaded creator James Brown has slammed the men's magazine sector, branding it "stale" and "embarrassing". Mr Brown said there was not a single magazine he would pick up without cringing, adding that Loaded was "appalling".

Sky News has set up a new unit dedicated to investigative journalism.

The Duke of York has complained to the Press Complaints Commission about the accuracy of a Mail on Sunday article linking him to an alleged drug dealer.

Elle editor Fiona McIntosh has ruled herself out of the running for the editorship of You magazine, saying she is not interested in moving.

BBC World Service staff are preparing for a 48-hour strike on November 25 in a bid to raise pay rates for night shifts.

Felix Dennis has hired Greg Williams, former editor of Arena, to oversee the launch of a new fashion spin-off in New York.

webTitle: Thomascook.com claims interactive TV first

fields.headline: Thomascook.com claims interactive TV first
fields.trailText: 12.30pm Thomascook.com is the first travel site to offer holidays and flights to all interactive television viewers, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Thomascook.com is the first travel site to offer holidays and flights to all interactive television viewers.

The site, which goes live on Open this week, today announced a further tie-up with NTL, the digital TV and internet operator.

The site has existing partnerships with Telewest and ONdigital's Onnet.

Thomascook.com claims that customers booking holidays via interactive television will now have 24-hour access to the largest selection of travel products available anywhere on the internet.

Katherine Gershon, head of interactive television at thomascook.com, said: "We're committed to giving consumers choice. There are now five channels to access thomascook.com products - the high street, the phone, the internet, through interactive television and via mobile phones.

"It is predicted that in five years, one in five bookings will be online, but not just through a PC."

webTitle: Livingstone reveals blueprint to tackle housing crisis

fields.headline: Livingstone reveals blueprint to tackle housing crisis
fields.trailText: London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, today announced a dramatic increase in the level of "social housing" as his blueprint for tackling the housing crisis.
fields.body:
London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, today announced a dramatic increase in the level of "social housing" as his blueprint for tackling the housing crisis.

Unveiling a report by the Greater London Authority Housing Commission, he announced that London's economic future is being jeopardised by the lack of affordable housing for vital workers who cannot afford to live in the capital.

The report says that at least 280,000 of the new homes built in London over the next decade must be earmarked for low income workers such as nurses, teachers and police to help maintain decent services. It comes in the wake of the publication of the government's urban white paper, and today's Commons statement by environment secretary John Prescott.

Researchers estimate that London's population will grow to more than 8m people by 2016, creating a need for approximately 318,000 new homes in the social housing sector to be built over the next 10 years. Another 11,200 are needed to deal with the backlog of homelessness, overcrowding and poor housing conditions.

"What we have arrived at is a vision of London as a thriving, inclusive world city in which all its inhabitants have a decent and affordable home in neighbourhoods where they want to live, within reasonable reach of their work and with high quality public services," said Chris Holmes, chairman of the Housing Commission and director of the homeless charity Shelter.

However, Conservative regeneration spokesman Tim Loughton said that such levels of increased "social housing" would endanger urban regeneration in the capital and inappropriately take control of housing away from London boroughs. "Livingstone is still living in the 1970s, trying to recreate a mythical socialist utopia. A left-wing municipal housing policy will be a recipe for continued deprivation and decay in London," he said.

webTitle: Working IT out: Judy Gibbons

fields.headline: Well connected
fields.standfirst: Judy Gibbons is the director of The Microsoft (MSN) Network UK
fields.trailText: Judy Gibbons, director of The Microsoft (MSN) Network UK
fields.body:
How did you get involved in computers and IT? I was studying civil engineering at university and shared the common view that computers were horrible and boring. Then I joined a graduate programme at NCR where I became fascinated, not by computers or programming, but by what they could do for people. I was involved in developing the first email and word processing systems for Hewlett Packard but it was clear to me that computers wouldn't take off until they were connected so I joined Microsoft to set up the MSN network.

Did you have a vision of what the Microsoft Network could or should be? I wanted to see the democratisation of IT, computer technology for the many instead of the elite few with software at the right price that everybody could use.

What will the Microsoft network offer in the future? There's lots of technology used in corporations that we're offering to the public, like electronic calendars you can access on the net, anytime anywhere. We're offering online filing cabinets where you can store information, files, photos, graphics and music safe from hard disc failure, viruses, or computer thieves and completely harmonisable with your Desktop using Office 2000 and an update. In addition, we'll be offering rich media with audio and video.

Do you think the current downturn in dot.com business is temporary? Absolutely! The downturn is due to over zealousness at the beginning. For a long time, technology stocks were stone cold; then the net came along and they were red hot, a herding instinct took over. There wasn't enough expertise in the market to evaluate these new companies and their true potential. Now, there are businesses based on internet technology and we will have a much more reasoned assessment of a very diverse area.

Computers and IT are often perceived as a male preserve. Is this valid? It's never been a problem for me. Because the new media and technology companies are young, high growth and meritocratic, there are far more opportunities for women than in traditional businesses. In the US, 70% of new business start ups are by women.

What are the benefits and problems of working for Microsoft? Wonderful people, great enthusiasm, shared values, a young, fast moving international company_ it's stimulating and exciting. The downside: people make assumptions about you. Sometimes they expect perfection when we're still learning.

Any favourite websites? www.squaremeal.co.uk, Greater London and UK restaurant guide. You can search by type of cuisine, location or view their top choices in each category.I rely on the Wall Street Journal and ft.com for worldwide business information. Also www.sharepages.com - comprehensive and advanced finance site with up to date share trading information and analysis. Also the official Dilbert website.

Interview by Suzi Pritchard

webTitle: Business: Notebook

fields.headline: Old Lady joins Fed chief for soft landings
fields.standfirst: Rate hawks head for the hills
fields.trailText: Rate hawks are becoming an endangered species on both sides of the Atlantic. City analysts, who a few months ago were confidently predicting that borrowing costs could rise as high as 7.5%, are now hastily backtracking.
fields.body:
Rate hawks are becoming an endangered species on both sides of the Atlantic. City analysts, who a few months ago were confidently predicting that borrowing costs could rise as high as 7.5%, are now hastily backtracking.

A raft of weak data appears to have convinced even the most paranoid analysts that inflation is not likely to threaten the government's 2.5% target anytime soon. This week's figures - the first rise in unemployment for nearly two years and the lowest service sector inflation for 2 years - only confirm the trend.

This morning's quarterly inflation forecast from the Bank of England is expected to confirm the newly fashionable view. A below target forecast today should help persuade the last remaining doubters that after keeping rates on hold at 6% since February, the next move by the Bank's monetary policy committee will be to cut rates.

Meanwhile, most US fund managers believe Alan Greenspan has guided the mighty American economy to a soft landing and that his next move will be to cut borrowing costs. The Federal Reserve was still warning about inflation risks when it announced its decision to keep rates on hold last night, but some analysts believe rates could be cut by Christmas. Successful soft landings are rare achievements. If the Fed and the Bank of England have simultaneously engineered one, the coincidence is even rarer.

The risk now could be on the down side. Some economists warn that the trebling of oil prices since the start of 1999 will inevitably lead to a collapse in growth in the industrialised world. For all the hype about the arrival of weightless economies, generating wealth from computer code and ideas, Britain and America are still powered by oil.

Out of the blue

Glaxo Wellcome slipped out a statement yesterday, saying it had won approval from America's Food and Drug Administration for Trizivir, a triple combination tablet for treating HIV.

The news had been expected. Like other potions pitched against life-threatening diseases, Trizivir has enjoyed "accelerated approval" status from drug regulators. The European Union, for example, should give the thumbs up by early next year. So there was no detectable City reaction to the news. The shares failed to fly. Financial followers are still just sitting around waiting for the Glaxo/SmithKline merger to solidify (or dissolve).

Yet Trizivir marks another milestone in the extraordinarily successful challenge to Aids funded by the world's major pharmaceutical firms as they chased therapies for what initially looked like a disease of the developed world, centred in the world's richest market for drugs.

The drug companies cracked how to suppress the virus some years ago now, but the resultant cocktails had sufferers popping up to 30 tablets a day, all carefully or confusingly timed to be with or without food, water or whatever. Trizivir, on the other hand, is a straight twice-a-day pill, with no food or water restrictions. At $26-a-day, it will prolong many lives, and it should be in US pharmacies by December.

Of course the developing world will have to await a while longer. For all the years of talking about so-called preferential pricing, aimed at helping the nations of Africa in particular to fight Aids, it seems that the first country under the programme - Senegal - was only signed up two weeks ago by Merck, Glaxo, Boehringer and Bristol Myers Squibb.

Compared with its neighbours, the country is said to be well advanced in terms of logistics and economic-cum-political will, but agreement still took seven months of negotiation.

Which is where we might drag in Gordon Brown, in the wake of last week's pre-Budget address, when he said he wanted an urgent review of how incentives, such as tax breaks, might speed vaccines for the world's killer diseases.

Yet the chancellor's statement seems to have come completely out of the blue to the big drug firms. No doubt they would be quite happy to pocket subsidies from the British government to ship their products to the sub-Sahara, but it seems strange that there was no consultation in advance.

Right stock

It is surprising that Bank of Scotland appears so determined that it should not be run by Ian Harley, the chief executive of Abbey, given that Mr Harley appears to possess one of the main characteristics necessary for admission to the BoS board: Scottishness.

Every member of the BoS board, which contains the usual sprinkling of Sirs and Lords, was born in Scotland. So was Mr Harley, in Falkirk to be precise.

In an attempt to show its diversity, BoS pointed out yesterday that three members of its board do at least work outside Scotland, as far afield as England, no less. Clearly, a demonstration of its ambition to be "nationwide".

webTitle: M&S supplier opts for buyout

fields.headline: M&S supplier opts for buyout
fields.trailText: Problems at Marks & Spencer yesterday took their toll on another supplier when Peter Black Holdings went into private ownership for £223m, a much lower figure than planned.
fields.body:
Problems at Marks & Spencer yesterday took their toll on another supplier when Peter Black Holdings went into private ownership for £223m, a much lower figure than planned.

The personal care and household products group, which has been on the stock market for 28 years and takes 40% of its sales from M&S, has endorsed a management buyout offer of 350p, down 30p on earlier predictions.

The final offer still gives a 30% premium to Peter Black's closing price of 270.5p on June 26, when talks began. Yesterday they jumped another 30% and closed at 343p, up 33p.

Gordon Black, the chairman and member of the buyout team, said he had examined the range of options for delivering additional shareholder value and concluded that taking the company private was in the best interests of all.

"The offer, which values the shares at a considerable premium, presents shareholders with the optimum route for realising the true worth of their investments," he added.

The management offer - backed by the 3i venture capital group - is recommended by non-executive directors and is understood to have the support of the Black family, which holds 20% of the stock.

Analysts said the price was reasonable, given the bad news from M&S.

webTitle: Dome takeover company threatens to pull out

fields.headline: Dome takeover company threatens to pull out
fields.trailText: The company negotiating to take over the Millennium Dome today threatened to "regretfully withdraw" from the project if ministers failed to back its £125m bid.
fields.body:
The company negotiating to take over the Millennium Dome today threatened to "regretfully withdraw" from the project if ministers failed to back its £125m bid.

Legacy Plc, headed by City property entrepreneur Robert Bourne, wants to convert the Greenwich, south London, site into a giant hi-tech business park, creating 14,000 jobs within three years. It is now the only firm to have an interest in taking over the dome, which closes in its present manifestation in just 45 days.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is to meet with other officials to decide whether to accept the Legacy bid today. Also expected to attend are treasury minister Andrew Smith, tourism minister Janet Anderson, and dome minister Lord Falconer, who has resisted demands for his resignation after last week's damning report on the dome by the National Audit Office. Lord Falconer has told the New Statesman magazine that he wants to stay in politics despite the pressure on him to go.

Earlier, Legacy appeared to have given ministers an ultimatum to settle the matter at today's meeting but the company stressed that it was merely anxious for a decision "before the end of the week".

A Legacy spokesman said: "We have been involved in the bidding process for a long time and if ministers don't go with us then they are scrapping an 18-month process and will have to start all over again.

"If we can be given preferred bidder status we can then get on with the business of taking over. We finished our period of negotiation with English Partnerships (the regeneration company which owns the dome site) on Tuesday and English Partnerships will now be able to brief ministers on the latest position."

The chairman of the House of Commons public accounts committee, David Davis, yesterday suggested that taxpayers' money was wrongly committed to the dome without MPs' knowledge.

The board of the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the attraction, had been assured that the government would meet the cost of any lawsuits if the dome became insolvent, the committee was told.

webTitle: Losses grow at newly floated ARC International

fields.headline: Losses grow at newly floated ARC International
fields.trailText: ARC International, the newly floated microchip designer, yesterday reported a strong set of sales figures but losses grew by nearly 30% and the share price dipped.
fields.body:
ARC International, the newly floated microchip designer, yesterday reported a strong set of sales figures but losses grew by nearly 30% and the share price dipped.

The company, which competes with ARM, said turnover increased to £3.2m for the three months to the end of September, 30% up on the previous quarter.

But ARC notched up a pre-tax loss of £5.3m in the third quarter, up from £4m for the three months earlier, bringing a total deficit for the first nine months of £11.7m. ARC stock fell 10p at one stage before ending the day down 6p at 276.5p.

Chief executive Bob Terwilliger described the first set of results since ARC became publically listed as "particularly strong".

He stressed the importance of ARC forming a strategic alliance with Xilinx, the software company, and signing an agreement as a licensee with SanDisk, the designer of data storage products. ARC recently unveiled its newest generation microprocessor, Tangent-A4.

While some in the City were worried about growing losses at ARC, others insisted the company was in line or doing even better than anticipated.

Russ Mould, pan-European technology analyst with UBS Warburg, believed the figures were roughly 10% above expectations.

Mr Mould is pencilling in an 80% improvement in 2001 revenues to just short of £20m and almost doubling this in 2002. He put the share price decline down to continuing turbulence around technology stocks.

webTitle: Land Securities hopes for dividend from racier image

fields.headline: Land Securities hopes for dividend from racier image
fields.trailText: Property group Land Securities yesterday predicted that investors will benefit from bigger returns as a result of the bold decision to shake off its conservative image.
fields.body:
Property group Land Securities yesterday predicted that investors will benefit from bigger returns as a result of the bold decision to shake off its conservative image.

The company, which is now providing property services such as maintenance, said it was on track to boost revenues for shareholders within the next three years.

But Ian Henderson, the chief executive, admitted it faced an uphill struggle to change the perception of property as being a fairly dull sector.

"The returns generated have not been enough to excite investors," he said last night. "I hope we will start changing perceptions and it may be beginning to get through, but it will probably take two to three years before we get a substantial re-rating."

In the six months to September 30, Land Securities acquired £400m of property and made it to the shortlists for two multi-million pound contracts - the London Underground Property Partnership and BBC private finance initiative.

The company said the general outlook was sound, despite the high oil price, unrest in the Middle East, a week euro and volatile global stock markets.

Its interim figures showed pre-tax profits had slipped 2.1% to £148.5m, but there was a 4.8% rise in the dividend to 8.65p and the company's net asset value had increased 3.5% to £11.28 over the period.

Since then the group has announced it is paying £165m for Trillium, the property services company contracted to run the Department of Social Security's estate until 2018.

The City responded positively to yesterday's news with shares having jumped 10p to 780p as the London markets closed last night. This is still some way off the year's high of 850p but comfortably ahead of the 623.5p low.

Mr Henderson said there was now more focus on developing buildings suitable for new technologies such as the internet.

webTitle: Jobless rise hits spring poll hopes

fields.headline: Jobless rise hits spring poll hopes
fields.trailText: Labour's hopes that unemployment will fall below 1m in time for a possible spring election were dented yesterday when official figures showed the first monthly rise for nearly two years.
fields.body:
Labour's hopes that unemployment will fall below 1m in time for a possible spring election were dented yesterday when official figures showed the first monthly rise for nearly two years.

The number of people out of work and claiming benefit rose by 3,500 in October, according to the office for national statistics. ONS statisticians said the trend remained downward but the rate of decline was slowing.

Industry leaders called for a cut in borrowing costs, warning that yesterday's figures could signal the end of the long decline in the jobless total which has taken unemployment from a peak of just under 3m in December 1992, to 1.047m last month.

"This data may mark a turning point in the labour market and adds strength to the case for the next move on rates to be down," said Ian Fletcher, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce.

Other economists said yesterday's figures were probably a blip. Over the past eight years, the claimant count total has registered monthly rises on three occasions before resuming its steady decline.

"Some may latch on to the rising unemployment numbers as further evidence of a slowing economy," said Ross Walker, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland. "We would urge caution, though the chances of the claimant count falling below 1m before the end of the year are that much slimmer."

The government's preferred jobless measure, which covers people looking for work, fell by 36,000 between July and September to 1,586,000 or 5.4%.

The ONS said average earnings growth had picked up to 4.1% in the three months to September from a year earlier. The figure remains well below the 4.5% the Bank of England considers to be compatible with its 2.5% inflation target.

"With earnings remaining in the Bank of England's 'comfort zone', and house and share prices slowing there is clear evidence that demand is firmly under control," Mr Fletcher said.

webTitle: 'Unison's Scottish strikes are foolish and pointless'

fields.headline: 'Unison's Scottish strikes are foolish and pointless'
fields.standfirst: Unison members in Scotland will gain nothing from the latest strike, writes Mark Irvine
fields.trailText: Comment:Unison members in Scotland will gain nothing from the latest strike, writes Mark Irvine
fields.body:
Striking is a serious business, which is why the tactic is so rarely used nowadays. Members join a union for protection, not to be used as cannon fodder in leaderless disputes. So, calling a strike needs very careful consideration to minimise casualties on your own side.

Today, Unison members will be manning the barricades for the third time in three months. The cost to someone earning £10,000 a year is around £40; £120 if they support all three days. The pay offer from employers is worth £300 a year. Good money is being thrown after bad, unless union leaders believe their action will result in a substantial further increase.

Small groups of members are also taking selective action from November 1, but will receive full take home pay. The union knows it cannot sustain lots of individual days of action; losing money is unpopular, unless the reward for sacrifice is attainable and clear.

In the original ballot, 15, 912 Unison members voted to strike, with 12,330 against. That's a majority of 56%, based on a turnout of 36%. This was always a poor mandate particularly as the other unions, the GMB and the TGWU, voted against such action. Solidarity, the watchword of unions, was in short supply from day one.

A majority vote in a ballot is not sacred - the strike option is never automatic and has to be approved by the national executive. In another recent Unison ballot of 3,500 Glasgow social workers, the outcome was quite different. Over half (53%) of members voted to strike based on a 30% turnout, but the action was called off. It had no hope of success, even without a damaging split in union ranks.

In reality, Scottish Unison leaders have lost control of the dispute, incredibly being forced to harden the union position in response to an improved offer from the employers. No one knows what more strikes are intended to achieve. Disgusted with events, the GMB and TGWU have broken ranks completely and accepted the deal that will increase pay by 3% this year.

Unison has made a rod for its own back by calling the employer's offer "derisory" and "insulting" and raising expectations that the claim for 5% can be achieved by more strikes. Its own leaders know this will never happen, but have been unable to persuade activists to drop their kamikaze tactics.

So, the dispute trundles on without hope or ambition; eight months into the financial year, council budgets all set and spending decisions in place. Unison's lay member committees are badly split with only one or two votes deciding to persevere with the strike weapon that has turned into a boomerang in unskilled hands.

Intriguingly, if Unison members take a fourth day of action, they trigger an entitlement to strike pay for all four days; the first three days of any dispute never qualify. At a cost of £6m, Unison leaders will want this like another hole in the head. For the members, it is the only way of cutting their earlier losses.

Essentially this is a foolish, pointless strike that hurts the rank and file. Instead of sending members out over the top to rush the barbed wire, Unison should have been doing its job of campaigning and lobbying for a better deal months ago. Opportunities grew on trees: the Scottish Labour conference (last March), the Scottish TUC (in April) and the TUC (September, in Glasgow). But the silence was deafening.

Using Unison members as a battering ram will leave them bruised and bloodied, while their leaders survey the carnage from a safe distance.

webTitle: Fears for coal as gas gets go-ahead

fields.headline: Fears for coal as gas gets go-ahead
fields.trailText: The government yesterday paved the way for a shake-up of Britain's energy mix by lifting the two-year-old ban on new gas-fired power stations and winning European commission approval for £110m in aid for the coal industry.
fields.byline: David Gow and Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
The government yesterday paved the way for a shake-up of Britain's energy mix by lifting the two-year-old ban on new gas-fired power stations and winning European commission approval for £110m in aid for the coal industry.

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, gave belated approval to six gas-fired plants generating up to 4800MW of power - equivalent to 15m tonnes of coal a year - in a move some saw as sounding the death knell for Britain's coal mines.

But coal producers, headed by RJB Mining, which has 13 deep-mined pits and employs 8,000 miners, welcomed the package as saving Britain's last colleries and jobs and securing the industry's medium-term future in a period of transition.

Mr Byers appeared to have given fresh impetus to the "dash for gas" that led to scores of pit closures in the late 1980s and 1990s but coal industry executives and analysts cautioned against expectations that all six stations would be built given the soaring price of gas.

The six plants - at Raventhorpe (450MW), Langage, near Plymouth (1,010MW), Isle of Grain, Kent (1,200MW), Fleetwood, Lancs (1,000MW), Partington, Trafford (380MW) and Spalding, Lincs (800MW) - would require up to £2bn investment and create up to 8,000 man-years of employment, according to Mr Byers.

He said the new power stations would bring economic growth, especially in areas requiring regeneration, promote competition, cheaper power prices and guarantee secure electricity supplies.

But analysts doubted whether the six, all refused consent within the past two years, would be built, suggest ing that three or four at most would leave the drawing board. Enron, the US energy group, merely said it was reviewing its Isle of Grain project while other US groups, including NRG and AES, remained cautious.

Coal industry insiders pointed out that the consents had been withheld when gas cost 9p a therm but the price had now trebled to 28p. They would need a big oil and gas company behind them.

Last year coal provided 28% of Britain's power, gas 38.5%, and nuclear 24.5%. However, coal burn in recent weeks has grown by up to 40% compared with last year as prices, up from £20 to £25 a tonne in the same period, have barely increased compared with oil and gas.

The aid applies only until July 2002 and government sources said coal would be expected to stand on its own feet after then. Mr Byers indicated that new applications for power stations would gain approval if they used combined heat and power and thus contributed to lower emissions.

webTitle: Wearing your wires

fields.headline: Wearing your wires
fields.standfirst:
Concerns about health could lead us to link our bodies to the internet. Sean Dodson looks at plans to turn us into cybermen and women

Net news
fields.trailText: Concerns about health could lead us to link our bodies to the internet. Sean Dodson looks at plans to turn us into cybermen and women
fields.body:
Wiring our bodies to the internet might sound like the stuff of science fiction, but the reality of such a far-flung idea is closer than you think.

A number of companies have this year been touting wearable computers as the next big thing. We've had fully mounted headsets, scarves that alert users to email and, ironically enough, anoraks with built-in PCs. But rising concern for our health - rather than our looks - is most likely to create a market for such products.

In both the United States and Scandinavia, a number of technology companies, ranging from small start-ups to telecommunications giants and even global sportswear manufacturers, are ready to release a range of wireless internet devices that can either be worn or even directly connected to the body. And as early as next spring, they could be coming to the United Kingdom.

By 2010, Forrester Research predicts, a billion people will access the net through some kind of wireless device. This means at least a third of the UK population will have wireless access. The majority of these devices will probably be advanced third generation (3G) mobile phones. But analysts believe the number will include fridges, washing machines and alarm clocks with wireless access. Devices that monitor the body's vital signs could well carve out a slice of the wireless pie.

The race to wire the body began in earnest last August when LifeChart, a $25m start-up, released a product for asthma sufferers called the AirWatch, a small electronic inhaler with a tiny LCD display. It enables users to regularly monitor their breathing. But what is really interesting is the web-enabled services run off the device.

By plugging the AirWatch into the nearest telephone socket, users can upload all their recorded data to the company's website. LifeChart converts the data into a series of graphs and tables that help users spot the "triggers" that might be causing their disease.

LifeChart charges $120 per year subscription fee. Subscribers are invited to share their password with their doctors. The company, based in California and funded by Johnson & Johnson, Nokia and the Finnish National Fund For Research and Development, offers similar devices and services for heart disease sufferers and diabetics. The service is available across the US and in Finland, Sweden and the Netherlands.

LifeChart calls this service "connecting people to constant care", and sees itself as part of a wider "wellness management" industry burgeoning in the US.

Rivals include Stayhealthy.com, which offers customers a device called the CT1 personal calorie tracker. It looks a bit like a pager and allows users to monitor their caloric burn rate by measuring and recording body movement. Unlike the AirWatch, the CT1 is worn on the waist and constantly tracks caloric burn throughout the day. Using a docking station and special software the data is uploaded to the Stayhealthy web site.

Another US company, Microfit, has for years been offering online services that connect an exercise bike to a PC, but Bodymedia, a start-up in Pittsburgh, wants to go one better and wire you and your mountain bike to the net.

"Just like a dieter needs a set of scales to lose weight, so a busy professional seeking a structure of wellness to their lives needs a tool to bring that about," says Astro Teller, the chief executive of Bodymedia. Next spring sees the launch of Sensewear - a series of sensors to monitor the human body in ways that are "fashionable and comfortable".

Sensewear monitors heart rate, skin temperature and even how well you are sleeping. Again, the information is transmitted to a PC and uploaded to a secure server - this time wirelessly. The system is similar to that used by athletes at the Olympics to monitor their training. But Bodymedia claims that eventually it will be able to download information to users. Suddenly, you can be told how well you are doing, when to get up, when to eat, even when to meditate.

Last month, Bodymedia launched its Healthmanager software that will run off Sensewear. For now, users will be expected to input their own data (indeed the health manager will run without Sensewear). There is an initial set-up fee of $25 and a further $50 a month subscription fee for the service.

"Bodymedia is not offering a quick fix or the next fad diet," insists Teller. "We will not replace your doctor or personal trainer or any other health professional.

"Rather, we wish to help you accomplish your goal and bring a health balance to your lifestyle."

Teller says that initally remote database access (RDA) technology, or cellphone networks, will be employed. He thinks that Sensewear is best suited to Bluetooth - a consortium of five companies (Nokia, Ericsson, IBM, Intel and Toshiba) - which is developing a specification to allow wireless devices to communicate with each other. But he admits that this is at least "three or four years away".

Hot on Bodymedia's heels is Nike. The sportswear manufacturer is facing falling sales of training shoes (last year's profits were barely half that of 1997), and looking to diversify into a number of computer-related products.

Nike rolled out its first MP3 player last month. The psa[play is developed in collaboration with Rio and is the first product to come out of Nike's high-tech research-and -development department, Techlab.

The MP3 player will be followed by a pedometer and heart-rate monitor and, ultimately, the world's first online training shoe.

Nike also wants to become a content provider by building a series of online communities based around the masses of data accrued from its work with Olympic athletes. At the moment this means something like their Olympic site, full of news, adverts for Nike sportswear and the odd chat room. But eventually - if Nike sells enough of their computer- related devices - it wants to offer customers the chance to compare their data with that of the athletes Nike sponsors. Suddenly you could compare your evening's jog with that of Olympians' Sonia O'Sullivan or John Brown.

"The beauty of it is that the more information we can offer the consumer about how they perform is going to make for a happier consumer," says Ray Riley, creative director of Techlab. "And who better to integrate technology into the gear you wear for sport? It is perfect, it is like a business that is pre-made for us."

And, says Riley, wiring the body need not prove prohibitively expensive. Nike's MP3 players start at £189, with the pedometers and heart-rate monitors expected to sell for a similar price.

But should we wire up our bodies, even for health reasons? For many, Teller's vision of Bodymedia-clad workers being told what to do has sinister overtones. Couldn't insurance companies offer cheaper medical insurance to those that wire up? And what if, some time in the future, employers insist that their workers wear body media?

Teller is scornful of such suggestions. He sees the growing scarcity of health-care as more reason for Bodymedia's success. In the US, he argues, how much you earn usually decides who receives healthcare, regardless of whether the rich have bothered to look after themselves.

He says: "Especially in a socialised medical society like Britain, it is certainly the case that one ought not to have to pay taxes for someone who didn't take care of themselves for 60 years and is going to be sick for the next 20."

Therefore, he argues, use of Sensewear could help ascertain who has been looking after themselves and who would be most receptive to health care.

Wearable computers are nothing new. Military, medical and industrial versions have existed for years. What is different about Sensewear or devices like the AirWatch and CT1 is that they will, for the first time, be mass-marketed and the first to be online.

Finally, if we want to wire our bodies to the internet, won't this make us become a hybrid of man and machine - effectively cyborgs?

The leading thinker in the field, the "cyber-feminist" Donna Haraway, said as long ago as 1997 that we were all already cyborgs. Through the use of commonplace products such as spectacles, pacemakers and pharmaceuticals we integrated ourselves with machines long ago - it is just that some of us have not yet realised what we are doing.

So maybe wiring our bodies to the internet - and embracing all its advantages might not be such a great leap forward after all.

Another US company, Microfit, has for years been offering online services that connect an exercise bike to a PC, but Bodymedia, a start-up in Pittsburgh, wants to go one better and wire you and your mountain bike to the net. "Just like a dieter needs a set of scales to lose weight, so a busy professional seeking a structure of wellness to their lives needs a tool to bring that about," says Astro Teller, the chief executive of Bodymedia. Next spring sees the launch of Sensewear - a series of sensors to monitor the human body in ways that are "fashionable and comfortable". Sensewear monitors heart rate, skin temperature and even how well you are sleeping. Again, the information is transmitted to a PC and uploaded to a secure server - this time wirelessly. The system is similar to that used by athletes at the Olympics to monitor their training. But Bodymedia claims that eventually it will be able to download information to users. Suddenly, you can be told how well you are doing, when to get up, when to eat, even when to meditate. Last month, Bodymedia launched its Healthmanager software that will run off Sensewear. For now, users will be expected to input their own data (indeed the health manager will run without Sensewear). There is an initial set-up fee of $25 and a further $50 a month subscription fee for the service. "Bodymedia is not offering a quick fix or the next fad diet," insists Teller. "We will not replace your doctor or personal trainer or any other health professional. "Rather, we wish to help you accomplish your goal and bring a health balance to your lifestyle." Teller says that initally remote database access (RDA) technology, or cellphone networks, will be employed. He thinks that Sensewear is best suited to Bluetooth - a consortium of five companies (Nokia, Ericsson, IBM, Intel and Toshiba) - which is developing a specification to allow wireless devices to communicate with each other. But he admits that this is at least "three or four years away". Hot on Bodymedia's heels is Nike. The sportswear manufacturer is facing falling sales of training shoes (last year's profits were barely half that of 1997), and looking to diversify into a number of computer-related products. Nike rolled out its first MP3 player last month. The psa[play is developed in collaboration with Rio and is the first product to come out of Nike's high-tech research-and -development department, Techlab. The MP3 player will be followed by a pedometer and heart-rate monitor and, ultimately, the world's first online training shoe. Nike also wants to become a content provider by building a series of online communities based around the masses of data accrued from its work with Olympic athletes. At the moment this means something like their Olympic site, full of news, adverts for Nike sportswear and the odd chat room. But eventually - if Nike sells enough of their computer- related devices - it wants to offer customers the chance to compare their data with that of the athletes Nike sponsors. Suddenly you could compare your evening's jog with that of Olympians' Sonia O'Sullivan or John Brown. "The beauty of it is that the more information we can offer the consumer about how they perform is going to make for a happier consumer," says Ray Riley, creative director of Techlab. "And who better to integrate technology into the gear you wear for sport? It is perfect, it is like a business that is pre-made for us." And, says Riley, wiring the body need not prove prohibitively expensive. Nike's MP3 players start at £189, with the pedometers and heart-rate monitors expected to sell for a similar price. But should we wire up our bodies, even for health reasons? For many, Teller's vision of Bodymedia-clad workers being told what to do has sinister overtones. Couldn't insurance companies offer cheaper medical insurance to those that wire up? And what if, some time in the future, employers insist that their workers wear body media? Teller is scornful of such suggestions. He sees the growing scarcity of health-care as more reason for Bodymedia's success. In the US, he argues, how much you earn usually decides who receives healthcare, regardless of whether the rich have bothered to look after themselves. He says: "Especially in a socialised medical society like Britain, it is certainly the case that one ought not to have to pay taxes for someone who didn't take care of themselves for 60 years and is going to be sick for the next 20." Therefore, he argues, use of Sensewear could help ascertain who has been looking after themselves and who would be most receptive to health care. Wearable computers are nothing new. Military, medical and industrial versions have existed for years. What is different about Sensewear or devices like the AirWatch and CT1 is that they will, for the first time, be mass-marketed and the first to be online. Finally, if we want to wire our bodies to the internet, won't this make us become a hybrid of man and machine - effectively cyborgs? The leading thinker in the field, the "cyber-feminist" Donna Haraway, said as long ago as 1997 that we were all already cyborgs. Through the use of commonplace products such as spectacles, pacemakers and pharmaceuticals we integrated ourselves with machines long ago - it is just that some of us have not yet realised what we are doing. So maybe wiring our bodies to the internet - and embracing all its advantages might not be such a great leap forward after all. webTitle: Vivendi sees revenues rise ahead of Seagram merger

fields.headline: Vivendi sees revenues rise ahead of Seagram merger
fields.trailText: 12pm: Vivendi's revenues have risen strongly ahead of the French media company's merger with Seagram. Dan Milmo reports.
fields.body:
Vivendi, the French media and environmental services company, has posted a rise in revenues ahead of its £66bn merger with Canada's Seagram.

The group is best known in the UK for its media division, which includes the Canal Plus pay-TV operation and the Havas advertising group, but its biggest earners are its water treatment and energy operations.

Vivendi said revenues for the nine months to December were E29.1bn (£17.5bn), against E19.9bn (£11.9bn) last year. The environment division contributed E18.8bn (£11.8bn), with the media arm's E9.4bn (£5.6bn) a distant second.

The merger with Seagram will produce a new company called Vivendi Universal, combining Universal Music, Universal Studios, the Canal Plus TV channel and Vivendi's telecoms and internet interests.

The deal is set to be passed at the companies' respective shareholder meetings in mid-December.

Vivendi has been ordered to sell its 23% stake in Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB by EU merger regulators, and could sell its holding back to Mr Murdoch.

Vivendi chairman Jean-Marie Messier is now unlikely to take a stake in Mr Murdoch's Sky Global Networks, which is formed by the satellite TV interests of News Corporation.

Analysts were quick to point out that this does not harm Mr Messier's global ambitions, as he already has a number of strategic partnerships with big hitters such as Bertelsmann, USA Networks and Vodafone.

Vizzavi, the internet joint venture with mobile phone operator Vodafone, has a potential customer base of 100m and is set to launch in the highly lucrative Japanese market.

Marc Loneux, media analyst at Commerzbank: "Vivendi has a lot on its plate and does not need to be a minority shareholder in Murdoch's company. If you want to be pro-active and have a say in News Corporation's decisions, it is very difficult to get around Murdoch."

webTitle: Mobile watch

fields.headline: Mobile watch
fields.trailText: Free SMS messages
fields.body:
If you are fed up already with reading e-mail from your Wap (wireless application protocol) phone then try the latest thing: sending short text messages to any GSM phone free from a regular web site. Shakil Khan, founder of SMSboy.com, claims that almost 12,000 messages were sent to phones across Europe on the inaugural day last week. It costs the company about 5p for each message sent. He reckons it is a price worth paying as he hasn't had to spend a penny on marketing - news of the site just spreads virally.

Wap and short text messaging are tailor-made for football - to satisfy the insatiable appetite of fans for news about players, goals and team line-ups.

The prince of football sites is Manchester United, which is planning a big Wap expansion programme. It has an estimated 20 million fans around the world and boasts 80% brand recognition in China, the country with the biggest potential market for mobiles.

See www.europewap.com/ and manutd/manmenu.wml

Arsenal has a mobile site, managed by Red Message (UK) at arseweb.com/wap/ which claims to reach nearly 100,000 subscribers around the world. They get match alerts, team line-ups, half-time and full-time scores naming who scored at what time. For other news of football and other sports like cricket and Formula1 try Sports.com at mmm.sports.com/index.wml

Building a Wap presence is getting easier and easier. The web site www.wapdrive.com/ enables you to build your own and have it up and running (on your Wap phone) within minutes. There is a more complicated version for aficionados. And it's free.

webTitle: Broadcasters draw up rules for war zone journalists

fields.headline: Broadcasters draw up rules for war zone journalists
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Leading broadcasters have agreed guidelines to protect staff reporting from war zones, writes David Rowan.
fields.body:
Rival media owners today agreed to work together to protect journalists in war zones, amid concern at the rise in deaths and injuries among broadcasters and support crews.

Broadcasters the BBC, ITN and CNN - and news agencies Reuters and APTN - will share information between themselves and agree to limit the risks they ask correspondents to take while filing stories from war zones.

The unprecedented alliance follows concern about record numbers of reporters and back-up staff being killed while reporting from the front line.

According to the International Press Institute, last year 86 journalists and media staff were killed or murdered in the course of their work, making it one of the worst years on record.

Already this year 37 journalists have been killed while on duty, including five in Russia, three in Sierra Leone and seven in Colombia.

Richard Sambrook, deputy director of BBC News, said: "This agreement represents unprecedented co-operation between competitors in the broadcast news industry to protect all journalists, staff and freelance, working in dangerous conditions.

"Our aim is to limit risk and to take responsibility for anyone working on our behalf in war zones or hostile environments. Safety can never be a competitive issue," he added.

The media organisations have agreed guidelines that put safety above the pursuit of ratings.

Assignments to war zones or hostile environments "must be voluntary", the guidelines say, and they "should only involve experienced newsgatherers and those under their direct supervision".

The media groups have agreed not to put staff and freelances under "unwarranted risks in pursuit of a story", stating that such pressure is "unacceptable and must be strongly discouraged".

A databank of safety information is being shared between the companies, so that up-to-date information is available to all on dangerous areas.

The guidelines, announced at the Newsworld conference in Barcelona, will also cover the "fixers", interpreters and drivers used by all journalists in war zones.

Last May, Jeremy Bowen, the former BBC war correspondent, and a freelance Lebanese cameraman narrowly escaped death after their car was hit by an Israeli artillery shell.

Their driver Abed Taboush was killed and Mr Bowen, who now presents Breakfast News, and the BBC are considering suing the Israeli army for compensation fom Mr Taboush's family.

Just two days later in Sierra Leone, veteran war correspondent Kurt Schork, who worked for Reuters, and cameraman Miguel Gil Moreno of the APTN agency were killed.

webTitle: A perfect start and a perfect end

fields.headline: A perfect start and a perfect end
fields.trailText: Now that Mohammad Azharuddin's career looks finished, he will have scored a hundred in his first Test innings and in his last one. Has anyone else done this? asks Nagarjun
fields.body:
Now that Mohammad Azharuddin's career looks finished, he will have scored a hundred in his first Test innings and in his last one. Has anyone else done this? asks Nagarjun

You're right, Mohammad Azharuddin did do this: he made 110 for India against England in the first innings of his Test debut, at Calcutta in 1984-85 (uniquely, he went on to score centuries in each of his first three Tests), and scored 102 in his most recent Test innings, against South Africa at Bangalore last winter.

The only other man to have achieved this exact feat was Greg Chappell, the upright Australian batsman. In his first Test, against England at Perth in 1970-71, Chappell made 108 after going in at No. 7 with Australia struggling at 107 for 5, chasing England's 397. And in his final Test innings, against Pakistan at Sydney in 1983-84, Chappell signed off with a majestic 182. That match marked the end of an era for Australian cricket: it was also the final Test appearance for Dennis Lillee and Rodney Marsh.

Two other players - both Australians too - made centuries in their first and last Tests (but not innings). The first was Reggie Duff. Usually an attacking opener, he was held back to No. 10 in the second innings of his Test debut, against England at Melbourne in 1901-02 - and hit 104. He also scored 146 in his last Test innings, against England at The Oval in 1905.

The other was Bill Ponsford, the prolific opener who is also the only man to make two quadruple-centuries in first-class cricket. Ponsford, who is usually described as a heavy-footed batsman (although he was a good fielder), made 110 in his first Test innings, against England at Sydney in 1924-25, and 266 in the first innings of his last Test, against England at The Oval in 1934. Ponsford put on 451 with Don Bradman, who scored 244, and Australia reached 701. In the second innings of that game Ponsford made 22.
