webTitle: Meet the technostupes

fields.headline: It's way too fancy for Clancy
fields.standfirst:
Scriptwriter Clancy Sigal is a "technostupe" - a 12-hour-a-day computer user who still can't work out how to send an email attachment

Net news
fields.trailText: Scriptwriter Clancy Sigal is a "technostupe" - a 12-hour-a-day computer user who still can't work out how to send an email attachment
fields.body:
I am a 12-hour-a-day computer user, a loyal internet fiend, who has sunk to an even more abysmal level than the web trawlers who mutter apologetically that they're "all thumbs". If the internet has no limits, neither does my systems backwardness.

With this column, I burst, like a reverse Superman, from my telephone booth, proudly announcing, "Is it a bird brain? Is it a plane without engine or wings? No, it's...TechnoStupe!"

First, my credentials. The mysteries of Wittgenstein, or Trotskyist sectarianism, or defusing a live land mine MK-14, or the baseball American League's notoriously convoluted "designated hitter" rule (don't ask), and how to unlock the hearts of heartless Hollywood producers hold no terrors for me.

But, when confronted, with the most absurdly simple computer problem, let alone glitch, I blow a mental fuse. I can smell the acrid fumes of crossed wires burning in my brain.

As we speak, I cannot access Amazon.com, surely the most user-friendly site in webdom. Eager-to-please technohelpers keep forwarding opaque messages about "firewalls" and please will I send them a 17-digit http:// number - what's that?

I file everything, no matter the subject, on my "C" drive because I have no idea what all those folder icons mean. And, though I have a genius-level neighbour, a theoretical physicist, who has patiently, deliberately written out baby-simple instructions for me in the same Janet and John idiom Al Gore uses in his speeches - r-e-a-l-l-y -s-i-m-p-l-e - I cannot send this article as an attachment. I simply do not know how and I am too thick to learn, no matter who teaches me and how many times they try.

I haven't even mastered peer-to-peer music transfer via Napster - which even straight-F-for-failure college students wield in their sleep.

This is costing me money. Increasingly, Hollywood, where I earn my bread, turns to cyberspace for future profits. Websites abound with full-length movie previews, hyperspaced animation, news of script sales, writing jobs - a fledgling industry for the technowhiz audience who are fluent in technospeak and therefore collect the cheques.

Please, no more talk of my left and right brain distortion, dyslexia, Attention Deficit Disorder, and "You just haven't had the right teacher, Clancy". I've had ALL the right teachers: Abigail, Corky, Janice, Gabriel_ the list may not be endless but it is long and guilt making. They all were, I'm sure, extremely bright in school and have carried the smarty-gene over to computers as naturally as a queen's swan bites your hand.

As a child I was not a classroom smarty. In fact, for an entire year, I was relegated to the subnormal, oops retarded, oops "educationally less advantaged" class - one of the happiest experiences of my youth. There, seated amid half-blind albinos, undiagnosed deaf children, pure idiots and the severely emotionally retarded, I basked in the bliss of no-pressure. Neither teach ers nor parent expected anything of me, I did not have to produce, and I didn't. Trouble is, there is no "subnormal class" for computer dimwits. Technostupes are basically walled-in. Like any dysfunctional person, I've even tried "professional help". Aside from the expense, these wizards usually leave me in worse shape, emotionally if not electronically.

Leaving me, as usual, to crawl to friends. Please, please, help me? They're wonderful, talented achievers who, by now, having "worked with" me, would rather cut their throats (or mine) than confess they are giving me up as a bad case. Now, one by stealthy one, like News of the World reporters, they make their excuses and leave before performing the miracle of the fishes and loaves on my electric box.

They download diagrams. And email me long lists of "simple" instructions. And send me carloads of analogies! "Look, Clancy, it's just like fly fishing..." Or, "Think of your ISP as an airport..." Then they wonder why I don't get it. Analogies confuse the panicked mind.

Now, some of my computer-wise angels are turning a shade nasty. Just a few minutes ago Bobby, keeper of my Hollywood screenwriters' bulletin board, started his umpteenth emailed "simple" explanation with an exasperated, "I really like you, Clancy. But..."

Very Hollywood, that. In a movie studio I always know I'm in schtook when they start with, "I really like you, Clancy..." You wait for the "but" as for the headman's axewhen a creative executive bounces out of his chair with a vigorous handshake, "I really like you, Clancy...".

It's some kind of made-in-Hollywood miracle that I manage to navigate my computer at all. I'm like those dyslexic or illiterate adults who, like Robert De Niro in Stanley And Iris, somehow manage to recognise motorway signs, buy groceries and keep a steady job despite their dirty little secret.

Somehow, on the internet, I politically organise. I do movie business by email, somehow. I once helped lead an electronic rescue mission that got much-needed antibiotics to besieged Sarajevo, somehow. Yet I still do not know the difference between a website, URL, ISP, browser and Bowser my dog.

It's said that the rise of computers has created a digital divide between the electronically privileged and computer-deprived underclass. I beg to differ. The real class distinction is between technosmarties and technostupes. My advice to others in my quandary?

Fake it.

 Clancy Sigal is a scriptwriter in Hollywood

The real class distinction is between technosmarties and technostupes. My advice to others in my quandary? Fake it.  Clancy Sigal is a scriptwriter in Hollywood

webTitle: Sting to sue MoD over airbase expansion

fields.headline: Sting to sue MoD over airbase expansion
fields.trailText: Sting is considering suing the Ministry of Defence over plans to extend an airbase near his home.
fields.body:
Sting is considering suing the Ministry of Defence over plans to extend an airbase near his home.

The singer, who lives in Amesbury, Wiltshire, has joined forces with other residents near the Boscombe Down site to argue the expansion is a breach of their human rights.

The situation has arisen because the Defence Evaluation and Research Agency (Dera) does not need planning permission to press ahead with a military development, said the Ministry of Defence.

Sting hopes to win a public inquiry into the proposals, which are still at an early stage, to relocate a fleet of tanker aircraft from RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire.

Dera spokeswoman Joanna Sale admitted the siting of a new base on Salisbury Plain would more than double air traffic.

However, she added: "Concerns have been raised locally, but it's not been a violent reaction. We have developed a good and productive relationship with the community and we will do anything to protect that."

Dera has promised a consultation exercise with local residents.

Ms Sale added: "We would be very happy for Sting to come around for a briefing - at least he would be in full charge of the facts."

A spokeswoman for Wiltshire County Council said it had no jurisdiction over the proposals because Boscombe Down was Ministry of Defence land.

webTitle: Business: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Microsoft faces EC hearing
fields.body:
Microsoft faces EC hearing

Microsoft will this week submit its defence to the European commission against allegations that it abuses its dominance in server software by refusing to supply information to competitors, Microsoft spokeswoman Tiffany Steckler said yesterday.

The deadline for Microsoft to submit its defence has been extended to Friday night. Microsoft could face fines of up to 10% of its annual turnover.

Grasso rings the changes

Richard Grasso, chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, met his London counterpart last night amid fresh speculation about the future ownership of the London Stock Exchange.

After fending off a hostile bid from OM of Sweden, the LSE is being courted by Nasdaq, the NYSE's closest rival.

Mr Grasso, on a whistle-stop visit to London, said he did not believe in hostile bids but talked of consolidation among the world's stock exchanges.

WTO rejects Clinton call

President Clinton yesterday called for speedy resumption of global talks on cutting trade barriers, but ran into opposition from the body which polices world trade.

Mike Moore, director general of the World Trade Organisation, said resuming negotiations too soon risked a rerun of last December's Seattle summit, where attempts to start another round of negotiations collapsed amid violent protests by anti-globalisation activists.

BBA spreads its wings

BBA Group yesterday underlined its recent refocusing from engineering to aviation services with the £106.2m cash purchase of Aircraft Service International Group. Florida-based Asig has fuelling and ground and cargo handling operations in 50 locations in North America and the Caribbean, as well as at eight airports in Europe, including Heathrow, Gatwick and Stansted.

Auditors restricted

The US securities and exchange commission yesterday voted unanimously to limit the types of consulting work accounting firms can do for audit clients, claiming such a dual relationship could appear to be a conflict of interest.

webTitle: EU rules blamed for adding £500 to price of a car

fields.headline: EU rules blamed for adding £500 to price of a car
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The price of a new car in the UK is inflated by at least £500 because of arcane European Union rules which allow manufacturers to restrict competition, claimed internet car retailer Jamjar.com yesterday.
fields.body:
The price of a new car in the UK is inflated by at least £500 because of arcane European Union rules which allow manufacturers to restrict competition, claimed internet car retailer Jamjar.com yesterday.

In a scathing attack on the present sales system timed to coincide with the release of a highly critical report from the European commission on the same subject, Jamjar argued that UK consumers pay as much as £1bn over the odds for their new cars every year.

The problem, it said, lies with the car industry's "block exemption" from normal EU competition rules which allows it to restrict sales to franchised dealers and control prices in an unfair way.

The end of the system moved a step closer today when the EC adopted a report saying consumers did not seem to be benefiting from the dealer system.

Mario Monti, the EU's competition chief, who is considering whether to modify the block exemption or scrap it altogether before it expires in 2002, agrees that the system is failing the consumer.

"There are a number of major weaknesses in the way in which the consumer is served. A picture of shadow and light emerges, and there are some very important shadows," he told the Guardian.

"We are particularly unhappy about the way in which the industry, coupled with the existing regulation, has only been able to deliver the value-added stage of the single market in a very limited way. My guiding star is and will be a well-meant notion of consumer interest."

Jamjar, owned by Direct Line insurance, said a new system "should provide greater commercial freedom to allow companies like Jamjar.com to pass on further price discounts to consumers".

webTitle: C&W wants to go spending

fields.headline: C&W wants to go spending
fields.standfirst:
£4bn is earmarked for web acquisitions

Net news
fields.trailText: £4bn is earmarked for web acquisitions.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless, the business telecoms group, is planning to spend a large part of its £4bn cash pile on small acquisitions to bolster its internet-related business, especially in the US.

Chief executive Graham Wallace ruled out a mega-bid or the purchase of any of the businesses which British Telecom, its longstanding rival, is putting up for sale.

Mr Wallace said that large companies tended to have legacy systems that were of no use to C&W which aimed to be the leading global supplier of internet protocol (IP) solutions to business customers.

The company, which expects to announce two deals within the next three months, is looking at businesses worth tens or hundreds of millions of pounds, rather than those worth a billion or more, he said.

Mr Wallace said C&W was interested in buying the data operations of Optus, the Australian telecoms business in which it has a 52.5% stake. Optus, which also has mobile and consumer divisions, yesterday put itself up for sale, in whole or in part.

C&W ended the year with net cash of £4.2bn, mainly as a result of the sale of its consumer business to NTL and disposal of its Hongkong Telecom stake to Pacific Century Cyber Works. It also received shares in NTL and PCCW which if sold would add a further £1bn to its cash pile.

The sale of the two businesses resulted in a £4.27bn exceptional profit which has distorted C&W's first-half figures. Pre-tax profits rose 33% to £4.59bn, though the underlying profit - after allowing for the gains on disposals - was £537m, against £539m for the same period last year. The interim dividend has been raised by 10% to 4.95p per share.

Mr Wallace said that the company was expecting continued strong growth. "We operate in a market place expected to grow by 15% to 20%," he said. "That is our stated growth target as well. Most of the growth will come from IP services."

webTitle: My wife the Tory

fields.headline: My wife the Tory
fields.standfirst: Real Lives: The last time Tim Luckhurst went canvassing was with his boss, Labour's Donald Dewar
fields.trailText: Real Lives: The last time Tim Luckhurst went canvassing was with his boss, Labour's Donald Dewar.
fields.body:
The Lada Jeep rattles to a halt on Archerhill Road. Candidate, child and reporter descend. The candidate looks good in ankle-length waxed raincoat, jeans and boots. Good, but not very Tory. No pearls, no shoulder pads. The toddler is a humanising prop too. A volunteer helper jokes that every politician should hire a small child. But Georgia is the real thing. Two-and-a-half years old, shivering with cold, and bored with Mummy's game.

The last time I went canvassing here was with my boss, Donald Dewar, then shadow secretary of state for Scotland, and these are the privately owned former council houses he once feared would turn his constituency against him.

Now my adorable wife, Dorothy, the Conservative candidate hoping to replace Dewar at Westminster, is working on the same assumption. You can tell a lot from doors, windows and neat flowerbeds. The cared-for homes are more likely to contain Tories. But it doesn't always work. Three semis in a row matched the stereotype. Little expressions of individuality in the external appearance, two new cars between them. But no support for Dorothy. This is Glasgow. Glasgow always backs Labour. "It's aye bin that way, luv."

And so she tries to persuade, never hectoring or aggressive. It's not her way. Just the simple questions to which Conservatives truly believe they are the answer: "What has Labour ever done for Glasgow?"

I'm getting confused here. I love her. She's dynamite on the doorstep. Plucky, youthful, convincing even. I find myself wanting people to support her, to like her. And some do. The former soldier on Chaplet Avenue is a classic. He doesn't know I'm her husband. I'm just the hack with a notebook following the candidate and fishing for quotes. That's why he flirts when he declares: "I've been a Labour voter all my life. But not now. There are two things I really don't agree with. Releasing terrorists and the Scottish parliament. If you told me you'd abolish that ... thing ... I'd give you my vote now."

Crunch time. I know what Dot thinks - but it isn't policy any more. Tories are supposed to be contrite about their principled hostility to devolution. They are supposed to have learned the errors of their ways. And she has. She promises him leaflets, policy documents, but not abolition. He's flattered by the attention. He'll think about it.

We press on. Alan, the trainee agent, knows there's no point in long doorstep debates. He's efficient. Cover the ground, identify support, move on. And we do, in the shadow of the vast 60s high-rises, shabby monuments to the decades of social- engineering which have left Glasgow at the bottom of every league. Health? Employment? Education? Forget it. That stuff's only available in the west end. Even there they vote Labour - in case the neighbours find out.

Georgia remains an asset - but an increasingly impatient one. "Come on Mummy. Come on. Georgie no like it ..."

Mrs Miller on Archerhill Road is charmed. Candidate and child are invited in for a chat. She shouldn't accept. But Dot does. The poor dear obviously can't stand for long - and she might be worth a postal vote.

But it is cold. The rain is coming down in needles. And even here most people are at work in the middle of a November morning. So it's back to headquarters - a redundant travel-agency just off Anniesland Cross. It's like any temporary campaign office anywhere in Europe. Freezing, damp, shambolic and full of good humour, leaflets and trailing modem cables.

Dot is smiling for the troops. Her enthusiasm is infectious. The smile sincere not strained. I remember the policeman's cafeteria off Westminster Hall in the Palace of Westminster. It was the late summer of 1986. I'd have talked to Dot even if I'd known she was a Tory. But I didn't. She didn't look like the enemy. I thought she was an American intern. So did my colleagues.

I abandoned the security of the shadow cabinet table, the grotty Formica item at which those fortunate enough to work for shadow ministers (and thus to receive approximations of real salaries courtesy of the Rowntree Trust) had gathered. Her friend had gone. She had been looking back at me. It looked like a potential boy-girl thing to me.

And to Dot too. I offered her a cigarette. She lit mine. We've been inseparable ever since. Three children, a fourth on the way, time spent working in Washington DC, Jerusalem and eastern Europe. Washington was best - we could both support Bill Clinton.

But politics never threatened to come between us - even when, in 1987, we both fought parliamentary seats at the general election, me in Roxburgh and Berwickshire for Labour, Dot in Paisley South for the Conservatives. She invented a name so she could call my constituency office without attracting unwanted attention. I still think fondly of Anne Williams (her maiden name was Dorothy Anne Williamson).

She knew Donald Dewar. He used to visit us at home. Did he like her? Donald found women incomprehensible whatever their politics. He was no ruder to her than to any other female. And she has a lot of Labour friends, even Labour ex-boyfriends. One of them is quite famous now - but that would be telling.

Anniesland is not going to elect a Conservative. Not even the only Tory in Britain who drives a Lada Niva while listening to the Red Army choir on the stereo. Not even one who hates coffee mornings, who can't see why Tory activists spend so much time talking to each other and shielding themselves from the electorate, who hates racism, abhors prejudice, cares about women; a practical feminist who insists on chairman not chair, detests the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child and loathes politicians who criticise single mothers.

So why the dilemma now? Well, here she is fighting to obliterate the legacy of the man I worked for when I met her. The man whose job paid my half of the mortgage on the Brixton flat we lived in before we got married. The man I hurried to escape from every evening so I could meet her in the Vitello d'Oro restaurant behind Church House in Westminster.

Next morning it's back to The Boulevard. The Labour and nationalist candidates are getting all the press and Dot is angry. "Why won't they bloody listen? I'm fed up of apologising for John Major. Labour is the establishment here and establishments need a good shake-up."

On Pikeman Road there are faint murmurings of agreement. "This is a byelection. Who do we want to give a fright to this time?" asks the retired bloke outside number 59. As Georgia attacks the flowerbed with her Bob the Builder truck another constituent says, "I'll be voting Greenpeace." Her neighbour is even more disllusioned: "I'm no voting at all. It's all rubbish. I'm no voting for anybody." But number 17 is more encouraging. "I'm not right intae politics," he announces, "but Blair doesn't seem to have done anything. We need a change."

"Damn right," says Dot. "Why not give the girls a chance? Me and my colleague Kate Pickering [Conservative candidate for the Holyrood seat in Anniesland]. Try Girl Power for once."

Next door is a Donald Dewar fan: "I always voted for Mr Dewar." "I had a soft-spot for him too," says Dot. But Georgia needs a clean nappy. And there isn't time for a lot of personal history on the doorstep.

Can our marriage survive the Anniesland byelection? Definitely. Whenever we doubt it we just join hands and think of Anne Widdecombe.

 Tim Luckhurst is a former editor of the Scotsman. Between 1985 and 1988 he was parliamentary research assistant and press officer to the late Donald Dewar.

webTitle: Net news: MP3.com tries again

fields.headline: MP3 restart
fields.standfirst:
Chastened music site tries again

Net news
fields.trailText: Internet music provider MP3.com has sold Universal Music warrants to purchase up to 3m shares, giving the world's largest record company a potential stake of nearly 5% in the San Diego company.
fields.body:
Internet music provider MP3.com has sold Universal Music warrants to purchase up to 3m shares, giving the world's largest record company a potential stake of nearly 5% in the San Diego company.

The purchase price was not disclosed but sources said Universal paid $250,000. The move follows an order by a federal judge calling for MP3.com to pay $53.4m in damages to Universal to resolve a copyright infringement case. Universal is a unit of Canada's Seagram.

In connection with that settlement, Universal agreed to license its entire music catalogue - which includes Jimi Hendrix, U2 and rapper Eminem - to MP3.com's web-based service, My.MP3.com.

Under the warrant, MP3.com's chairman, Michael Robertson, said Universal had the right to buy up to 3m shares of MP3.com common stock at prices from $3.75 to $5 per share over terms of one to three years.

webTitle: Bubble bursts for Interactive Investor

fields.headline: Bubble bursts for Interactive Investor
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Interactive Investor International yesterday reported falling revenues and widening losses amid evidence that interest in online financial websites is subsiding.
fields.body:
Interactive Investor International yesterday reported falling revenues and widening losses amid evidence that interest in online financial websites is subsiding.

Turnover fell to £1.5m in the fourth quarter, ended September 30, from £1.8m in the previous quarter. Losses rose to £4m from £3.8m. Advertising revenue dropped by 22% while transaction-related revenue was down 13% on the previous quarter. Over the year, losses increased to £17.4m from £3.9m the year before.

Visits to the iii.com site leaped earlier this year but growth has tailed off. Average monthly page impressions rose from 9m in 1999 to an average of 42m in the third quarter, but dipped to 41m in the fourth.

The results are the first full year figures since Interactive floated in February.

Around 80,000 small investors applied for Interactive shares at the float price of 150p and at the end of its first day's trading it more than doubled to 335p, valuing the company at £550m. Yesterday its shares were trading at 39p, unchanged on the day.

Interactive says its aim now is to turn its 1.1m-strong user base into paying customers. Chief executive Tomas Carruthers said: "Interactive Investor is transforming itself from being an acquirer of traffic to facilitating transactions across many investment products from our site."

Interactive's results come a week after rival Exchange Holdings quit the business-to-consumer online finance market.

webTitle: In brief: Huston and Roberts for historical satire

fields.headline: Huston and Roberts for historical satire
fields.trailText: Plus: Michael Douglas and Billy Crystal in the running to co-star in comedy remake; Barry Sonnenfeld leaves Twisted direction to George Armitage; and M Night Shyamalan pleads for his latest ending to be kept secret
fields.body:
 Julia Roberts and Anjelica Huston are to team up to develop A Time to be Born for Revolution Studios. Huston will direct and Roberts will star in the film, adapted from Dawn Powell's scathing satire about society types in 1940s New York. Roberts will play a small-town girl who steals a wealthy press baron away from his wife and uses her discarded friends as a decoy for an illicit affair. A Time to be Born goes into production next spring.

 Michael Douglas and Billy Crystal are being courted by Warner Bros to star as squabbling in-laws in 'Til Death do Us Part. A comedy thriller, the film is a loose remake of the minor 1979 hit The In Laws, which featured Peter Falk and Alan Arkin as an odd couple pair of middle-aged men on the run from crooks in South America. The studio is hoping to fast-track the project in order to have it completed before the projected Screen Actors Guild and Writers Guild of America strikes next year.

 Men in Black director Barry Sonnenfeld will be handing the directing reins over to George Armitage on his new film, the Iranian-set heist flick Twisted. Instead, Sonnenfeld will produce the film with creative partner Barry Josephson and leave the early mornings to Armitage (best known as the director of Grosse Pointe Blank). The film tells the tale of a thief whose plan to nab the royal jewels in Iran is foiled by his double-crossing buddies.

 In the run up to the release of his new film, Unbreakable, director M Night Shyamalan has been pleading with the public not to give away the film's ending. Shyamalan, of course, built his reputation on the twist in the tale of his last picture, The Sixth Sense, and Unbreakable (again starring Bruce Willis) apparently has an equally audacious pay-off. For Shyamalan, it seems, revealing a film's ending is a moral transgression akin to mugging a pensioner or mistreating your pet. "The only person it hurts is the one you're talking to," he says. "It's a very unsatisfying thing to do and very unkind."

webTitle: Comment: They're all domed

fields.headline: They're all domed
fields.standfirst:
Plans to build a giant egg to house the opera are the final straw for long-suffering inhabitants

Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: I wonder if President Jiang Zemin is taking note of the final collapse of the pretence that the dome is a cultural triumph. I ask because he is sitting on a similar project ... a project also likely to be railroaded into being over the reasoned objections of people who do not have an eye on buying immortality at public expense.
fields.body:
I wonder if President Jiang Zemin is taking note of the final collapse of the pretence that the dome is a cultural triumph. I ask because he is sitting on a similar project, undertaken for similar, flawed reasons, a project also likely to be railroaded into being over the reasoned objections of people who do not have an eye on buying immortality at public expense. In Jiang Zemin's case, the project is a slightly dome-shaped opera house.

There is nothing wrong with grand cultural projects. On a good day they can speak both to imagination and cultural commitment. The problem with the dome - apart from its outrageous cost - was that it was not so much a grand cultural project as a wrapping for an empty box. True cultural projects start from the standpoint of the content, not of the wrapping around it. An opera house might be supposed to avoid such a trap, but only if it exists to embrace and support a vibrant opera tradition. The case of the proposed Beijing opera house, though, is just another example of gestural cultural politics.

The designated site (an empty space on the edge of Tiananmen Square, next to the hideously Stalinist Great Hall of the People and within sight of the crimson walls of the Forbidden City) was once reserved for a parliament -something China, it could be argued, needs rather more urgently than an opera house. But a parliament would clearly not be so much fun for the government.

A parliament might want to do something - pass laws, or complain about the Communist party's monopoly of power, perhaps. An opera house, at least, is unlikely to answer back.

So the idea of a parliament was quietly dropped and a competition was duly held for the opera house, though the British and the American architects' chances were diminished by Nato's unfortunate bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade. The final winner was a Frenchman, Paul Andreu, whose egg-shaped design was promptly criticised on all sides. But the opera house has channelled the resentment of the long suffering inhabitants of Beijing who have suffered the ruination of their city by men who destroyed the people's habitat in the name of the people.

Finally, faced with the opera house, they have said: "Enough". Ad hoc groups have sprung up to coordinate resistance; petitions have been signed. An unprece dented degree of public resistance has been mobilised.

Over the past 50 years, the government of the People's Republic of China has destroyed almost everything of cultural value in Beijing. It has taken what was the greatest walled city the world has ever known - a city that was the expression of a civilisation's cosmology and which contained all that was finest in its culture - and quite deliberately wrecked it.

Mao Zedong began the demolition, pulling down the memorial arches, then the magnificent walls, creating desolate boulevards, first for the wind to whistle down then for the traffic to snarl up in. Deng Xiaoping completed the devastation by fostering a deadly combination of greedy speculators and unscrupulous and corrupt officials who saw in Beijing only a chance to make illicit fortunes by building gimcrack plazas. Between them, they have erased one of the finest expressions of Chinese culture, shouting the while about the superiority of the civilisation they claimed to represent.

As to the living culture, the story is much the same. The intellectuals were persecuted for 40 years and now they are marginalised. Chinese opera was crushed in the disaster of the cultural revolution; now it is withering through neglect, as China junks her traditions in favour of the wholesale acquisition of the culture of global capitalism. If it is ever built, the giant egg will house a 2,500-seat opera house, a 2,000-seat concert hall, a 1,200-seat theatre and a smaller theatre with 520 seats.

But the splashier the building itself, the more evident it is that the cultural activity within is below par. Beijing's theatres are desperately underfunded and lacklustre. Its traditional opera is threadbare and it is no surprise that most of the population, educated by the same government to despise its own traditions, prefers televisions games shows.

The £200m that the theatre would cost, as anyone who is struggling in Beijing's cultural life will tell you, would be more productively spent on sponsoring new writing or even refurbishing the scores of existing Beijing theatres. So why, given the government's unequalled record of philistinism, this desire to spend a fortune on what would be one of the world's biggest theatre complexes?

It's partly a crude competition with Shanghai - which has spent lavishly on grand cultural projects. But it's also the desire to make a splash.

Having wrecked the existing culture, Jiang Zemin wants to buy something he can show off, perhaps to ensure that his obituary will honour him as a patron of the arts. The irony is that by persisting with his project, he may do more for the city than he intends - if only because the people of Beijing say no.

webTitle: China wants the car economy but not the fumes

fields.headline: China wants the car economy but not the fumes
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: Chinese leaders object to lectures about environmental pollution from high-consumption nations such as the US when a quarter of China's population still lives on less than $1 a day.
fields.body:
Chinese leaders object to lectures about environmental pollution from high-consumption nations such as the US when a quarter of China's population still lives on less than $1 a day.

Until recently, Beijing said that while the environment was important China must "put development first" and should be allowed more leeway in tackling pollution. Now, increasingly alarmed by visible signs of global warming, the Chinese say they place "equal stress on development and conservation".

But when economic interests are at stake will development really be throttled back for the sake of the environment? So far, in the critical case of the car industry, the answer remains ambiguous.

Environmental arguments have to contend with a pro-car culture among provincial elites which has grown stronger during the past 20 years of economic reform. New motorways are a symbol of that development even though they are seriously under-used - largely because tolls are too high or slower-moving transport is banned.

Most Chinese towns, even in rural areas, have been rebuilt with wide highways. The bicycle, once the symbol of Chinese self-sufficiency, is being pushed to the side of the road.

China's official environmental website highlights the contradiction. One headline calls for a "new goal for automobile pollution control"; the other says, "China must encourage the purchase of automobiles."

By 2005, China hopes to meet European emission levels seen in the late-1990s. By 2010, it hopes to catch up with international standards and that does not take into account rising vehicle numbers.

Here the Chinese state planning commission's policy is unambiguous: "The automobile industry is one of the five mainstays of China: the promotion of automobile purchase must be placed in first position."

Beijing reassures itself by pointing out that there are only 15m vehicles in China, compared with 70m-plus in the US. But the comparison is incomplete without considering respective emission levels.

More serious efforts are now being made to cut emission levels in the big cities which are most visibly affected by pollution - Beijing has banned a fleet of mini-taxis while Chengdu has just staged China's first car-free day.

Permissible emission levels have been loweredand, less specifically, the government is to "encourage" production and use of clean-fuelled vehicles.

The big question is whether these tougher rules will be effective outside the main cities.

The Beijing media has highlighted a campaign on the capital's outskirts to prevent "air-polluting vehicles" entering the city. Most offenders, it explained, "were coal-carrying trucks" hailing from neighbouring provinces - and if the trucks avoid Beijing they will not be taken off the road.

Economists want to increase private car ownership to stimulate consumption and boost the home-grown car industry. Domestic automobile output rose to 1.83m units last year from just 150,000 in 1978. But with annual production capacity at 2.4m units, there is a strong incentive to fill the gap.

At present, nearly two-thirds of vehicles are used commercially, including buses and trucks, while the 5.34m "private" cars usually belong to government bodies or firms.

But real private ownership is looming for China's expanding middle class. There is intense competition to make economy cars around the magic price of 100,000 yuan (£8,400) each. One in five urban families say they could and would afford such a car, prompting foreign carmakers to enter the fray: a process that will be helped along by China's entry into the World Trade Organisation.

webTitle: Bandit king frees Bollywood idol

fields.headline: Bandit king frees Bollywood idol
fields.standfirst: Curtain falls on saga that gripped India as kidnapper tires of his film star hostage
fields.trailText: Curtain falls on saga that gripped India as kidnapper tires of his film star hostage
fields.body:
India's most surreal hostage crisis ended with a suitably bizarre denouement last night when the jungle bandit Veerappan unexpectedly released his ageing movie star captive Rajkumar, with little to show for his efforts and amid claims that he had merely grown tired of the actor's company.

More than three months after marching him into the forest at gunpoint, the bandit set Rajkumar free late on Tuesday, despite the fact that none of his demands appear to have been met.

The move took India by surprise, provoked delirious scenes at the actor's home and drew thousands of fans on to the streets of his home city, Bangalore. He is expected to return there by helicopter later today.

After emerging from the Satyamangalam jungle, a dishevelled Rajkumar was taken to a safe house in nearby Bhavani, near Erode, in the state of Tamil Nadu, where he was checked by doctors and reunited with his family. "He is weak and emotionally drained but OK," one source said.

The family learned of his release in a phone call in the early hours of yesterday morning from a negotiating team which entered the forest to meet the bandit three days ago.

"The call came through at 12.30am. We were very very happy," B Raghunandan, a film director and friend of the family, said. "We immediately started partying. People were dancing and shouting. He has a very big family. Dr Rajkumar is in very good shape because of all the yoga he did in the jungle," he added.

Other family members gathered to celebrate again last night at the star's home which was decorated. Seasoned Veerappan watchers expressed bafflement at the timing of the release which came after India's supreme court had rejected his key demand - the release of 51 of his associates from prison.

The two states involved in trying to secure the actor's release, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu, had earlier approved the demand. They were castigated by the court last month for their incompetence and told to come up with an alternative rescue plan.

Sources said that a very large ransom had been paid. The money appears to have come from Rajkumar's family and the Karnataka film industry. Intriguingly, the sources added that the bandit had also grown "fed up" with the matinee idol after 108 days in his company.

"After three months they were tired of each other. The supreme court ruling meant Veerappan knew there was no point in prolonging the agony. The longer he left it the more likely it was that the commandos would come in and get him," one said.

Veerappan eventually released his hostage, not to RR Gopal, the assiduous magazine editor who had trekked out to see him five times, but to an extreme Tamil nationalist politician and Tamil Tiger sympathiser, P Nedumaran - suggesting that the bandit's future lies in politics.

Mr Nedumaran, who made one previous attempt to free Rajkumar, had made it clear that this was his last mission. In the end he did not have to do any negotiating.

India's prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, said he was delighted by the release. "It's marvellous he is out. These have been very anxious times. If anything had happened to Rajkumar, Karnataka would have burned," one source said.

Although a film loosely modelled on Veerappan's life, Jungle, is already playing in Indian cinemas, Bollywood directors were scrambling last night to be the first to make one based on the extraordinary Rajkumar saga.

Ever since Veerappan burst into Rajkumar's farmhouse in the Tamil Nadu village of Gajunur with his armed gang on July 30, India has been transfixed by the crisis. The actor, who suffers from high blood pressure and weak knees, was given an early indication that he could be away for some time when Veerappan - as he marched him out of the door - turned back and collected the star's reading glasses.

Since then things have got more surreal. Six weeks later 300 of Rajkumar's fans mounted a quixotic and unsuccessful attempt to penetrate the mountainous forest and rescue him. Two weeks later, one of three male relatives who was kidnapped by Veerappan at the same time managed to escape and hail a passing bus to freedom. On board he told passengers he had been attacked by a bear, fearing they would send him back into Veerappan's clutches.

Initial reports suggested that Rajkumar had been taken deep into the heart of the jungle, where Veerappan operates a series of well-hidden camps. In fact, for much of the time he was holed up close to the spot where he was seized.

When Veerappan last went on a kidnapping spree in 1997, he demanded an amnesty for the 138 murders he had carried out over a criminal career spanning two decades. His victims have included 32 policemen. He also asked that a film should be made of his life.

This time he asked for the statue of a Tamil poet to be erected in neighbouring Bangalore and demanded higher wages for Tamil tea plantation workers. Now the crisis is over, Veerappan is unlikely to emerge from the jungle where he has spent the last 15 years in hiding.

He is also wanted for slaughtering more than 3,000 elephants and presiding over a £15m smuggling empire in looted ivory and sandalwood. "We expect him to disappear for a while. But he is sure to be back," one source said last night.

webTitle: EU lifts travel ban on Milosevic allies

fields.headline: EU lifts travel ban on Milosevic allies
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The European Union has lifted a visa ban on Serbia's state security chief to reward him for refusing to defend the regime of Slobodan Milosevic, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The European Union has lifted a visa ban on Serbia's state security chief to reward him for refusing to defend the regime of Slobodan Milosevic, it emerged last night.

Diplomats confirmed that the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, asked for the removal of Rade Markovic's name from a large group of close Milosevic associates banned from travelling to the EU.

"Kostunica's people produced a long list of names they wanted removed," an official said.

Mr Markovic remains the state security chief.

Chris Patten, the EU's external relations commissioner, discussed the issue with the new Yugoslav leader in Belgrade earlier this month, EU sources confirmed, but they insisted that he had not initiated the move.

Addressing the European parliament in Strasbourg yesterday, Mr Kostunica appeared to want to avoid answering questions on the subject, saying only that he was against a visa ban in general. He was also vague on what to do with the former president.

webTitle: Bosnians turn a deaf ear to west's plea for change

fields.headline: Bosnians turn a deaf ear to west's plea for change
fields.trailText: Western policy in Bosnia has suffered a major blow with the election victory of Serb nationalists in one half of the country, and the better than expected showing of Croat and Muslim nationalists in the other half.
fields.body:
Western policy in Bosnia has suffered a major blow with the election victory of Serb nationalists in one half of the country, and the better than expected showing of Croat and Muslim nationalists in the other half.

The international high representative in Bosnia, the Austrian diplomat Wolfgang Petritsch, had urged voters in Saturday's general election to follow Croatia and Serbia in voting for change. With most of the votes counted, only the Bosnyaks - Bosnia's Muslims - appear to have even partly heeded his advice.

In Republika Srpska (RS), the Serb-controlled half of the country, the Serbian Democrat party (SDS), set up by Radovan Karadzic, now in hiding to avoid war-crimes charges, won 37.5% of the vote for the Bosnian Serb assembly, and 41% of the vote for the Serb seats in the national parliament.

Its presidential candidate, Mirko Sarovic, who was allegedly chosen by Mr Karadzic, defeated the man long supported by the west, Milorad Dodik, by 49% to 30%.

In Croatian areas, hardline nationalists from the HDZ, the Croatian Democratic Union, are in open confrontation with the office of the high representative. They organised their own referendum parallel to the official elections on Saturday, demanding a "third entity" for the Croats in Bosnia.

Despite declaring the referendum illegal, the authorities allowed it to go ahead. At present, Muslims and Croats live together in a single federation. "Change in Zagreb did not equal change among Bosnia's Croats," said James Lyon, director of the International Crisis Group, a respected non-governmental thinktank in Sarajevo. "Change in Belgrade did not equal change among Bosnia's Serbs. In fact, change in Belgrade may have emboldened Bosnia's Serbs."

He points out that the new Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, actively favoured the SDS in last weekend's vote.

The good showing of the SDS was probably also helped by widespread allegations of corruption against the current western backed prime minister, Milorad Dodik.

The vote has left the majority Bosnyak community in the weakest position because, unlike the Serbs and Croats, they split their vote almost equally between the nationalist Party of Democratic Action (SDA) and the multi-ethnic Social Democratic party (SDP).

The immediate reaction of international representatives in Bosnia has been to sound disappointed, and even retract some threats they had made if multi-ethnic parties were not chosen.

Mr Petritsch can be expected to continue to impose laws which the entity or national parliaments fail to agree on, using the powers vested in him by the Dayton peace agreement.

A more radical option would be to issue a tough wish list of long delayed laws which must be passed within a short time limit. Any party which opposed such laws would be banned - despite the popular support they clearly still retain.

A longer term solution, under discussion in some diplomatic circles, would be to re-draw the Dayton agreement altogether, abolish the two entities, and recreate a united, but decentralised Bosnia.

webTitle: Beware of 'ice bombs' from airliners, says MP

fields.headline: Beware of 'ice bombs' from airliners, says MP
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Ice bombs - frozen effluent falling from aeroplanes - will reach record levels this year, an MP warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Ice bombs - frozen effluent falling from aeroplanes - will reach record levels this year, an MP warned yesterday.

The Liberal Democrat MP Jenny Tonge is calling on the civil aviation authority to tighten safety procedures, claiming the bombs threaten public safety.

The authority recorded 36 incidents of frozen effluent from planes hitting the ground in the first 10 months of this year, Dr Tonge said. The record of 37 occurred in 1997. There were 21 other incidents of objects falling from planes.

Dr Tonge, whose Richmond constituency is underneath the flight path into Heathrow, said that in her area last year ice bombs had narrowly missed a primary school and a man walking home. In 1998 the body of a frozen stowaway had hit what was now a supermarket. This was despite CAA promises to tighten safety.

webTitle: Health advisers abandon confidentiality clause

fields.headline: Health advisers abandon confidentiality clause
fields.trailText: An embarrassing series of leaks has forced a key government health advisory body to abandon a confidentiality policy which attempted to keep secret interim decisions on whether the NHS should pay for new drugs.
fields.body:
An embarrassing series of leaks has forced a key government health advisory body to abandon a confidentiality policy which attempted to keep secret interim decisions on whether the NHS should pay for new drugs.

The national institute for clinical excellence (Nice) said its failure to prevent leaks, coupled with pressure from patient groups to make its decision-making process more open, has persuaded it to make public its "provisional" guidance on new health technologies.

Its current drug assessment procedures require interim decisions to be released for consultation to a relatively narrow group of interested parties such as patient lobby groups, health professionals and manufacturers.

The final decision on whether a drug should be made available on the NHS is made only after this confidential four week consultation period.

Nice introduced the confidentiality policy under pressure from the pharmaceutical industry, which was concerned that releasing interim decisions - which might change after consultation - could have a volatile effect on the value of pharmaceutical company shares.

It argues the interim decisions are effectively "price-sensitive" information. Without a confidentiality clause, it could trigger confusion on overseas markets which might not properly understand the nature of Nice's advice.

But Nice says the policy is unsustainable because it has proved impossible to prevent leaks related to high profile or controversial drugs such as taxanes, used to treat cancer, and beta interferon, used to treat multiple sclerosis.

Patient groups have lobbied for the "patronising" confidentiality policy to be dropped because it prevents patients and carers from commenting on the provisional advice while it is still at an emergent stage.

Nice chair Professor Sir Michael Rawlins said the confidentiality policy was unsustainable and not in the interests of either the institute or patients. "There are large numbers of people involved in the consultation process and whilst Nice can guarantee the integrity of its own processes, we can't control what others might do, therefore confidential documents have regularly been leaked," he said.

But the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry said it would forcibly oppose Nice's decision to drop the clause. It warned that if Nice goes ahead, drug companies might be put off launching new products in the UK.

webTitle: North Lakeland NHS trust: nurses raised alarm but trust failed to act

fields.headline: North Lakeland NHS trust: nurses raised alarm but trust failed to act
fields.standfirst: Investigators "deeply disturbed" by abuse
fields.trailText: Patients with mental health problems were subjected to "unprofessional, counter-therapeutic and degrading, even cruel practices" at the former Garlands hospital in Carlisle, says CHI report.
fields.body:
Patients with mental health problems were subjected to "unprofessional, counter-therapeutic and degrading, even cruel practices" at the former Garlands hospital in Carlisle run by Lakeland NHS trust, commission for health improvement (CHI) inspectors found.

The CHI report reveals that one patient was tied to a commode. Others were fed while on commodes. Some were denied food, clothing and blankets. The CHI's chief executive, Peter Homa, said that elderly patients at the hospital, run by the North Lakeland NHS trust, had suffered appalling abuse. "At the time of our visit to the trust, we could not be sure that it would not happen again," he said. "The culture of this organisation needs to change fundamentally, so that the rights of patients are understood right across the trust."

The alarm was first raised in May 1996 by five student nurses concerned about physical abuse of patients. They alleged patients were being tied to commodes, but the trust concluded that "departures from accepted good practice" had been made with "good intent".

In December 1998, two nurses made fresh allegations. The trust investigated the incidents but did not explore wider issues. Three staff were disciplined, one was sacked and one resigned.

In March this year, an external review panel found that degrading practices had been used by some staff and condoned by others. Yesterday's report said it was clear that if the trust had responded positively to the whistle-blowing students in 1996, further abuse might have been prevented.

The CHI investigators said they were "deeply disturbed" by comments by a consultant - named yesterday as Chris Hallewell - that he felt like a visitor on the ward. Dr Hallewell was responsible for patients who were abused in 1996 and 1998 but told investigators he did not know of the abuse. "The CHI is deeply disturbed by the consultant's lack of awareness and passive acceptance of being treated like a visitor on the ward where the abuse occurred.

"This reflects an inadequate sense of medical accountability in so senior a figure. That the consultant is also the associate medical director and has joint responsibility for clinical governance across the trust, compounds CHI's concern."

The trust's chairman, Mary Styth, the director of personnel, Catherine McCreadie, and the chief executive, Alan Place, have been sacked but have the right of appeal. Other managers have received disciplinary warnings.

webTitle: Medical crews to get new drugs

fields.headline: Medical crews to get new drugs
fields.trailText: Ministers will today authorise ambulance paramedics to use clot-busting drugs on heart attack victims before they reach hospital for treatment.
fields.body:
Ministers will today authorise ambulance paramedics to use clot-busting drugs on heart attack victims before they reach hospital for treatment.

Under present rules, thousands of lives are lost every year because heart patients do not get sufficient medical attention in time. Clot-busting drugs such as Streptokinase should be given within 60 minutes of calling for professional help, but this has happened in only one case in 10.

"By including Streptokinase in the range of drugs that paramedics can administer under their own initiative, patients will get thrombolysis, on average, an hour sooner than if they were taken to hospital first," the Department of Health said.

Other drugs to be added to the paramedics' medicine chest are Benzylpenicillin for suspected meningococcal septicaemia, Syntrometrine for bleeding after childbirth and Frusemide for fluid on the lungs.

webTitle: News in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Firefighters lose badges
fields.body:
Firefighters lose badges

Firefighters in Northumberland are to be stripped of their badges of rank to break down the service's "militaristic attitude". Only officers at emergencies will be allowed rank markings on their helmets.

No hope for £2m losers

A council worker arrested when colleagues called police after he said he had put on the wrong numbers when their syndicate's lottery numbers came up will not be charged. Camelot told police the sole winner, who claimed a £4m jackpot, had no links with Jimmy Robinson of St Helens.

Early Scots liked milk

Milk proteins retrieved from an Iron Age house at Cladh Hallan, South Uist, show dwellers on the Scottish Atlantic coast 2,500 years ago relied on dairy farming. Archaeologist Oliver Craig, who led the research, said the findings indicated an "intensive, sophisticated economy".

English No 1s unwelcome

A CD featuring England's 1966 World Cup winning side on the cover has been withdrawn from sale in Scotland. Warner Brothers plans a separate version of 60 Number Ones of the Sixties - The Ultimate 60s Collection - for Scottish shops.

£140m waste recycling drive

Ministers hope to create thousands of jobs with the launch yesterday of the Waste Resources Action Programme, which will receive £140m of government money over three years to recyle more of the country's waste.

Children defy Home Office

Three Chinese children who fled to Britain with their parents after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 have defied a Home Office order to report to Heathrow for deportation. Miao Hong Su, 16, and her brothers Jing, 14, and Zhao, 11, who went to school as normal in Manchester yesterday, have had applications for refugee status rejected.

Polyester smoke screen

People who want to avoid going home from pubs or bars smelling of cigarette smoke should wear polyester, say researchers. Tests in the US showed polyester absorbed up to four times less smoke than wool, cotton and linen. The findings are revealed in New Scientist.

Eat, drink and be healthy

Having a light snack and non-alcoholic drink before boarding a plane may reduce the risk of an in-flight heart attack, say researchers in Japan.

Archaeology award

Maev Kennedy, the Guardian arts and heritage correspondent, has won this year's British archaeological press award along with archaeologist and freelance journalist Mike Pitts for the best reporting on the subject and "the consistent high standard of articles they have written for the Guardian".

webTitle: Jimmy in Spanish slanging match

fields.headline: Jimmy in Spanish slanging match
fields.trailText: Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has claimed that Fernando Hierro does not deserve to be Spanish captain after the two players were sent off during Wednesday's friendly international in Seville.
fields.body:
Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has claimed that Fernando Hierro does not deserve to be Spanish captain after the two players were sent off during Wednesday's friendly international in Seville.

The pair squared up after Hasselbaink had equalised Hierro's opening goal in a game that ended in a 2-1 win for the visitors.

Hasselbaink, who played in Spain last year for Atletico Madrid, kicked out at Real Madrid's Hierro, who retaliated by appearing to aim a headbutt at his opponent and both were sent off.

"He doesn't deserve to be captain of a major side like Spain," the Chelsea striker then claimed.

"There was just a bit of pushing and then he gave me a bash. I've always said he was a great player as well."

Hierro declined to comment on the matter.

webTitle: I never agreed to treatment, says triplets case wife

fields.headline: I never agreed to treatment, says triplets case wife
fields.trailText: A couple making a compensation claim against a fertility clinic told a court yesterday of their shock and alarm when they discovered they were going to be the parents of triplets.
fields.body:
A couple making a compensation claim against a fertility clinic told a court yesterday of their shock and alarm when they discovered they were going to be the parents of triplets.

Patricia Thompson, whose breach of contract action in the high court is the first of its kind, described how her husband, Peter, went white when the news was broken to him.

Mrs Thompson, 34, also told Mr Justice Hooper, sitting in Sheffield, that the workload of dealing with three babies instead of the one for which she had taken a £1,600 IVF course had left her exhausted. She and her husband, who is 57, are seeking more than £100,000 damages from the private Sheffield Fertility Clinic.

The couple are able to sue for breach of contract rather than medical negligence because the clinic is a private, charitable business. Similar actions against the NHS would fail after a House of Lords ruling on the issue last year.

Mrs Thompson, whose claim is based on the cost of bringing up her unexpected children, said that she had never agreed to the implanting of three embryos when she took the Sheffield course in 1996. She told the court: "I just wanted two babies or one baby. I think two at once is enough for anyone to handle."

The court heard that the Thompsons had tried unsuccessfully to have children for five years, and had told the clinic that they would like the implanting of two embryos, from eggs taken from Mrs Thompson and fertilised by her husband's sperm.

Mrs Thompson said that she had taken sedatives before the 10-minute implanting, but then saw "three little brown blobs" on a monitoring screen. She told the judge: "I asked the nurse how many embryos she had put in and she said three. I said 'Oh.' It didn't sink in until later."

Mrs Thompson denied a suggestion from counsel for the clinic, Ronald Walker QC, that there had been a discussion before the treatment and that the doctor's advice "was to replace three embryos which you accepted". Mr Walker added that the three embryos had been clearly displayed by a microscopic camera before the implanting.

"It must have been obvious that these were the embryos to be replaced," he said. "You didn't say afterwards 'Why have you replaced three?' If you hadn't been expecting it why on earth didn't you say 'Why have you done that'?"

Mrs Thompson, who later conceived and gave birth to a fourth child naturally, said: "I didn't react immediately afterwards because it was a shock."

Mr Walker told the court that implanting three embryos to increase the chance of a conception was "a clinical judgment which cannot be impugned." Out of 350 women undergoing fertility treatment, 254 opted to have three embryos replaced and only one, Mrs Thompson, had had triplets.

The couple had turned down an offer to abort one of the foetuses on principle.

Peter Thompson, an engineer who has three children by a previous marriage, told the court: "When I heard that three embryos had been implanted, I felt a bit numb." He has given up work to help look after the children, after undergoing a heart bypass operation three years ago.

The case continues.

Mrs Thompson denied a suggestion from counsel for the clinic, Ronald Walker QC, that there had been a discussion before the treatment and that the doctor's advice "was to replace three embryos which you accepted". Mr Walker added that the three embryos had been clearly displayed by a microscopic camera before the implanting. "It must have been obvious that these were the embryos to be replaced," he said. "You didn't say afterwards 'Why have you replaced three?' If you hadn't been expecting it why on earth didn't you say 'Why have you done that'?" Mrs Thompson, who later conceived and gave birth to a fourth child naturally, said: "I didn't react immediately afterwards because it was a shock." Mr Walker told the court that implanting three embryos to increase the chance of a conception was "a clinical judgment which cannot be impugned." Out of 350 women undergoing fertility treatment, 254 opted to have three embryos replaced and only one, Mrs Thompson, had had triplets. The couple had turned down an offer to abort one of the foetuses on principle. Peter Thompson, an engineer who has three children by a previous marriage, told the court: "When I heard that three embryos had been implanted, I felt a bit numb." He has given up work to help look after the children, after undergoing a heart bypass operation three years ago. The case continues.

webTitle: Health benefits of seeing the funny side

fields.headline: Hearty laughter
fields.standfirst: Health benefits of seeing the funny side
fields.trailText: Health benefits of seeing the funny side.
fields.body:
Laughing at life is one of the best ways of guaranteeing it does not end prematurely, scientists said yesterday.

Researchers found that people who often laugh out loud and see the funny side of difficult situations are far less likely to have a heart attack than humourless individuals.

The study looked at the humour responses of 150 patients who had either suffered heart attacks or undergone treatment for blocked arteries.

They were compared with the responses of an identical number of age-matched healthy people who had no history of heart problems.

The results showed that the heart patients were 40% less likely than their healthy counterparts to laugh in a variety of common situations.

Michael Miller, director of the centre for preventive cardiology at the University of Maryland, Baltimore, who led the research, said: "The old axiom that laughter is the best medicine appears to hold true when it comes to protecting your heart."

The findings suggested that making oneself laugh when angry might offset the harmful effect of stress on arteries.

The team's findings were presented yesterday at the American Heart Association's annual scientific meeting in New Orleans.

Study participants were asked to answer multiple choice questions about how much, or how little, they would laugh in a variety of situations.

An example of one question was: "If you arrived at a party and found someone else wearing a piece of clothing identical to yours, would you (a) not find it particularly amusing, (b) be amused but not show it outwardly (c) smile, (d) laugh, (e) laugh heartily?

Each of the 21 questions had five answers. A total score was reached by adding the number of positive answers to each question. The highest possible score was 105, and the lowest 21. Overall, the study found that people with a humour score above 50 had a significantly reduced risk of heart disease.

webTitle: Elton John tells of his epic spending sprees

fields.headline: Elton John tells of his epic spending sprees
fields.standfirst: Singer admits to high court he frittered away £40m but says he had no interest in business and relied on his trusted friend of 25 years
fields.trailText: Singer admits to high court he frittered away £40m but says he had no interest in business and relied on his trusted friend of 25 years.
fields.body:
There have been bigger crowds and flashier venues, but the audience at the high court in London yesterday was as rapt as any Sir Elton John has faced in his 30-year career.

Taking the witness stand to give evidence in a multi-million pound action against his former management company, John Reid Enterprises Limited, and accountants PriceWaterhouseCoopers, Sir Elton treated press, public, lawyers and court officials to a tour of his lavish lifestyle and cavalier attitude to business.

The court heard of business meetings in St Tropez and Paris, Los Angeles and Atlanta, of million-pound overdrafts and of epic spending sprees.

Sir Elton, 53, is suing Andrew Haydon, 45, managing director of JREL, and PWC for negligence in managing his affairs.

He alleges that under a management agreement between himself and former close friend Mr Reid "several millions" in tour expenses should have been borne by JREL. Both defendants deny the allegations.

Between January 1996 and September 1997, following the signing of a £40m record deal with Polygram, Sir Elton "went spending mad". Mark Hapgood QC, appearing for PWC, put it to him that he had spent just under £30m at an average of £1.5m a month in that period. "Do you have any reason to think that innacurate?"

"Probably not, no," he said.

"It says here you spent £293,000 on flowers alone. Is that possible?"

"Yes, I like flowers," replied Sir Elton.

After hearing that he had spent an additional £9.6m on property in the same period, taking his spending towards the £40m mark the singer said: "I have no one to leave my money to, I am a single man, I like spending money."

Mr Hapgood said that following the spending spree Sir Elton realised he had run through his entire fee from Polygram and decided to try to claw back some of his costs from JREL, a claim the singer described as "nonsense".

"You can't say you felt bewildered in the summer of 1997," said Mr Hapgood.

"Yes I am, that's why the case is here"

Told again that he had spent the money, Sir Elton said: "Yes, but no one had told me ... I suspected I was being ripped off, I believe the expression is."

Sir Elton explained that his relationship with Mr Reid had begun in 1973 and for the next 25 years he had acted as his manager. They had enjoyed a personal relationship, a business relationship and finally a close friendship. They had much in common, including problems with drink and drugs and a short fuse. In 1992 Mr Reid became the sole benificiary of the singer's will.

The singer told the court that in the early 1980s Mr Reid had taken over all his business affairs and in 1984 they met in St Tropez to thrash out a new management agreement under which, Sir Elton said, Mr Reid would handle all his affairs and meet his costs in exchange for commission of 20% on all gross earnings, including publishing.

"It was an extremely generous agreement," he said.

"I wanted an uncomplicated life. You take care of everything," he said he told Mr Reid.

Sir Elton repeatedly said he had no interest in business and signed documents sent to him by Mr Reid without reading them first.

"I was never interested in business. I have a flair for writing, I have a flair for composing, but I don't have a flair for this," he said gesturing at 24 box files of legal documents alongside the witness box.

On his relationship with Mr Reid he said: "When you have a relationship with someone over 27 years who you trust implicitly, that is trust. We had been through a personal relationship, then a business relationship. He was my right arm, the business arm. I was the left arm. I produced the goods."

Earlier Sir Elton accepted Mr Hapgood's contention that "what you are trying to do is get back from the deep pockets of PWC some of your past generosity to Mr Reid."

webTitle: Broadcast round-up

fields.headline: Broadcast round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 17
fields.trailText: November 17: Channel 5 is planning a bid for the long-running ITV drama The Bill.
fields.body:
Channel 5 is planning a bid for long-running ITV drama The Bill when the contract for the show comes up for renewal next year. The police show is made by Pearson Television, which has already begun negotiations with ITV.

The BBC is to reposition BBC2 to target a 35 to 55-year-old audience to differentiate it from BBC1. Under the plans, BBC2's youth-targeted programmes would air on BBC3 once the new channel is launched.

Video-on-demand supplier Videonet is in talks with major UK broadcasters to launch a "best of British" service to showcase top British programmes. The company wants to form a joint-venture outfit with broadcasters including the BBC and Granada.

The second series of Big Brother will be broadcast on E4, Channel 4's digital entertainment channel, as well as on the main terrestrial channel. E4's digital capacity means the show could be broadcast using split-screen techniques, enabling viewers to see live footage on their TV screens.

Jeremy Thorpe, managing director of interactive services at NTL, is expected to leave the company after his brief, which includes the interactive content fund, was taken over by former Cable & Wireless head of content promotion Bill Goodland.

Channel 4 director of programmes Tim Gardam has said his top priority is to improve the channel's relationships with independent producers. Speaking at Channel 4's Pact open day, he expressed concern that Channel 4 could sometimes appear aloof and aggressive.

webTitle: Last cut is the deepest as Kevin's edit beats Kurt's

fields.headline: Last cut is the deepest as Kevin's edit beats Kurt's
fields.trailText: In what is being seen as an unprecedented example of star power, actors Kevin Costner and Kurt Russell were both given the chance of overseeing the "final cut" on their new movie, 3,000 Miles to Graceland
fields.body:
In what is being seen as an unprecedented example of star power, actors Kevin Costner and Kurt Russell were both given the chance of overseeing the "final cut" on their new movie, 3,000 Miles to Graceland. According to Inside.com, both actors were afforded the opportunity to edit the film as they saw fit and then the two contrasting versions were shown to a test-preview audience. The result? The Costner cut won by a mile.

Initially hired as the simple star of the film (a Pulp Fiction-style yarn about crooks who rob a Vegas casino during an Elvis convention), Costner wound up as arguably the last word on the finished product. A source close to the film insists that there was no unpleasant rivalry between the two actors, but that the versions each man submitted proved to be significantly distinct.

"Kevin's was more pure action," says the source. "Kurt's was more character-oriented." Having won over the popcorn brigade with his action edit, Costner will now see his cut released as the final print. The source reckons that the movie's humble director - first-time film-maker Denian Lichtenstein - has no problem with that. Not if he knows what's good for him, presumably.

This is not the first time that Costner has gatecrashed the editing suite after shooting his role. Hollywood gossip has it that he was a meddlesome presence during the editing of Robin Hood: Prince of Thieves where, worried about being upstaged, he allegedly juggled the edit to minimise Alan Rickman's barnstorming performance as the Sheriff of Nottingham.

Later, on Waterworld, he is rumoured to have ordered costly post-production to digitally "enhance" his thinning hair. With such a track record, one can only imagine the changes he may have made to 3,000 Miles to Graceland. Keep watch, perhaps, for a Kevin Costner spectacular, co-starring oodles of luxuriant hair and featuring a blink-and-you'll-miss-him cameo from Kurt Russell.

fields.headline: New Media Age round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: November 16.
fields.trailText: November 16: The wireless marketing industry is to get its first UK regulator.
fields.body:
The wireless marketing industry is to get its first UK regulator with the formation of the Wireless Marketing Association. The regulator is already compiling a code of practice.

Internet service providers may be forced to stop hosting controversial newsgroups as part of a series of proposals being considered by the industry regulator.

United News & Media's new media division, Xilerate, has taken a 46.5% stake in the clubbing start-up Spaced.

Dobedo editor Tamsin Bishton has resigned, saying that a series of redundancies last month were a direct result of management incompetence.

CNN.com Europe is launching an advertising campaign to challenge preconceived ideas about its American heritage.

T-Motion, Deutsche Telekom's mobile internet service provider, will launch in the UK next year.

Associated New Media has hired Stephen McDowell, editor of Interactive Investor International, to be editor of its personal finance site, This is Money.

The government has cleared M&C Saatchi of blame for the problems that have engulfed the Millennium Dome.

Wieden & Kennedy has created 19 Nike UK sponsorship credits for Sky Sports' daily breakfast show, Good Morning Sports Fans.

webTitle: Value of internet banner ads questioned

fields.headline: Value of internet banner ads questioned
fields.trailText: 11am: Companies that spend millions advertising their brands online could be wasting their money, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Companies that spend millions of pounds advertising their brands online could be wasting their money.

The effectiveness of internet banner advertising has fallen during the last year as web users have become increasingly ambivalent to poorly targeted ads.

These findings are published this week by Continental Research in its sixth annual internet report exploring internet usage in the UK.

More than 2000 respondents interviewed claimed to read or glance at only 12% of all banner ads they were exposed to, compared with 25% last year.

The research also showed that internet users may be learning to ignore banner ads altogether.

In 1998, 59% of internet users said they had clicked onto a banner ad that provided a link to the advertiser's own website.

That figure has dropped over the past two years to 40%.

The research also suggests that growth in internet take-up and usage has peaked, with expansion in both home and work internet growth showing signs of slowing down.

Only a 5% increase has been recorded since January this year in UK home access, a considerable slowdown in comparison to other years.

Continental research director Colin Shaddick said: "Clearly an innovation is needed in the marketplace to introduce the internet to other sections of society."
