webTitle: Damning reports expose hospital failings

fields.headline: Damning reports expose hospital failings
fields.standfirst: Take more heed of whistleblowers, says inspector
fields.trailText: Public faith in the NHS's ability to deliver good patient care and act swiftly to correct mistakes would be tested by damning reports exposing failings within two health trusts and a leading heart centre, doctors have warned.
fields.byline: James Meikle, Geoffrey Gibbs and David Ward
fields.body:
Public faith in the NHS's ability to deliver good patient care and act swiftly to correct mistakes would be tested by damning reports exposing failings within two health trusts and a leading heart centre, doctors have warned.

Surgeons, nurses and management were severely criticised after official investigations highlighted the need for hospital authorities to take more heed of whistleblowers.

The commission for health improvement, the government's new watchdog on standards, criticised North Lakeland NHS trust, where elderly mentally ill patients were tied to commodes, and Carmar- thenshire NHS trust, where a patient died after having the wrong kidney removed. An independent report commissioned by the NHS executive said the Oxford heart centre was "on its knees and riven by internal conflict".

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said the reports might leave the public "seriously concerned about the ability of the health service to deliver quality patient care, to learn from mistakes and to act swiftly when problems and concerns have been identified."

Abuse of patients could never be justified "but staffing shortages, excessive working hours and poor facilities can turn other, genuine, errors into tragedy". The NHS as a whole would continue to struggle until the effects of new investment were felt.

The Oxford inquiry, by a panel of experts in cardiothoracic services, highlighted staff reports of a "drinking club" culture within the centre, based at the John Radcliffe hospital, and found failures of leadership, antagonism between surgeons, difficulties in retaining nursing staff, complacency and secrecy.

The report, which made 34 recommendations, said a policy for treating whistleblowers seriously must be introduced. A senior nurse, Colette O'Keefe, who has been on sick leave for a year, alleged she and her children had been threatened after raising concerns about public care.

The health minister, John Denham, said the report "paints a picture of a dysfunctional team and, more than that, a failure to deal with problems when they were first raised". David Highton, chief executive of Oxford Radcliffe hospitals trust, said it would be "a catalyst for improvements".

Degrading practices at the Garlands hospital in Carlisle, administered by the North Lakeland NHS trust, might not have been repeated if whistleblowers among student nurses had been heeded in 1996, a CHI report concluded. Patients were sworn at, tied to commodes, and denied food, clothing and blankets.

The trust's chairwoman, Mary Styth, the chief executive, Alan Place, and the director of personnel, Catherine McCreadi, have been dismissed, and other senior management have received warnings.

Peter Homa, chief executive of the CHI, said: "The abuse of elderly people was appalling ... The culture of this organisation needs to change so that the rights of patients are understood across the trust."

Nigel Woodcook, acting chief executive for the trust, apologised to patients and their families for the "inexcusable mistreatment" and praised the courage of students and health care assistants who drew attention to it.

The CHI also criticised Carmarthenshire health trust for being slow to correct procedures following the death of a Korean war veteran, Graham Reeves, 70, of Burry Port, south Wales, who died at the Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli in February, after having his one healthy kidney removed by mistake.

It said the Prince Philip and West Wales general hospital in Carmarthen were stuggling to work as one organisation following a merger of the two trusts that ran them. Failure to share procedures in operating theatres posed "a significant risk", and the management of nurses was outdated. Three members of the surgical team that carried out the operation remain suspended pending displinary proceedings.

It said the Prince Philip and West Wales general hospital in Carmarthen were stuggling to work as one organisation following a merger of the two trusts that ran them. Failure to share procedures in operating theatres posed "a significant risk", and the management of nurses was outdated. Three members of the surgical team that carried out the operation remain suspended pending displinary proceedings.

webTitle: Carmarthenshire NHS trust: confusion remains after patient's death

fields.headline: Carmarthenshire NHS trust: confusion remains after patient's death
fields.standfirst: Trust should review practices and procedures
fields.trailText: Trust failed to act quickly to improve procedures after bungled surgery incident, says CHI report.
fields.body:
Graham Reeves, a 70-year-old veteran of the Korean war, died on March 1 this year, five weeks after what should have have been a routine operation to remove a diseased kidney.

Surgeons at the Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli, west Wales, were found to have removed the pensioner's one healthy kidney after allegedly failing to comply with established procedures.

In an official report yesterday, the Commission for Health Improvement said that Carmarthenshire NHS Trust, which runs the Llanelli hospital and the older West Wales general hospital in Carmarthen, had produced a comprehensive action plan in the aftermath of the tragedy.

But the plan had not been fully implemented and there was still confusion in the minds of some staff about the handling of critical incidents.

Separate investigations into the bungled operation have already been carried out by the Royal College of Surgeons and by the trust itself. Neither has been made public on the grounds that the inquest into Mr Reeves's death has yet to take place. Dyfed Powys police are continuing to investigate the incident.

The commission's chief executive, Peter Homa, said it could not be specific about the failures that led to Mr Reeves's death. But its report recommended that meetings should be arranged across the trust "as a matter of urgency" to ensure that common standards and practices are established for patients undergoing surgery.

It said the trust should review its method for marking x-rays to ensure a consistency of approach. It expressed concern that the action plan had not adopted the suggestion that an additional nurse should accompany patients to the operating theatre and provide a handover.

The report, which praises the enthusiasm and commitment of the trust's front line staff, found the two hospitals were struggling to work as one organisation. There was no overall programme for the continuous improvement of patient care.

The commission expressed particular concern at the trust's "outdated" way of managing nursing staff, its lack of a human resources director and its failure to share policies and procedures now in place in operating theatres at Prince Philip with its sister hospital in Carmarthen.

Mr Homa said these broader issues needed tackling urgently. "If the trust carries out all our recommendations, local people can again have confidence in the services it provides."

webTitle: X-Men 2 scheduled for summer 2002

fields.headline: X-Men 2 scheduled for summer 2002
fields.trailText: Director Bryan Singer slotted into place the final piece of the X-Men jigsaw, confirming that he would return to direct a sequel, tentatively scheduled for summer 2002
fields.body:
The final piece in the X-Men sequel jigsaw slotted into place this week as director Bryan Singer confirmed his availability for the second instalment in Fox's budding franchise. But now Fox have another problem: the congested work schedules of the principal cast now means that the film will not go into production until next autumn, with a release date tentatively set for summer 2002.

For anyone who saw the original X-Men, the news that a sequel is on the cards will come as no surprise (the film did not so much close with a bang as point the way towards a second chapter).

But the movie's runaway success has made Fox anxious to strike while the iron is hot. While the studio had locked the original stars (Hugh Jackman, Anna Paquin, Ian McKellen, Patrick Stewart, Famke Janssen and Halle Berry) into sequel deals, the participants are proving difficult to round up again. Victims of the film's success, their diaries are now full to bursting.

One of the year's biggest summer blockbusters, the original X-Men has so far made around $375m at the worldwide box-office. With Fox eager to capitalise on the film's success, there had been talk of a semi-official follow-up featuring just two or three of the X-Men being rushed into production.

Last night a Fox source moved to dampen down these rumours: "It's kind of a all-for-one and one-for-all situation at the moment. We don't want to create a spin-off from the movie, at least not yet. That's a possible long-term plan."

webTitle: Harrison attacker was not treated for schizophrenia

fields.headline: Harrison attacker was not treated for schizophrenia
fields.standfirst: Schizophrenia alarm bells ignored, court heard
fields.trailText: The man who tried to kill former beatle George Harrison was misdiagnosed by psychiatrists and failed to receive proper treatment for his schizophrenia, a court heard. Michael Abram, 34, was yesterday found not guilty of attempting to murder Harrison and his wife Olivia due to insanity. He was ordered to be detained indefinitely in a secure psychiatric hospital.
fields.body:
The man who tried to kill former beatle George Harrison was misdiagnosed by psychiatrists and failed to receive proper treatment for his schizophrenia, a court heard.

Michael Abram, 34, was yesterday found not guilty of attempting to murder Harrison and his wife Olivia due to insanity.

He was ordered to be detained indefinitely in a secure psychiatric hospital.

The pop star's son Dhani, speaking on behalf of the family, said that it was "tragic that anyone should suffer such a mental breakdown to commit such a brutal act."

Abram had set out to kill Mr Harrison because he believed the pop star was a witch who had possessed him.

Abram's mother Lynda said it was "appalling" that her son's schizophrenia had not been diagnosed. Calling for an inquiry she said: "All the alarm bells were ringing but they were dismissed."

Last night it was revealed that Abram wrote a letter of apology to the Harrison family. "I wish to say how sorry I am for the alarm, distress and injury that I have caused when I was ill," he wrote.

"I thought my delusions were real and that everything that I was experiencing was some kind of witchcraft."

Abram and his family had tried to get help for 10 years but psychiatrists believed his disturbed state stemmed from heroin abuse. Doctors now believe he was using the drug to try to suppress the symptoms of his illness. Only the month before the attack on December 30 last year he was admitted to hospital but released.

Consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr Philip Joseph said that the severity of Abram's illness appeared to have been missed. At the time of the attack he was legally insane.

Dhani, 22, speaking on the steps of the court, said: "The prospect of him being released into society is abhorrent to us and we hope that the authorities will act with the utmost responsibility in avoiding it in future and allow us to be consulted before reaching any conclusion."

The court had heard how Harrison, 57, and his 52-year-old wife had fought for their lives after finding the intruder, armed with a knife and a stone sword broken from a statue, in their gothic mansion in Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire.

Abram, believing he was on "a mission from God", stabbed the guitarist at least 10 times before battering him with a table lamp and threatening to kill Mrs Harrison with the flex. Harrison suffered a punctured lung and said that he thought he was going to die. Abram is now considered "stable" but will need treatment with drugs for the rest of his life.

webTitle: Broadcasters draw up guidelines for war zone journalists

fields.headline: Broadcasters draw up guidelines for war zone journalists
fields.trailText: 10.15am: Broadcasters have agreed guidelines to protect their reporters operating in war zones. Lisa O'Carroll reports.
fields.body:
The world's leading broadcasters today took steps to ensure the safety of journalists reporting from war zones.

BBC, ITN, CNN, Reuters and APTN have drawn up a series of guidelines that they hope will cut the number of deaths and injuries to reporters, both staff and freelance.

Richard Sambrook, deputy director of BBC News, said: "This agreement represents unprecedented co-operation between companies in broadcast news. Safety can never be a competitive issue."

The guidelines, announced at the Newsworld conference in Barcelona, will also cover the "fixers", interpreters and drivers used by all journalists in war zones.

Last May, Jeremy Bowen, the former BBC war correspondent, and a freelance Lebanese cameraman narrowly escaped death after their car was hit by an Israeli artillery shell.

Their driver Abed Taboush was killed and Mr Bowen, who now presents Breakfast News, and the BBC are considering court action in Israel.

Just two days later in Sierra Leone, veteran war correspondent Kurt Schork, who worked for Reuters, and cameraman Miguel Gil Moreno of the APTN agency were killed.

webTitle: Scoot.com in tie-up with French internet service

fields.headline: Scoot.com in tie-up with French internet service
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Online business directory Scoot.com has signed a lucrative deal with the French Vizzavi internet service, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Scoot.com, the online business directory, has signed a lucrative contract with the French Vizzavi internet service.

Under the deal, Scoot will become the official directory service for the multi-access site. Vizzavi is a joint venture between French media giant Vivendi and UK mobile phone company Vodafone.

Vivendi is the main shareholder in Scoot and has often been linked with a full takeover of the company.

Robert Bonnier, chief executive of Scoot, said: "Vizzavi is rapidly becoming Europe's most prominent multi-access portal with a prospective user base of more than 100m.

"As a result of this partnership, we anticipate that Scoot will generate a significant incremental amount of referral and transaction value in the future."

Meanwhile, Scoot said fourth quarter revenues had soared from £2m to £7.3m on the back of a 29% increase in subscriber figures.

However, it added that pre-tax losses had nearly doubled from £9.4m to £18.6m, with only £41m left in the company's coffers.

This was compounded by the full-year losses, which almost doubled from £21m to £38.5m due to the cost of expanding Scoot's European operations.

The market preferred to concentrate on the good news about Vizzavi and fourth quarter earnings, sending the shares up 1p to 86.5p.

webTitle: Heskey rises above the racists

fields.headline: Heskey rises above the racists
fields.trailText: England's young team showed no signs of an inferiority complex last night. Particularly commendable considering the racist taunts and hard man antics on display, writes Richard Williams.
fields.body:
It is tempting to write nothing about last night's meeting between Italy and England other than a description of the despicable racism of the Italian fans, a significant percentage of whom greeted every touch of the ball by Emile Heskey with a chorus of booing and monkey noises.

Two weeks ago, in Rome's Olympic stadium, in a league match between Lazio and Bologna, 20,000 or so of the home fans gave similar treatment to the visitors' three black players. Pierre Nlend Wome of Cameroon and the Brazilians Lima and Luis Oliveira seemed to shrivel under the hail of abuse, and no wonder. Last night it was the turn of the supporters of Juventus and Torino.

Heskey appeared to handle the provocation with admirable sang-froid, and it was a pity that he could not ram the Italians' jeers down their throats with a goal, although he came close. In terms of the football, a 1-0 victory for Italy was an accurate reflection of the play, although there was an irony in the fact that the winning goal came from a superb long shot by Gennaro Gattuso, whose primary function during the evening was to keep David Beckham quiet.

This was the fourth time Beckham had faced Italy, following the three games in 1997 - two World Cup qualifiers and the match in Le Tournoi. But it was the first time that he had been confronted by Gattuso, the 25-year-old hard man of the AC Milan midfield. "I'll bring all my meanness to the team," Gattuso had promised the Italian public on the eve of the fixture, his debut in a starting role. In Italy the former Glasgow Rangers man is known as "the warrior", and Giovanni Trapattoni had shrewdly raised his morale by letting him know that he had tried to buy him for Fiorentina a couple of years ago, only to be outbid by Milan.

The player Gattuso most resembles is Romeo Benetti, the Juventus and Italy midfield destroyer of the 1970s. Like Benetti, Gattuso can also play a bit. More than a bit, in fact, as he showed by his careful and shrewd use of the possession he won in the early stages of the game.

But Beckham was not to be easily subdued. A beautiful early chip to Nick Barmby was intercepted by Alessandro Nesta on the edge of the six-yard box, and an even better ball from his own half up the inside-right channel found Heskey, who took one touch, held off Nesta, and smashed a drive just over the bar.

Probably mindful of the significance of his armband, England's new captain chose to restrict the bulk of his activities to the area around the centre circle. But when he accepted the ball from Dyer just after the half-hour he looked up, measured the range, carried the ball a stride or two and then let fly with a dipping drive from 30 yards which had Gianluigi Buffon hurrying to slap the ball down at his left-hand post.

England's young team showed no signs of an inferiority complex when confronted by the team who were only a minute away from triumph in Euro 2000. There were occasional hesitations and misunderstandings, but there was also a willingness to put together neat moves based on short passes and good movement, although the small inaccuracies that plague English football at this level were sometimes costly, disrupting the flow of otherwise well conceived patterns. The work of Barmby and Kieron Dyer, at times linking with Gareth Barry on the left, would have given Sven-Goran Eriksson food for thought, and when Barmby sent Heskey charging down the left the Liverpool forward's surprisingly delicate low cross was only a foot away from enabling Ray Parlour to put England into the lead.

But when Buffon collected the ball and sent Italy back on the attack, a momentary lack of concentration in the England midfield allowed Gattuso to beat David James from 30 yards with a shot of which Beckham would have been envious. Unsurprisingly, Peter Taylor's men had finally been betrayed by their lack of international maturity. They, and he, deserve further chances to discover their potential for growth. The prospect of waiting until July for the new head coach's arrival may not mean the end of the world after all.

webTitle: Murdoch rethinks Sky float

fields.headline: Murdoch rethinks Sky float
fields.standfirst: Weak tech markets lead News Corp to consider alternatives to satellite assets listing
fields.trailText: 8am: Weak tech markets are forcing News Corporation to consider several alternatives to listing its satellite television assets on the stock market. By Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
News Corporation is considering several alternatives to listing its satellite television assets on the stock market - including a reverse takeover of Hughes Electronics, the US company controlled by General Motors.

The group headed by Rupert Murdoch has been forced by weak demand for technology shares to reassess plans for an initial public offering of Sky Global Network, estimated to be worth $40bn (£28bn).

It had intended to float the business, which includes British Sky Broadcasting, by the end of this year. That date has since been put back as far as next June.

Speaking in New York yesterday, Peter Chernin, the company's president, said: "We still think the IPO is the best option and it will be done by the first half of next year."

However, company executives privately admit they are looking at several options in the event of continued market weakness.

One of the most attractive is a plan to offer shares in its satellite operations to Hughes investors in a complicated share swap.

The details of such a reverse takeover are still sketchy, but are likely to involve strategic partners making a significant investment.

Mr Murdoch has made no secret of his desire to fold DirecTV, a Hughes company and the largest satellite broadcaster in the US, into Sky Global Networks.

His problem is that, without the money raised from an IPO, such a deal would be difficult to achieve.

GM, the motor group which owns 30% of Hughes, is likely to want cash for its stake

Analysts believe this has prompted News Corp to talk with investors including the software group Microsoft about making an investment of $1bn or more.

Several Hughes investors have indicated they would welcome a deal with News Corp. Larry Haverty at State Street Research said: "As shareholders of Hughes, we would run to own a company that includes DirecTV and BSkyB. And we wouldn't be alone."

Few on Wall Street expect any decision until next year because of political and economic uncertainties.

In comments made to investors in the Fox entertainment business yesterday, Mr Murdoch made it clear he intended to cut further the company's internet ambitions. "Until we see some profits we will be scaling back even more on the internet."

News Corp has already laid off editorial staff at its internet operations. Mr Murdoch mentioned with some satisfaction that, although he was criticised for his apparent mistrust of the internet a year ago, his tardiness meant that he had spent far less than his rivals.

He suggested that a subscription-based model was the only way to make money on the net but acknowledged that web surfers would not pay for news. News Corp's internet operations would continue, he said. "But we don't look at it as a profit centre or as a potential profit centre."

Asked whether he would consider buying some of the internet rivals trading at a fraction of their all-time highs, he said: "No, not yet."

Shares in Fox have been hit by signs of generally weaker advertising expenditure in the US. Mr Murdoch said the "disappearance of the bulk of dot.com advertising" combined with the amount spent by large firms in the past few months would mean a "softer" environment until next year.

Separately, Mr Murdoch staunchly defended the executive heading election coverage at Fox News - a cousin of George W Bush - from the suggestion of bias.

"We take very, very great care not to show partisanship in any way," he said.

webTitle: England: An Elegy by Roger Scruton

fields.headline: Scrutinising Scruton
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss on Roger Scruton's hymn to a time past, England: An Elegy
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: Stephen Moss on Roger Scruton's hymn to a time past, England: An Elegy
fields.body:
There was one important qualification to review Roger Scruton's England: An Elegy (Chatto and Windus, £16.99) - you had to be a man, preferably a middle-aged white man. It appears that only men of a certain age are permitted to pronounce on English history, character and culture.

As Nicholas Wroe noted in his profile of Scruton in the Guardian, the Tory philosopher has at times been a hate figure for the left. "His books have been unmercifully slaughtered by reviewers and his pronouncements on society mocked," said Wroe. "He is accused of being a grammar-school boy in thrall to the upper classes."

I looked forward to plenty of unmerciful slaughterings (incidentally, is it possible to be mercifully slaughtered?), but only Terry Eagleton in the Irish Times came up to scratch. Eagleton's first sentence showed the glint of his blade: "Few books are as odiously self-satisfied as this one." This was going to be bloody.

Eagleton allowed one note of mercy before the slaughtering: "This is a silly book rather than a stupid one. Some of its reflections, not least on English common law, are probing and suggestive, and Scruton himself is one of Britain's most brilliant philosophers." Then the punchline: "But the priggish, mawkish tone of this elegy suggests that he has now degenerated from Kant to cant."

The knockabout had a serious point: "The book either edits out uglier English realities or disingenously excuses them. Its vulgarly sentimental hymn to the English countryside, a land which may have been green but was rarely pleasant, is mostly silent on the dispossession and exploitation which made it the first capitalist rural set-up in world history."

James Wood in the London Evening Standard was almost as dismissive, and also began with an arresting, almost novelistic opening sentence: "There is always a danger of confusing one's childhood with the universe."

Where Eagleton wielded a machete, Wood skewered Scruton with an elegant dagger. "Scruton's vision of England mixes Burke's conservatism (in which a proper society honours both the dead and the unborn) with Orwell's quiet patriotism. But he lacks the eloquence of the former and the precision of the latter. Instead, his intellectual tone is closer to the windy popular travel books of the 1930s, by writers like HV Morton, which went 'in search of the English'.

"What dismays is the utter conventionality of what Scruton loves: he laments the passing of the country house, the death of the hedgerow, the debunking of empire by left-wing academics, the killing of the grammar schools, the fading relevance of the Church of England, the demise of the idea of the English gentleman and the hereditary principle. It is not that what Scruton writes is necessarily untrue, though his generalities unman verification; it is that what he writes is too true, is bloated on truism ... So in a curious paradox, the book which so praises English individuality entirely lacks it." A clever putdown.

Blake Morrison, in the Independent on Sunday, used neither machete nor dagger, but sought to kill the book by irony. It was a wickedly effective weapon. "If there was a kinder, wiser, more equable place than Old England, he [Scruton] can't think of it. And if a people ever matched the English for 'their stoicism, their decorum, their honesty, their gentleness and their sexual puritanism', he hasn't met them."

Surely the Sunday Telegraph would gallop to Scruton's aid. Sadly not. Alasdair Palmer was neither entertained by the prose nor convinced by the polemic. "Scruton's philosophical analysis of England is in fact very un-English. In its determined ponderousness, its true homeland is not England, but Germany. We get an Hegelian analysis of cricket and of public schools - something which no Englishman who had participated in either would ever be tempted to formulate."

Parts of Scruton's book - the better parts, many thought - are autobiographical, and Palmer got personal at the end of his review. "Just about everything that Dr Scruton values about his own life derives from the changes he excoriates as having killed off England. It would be too much to expect a Germanic philosopher to be grateful for that. But you might expect an Englishman to notice it." Ouch.

There was some respite for the harried Hegelian in previously hostile territory - the Guardian. "Scruton, who is a huntsman and Tory philosopher, and runs an austere 'experimental farm' in the hard, dry soil of northern Wiltshire, has written a defence, of some elegance and sophistication, of the crustiest version of Englishness imaginable," wrote Andy Beckett.

Beckett admired the style and passion, and enjoyed the biographical bits, but he too found the argument unfocused: "This story has some of the moral momentum and intensity of a Victorian novel," he wrote. "Around his grainy memories, Scruton arranges essays about the educational, legal and geographical structures that bred his favourite sort of Englishness in others. These sections are less successful. Over-familiar assertions of national uniqueness ... replace the usual Scruton logic and economy of expression."

Scruton did have one supporter, again an unlikely one - the Labour peer, Lord (aka Melvyn) Bragg, in the Independent. "This is an elegant and moving book. It will be read by those whose affection for Roger Scruton's England has survived the disparaging assaults of the last few decades. It deserves to be read by those who have often led the half-baked attack on this particular view of England. Scruton's England, apart from its final over-compressed, over-simplified chapter, is a classic elegy: biased, selective and resonant, done with that passionate regret which can seed re-emergence."

A romantic Tory vision rejected by the Telegraph and embraced by the artistic arm of New Labour: we live in confusing times. Now let's hear from a few non-male, non-white, non-Oxbridgeans. There are, apparently, one or two such people in England.

webTitle: Gore peace offer to end stand-off

fields.headline: Gore peace offer to end stand-off
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: Gore seizes on morale-boosting legal win to bid for political high ground
fields.byline: Michael Ellison in Tallahassee and Martin Kettle  in Washington
fields.body:
Al Gore last night seized on a morale-boosting legal win in the Florida courts to make a bid for the political high ground in the stand-off over the result of the US presidential election.

Mr Gore called for a one-on-one meeting with his opponent George W Bush "not to negotiate but to improve the tone of our dialogue in America" while hand recounts continue in any Florida counties which wish to hold them.

"We should both call on all of our supporters to respect the outcome of this election, whatever it may be. We should both call on all our supporters to prepare themselves to close ranks as Americans and unite the country behind the winner as soon as this process is completed," Mr Gore said.

It was not immediately clear how Mr Bush would respond.

Mr Gore's attempt to inject statesmanship into his challenge to the Florida election results followed new moves by the Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris, a Republican, to stop the recounts and lock all outstanding post-election law suits into one court action in Tallahassee. But the Florida supreme court threw out Ms Harris's petition within hours of receiving it, allowing the counts to continue.

The decision kept open Mr Gore's chance of emerging on top in the post-election dispute.

Eight days after 100m Americans cast the votes that have divided the nation, the judges were asked to rule between two apparently tie-breaking motions from the Bush and Gore campaigns.

Warren Christopher, the emissary to Al Gore, countered with a proposal that the Florida supreme court should rule instead on whether recounting by hand is constitutional, set a deadline and fix standards for legitimate votes.

All the evidence suggests that Mr Gore is picking up more votes with each recount, even though he is still 300 behind Mr Bush, according to totals released on Tuesday.

The recounts might not be finished for several more days and there was no immediate indication of how long the state supreme court might take to arrive at a conclusion.

Referring to the Republican request to the supreme court, Mr Christopher said yesterday: "The effect of this proposal would be to delay again the date to resolve the wishes of the people of this state. All of us want to have a full, fair and accurate count of the votes in Florida."

And Ms Harris declared in papers filed with the state supreme court: "Without question, the court must make clear that the election of the president and vice-president is not a matter of local pleasure."

As the legal battle grew more intense in Tallahassee, officials in two of Florida's largest and most heavily Democratic counties continued to defy Republican attempts to close down manual recount efforts that could ultimately hand the White House to Mr Gore.

Broward county reversed an earlier decision not to hold a hand recount and began tallying the 560,000 votes cast there on November 7. Officials estimated the recount would be finished on Monday.

Meanwhile Palm Beach county also got started on a manual recount of its 420,000 votes after a court told officials that they could include the unbroken "dimpled chad" ballot papers in their efforts.

Both counties were intending to comply with Ms Harris's call for them to submit reasons to her by 2pm yesterday explaining why they needed to carry on with recounts. A judge in Tallahassee ruled on Tuesday that Ms Harris has discretion to accept the results of such recounts.

But Florida's largest county, Miami-Dade, decided against a hand recount after a sample exercise showed just six more votes for Mr Gore.

In Atlanta, Bush supporters also lodged an appeal against Monday's decision by a Miami-based federal judge not to intervene to stop hand counts.

As the legal moves multiplied in Florida, a key deadline approached for any attempt by Mr Bush to reopen the results of voting in Iowa, a state which Mr Gore won by just over 4,000 votes last week.

Mr Bush has until 5pm today to ask for a recount. If he does not, the outcome of the election will rest on decisions in Florida.

Officials in Florida announced yesterday that they had so far logged the receipt of 447 overseas postal votes sent in by members of the US armed forces. The deadline for the receipt of all overseas postal votes - of which the military votes are a part - is midnight tomorrow. The totals including these votes are to be announced on Saturday.

webTitle: When the NHS falters it is best for the truth to come out

fields.headline: When the NHS falters it is best for the truth to come out
fields.trailText: Comment
fields.body:
The trio of reports documenting serious failings in the health service yesterday is not entirely bad news. It signals more openness in what has too long been a stealth service. Each report is alarming reading: a Carlisle hospital for elderly mentally-ill patients with "a shocking culture of cruelty"; a Welsh hospital where a man died after his one healthy kidney was removed; a heart unit in one of Britain's most famous hospitals, Oxford's John Radcliffe, "on its knees and riven by internal conflict". Even the BMA did not try to gloss over their seriousness. "Today's reports paint a picture of an NHS in trouble and under pressure," it said. "It could leave the public seriously concerned about the ability of the health service to deliver quality patient care, to learn from mistakes and to act swiftly when problems and concerns have been identified."

Perverse though it may seem, yesterday's reports are an advance. Four years ago, five student nurses blew the whistle on Carlisle's unacceptable procedures including tying patients to commodes. There was an inquiry, but nothing happened. The students' complaints were "lost". Nothing emerged publicly. All that has changed. Even before yesterday's report, the trust chairman had been dismissed, the chief executive suspended pending disciplinary hearings, senior managers warned. Similarly, Oxford's warring heart surgeons only came to light because a senior clinical nurse complained. She suffered severe harassment and an unacceptable two-year wait, but she finally succeeded.

What does emerge is that whistleblowers still need more protection; that hospital authorities need to move more quickly (10 months on in Wales the action plan is still not in place); and less obviously, that care needs to be taken in deploying the new health watchdog, the commission for health improvement. Using it in Wales made sense. It looked at wider issues than a single death. It might have made sense to use it in Oxford too, but that did not happen. But the CHI should not have been sent to Carlisle, where there had already been an external review. This was a diversion to deflect any political heat from ministers. The CHI is not a hit squad. It is a crucial monitoring unit, with a remit to visit every hospital and GP practice within the next four years. To raise standards, it needs their trust. Set up a separate hit squad if necessary, but the CHI's prime purpose must be protected.

webTitle: Government to back Rogers' regeneration blueprint

fields.headline: Government to back Rogers' regeneration blueprint
fields.standfirst: 'Bulk"of urban task force ideas will be adopted in white paper
fields.trailText: The urban white paper published today will draw heavily on architect Lord Rogers' ideas to revitalise inner cities.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, chief political correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
The urban white paper published today will draw heavily on architect Lord Rogers' ideas to revitalise inner cities.

Taken alongside measures designed to stimulate inner city regeneration, announced by chancellor Gordon Brown in the pre-budget report last week, it means the vast bulk of the proposals laid out in his Urban Task Force 18 months ago are expected to be adopted as official government policy.

Rogers has faced frustration at the slow progress of urban policy as through Whitehall, and he is eager to put his plans into action, starting with the resdesign of London with mayor Ken Livingstone.

Rogers says: "Vast areas of our cities are really crumbling in terms of sustainable development and vitality. We have to attract people back into the city and end the so-called doughnut effect wherby everyone gets out of the city and into the suburbs. We have to find ways to reuse the land that has already been used, the so-called brownfield sites.

"The most frightening thing about going to Copenhagen or Barcelona is the difference in the quality of the street - the whole public domain. The whole physical environment ranging from the quality of design, safety or cycle ways is just years ahead of us".

And he remains daunted by the lack of architectural design skills in this country, an issue Mr Prescott will address through a proposed new national design school.

Rogers admits to disappointment at the chancellor's decision not adopt his proposal for the harmonisation of VAT on the development of greenfield and brownfield sites. Rogers refuses to predict whether the absence of this measure will mean the government will not reach its key strategic target of 60% new build on brownfield sites. He prefers to concentrate on how much the government has accepted the urban task force's agenda.

Rogers' adviser Tony Travers said: "Defining the derelict zones will be important. It will have to avoid the problem of going for Manchester and picking up Didsbury."

Rogers added: "It is also critical we have incentives to remove the deterrents from developers improving contaminated land." He also predicts that the proposal to offer 100% capital relief for the costs of converting redundant space over shops into flats for letting will mark a real shift.

Rogers and Travers end by calling for a single minister to thread this altogether and retain the sense of urgency.

Travers intercedes: "Richard cannot say this, but I can. We all know there is a powerful rural lobby and it has very useful allies in the Lords. There is no urban lobby in the same way. We need a Council for the Protection of Urban Britain."

webTitle: All bodies recovered from disaster tunnel

fields.headline: All bodies recovered from disaster tunnel
fields.standfirst: More about the tunnel tragedy
fields.trailText: Emergency workers in Austria yesterday completed the traumatic operation of extracting the bodies of 155 passengers killed on Saturday after fire engulfed an Alpine train in a tunnel.
fields.body:
Emergency workers in Austria yesterday completed the traumatic operation of extracting the bodies of 155 passengers killed on Saturday after fire engulfed an Alpine train in a tunnel.

Police said they had uncovered 152 corpses in the two-mile mountain tunnel, many of which had melted together in 1,000C-plus heat. Three more were found near the uphill station. The charred remains have been flown to Salzburg for identification.

The accident happened on Saturday morning near the small town of Kaprun in south-west Austria when the fuel-less aluminium train entered the tunnel near the Kitzsteinhorn glacier. Only a dozen people escaped.

Experts are focusing on evidence that the train may have had a technical defect but have yet to discuss their tests on a lubricant found on the track.

Eye-witnesses reported hearing two explosions and seeing a cable snap. A woman who travelled on a train car directly before the one that caught fire, said it had stopped briefly in the tunnel, and heard knocking "like a hammer on a pipe".

The death toll fell yesterday after police traced a suspected victim, a US citizen who had failed to return to a ski shop with his hired snow-board.

The train's manufacturers told a press conference yesterday that the train had received a technical and electrical overhaul in 1994, but its chassis did date back to 1974.

Only a dozen people escaped. Experts are focusing on evidence that the train may have had a technical defect but have yet to discuss their tests on a lubricant found on the track. Eye-witnesses reported hearing two explosions and seeing a cable snap. A woman who travelled on a train car directly before the one that caught fire, said it had stopped briefly in the tunnel, and heard knocking "like a hammer on a pipe". The death toll fell yesterday after police traced a suspected victim, a US citizen who had failed to return to a ski shop with his hired snow-board. The train's manufacturers told a press conference yesterday that the train had received a technical and electrical overhaul in 1994, but its chassis did date back to 1974.

webTitle: Telewest losses deepen

fields.headline: Digital delays push up Telewest losses
fields.trailText: 10am: Telewest Communications has followed the trend in the cable and digital TV sector by sinking further into the red, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Telewest Communications has followed the trend in the cable and digital TV sector by sinking further into the red.

The UK's second largest cable company said it had been hit by a shortage of digital TV equipment, which delayed sales to customers and prompted a new sales campaign last month.

Telewest said its third quarter losses leapt from £104.8m to £178.3, although sales for the period climbed from £196.1m to £279.9m.

The nine-month figures to September also made gloomy reading, with the loss of £478.2m widening from £465.6m and coming in at the lower end of analysts' expectations.

However, Adam Singer, chief executive of Telewest, was upbeat. He said: "Telewest is back on track to reap the benefits of the digital age. Our current trading demonstrates that we are once again making rapid progress in all areas of our business."

Telewest remains far behind BSkyB in the battle for digital subscribers, with 315,000 customers compared to Sky's 4m.

But it is not alone in reporting increased losses, as the likes of Sky and close rival NTL have thrown financial caution to the wind in the chase for customers and network expansion.

The recent acquisition of cable operator Eurobell from Deutsche Telekom has extended the company's reach in southern England, and it aims to have 500,000 subscribers by early next year.

The company's ploys for attracting customers have included high-speed internet access, but speculation continues that a merger with NTL would be the best way to challenge Sky.

Telewest's major shareholders include US computer goliath Microsoft and Liberty Media Group, which has a stake in Rupert Murdoch's Sky Global Networks company.

webTitle: Sony renews Uefa Champions League deal

fields.headline: PlayStation2 idents spearhead Sony's soccer spots
fields.trailText: 9am:Sony is renewing its Champions League sponsorship with a series of idents for its PlayStation2 console. Jade Garrett reports.
fields.body:
Sony is renewing its sponsorship of the Uefa Champions League with a series of idents for its PlayStation2 console.

TBWA, Sony's ad agency, has created eight spots due to break on ITV later this month.

Entitled 'Pilgrimage', the bumpers depict a footballing equivalent of 'The Third Place' - a reference only the PlayStation2 fan will relate to.

The same theme runs heavily through PlayStation2's TV campaign, which has been shot by Hollywood director David Lynch and hits screens later this month.

Viewers will see the surreal image of a luminescent blue football pitch surrounded by a seemingly limitless desert. Groups of people and a dog are drawn in as if to a religious place. This represents their experience of 'The Third Place'.

There is no clear explanation of the story or its meaning leaving much to the imagination of the viewer.

PlayStation's European marketing director, David Patton, said: "The break bumpers complement the PlayStation2 ad campaign and aim to create an affinity between the powerful experience shared by PlayStation users and football fans.

"This is football fanaticism in 'The Third Place'. PlayStation believes in indulging in powerful experiences - like the passion for football. The break bumpers aim to reflect this."

The idents were art directed by Gavin McGrath, written by Pat Burns and directed by Stuart Douglas with FourHundred Films.

webTitle: Rivals in RIM takeover refuse to bid by auction

fields.headline: Rivals in RIM takeover refuse to bid by auction
fields.trailText: 8.45am: Regional Independent Media's attempt to draw rival bidders into an auction looks set to fail, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
The gang of three bidding for Regional Independent Media is refusing to be drawn into an auction for the newspaper group.

RIM, which publishes the Yorkshire Post, has refused to accept a bid from Gannett, because the US publishing giant intends to share the spoils with rival publishers Johnston Press and the Guardian Media Group.

But sources close to the consortium said they will not be drawn into an auction which will push RIM's price tag above £600m .

"RIM really want to force the group into an auction in order to push the price up. The group will not be forced into a whirlwind bidding war, as that would put a financial millstone around their necks," said one source.

The source also scoffed at talk of a £700m asking price for the group, adding the figure suggested by most industry observers is much lower.

RIM was said to have received a rival bid from Fairfax, an Australian publishing firm, but the offer never materialised and there have been no other approaches.

A spokesperson for RIM said the company is willing to talk to Gannett, but not if it is part of a consortium.

A continued Mexican stand-off will frustrate RIM's venture capitalist owner, Candover, as it will look for a quick return on its £360m investment.

Candover bought RIM from United News & Media in 1998, and most investment firms try to make a profit on their stakes two years after any acquisition.

webTitle: Clean-up begins for flood victims

fields.headline: Clean-up begins for flood victims
fields.standfirst:
Insurance payout expected to reach £1m for one housing estate alone as homeowners wait for Ouse to recede
Special report: weather watch
fields.trailText: The floods have started to retreat at last, but a fresh tide has washed through the village of Barlby on the banks of the temporary lake which was once the river Ouse in North Yorkshire.
fields.body:
The floods have started to retreat at last, but a fresh tide has washed through the village of Barlby on the banks of the temporary lake which was once the river Ouse in North Yorkshire.

Sodden sofas, short-circuited lawnmowers and whole shelves of waterlogged, swollen books fill gardens of a housing estate built by Wain Homes developers along Woodlands Close.

"I think the names Barlby and Wain Homes ring every bell in England now," said Gavin Watt dolefully, lobbing his family's stereo on to a dank pile - "everything we had on the ground floor" - in a skip. "No one's likely to be selling or buying houses round here for a while, I wouldn't think."

The picture is a familiar one across swaths of Yorkshire, Cheshire, Gloucester and West Sussex. Lakes still lie where fields once thrived, roads used for pleasant country drives and commuting remain impassable either due to water or to the debris of the great floods. Life has been turned on its head.

Many residents in the stricken areas can only look on and wait for the waters to recede before they can start the depressing task of reclaiming their homes and businesses.

In Barlby things are slightly better - but not much. Across the street from Woodlands Close a detached house with drawn curtains and a still-visible tidemark was just about to change hands, when the water circled round from the Ouse and poured in both back and front doors.

"The timing couldn't have been crueller," said another neighbour, humping a dehumidifier up the neat street, where Simon Brooks was brushing ornamental pebbles back into his front garden.

A financial services executive in York, Mr Brooks has reflected several times on the name of his six-year-old home, Ouse House, and the fact, which he and his wife had not noticed before, that it stands a couple of feet higher than most of the road.

"That didn't save our hall carpet," he said. "But we have got off lightly compared to the neighbours. Everyone is mucking in and helping - it's a friendly street - but some of the damage has been terrible."

Next door to the Watts, where Gavin was hauling a three piece suite and drenched comics into the skip, some £14,000 of damage has been done to the ground floor. Whistles and hammering from a building firm - all the way from Hull because of the huge demand locally - alternated with the sound of skirting boards and kitchen units joining a growing pile on the lawn.

Mr Watt, who works in a food company in Pontefract, is happy with his insurance settlement, which includes three months rent of another house and the value of everything except the top kitchen units.

"I'm a bit sorry about that," he said. "The top units weren't damaged but they matched the others so we will have to replace them. When it comes to selling one day, no one is going to want hybrid units in the kitchen, are they?"

On the Wain Homes estate in Barlby alone, the damage is expected to edge over £1m by the time children's videos, fridges and even a frost-damaged rubber plant exiled on to a lawn, are added to more serious structural costs and bills for temporary housing. Meanwhile, the Ouse lake, bigger than Windermere at its height, stays stubbornly on the surface of thousands of acres of farmland, in spite of dry weather and heavy duty pumps from Holland.

Waterlogged soils will mean only a gradual soakaway according to the environment agency, which is gradually scaling down its emergency operation on the Ouse and 12 other rivers which have seen significant floods in the past three weeks. Sandbags will remain temporarily on defences like the Barlby dyke, the collapse of which would have seen Woodlands Close with water up to the first floors.

webTitle: Paul Whitehouse show

fields.headline: BBC star Whitehouse signs to Sky
fields.trailText: 8.15am: Fast Show Creator is taking his Ron Manager character to Sky One in a £1m-plus deal, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The BBC obviously didn't suit Paul Whitehouse.

For the Fast Show creator and star is taking the characters he developed for the hit BBC2 sitcom off to satellite TV in a £1m-plus commission.

The offbeat comedian and his Fast Show co-stars, Mark Williams and Simon Day, are going to host a spoof quiz show on Sky One billed as "A Question of Sport on acid".

In Jumpers for Goalposts, Mr Whitehouse' Ron Manager will dispense his inimitable football wisdom over 13 weeks as captain of a panel of sporting and celebrity guests.

And in place of Question of Sport host Sue Barker will be Simon Day who has modelled his character, Tommy Stein, on the BBC sports presenter Steve Rider.

Mr Whitehouse's decision to take the show to Sky is being seen as yet another blow to the BBC. The corporation recently lost Ant and Dec to the BBC and earlier this year watched Harry Enfield take his new characters to Sky One.

Sky said it was the "natural" home for Mr Whitehouse's idea for a comedy quiz show. "Because we offer the best in football and entertainment, we were the obvious choice," said a spokesman.

The deal is not exclusive, however, and Mr Whitehouse is currently filming a new 40-something sitcom, Happiness, for the BBC.

Mr Whitehouse said: "Jumpers for Goalposts is a simple fun football quiz for small girls, small boys, large girls, large boys. We have to keep it simple because we have footballers and celebrities as guests so the questions can't be too hard, can they?"

The show is being produced by Chrysalis TV, which make Channel 4's Italian football series and Formula One coverage for ITV.

Chrysalis boss Neil Duncanson said: "Ron Manager has deserved his own show for a long time."

The offbeat comedian and his Fast Show co-stars, Mark Williams and Simon Day, are going to host a spoof quiz show on Sky One billed as "A Question of Sport on acid". In Jumpers for Goalposts, Mr Whitehouse' Ron Manager will dispense his inimitable football wisdom over 13 weeks as captain of a panel of sporting and celebrity guests. And in place of Question of Sport host Sue Barker will be Simon Day who has modelled his character, Tommy Stein, on the BBC sports presenter Steve Rider. Mr Whitehouse's decision to take the show to Sky is being seen as yet another blow to the BBC. The corporation recently lost Ant and Dec to the BBC and earlier this year watched Harry Enfield take his new characters to Sky One. Sky said it was the "natural" home for Mr Whitehouse's idea for a comedy quiz show. "Because we offer the best in football and entertainment, we were the obvious choice," said a spokesman. The deal is not exclusive, however, and Mr Whitehouse is currently filming a new 40-something sitcom, Happiness, for the BBC. Mr Whitehouse said: "Jumpers for Goalposts is a simple fun football quiz for small girls, small boys, large girls, large boys. We have to keep it simple because we have footballers and celebrities as guests so the questions can't be too hard, can they?" The show is being produced by Chrysalis TV, which make Channel 4's Italian football series and Formula One coverage for ITV. Chrysalis boss Neil Duncanson said: "Ron Manager has deserved his own show for a long time."

webTitle: Budweiser's 'Whassup?' takes top prize in ad awards

fields.headline: Budweiser's 'Whassup?' takes top prize in ad awards
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Budweiser's infectious 'Whassup?' campaign has taken the top prize at this year's London International Advertising Awards, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Budweiser's infectious 'Whassup?' campaign has taken the top prize at this year's London International Advertising Awards.

The 60-second ad from DDB Chicago saw off competition from nearly 20,000 competitors from more than 80 countries worldwide.

It picked up the Grand Prize after being voted the best by a jury of senior international advertising executives chaired by Trevor Beattie, TBWA's creative director.

'Whassup?', which captures a group of friends drinking beer and watching a football game, was based on a two-minute film shot by Charles Stone III, who also stars in the ad.

Since then 10 spots have been created and the phrase 'Whassup?' has entered the vernacular.

This years's public service campaign winner was The Alliance campaign from America's Arnold Communications for its hard-hitting anti-tobacco ads.

Designed to engage teens and expose tobacco companies' deceptive marketing practices aimed at youngsters, the controversial ads are titled 'Lie Detector', 'Body Bag', 'Operation Hypnosis' and 'Shredder'.

Leo Burnett, London's billboard advertisement for John West captured the Grand Prize for print advertising.

The ad depicts a fishing line bobbing in what appears to be a gently rippling pond, but is, in fact, a tuna can. There were more than 8,000 entries world-wide in the print media category alone.

webTitle: US election: Stranger than fiction

fields.headline: Stranger than fiction
fields.standfirst:
Vote-rigging, bogus candidates, dead voters, cronyism, cruelty to alligators ... it's business as usual in America's Banana Republic. But with the world looking on in amazement, it doesn't seem quite so funny any more, says Julian Borger

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Vote-rigging, bogus candidates, dead voters, cronyism, cruelty to alligators ... it's business as usual in America's Banana Republic. But with the world looking on in amazement, it doesn't seem quite so funny any more, says  Julian Borger.
fields.body:
Just when it seemed things could not get any stranger in West Palm Beach, Joseph Stalin waded in. Out of the crowd of demonstrators in T-shirts and Bermuda shorts, a placard rose up reminding the Sunshine State of Uncle Joe's prophetic words. "Those who cast the votes decide nothing. Those who count the votes decide everything," the placard said.

The sign was hoisted with pure, ironic glee. Nothing could be more perfect. America's future will not be decided in the bland plains of the midwest nor in the endless identical suburbs full of soccer moms so beloved of the party pollsters. It is going to be decided in Florida, America's weird, troubled protuberance in the Caribbean, where a million Cuban exiles still plotting revenge against Castro rub up against Jewish pensioners from Brooklyn, Haitian refugees and a dysfunctional shoal of opportunists, lost souls and part-time Disney employees. All them have been known to act as if under the influence of the local swamp gas.

Over the past week, the rest of the nation has been looking on in amazement, with the frozen grin of a solid Yankee family which has just been told that the drug-addled, beach-bum cousins it has spent years trying to ignore have been named the executors to its inheritance.

Almost every day in the Florida papers there can be found tiny buried news items that stretch the definition of bizarre - each one alone sufficient to launch a comic novel or seminar in psychiatry, or both. This, after all, is a state where a man has been found in bed with a pet alligator, triggering a protracted court-case about the treatment of animals - even though it was the human half of the relationship which bore the scars. More recently, but on a similar theme, a man in south-central Florida was charged with shooting his dog because he suspected it of being gay.

For the purposes of political comedy, there is no better place for the leadership of the world's sole superpower to be decided. Not for nothing is Florida known to its own residents as the Banana Republic. It is a state with a history of election fraud to compete with any of its Central American neighbours. In Miami, the dead have been known to vote early and often. Ballot boxes take strange journeys, disappearing and appearing like phantoms.

In the words of Mark Lane, a Florida columnist: "The English can't cook, Italians can't form governments, Germans can't do comedy and Floridians can't hold an untainted election. It's just a cultural thing."

It seems to have been ever thus. Since the British got control of Florida in 1763 in exchange for Havana, it has been difficult territory to govern. The redcoats were forced out 20 years later, but the colonists who replaced them found it just as difficult to impose their will on the local native Americans until president Andrew Jackson finally spent $20m on ethnically cleansing the entire Seminole Indian population.

In the civil war, Tallahassee was the only state capital in the Confederacy not to be captured by Union troops, who were still garrisoned there in the pivotal election of 1876.

That election was an uncannily similar precursor to the present mess. Florida only had four electoral votes, but then as now they were the ones that counted in the extremely tight contest between the two contenders: Samuel Tilden, the Democrat and Rutherford Hayes, the Republican.

There were 50,000 ballots cast in 1876, a hundredth of this year's total, and at the end of the count, the two candidates were only 100 votes apart, amid claims and counter-claims of rigging. Ballot boxes were stolen and the state appeared to take forever to count and recount the votes. Sound familiar?

By New Year's Day the next year, with no clear winner and the nation growing restless amid predictions of a new civil war, Florida sent not one, but three counts to Congress by three rival electoral boards. Two declared Tilden the winner. The other opted for Hayes. In the end a congressional electoral commission was set up which awarded the election to Hayes - a result still disputed.

To this day, electoral malpractice is assumed to be part of the scenery in Florida, but it usually only affects the polls for mayors and local school inspectors. The only remarkable aspect of the 1876 and 2000 elections is that Florida, in all its glorious eccentricity, has ended up picking the man for the top job in the land. Otherwise, the post-electoral squabbling over ballots is entirely familiar to the locals.

The fact that the election may hinge on the absentee ballot is particularly ominous. In Volusia, one of the four disputed counties, election officials were found in 1996 to have filled in hundreds of absentee ballots for the sheriff's job. This year in Volusia, one electoral official left a bag full of ballots on the back seat of his car and several other ballot bags were found to be without official seals. In the end, the police had to stretch yellow crime-scene tape around the electoral board offices in an attempt to salvage the credibility of the count.

In Florida the dead not only vote, they have been known to stand for office. In 1998, there were allegations that one Republican candidate had actually been dead for three years. (It is not quite clear why someone had decided to stand using his identity.)

In Miami, the mayoral election three years ago was so fraudulent it even drew gasps from a state inured to vote-rigging. The number of absentee ballots from Cuban-American precincts of Dade county rocketed and many were later found to have been cast by dead Floridians whose sense of civic duty remarkably appeared to have endured long beyond the grave.

Eventually, the result was overturned and 56 "vote-brokers" who had organised the scam, faced criminal charges. The result was eventually overturned and Mayor Xavier Suarez, known as "Mayor Loco" for his penchant for visiting constituents in the middle of the night in his bathrobe, had to give way to "Crazy Joe" Carollo, who earned his nickname whipping up Cuban exile sentiment in the Elian Gonzalez affair.

Since the elections, Mayor Carollo has announced he is standing down due to the collapse of his marriage, but other cast members familiar from the Elian saga are still in action, not least the irrepressible lawyer, Kendall Coffey. His career appeared to be over eight years ago when he lost a big narcotics case as a federal attorney and consoled himself by visiting the Lipstik Adult Entertainment Centre, buying a $900 bottle of Dom Perignon and retiring to an upstairs room with a lap-dancer, who at some point in the evening, he bit so hard on the arm that she pressed assault charges.

But Florida is a state of forgiveness. Coffey rebounded to lead the legal case brought by Elian's Miami relatives to keep the shipwrecked Cuban boy in the US.

Now he has reappeared Zelig-like in the election imbroglio, but on the opposite side, representing the Democrats - much to the disgust of the Gonzalez family, who have declared him a traitor.

The ubiquitous Coffey is just one example. Almost every character with a walk-on part in this tropical farce seems to bear a Floridian twist. Terry Lewis, the judge who gave the crucial recount deadline ruling on Tuesday, turns out to have been an aspiring novelist, whose legal potboiler Conflict of Interest, told the tale of a Florida lawyer juggling alcoholism with the law

Katherine Harris, the Republican citrus heiress who has since replaced Judge Lewis at centre-stage, was forced to hand back $20,000 in a campaign finance scandal in 1994 and has been criticised for over-spending public money.

It is as if this hot steamy state was never meant to withstand the cold stare of international scrutiny and its denizens are shrivelling up under our gaze. It would be a shame if its exotic political fauna were killed off in the process and its unique electoral swamps concreted over once and for all, to make Florida safe for democracy.

webTitle: Aristoc steps out with new cinema ads

fields.headline: Aristoc steps out in style with new cinema ads
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Aristoc is launching a racy new ad campaign to promote its new Slimline System tights, writes Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Aristoc is offering women a shortcut to smaller buttocks and slimmer thighs and is launching a racy new ad campaign to promote it.

A 40-second cinema ad launches next week for its new Slimline System tights with the line "Aristoc. For legs. For eyes".

The campaign, by Miles Calcraft Briginshaw Duffy, opens with an elegant young woman walking into a stylish room wearing the new tights.

She approaches a young man and begins to speak. As she talks, subtitles cover her head and shoulders. When he responds, his subtitles appear at the bottom of the screen.

Finally, she says: "These stupid subtitles. Why aren't mine at the bottom? No one can see my face."

His response: "That's because you are wearing Aristoc Slimline System tights, my darling," and spells out what a crime it would be to cover her fabulous figure.

As she turns to the camera her face is completely obscured by the Aristoc pack.

Aristoc's commercial director, Sue Clague, said: "We were looking to provide some real impetus behind our brand."

"We wanted to reinvigorate it in a highly competitive marketplace. Here we have an effective, witty and beautifully crafted execution, showcased in a medium that is a different for us."

The campaign was art-directed by Paul Briginshaw and written by Malcolm Duffy. It was directed by Peter Thwaites through the production company Gorgeous.

Media was planned by MCBD and bought by MBS.

webTitle: Comment:The Hindujas brothers

fields.headline: The big brothers
fields.standfirst:
Mark Hollingsworth investigates the mysterious Hindujas, who have bid £100m for the Express group

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Mark Hollingsworth investigates the mysterious Hindujas, who have bid £100m for the Express group.
fields.body:
The four billionaire Hinduja brothers have offered £100m plus for the ailing Express group in order to become British press magnates and - as they recently told David Frost on breakfast TV - to exercise a novel influence on the country: "We would not like to make the paper left or right. We would like to see what is in the national interest so far as policies are concerned. We have plans to see how it could also contribute towards the ethnic community."

As media analysts argue that the brothers will need to invest an extra £75m to compete with the awesome Mail group, they will need to reach very deep into their pockets.

Worth an estimated £1.3bn, the Hindujas have accumulated their multi-national fortune from oil trading, Swiss banking, films, telecommunications and trucking. But they have been dogged by allegations of facilitating arms deals. The Indian central bureau of investigation accuses three of the brothers (not Ashok) of handling £7.1m in bribes from Bofors, a Swedish arms firm, for securing a lucrative contract to supply howitzers to the Indian army. A judge is to rule on Monday whether they will be formally charged. The Hindujas vehemently deny the allegations and claim they have been "treated in an unfair and unjust manner".

With an aura of mystery, power and ostentatious wealth, the brothers are extremely close. They are all conservative, teetotal vegetarians and even wear identical suits. The Hindujas' commercial empire has four colonies. In New York the eldest brother, Srichand, 64, known as "the Boss", runs the business as chairman from their luxury apartment on Fifth Avenue. Gopichand, 60, is president and runs an oil-trading arm from 12th floor offices at New Zealand House in London, near Leicester Square. Their banking and investments are managed by Prakash, 54, from Geneva. And the film interests are looked after by Ashok, 50, in Bombay.

But the family has few visible assets and this has led to persistent speculation that their fortune is derived from hidden, controversial sources. "The Hindujas flaunt their wealth but conceal its flow," concluded Forbes, the US business magazine.

Britain's aspiring press barons dislike these suggestions. "The only way in which the Hindujas 'flaunt their wealth', if at all," says their spokesman, "is through their generous public charity works through the Hinduja Foundation ... If establishing the best teaching hospital in India, funding exchange programmes for doctors and medical students in India and the US, funding centres of learning at Cambridge and Columbia universities, funding the faith zone at the dome, and spending money on promoting tolerance and understanding between cultures and religions is 'flaunting their wealth', then that is what they do.

"The Hinduja brothers fully subscribe to their father's guiding principle: 'My duty is to work so that I may give.' As private individuals they live modestly by comparison with their wealth - they do not have fleets of yachts, cars and jets; they have not amassed fabulous collections of fine art; they do not have sprawling country estates with hot and cold running servants."

The Hindujas point to their website which, they say, lists their business interests (www.hindujagroup.com). "Who says we are secretive?" Srichand Hinduja asked in the Daily Express last year. "We are simply a privately owned company that has never been a borrower. When do you project yourself? When you want to go public to sell shares. But we have never been a borrower or a public company, so there has never been a need."

But the reality is that if the Hindujas enter the very public world of newspaper publishing, more transparency about their wealth may be paramount.

So where does their vast fortune come from? The search for the Hinduja billions is a journey across continents. The trail begins in the Indus valley of Sindh, the fertile coastal province now part of Pakistan but then an ancestral home for Indian merchants. The brothers' father, Parmanand, moved to Bombay and began trading textiles, dried fruits and clothes with Persia.

After migrating to Tehran prior to 1914, the brothers say, he also distributed Indian films, dubbed into Farsi. As oil-rich Iran prospered in the 1960s and 1970s, the Shah embarked on a massive spending spree. The Hindujas cultivated close links with him and were awarded a vast range of contracts - from overhauling the electricity industry to supplying, during one fashion craze, trilby hats. On certain deals, notably an iron ore contract with India, the Hindujas acted as the Shah's personal intermediary.

When the father died in 1971, the four brothers inherited £2m and diversified into investment banking, manufacturing and property. By the mid-1970s they virtually had a monopoly in brokering the sale of goods from Iran to India. Their wealth was dependent on the Shah and they cultivated a network of informants to monitor threats to his regime. Srichand, the eldest brother, was tipped off in early 1978 that the Shah would be overthrown. Many of their assets - land, property, companies and shares - were quickly liquidated. Srichand Hinduja says he consulted politicians, economists and, bizarrely, his astrologers. "In this way I analyse every country where we have a large stake from the point of view of an outsider, as if I had no investment," he said. He also said that he sold family holdings in Beirut before it was a war zone and predicted the successor to Rajiv Gandhi as India's premier by consulting astrologers and advisers.

By the time the Shah of Iran was overthrown and in exile, the Hindujas were safely installed in London. But they retained a base in Tehran - a house, an office and about £1.5m on bank deposit. And they continued to operate in Iran under Ayatollah Khomeni. This was through two companies - Sangam (named after a top-selling romantic film drama) and Ashok Trading which represented Daimler-Benz, Lockheed and PanAm. The Hindujas may be devout Hindus but they have prospered primarily in the Muslim world.

The brothers were wealthy because of their deals during the Shah's regime. But their elevation to the super-rich was based on oil trading. In 1984 the Hindujas, in partnership with former Saudi oil ministers Sheik Yamani and Dr Taher, bought a large slice of the Gulf Oil company (mainly the Asian operations). But their relationship with the Saudi investors soured. The brothers bought them out and created the Gotco supply and trading operation which later controlled the Gulf brand throughout the world except Iberia and North America. Its holding company is Gotco Trading Ltd, registered in Bermuda.

So the dictatorial regimes in Saudi Arabia and in Iran under the Shah have been ultimately, the background to the way in which the Hindujas have amassed their billions.
