The brothers' father, Parmanand, moved to Bombay and began trading textiles, dried fruits and clothes with Persia. After migrating to Tehran prior to 1914, the brothers say, he also distributed Indian films, dubbed into Farsi. As oil-rich Iran prospered in the 1960s and 1970s, the Shah embarked on a massive spending spree. The Hindujas cultivated close links with him and were awarded a vast range of contracts - from overhauling the electricity industry to supplying, during one fashion craze, trilby hats. On certain deals, notably an iron ore contract with India, the Hindujas acted as the Shah's personal intermediary. When the father died in 1971, the four brothers inherited £2m and diversified into investment banking, manufacturing and property. By the mid-1970s they virtually had a monopoly in brokering the sale of goods from Iran to India. Their wealth was dependent on the Shah and they cultivated a network of informants to monitor threats to his regime. Srichand, the eldest brother, was tipped off in early 1978 that the Shah would be overthrown. Many of their assets - land, property, companies and shares - were quickly liquidated. Srichand Hinduja says he consulted politicians, economists and, bizarrely, his astrologers. "In this way I analyse every country where we have a large stake from the point of view of an outsider, as if I had no investment," he said. He also said that he sold family holdings in Beirut before it was a war zone and predicted the successor to Rajiv Gandhi as India's premier by consulting astrologers and advisers. By the time the Shah of Iran was overthrown and in exile, the Hindujas were safely installed in London. But they retained a base in Tehran - a house, an office and about £1.5m on bank deposit. And they continued to operate in Iran under Ayatollah Khomeni. This was through two companies - Sangam (named after a top-selling romantic film drama) and Ashok Trading which represented Daimler-Benz, Lockheed and PanAm. The Hindujas may be devout Hindus but they have prospered primarily in the Muslim world. The brothers were wealthy because of their deals during the Shah's regime. But their elevation to the super-rich was based on oil trading. In 1984 the Hindujas, in partnership with former Saudi oil ministers Sheik Yamani and Dr Taher, bought a large slice of the Gulf Oil company (mainly the Asian operations). But their relationship with the Saudi investors soured. The brothers bought them out and created the Gotco supply and trading operation which later controlled the Gulf brand throughout the world except Iberia and North America. Its holding company is Gotco Trading Ltd, registered in Bermuda. So the dictatorial regimes in Saudi Arabia and in Iran under the Shah have been ultimately, the background to the way in which the Hindujas have amassed their billions. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Embryonic European defence force inches forward

fields.headline: Embryonic European defence force inches forward
fields.standfirst:
The planned 60,000-strong Eurocorps has raised questions about the future role of the US and Nato, writes Guardian foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall

Related special report: EU enlargement
fields.trailText:
The planned 60,000-strong Eurocorps has raised questions about the future role of the US and Nato, writes Guardian foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall.

Related special report: EU enlargement
fields.body:
Controversial plans to create an independent European defence capability under the auspices of the European Union will take another step forward at a "troop-pledging" conference in Brussels next Monday.

Britain and Germany are each expected to contribute about 15% of the proposed 60,000-strong force, with France making a slightly larger commitment.

The idea is that the EU rapid reaction force would be able to deploy for up to a year at 60 days' notice. Its role would be confined to peacekeeping, crisis management and humanitarian operations.

A standing army is not envisaged. Each contributing country among the EU's 15 members will earmark elements of its armed forces for the so-called "Eurocorps", to be called upon when the occasion demands. Nor will any country be obliged to contribute soldiers to a mission whose objectives it does not support.

The creation of the force, with permanent headquarters in Brussels, is supposed to underpin the development of a common European foreign and security policy under the political direction of Javier Solana, a former secretary-general of Nato.

But decisive impetus for its creation was provided by last year's Kosovo crisis when European countries were severely embarrassed by their inability to match the US military commitment there.

Longstanding US complaints that Europe is not pulling its weight when it comes to defence (most EU national defence budgets have been falling in recent years) became even more strident after Kosovo.

On top of that, US policymakers (both Democrat and Republican) are increasingly opposed to US ground troop commitments in Europe, preferring to concentrate on areas of greater national strategic importance such as the near east and east Asia.

George W Bush, the Republican presidential candidate, has suggested that if elected he may seek to pull American troops out of Kosovo and Bosnia.

All the same, one of the reasons why the Eurocorps is controversial is America's fear that the force may become a competitor to Nato, the transatlantic alliance that has linked Europe and the US since the beginning of the cold war.

The Americans have insisted that the European force must only be used in places or situations in which the US-led Nato does not want to get involved.

There is also concern about duplication of effort between the EU force and Nato, in terms of planning, intelligence and procurement.

Much time has been devoted to establishing secure links between the two organisations, in part to assuage Washington's concerns that Nato "assets" might be compromised.

Other problems relate to the position of non-EU countries that belong to Nato, such as Turkey, Iceland and Norway, which fear their security may be impaired as the majority of their Nato allies concentrate on their new commitment to the EU force.

Turkey and Iceland have said they do not want the EU to be given access to Nato military planning - a crucial link if the two organisations are to coexist without rivalry.

Worries about "decoupling" are shared by European countries, particularly Britain, with it long history of close military cooperation with the US.

Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, and George Robertson, the current Nato secretary-general (and Mr Hoon's predecessor) have been at pains in recent days to offer public assurances that the problems can be worked out.

Lord Robertson has denied reports published last week that he recently told the prime minister, Tony Blair, in private that the EU's defence plans could trigger a transatlantic crisis.

Those reports focused on claims that France, historically antagonistic to Nato as the supposed European arm of Anglo-Saxon global hegemony, was taking over the EU project. Lord Robertson was said to have told Mr Blair that Britain and Germany must do more to counter French influence.

Despite its role being delineated in broadbrush terms, it remains unclear how such a European force may be used in future. Would it have sufficient air and sea capability, for example, to back up a Kosovo-like operation?

Would it be called upon to help Britain in an intervention like that currently under way in Sierra Leone, where neither Nato nor the US itself has offered to get involved?

Even if asked, would a country such as France say yes? Despite its long colonial era involvement in west Africa, it has not done anything directly to assist Britain or the UN peacekeeping mission in Freetown.

But an even more intriguing question still hangs in the air as the Brussels meeting and the subsequent EU summit in Nice (which will give the force official blessing) approach.

If the European force does become established, and is augmented as the EU enlarges to the east and south; and if in time countries such as Turkey join the EU (as it hopes to do), then who needs Nato any more?

webTitle: Comment: Elsewhere

fields.headline: Men of feud words
fields.standfirst:
Elsewhere

MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: On Monday the Daily Telegraph found itself forced to print a letter condemning its leader comment three days earlier on the US elections as ill-informed and bizarre. That its judgment had been bizarre - even barmy - is barely disputable. But what gave the rebuke special authority was the signature at the end of it: that of Conrad Black, the paper's proprietor.
fields.body:
On Monday the Daily Telegraph found itself forced to print a letter condemning its leader comment three days earlier on the US elections as ill-informed and bizarre. That its judgment had been bizarre - even barmy - is barely disputable. It proposed a deal in which Gore would concede the election to Bush, in return for letting the Democrats choose the next attorney-general and the judges next in line for the supreme court. But what gave the rebuke special authority was the signature at the end of it: that of Conrad Black, the paper's proprietor.

This wasn't by any means the first time that Black has used the columns of one of the papers he owns (the Sunday Telegraph and Spectator are his as well) to attack what his editors write or commission. Yet however much pain these forays must cause to those who wrote the words complained of, this method is surely preferable to the usual Fleet Street practice of leaning on errant editors in private. Of course we are often told that such practices no longer exist. Rupert Murdoch, his defenders assure us, never bullies his editors. But that is not, it has to be said, the impression you get from the memoirs of former discarded Murdoch hands such as Harold Evans or Andrew Neil. And you also have to remember the proprietor's right to appoint editors in his own image - or at least equipped with a kind of sixth sense which tells them what Rupert won't like.

But even Rupert Murdoch is a saintly example of self-restraint compared with some of those who went before. The most hands-on proprietor of them all in this sense was Beaverbrook, of whom one of his editors said: "He is Allah, and we are his prophets." (He got dumped before long, even so.) "Who," the Canadian mischief-maker would habitually ask of some organisation under review "is in charge of the clattering train?" Where his newspapers were concerned, the true answer was always: you are. No corner of his empire was immune from his quirky instructions, which is why in old annuals when Rupert and his chums espy/ a gleaming object in the sky, it is always an airplane, not (a banned word) an aeroplane.

His papers were there to propagate his ideas. "I run the Daily Express purely for propaganda and no other purpose," he assured the royal commission on the press in 1948, though they'd probably noticed already. But that did not only apply to great issues like the empire or the need to eradicate socialism. His quirky addictions and hatreds crept in all over his papers. The Londoner's Diary in the Evening Standard was a favourite dumping ground for poisonous paragraphs designed to settle old scores. The leader columns of his newspapers had regularly to accommodate items inspired by his spites and whims. The Arts Council and the National Trust were for ever being lambasted.

The most furious feud of all was directed against Lord Mountbatten. No one was quite sure why. One theory was that he blamed Mountbatten for a scene in Noël Coward's film In Which we Serve when, after a destroyer is sunk, a copy of the Express is seen on the water bearing the headline: "No war this year". (The Express had been busy reassuring its readers almost until the first sirens sounded.) But Anne Chisholm and Michael Davie, in their 1992 life of Beaverbrook, think it had more to do with the belated discovery that one of his favourite mistresses had also slept with Mountbatten. Even more bizarre was the way Beaverbrook's mouthpiece used regularly to assault the composer Sibelius, who had published nothing new since 1926. "Call yourself a composer?" the Express used to chide well into the 50s. How can you be a composer when you never compose?

Conrad Black husbands his ammunition better than that. Indeed, Monday's letter was almost as remarkable for what he held back as for what he said. If he doesn't like to see his newspapers held up to ridicule, he must surely have been aghast at the performance through the US election campaign of one of the paper's star pundits, Mark Steyn. Two weeks ago this column called on the US electorate to engineer a dead heat. It mustn't be Gore, I argued, because that would vindicate the electoral predestinarians who had said since the summer that given the health of the US economy Gore could not lose. But it also mustn't be Bush, since that would appear to justify the entrailist school of predictors, which relies on what its guts tell it - of whom the leading practitioner, who'd been preaching for months that Bush could not possibly win fewer than 40 states and 378 seats in the electoral college, was Steyn. The results, whatever they finally are, seem certain to leave Mark Steyn looking an even bigger fool than the predestinarians. Thank you, America.

david.mckie@theguardian.com

webTitle: Leader: On the controversy over Coronation Street's pub

fields.headline: Relegating the Rovers
fields.standfirst:
The days of Boozy Newts are numbered
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The pub in Coronation Street is to change its name from the Rovers Return, which has served it so well down the years, to the Boozy Newt, marking its transition to one of those groups which themes all its pubs by applying a common designation, like Ferret.
fields.body:
The pub in Coronation Street is to change its name from the Rovers Return, which has served it so well down the years, to the Boozy Newt, marking its transition to one of those groups which themes all its pubs by applying a common designation, like Ferret. It is clear what will follow. A poll in the Sun on whether or not the old name ought to be scrapped will attract a greater turnout than the last European elections. Tony Blair will express grave concern. John Prescott will threaten a boycott. William Hague will blame it on Brussels.

All will have missed the real offence. For a start, the vogue for such changes of name belongs much more to southern middle-class suburbs than to working-class sectors of Manchester, where ferrets are few, cows are still invariably brown and dogs remain teamed as ever with partridges, ducks and pheasants. And in any case, the fashion for making such changes is surely hopelessly 80s. A survey which surfaced yesterday based on interviews with 9,000 people across 12 countries shows the British shedding their taste for basic boozers and transferring their allegiance to cafés. We are now more likely even than the Italians to spend our time in a café, while Italy outstrips us in using bars. If Coronation Street is not to shed its reputation for realism, the Rovers Return should become not a Newt but the Café Biarritz, or if something with more local associations is needed, the Café Wilmslow.

Alternatively, the new owners could join the trend which has seen one pub in in Surrey changing its name to Rumpole's, after the TV celebrity. To remarket yourself as, say, the Queen Victoria, like the pub in EastEnders, would surely have far more appeal in a place like Weathersfield than inflicting upon its supping-up public a name like the Boozy Newt - invoking as its second half does the mayor of that deplorable city, London. Why not, on this basis, rename it the Rovers Return?

webTitle: BBC considers signing Olympic boxer

fields.headline: Olympic gold to BBC gold
fields.standfirst: Multi-million media deal beckons for Heavyweight Harrison
fields.trailText: BBC executives meet charismatic Olympic boxing champion Audley Harrison to discuss a unique deal that would involve televising his fights and training him to become both a sports pundit and a presenter on non-sports programmes.
fields.body:
BBC executives will today meet charismatic Olympic boxing champion Audley Harrison to discuss a unique deal that would involve televising his fights and training him to become both a sports pundit and a presenter on non-sports programmes.

The personable Harrison, 28, who has a university degree, is considered bright and articulate and someone who has battled against adversity to gain success. The boxer recently revealed that he served 32 months in a young offender institution and claimed boxing helped him to improve his life and receive a good education.

The deal would represent a major victory for the corporation in its attempt to secure new sports rights and could be worth up to £10m to Harrison depending on how successful he is in the ring.

The BBC has a large amount of money set aside for sport after missing out on the right to televise highlights of Premier League matches with a bid of £123m earlier this year. It is believed that some of this money could be used to secure Harrison's signature.

The deal would give the BBC exclusive rights to televise Harrison's bouts during prime time once the amateur boxer turns professional next year.

A BBC source said: "Greg Dyke [the director general] was extremely impressed by Audley and the public and media reaction to his win.

"Audley won gold on BBC television so it would be stupid of us not to get involved with him. At the moment we are asking a lot of questions, there are offers on the table but we have to see what's in it for us."

Mr Dyke, Peter Salmon, director of BBC sport, and a number of other officials from the corporation's sports department are to meet Harrison and his advisers who have been examining ways to increase his profile and popularity with the British public since his Olympic win.

Harrison is keen to use terrestrial television to promote his professional career in and out of the ring, believing that it would give him wider exposure than signing up with satellite television, as most boxers have done.

The BBC would also give Harrison media training and use him as a boxing pundit and presenter on a number of programmes. He would be considered ideal for children's programmes and a number of prime-time evening shows as well as sports programmes.

Harrison has been involved in negotiations with a number of boxing promoters and television companies since winning gold.

Mr Dyke, who began his career in journalism as a freelance boxing reporter, believes Harrison would benefit from signing with the corporation in the same way that Frank Bruno and former world champion Barry McGuigan did during the 1980s, when their fights were shown on terrestrial television.

Boxing has had a low profile on the BBC since the mid-1980s when world championship fights drew television audiences of 15-18m.

Harrison's bout in which he won a gold medal was shown on BBC television and proved to be one of the most popular moments of the Olympic Games.

webTitle: English as an Asian language

fields.headline: English as an Asian language
fields.standfirst: It is time for East and Southeast Asia to learn its own version of English, argues Andy Kirkpatrick
fields.trailText: It is time for East and Southeast Asia to learn its own version of English, argues Andy Kirkpatrick
fields.body:
It is impossible to identify and isolate an "English" culture that is common to all speakers of English. The cultures represented by Nigerian, Singaporean, Indian, Scottish, Filipino or Australian Aboriginal English are all very different. So, while a language must be linked to a culture, a language is not inextricably tied to one specific culture. Specific cultural identities can be represented by new varieties of English.

In East and Southeast Asia English plays a major role in the region as a lingua franca of the political elite and the Association of Southast Asian Nations. It is also used as a lingua franca between professionals and the business community. But what variety of English will serve as the region's lingua franca? I suggest that a variety which reflects local cultural conventions and pragmatic norms is developing to serve this role.

I further suggest that it is this regional variety that will be taught in schools, rather than an external "native speaker" variety. The vast majority of people who are learning English are doing so to be able to use this lingua franca. They are not learning English with the express purpose of communicating with native speakers of English. English is being used by non-native speakers with other non-native speakers. The English that they use need not therefore reflect any "Anglo" cultural values. This emerging role of English was identified by Gordon Wu of Hong Kong's Hopewell Holdings, who told the Far Eastern Economic Review: "English is no longer some colonial language. What they need are materials that provide some knowledge of the culture of the people they are dealing with. They also need to be aware of their own cultural norms. The cultural values and daily lives of the people in the region who are using English as a regional lingua franca become more important than the cultural values associated with native speakers.

This has important implications for English language teaching in the region's schools. It is a regional variety of English, not an external model, that needs to be promoted, because it is a regional variety of English that people in the region will want to use. People will be able to maintain their identity while speaking their variety of English. As Tommy Koh, a senior minister in the Singapore government, put it recently, "When I speak English I want the world to know I'm a Singaporean."

The curriculum of a new variety of English should reflect the lives, cultures and values of the learners. Speakers of this new variety will want to preserve their identity by reflecting that identity in the local variety of English they use. English language teaching materials are needed that promote the local or regional variety and represent the cultures of the speakers of these newly developing varieties. These materials also need to contrast regional cultures, so making the English language curriculum more a curriculum of regional cultures. Students are fearful of speaking, because they falsely consider themselves to be poor speakers unless they sound like Americans. Suitably qualified and trained speakers of the regional variety could be the teachers.

More research into the development of varieties of English is urgently needed. In particular we need to know what cultural and discourse conventions are being reflected in these new varieties. Governments need not fear that the learning of English will necessarily imbue the learners with inappropriate cultural values or ways of thinking. fields.trailText:
US poll results
Voters in Arizona have decided to dump bilingual education programmes in state schools in favour of an English-only initiative. The initiative was supported by more than 60% of voters in a ballot held simultaneously with last weekÍs presidential and congressional elections. The measure is similar to that adopted in California in 1997, which supporters of English-only education claim has led to a significant improvement in school test results. The Arizona proposition will require all public school instruction to be conducted in English. Children who are not fluent in English will be placed in an intensive one-year "immersion" programme, after which they will enter English-only classrooms. Meanwhile neighbouring Utah became the 26th state to declare English its official language, on the same day of voting. The new law requires government business to be conducted in English, but it will not affect education.

Refugee medics
Two thousand qualified doctors registered as refugees in Britain are to be offered English language training as part of a government initiative to ease a severe shortage of trained medical staff in the national health system. A budget of $750,000 has been provided to retrain doctors and other medically qualified refugees to fill jobs.

Belarus closure
The British Council announced last week that it will close its office and English language teaching programme in Belarus. The decision was taken in the light of increasing political tension after recent parliamentary elections condemned by European observers as "neither fair, free, nor transparent".

Sweden has avoided a dispute about the use of anglicised names among its European Union partners by announcing that it will hold the first summit of its EU presidency next year in Gsteborg  not "Gothenberg", the anglophone version of the cityÍs name.

webTitle: Swiss push to put English first in schools

fields.headline: Swiss push to put English first in schools
fields.trailText: Switzerland, which boasts four official languages, is agonising about how to reconcile its multilingual pride and multicultural traditions with the global advance of English.
fields.body:
Switzerland, which boasts four official languages, is agonising about how to reconcile its multilingual pride and multicultural traditions with the global advance of English.

A meeting this month of education chiefs from the country's 26 cantons ended without agreement on whether to promote English as the first foreign language in Swiss schools, or to favour local languages. Conference president Hans-Ulrich Stoeckling said the education directors would meet again next June. But individual cantons said they would switch to English regardless. Some 64% of Swiss speak German and learn French as their second language. The dwindling handful of speakers of Romansch, a descendant of Latin, learn French as a second language. The 19% who have French as their mother tongue, and the 5% who have Italian, learn German at school.

Compounding the tongue test is the fact that foreigners account for nearly 20% of Switzerland's 7m population. School playgrounds thus reverberate not just with the national languages but with Albanian, Arabic, Turkish, Portuguese, Spanish and of course English. German-speaking Zurich, the nation's financial pulse, announced in September that it would introduce English for all third-graders and relegate French to fifth grade, in recognition of the reality of global business, science and internet communication.

At this month's conference 12 of the cantons pressed for English as the main foreign language, 13 wanted to stick with national languages, and one abstained. In the absence of consensus Lucerne in central Switzerland said it would follow Zurich's lead and introduce English. Other cantons have indicated they will do likewise.

Critics of the switch to English argue that learning each other's language and culture has enabled Switzerland's different regions to live in harmony and avoid violent separatist movements and ethnic strife. "I don't want English to roll over the world like a steamroller, crushing the richness of languages," the interior minister, Ruth Dreifuss, said in a recent newspaper interview. However, there has been widespread public support - especially among the youth - for change. "I prefer English to German," said five-year-old Line Effrancey-Dao, proud of the few words she has picked up from Geneva classmates enrolled in private English lessons. Her mother, Nicole, disagreed. "I want my children to continue to learn German, not just because it makes it easier for them to find a job here, but also because of our culture. It would be a shame for Switzerland to go the way of countries like the Netherlands, where English has really taken over," said the 36-year-old engineer.

However, English has in fact for years been the common language among Swiss themselves. French and Italian speakers learn High German in school, and are unable to speak or comprehend the Schwyzerdeutsch dialect favoured by their German-speaking compatriots. "United Nation?" asked a headline in the weekly SonntagZeitung. It featured a caricature of three Swiss men with union jacks on their tongues and clanking beer glasses together.

webTitle: Tongue-tied in their own language

fields.headline: Tongue-tied in their own language
fields.standfirst: Britain is still learning how to communicate in English, reports Max de Lotbinire
fields.trailText: Britain is still learning how to communicate in English, reports Max de Lotbinire
fields.body:
David Blunkett, Britain's minister for education and employment, has challenged British businesses to use their fluency in English to gain a competitive edge in global trade. But his exhortation, delivered to business chiefs in London last month, failed to raise awareness about the difficulties that native speakers can encounter in communicating with people who speak English as their second language.

Mr Blunkett told his audience that by the end of this year 750m people would have English as a second language, and second-language speakers would outnumber first-language speakers for the first time in history. "It makes good economic sense that we use English fluency as a platform to underpin our economic competitiveness and to promote our culture overseas," he said. Mr Blunkett was careful to add that British people should not use this advantage as a reason to stop learning foreign languages.

This point was welcomed by Peter Blackburn, chairman and CEO of the British arm of Nestlé, the European multinational. Mr Blackburn, who is an honorary fellow of the Institute of Linguistics, added: "Business is becoming increasingly international, and British managers need to develop their knowledge of other languages - and, importantly, their understanding of other languages. In business the spoken word is more important than the written word."

Yet Mr Blunkett's speech overlooked the increasing challenges that the spread of English raises for native speakers. Not only will they need to understand how to communicate with people with a lower proficiency in English, they must also adapt their language to suit users of emerging regional varieties of English.

According to Jeremy Comfort of York Associates, a languages and inter-cultural training consultancy in England, the problem for British business starts with the assumption that their English will be understood. "Being fluent doesn't make you a good communicator," he says. "We have to be aware that language can be a tool of communication and also a tool of power. Subconsciously many British business people use it as a tool of power and take advantage in situations where they are working with non-native speakers."

Jean Vanhoegaerden, who teaches cross-cultural management at Ashridge business school near London, says a common mistake made by native speakers is to assume that the level of second-language speakers is as high as their own. "The other side of this problem", says Mr Vanhoegaerden, "is that non-native speakers tend to avoid direct communication. For example, they will use a colleague with a higher level of English than their own as an intermediary with their British business partners, and that kind of indirect communication is not good for business."

However, trainers and business leaders agree that the best ways for British people to increase their awareness of communication problems and achieve business advantage is to learn foreign languages.

"Not to have a second language is to depreciate yourself on a business and social front," says Ruth Lea of the Institute of Directors in London.

 The evolution of a distinct regional variety of English in Europe and its use as a lingua franca is the subject of a special debate organised by the Guardian Weekly and Macmillan Heinemann ELT, to be held at next year's International Association of English Language Teachers conference.

webTitle: Testing times in class as pressure grows for results

fields.headline: Testing times in class as pressure grows for results
fields.standfirst: Teachers must be ready to work with new and varied methods of assessment, explains Barry O'Sullivan
fields.trailText: Teachers must be ready to work with new and varied methods of assessment, explains Barry O'Sullivan
fields.body:
Over the past 20 years there has been a revolution in the world of language testing. Where early approaches to the subject were often based on intuition and necessity, these have been superseded by complex, theory-driven frameworks that define all aspects of test development.

On another front, the code of ethics of the International Language Testing Association is increasingly influential in ensuring that testing professionals are aware of their responsibilities in devising tests that are fair and unbiased, and that the inferences drawn from these tests are reliable and valid.

For all of this to make a real difference, though, teachers, researchers and policy-makers must also change. Whether they like it or not, almost all teachers are regularly asked to make judgments on the language of their students. In the EFL world these judgments are most often related to placement or achievement on language courses, and to estimations of a student's general proficiency. Teachers also find themselves having to assess the meaning of a score from a test such as the IELTS or the TOEIC, or having to recommend to a student a test of general proficiency such as the Cambridge First Certificate or TOEFL. While the ability to assess a test or test score is important to any teacher, it is even more important to be able to prepare, score and evaluate the tests that they are responsible for designing and administering.

Researchers and policy-makers, on the other hand, are more often faced with the task of making decisions on the reliability, validity and viability of tests with which they are associated. Though some educators take it upon themselves to keep up to date with developments in language testing, and develop a keen working knowledge of the area, the vast majority rely on the testing modules that form part of all self-respecting postgraduate programmes, or rely on their experience to get them through. An option that has become more and more popular in recent years is for educators to seek out courses that introduce participants to the complex world of language testing.

One such course on offer in Britain at the University of Reading is the Language Testing and Test Development course. This introduces participants to all aspects of test design, development, administration and evaluation, and uses an approach that calls for each person to focus on a project of his or her choice. This means that participants are "personalising" their learning and using the knowledge gained to make tangible improvements to the tests they are designing.

For the staff at Reading the course offers an opportunity to meet teachers, testers and researchers from around the world, who are working on a sometimes bewildering array of projects. This year we saw a group of testers from Denmark, who were working on a national test of Danish as a second language; language teachers of various nationalities working in a variety of circumstances (from Japanese high schools to Middle Eastern universities); researchers from Eastern Europe and Asia aware of the need for valid and reliable measures for their research; and students of language testing from around the world.

The great advantage of having such an eclectic group is that concepts such as validity, which by definition is very much context-related (meaning that a test can be valid in one context but not necessarily in another), can be explored from the perspective of "real" situations and experiences. This was exemplified by the differences in a pair of projects that were related to the assessment of spoken proficiency in contexts that couldn't have been more different: Slovenian children and Malaysian civil servants. Through extended discussion and comparison of both projects the participants and staff gained a deeper understanding of how tests of the same ability can differ in terms of construct (the ability being measured) and test validation.

Above all, however, the diverse interests and backgrounds of the group brought a realisation of the fact that particular features of any test should be seen as fundamental, irrespective of whether the test is for classroom use, or if it is to form part of a nationÍs educational policy.

Although these features are fundamental, their application is not universal. A good test is custom-made for a specific situation, based on these features, and requires the expertise of the language tester and the informed participation of the people who are working in that situation. Language testing is changing. The roles of teachers, researchers and policy-makers are becoming more unified by their common need to demonstrate a working knowledge of language testing theory and practice. To achieve this unity, they need to learn new skills together.

Dr Barry O'Sullivan is director of the Testing and Evaluation Research Unit at the University of Reading.

fields.trailText: Anniversary of independence declaration sees eight more Palestinian deaths
fields.body:
Soldiers opened up with heavy machine guns and rockets in a ferocious firefight yesterday, on a day of protests that saw eight more Palestinians cut down by Israeli gunfire in the West Bank and Gaza.

Yesterday, the 12th anniversary of a symbolic declaration of Palestinian independence, was one of the putative dates for Yasser Arafat to proclaim a state.

Instead, the day dawned with the arrest of several members of his Fatah tanzim militia - including the father of the youngest victim of the seven weeks of bloodshed - as Israeli undercover agents raided the West Bank villages to thwart a new Palestinian strategy of confronting soldiers and settlers head-on.

It ended in flames at midnight after Israeli attack helicopters fired three missiles at a Fatah office in the city of Hebron, setting it alight, after several hours of gun battles. Earlier in the evening, attack helicopters rocketed the town of Beit Jalla. Palestinian gunmen fired on the settlement of Gilo, built on occupied land on the southern edges of Jerusalem.

Despite the crackdown, and the killing of more than 220 people, mainly Palestinian, in the past seven weeks, thousands of protesters took to the streets yesterday. The death toll was the highest for a month.

In Ramallah's explosive confrontation, Israeli soldiers fired heavy machine guns, sending dozens of people diving behind cars for cover, and rocketed the offices of the Palestinian ministry of local government on the outskirts of town.

The ministry is headed by Saeb Erakat, the senior Palestinian negotiator who was seeking Israel's blessing for an independent state.

Israeli radio said 15 members of Fatah's tanzim militia were captured by undercover intelligence and police officers in raids on three villages in the Nablus area.

Fatah leaders said Abid al-Azeem Abdul al-Haq was arrested with six family members from Kusra village, near Nablus. They said they knew of the capture of 35 men from the Nablus area, and 13 from villages north of Ramallah, but many more could have been seized in the night raids.

In the last weeks, Mr al-Haq's two-year-old daughter has become an emblem of the intifada after she was killed, allegedly by an Israeli settler, while she was in his car.

Yesterday, leaders of Mr Arafat's Fatah movement announced they would no longer respect the division of the West Bank into areas A, B and C. The designations are the bedrock of seven years of peace agreements, graduating from full Israeli sovereignty in C areas to total Palestinian control over A areas, such as Ramallah and other Palestinian towns.

The West Bank is closed to Israeli settlers and soldiers, said Hussein Sheikh, who heads the Fatah tanzim militias in the West Bank. "The Palestinian people are convinced now that there is no coexistence with the occupation," he added.

In this new strategy, Fatah sees no difference between Israeli troops and some 200,000 Jewish settlers in the West Bank and Gaza.

The settlers are heavily armed, and are blamed by human rights organisations for attacks on Palestinian villages, especially in the Nablus area where their most extreme elements live in heavily fortified outposts.

"They are soldiers who have their with families with them," said Ahmed Ghnaim, a senior official in the local govern ment ministry. "All are legitimate targets.

"Our people will prevent Israeli soldiers and Israeli settlers from entering our cities and towns and we will start to rule our areas."

At the moment, however, such declarations are bravado as the arrests overnight dem-onstrate. Palestinian officials said Mr al-Haq was the head of Fatah in Kusra village, but his arrest was probably ordered as a reprisal for the publicity surrounding his daughter's death, rather than for his importance in the movement.

The attack took place in Area C - under full Israeli control. An army spokesman said Sara died when her father accidentally fired his gun in the living room, but there were eight bullet holes in his car. The disputed killings look set to continue with the Palestinians swearing yesterday to drive out the settlers, and regular reports of attacks by Jewish settlers on Palestinian motorists.

webTitle: Drug taking on increase in armed forces

fields.headline: Drug taking on increase in armed forces
fields.trailText: Drug taking in the armed forces is at a record level, according to the Ministry of Defence.
fields.body:
Drug taking in the armed forces is at a record level, according to the Ministry of Defence.

Five hundred and eighty soldiers, 41 sailors, and 14 RAF personnel were tested positive for controlled drugs between January and October this year.

Respective figures for the whole of last year - which were also up on 1998 - were 485, 33, and 10.

Of the army's total trained strength of 96,110, 0.26% were tested positive for cannabis, 0.04 % for cocaine, and 0.1% for other controlled substances - ecstasy, LSD, amphetamines, benzodiazepines, or other performance enhancing drugs, Jim Spellar, the armed forces minister, told Paul Keetch, Liberal Democrat defence spokesman, yesterday.

Figures for the navy were respectively 0.4%, 0.01%, and 0.03% of a total strength of 38,198, and 0.08%, 0.03%, and 0.03% for the RAF whose personnel totals 50,255.

"We all know that armed forces personnel are under increasing strain," said Mr Keetch. "While still small, these figures show a worrying trend and should serve as a warning sign that we hope and believe the government will take seriously."

Save in exceptional cases, a positive random test result, or the refusal to provide a specimen, will lead to army and RAF officers being required to resign and to administrative discharge in the case of an RN officer, said Mr Spellar.

Soldiers, ratings, and airmen would normally be administratively discharged, he said. Personnel of the rank of lance corporal or equivalent and below may be retained in exceptional circumstances .

webTitle: Lawyer who took on Microsoft ready to help Gore

fields.headline: Superstar lawyer who relishes the impossible
fields.standfirst:
Legal David Boies, who took on Microsoft, is ready to help Gore
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: David Boies, the closest thing to a superstar in US corporate law, likes his trials to be both high-profile and precedent-setting. This week he turned up in the highest profile legal battle in America as an adviser to Al Gore, the presidential contender.
fields.body:
David Boies, the closest thing to a superstar in US corporate law, likes his trials to be both high-profile and precedent-setting. This week he turned up in the highest profile legal battle in America as an adviser to Al Gore, the presidential contender.

Mr Boies appeared on national television to urge the Florida secretary of state, Republican Katherine Harris, to "do the right thing" and allow the full recount to go ahead. If she failed to do so, he would see her in court.

Democrats already have reason to love this sharp litigator, who wears ready-made suits and scruffy sneakers to court. He worked on behalf of the US government in its anti-trust case against Microsoft, the software giant, this year.

A small man known for his passion for red meat, he comes across as an intellectual bruiser in court. His wife, Mary, said recently of her husband: "He'll opt for the nearly impossible case every time. He likes the challenge of the work."

The 58-year-old's clients have included Napster, the cult song-swapping service which is being sued by the recording industry for copyright infringement.

It was his performance against Microsoft that brought him to national prominence, however, after Bill Gates, the world's richest man, moaned that Mr Boies was "out to get him". Mr Boies landed a slot in People magazine as well as Vanity Fair's 1999 Hall of Fame. The magazine photographed him behind the wheel of a 1938 Chevrolet bought at a charity auction, and publishing it alongside television stars and athletes.

The Gates comments were provoked by Mr Boies' decision to question the honesty of the Microsoft founder in court. The lawyer used a video with excerpts of Mr Gates' evasive, belligerent answers for questions about his company's behaviour. Demonstrating a flair for showmanship as well as an ability to dissect incredibly complicated legalese, he edited the video with in-house emails that contradicted parts of the Gates testimony.

Few Republicans fail to point out the link to Mr Boies' appearance. George W Bush is known to be against the tough anti-trust line taken by the current administration and he would be unlikely to take the action against Microsoft, now on appeal, any further.

His fees, understood to have been reduced when he acted for Napster, could also take a fair slice of the $3m (£2m) raised by the Gore campaign team for the recount effort.

His previous clients have expressed loyalty towards him. The comedian Garry Shandling has said of him: "I was taken by his earthiness and his authenticity, which I find rare, living in Hollywood."

Mr Boies is likely to prove unaffected by any Republican criticism. Talking of the Microsoft case, he said: "The more complicated it is, the more important it is to define what your simple truths are." This precept could be challenged in Florida.

webTitle: Internet thrilled the radio star

fields.headline: Internet thrilled the radio star
fields.standfirst:
Sean Dodson tunes in as the UK's first ever personalised radio station hits the airwaves
Net news
fields.trailText: Sean Dodson tunes in as the UK's first ever personalised radio station hits the airwaves
fields.body:
What claims to be the UK's first ever personalised, multi-channel internet radio station has been launched in London.

Two years in the making, Puremix.com is the first investment backed by Chrysalis New Media, a subsidiary of the famous record and television company.

Backed to the tune of £4m, the new station is an attempt to build the UK's first standalone net radio station that delivers multiple channels - or streams - to an audience listening in on their PCs.

What Puremix hopes to do is take the best bits of new media (interactivity and personalisation) - and mix them with the best from old media (disc jockeys between records and news on the hour). The Guest IJs - or internet jocks - include Barry White, Gary Crowley, international club DJ Paul Oakenfold and record producer Arthur Baker.

"Up until now, nothing has sounded like radio, as most internet radio stations have sounded like a CD jukebox," says Keith Pringle co-founder. "I think this is the first time that net radio sounds like real radio."

But despite all the bold claims, is Puremix a truly personalised station? The answer is, not quite. While Puremix does work out for you which stream is most likely to be closest to your preference, the service merely points you towards one of the 40 different channels of music. This, says Pringle, should be more than enough. Even in New York you would struggle to find 40 radio stations playing different styles of music, he says.

"The one thing I didn't realise - this was my first foray online - is that I don't think you can underestimate how complex technically the net is." This might explain why the launch has been dogged by technical problems, with Mac users in particular finding themselves locked out.

So how will the station make money? Puremix says its revenue model resembles that of commercial radio - a mix of advertising, sponsorship and promotions. Add to that a number of e-commerce opportunities (Puremix has already signed deals with Expedia, BOL and Sony Playstation 2) and the station claims it will reach profitability within three years. This is despite a further round of funding expected next year.

But to dominate the market Puremix will have to be quick. A number of other net radio stations are about to launch in the UK. Virgin Interactive is gearing up for a major launch early next year, Viacom - which owns MTV - will launch in Europe next spring, and stations such as StormLive.com, backed by DJ Bruno Brooks, have been streaming radio for some time now.

And let's not forget that the net is a global medium. US stations already take up a sizeable portion of the UK audience and, in fact, one new US station (still in beta), www.echo.com, has developed software that does allow for a truly personalised net station - not just 40 streams. Echo allows users to build their own stations and - crucially - invite others to listen with them. This, says Echo, is what net radio is all about: creating communities.

Also, a number of other innovations made by more established sites have been passed over. Spinner.com, for example, allows its listeners to skip tracks they do not like. Why hasn't Puremix gone the same way?

"If people have the option to skip forward, for a start, they will usually skip past a new song they hear," says Pringle. "If you never get to hear new songs you never get to love them."

To show its commitment to new music, Puremix even claims it has its own online version of John Peel, the veteran Radio 1 DJ.

webTitle: US Elections - what happened last time?

fields.headline: The last time all this happened what did they do? Strike a deal
fields.standfirst:
A near tie more than 100 years ago ended in sellout of blacks
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: It was America's most hotly contested presidential election. The Democratic candidate was ahead in the popular vote. His Republican rival was heading for victory in the electoral college. Florida held the key, with both parties engaged in a ruthless battle to claim the state. The outcome in Oregon, as well as Florida, remained up for grabs.
fields.body:
It was America's most hotly contested presidential election. The Democratic candidate was ahead in the popular vote. His Republican rival was heading for victory in the electoral college. Florida held the key, with both parties engaged in a ruthless battle to claim the state. The outcome in Oregon, as well as Florida, remained up for grabs.

The year was 1876.

If this month's presidential election in the US seems to set new standards for a close-fought contest that is bound to leave a big legacy of bitterness, consider the White House race 124 years ago between the Republican governor of Ohio, Rutherford Hayes, and the Democratic governor of New York, Samuel Tilden.

Early returns in the 1876 election suggested a comfortable victory for Tilden, seeking to recapture the presidency for the Democrats for the first time since the Civil War. When the votes were tallied, Tilden had 51% of the popular vote, against 48% for Hayes, a lead of more than 250,000 votes among the 8m cast.

Tilden had won the swing states of New York, Indiana and New Jersey. Assuming that he would win the southern states - which could be relied on to vote for the Democratic party in those days - Tilden went to bed thinking that he was one vote short of the 185 electoral college votes then needed for a majority.

But Tilden reckoned without Florida, whose four electoral college votes were among the southern total that both candidates were counting on to win.

The balloting and its aftermath in Florida, Louisiana and South Carolina were the focus of ferocious argument and manipulation.

Fraud raged on both sides. Boxes of votes were discovered hidden under water. Black voters were pivotal, with Republicans - the party of Lincoln - aggressively persuading blacks to vote while the Democrats, as the traditional party of the southern whites, struggled to stop them.

Physical intimidation and legal challenges abounded, and so did bribery. The results in Florida ended with both sides claiming victory. The Republicans said Hayes had it by 922 votes. Democrats said Tilden won by 94 votes. The US justice department sent detectives to Florida to investigate.

The election ended with all three southern states claimed by both sides and Oregon's votes also in dispute. To try to resolve the disputes, the US Congress was compelled to set up a 15-member bipartisan commission that included supreme court judges, senators and members of the House of Representatives.

By eight Republican votes to seven Democratic votes, the commission voted to accept the Republican claim in each of the cases, starting with Florida. Hayes was declared the winner by 185 electoral votes to 184 for Tilden,

Democrats threatened a filibuster as tensions rose again. Then, at the eleventh hour, the two parties struck a deal: Hayes would get the White House, as the committee had voted, but there would be a price: federal troops would be removed from southern states.

In effect, the arrangement returned the South to white rule for nearly a century.

On March 2 1877, just two days before the expiry of President Ulysses Grant's term, the US Senate confirmed Rutherford Hayes as his successor. During his single term he was known as "Mr Fraudulency".

webTitle: Suicide suspected after Fiat heir found dead

fields.headline: Suicide suspected after Fiat heir found dead
fields.trailText: The heir to Italy's most powerful industrial dynasty, was found dead yesterday. The body of Edoardo Agnelli, 46, was lying at the base of a 200ft viaduct in northern Italy after what police said was an apparent suicide.
fields.body:
The heir to Italy's most powerful industrial dynasty, was found dead yesterday. The body of Edoardo Agnelli, 46, was lying at the base of a 200ft viaduct in northern Italy after what police said was an apparent suicide.

It was the second time in three years that tragedy had struck the family that controls the Fiat manufacturing group: Edoardo's cousin, who was being groomed to lead the business, Giovanni Alberto Agnelli, died in late 1997 of a rare form of stomach cancer at the age of 32.

Police saw Edoardo Agnelli's dark Fiat Croma parked at the side of motorway between Turin and Savona, near the village of Fossano. His body was lying at the foot of one of the viaduct's pillars among plastic bags, bottles and other refuse.

His father, Gianni Agnelli, 79 - long the charismatic figure at Fiat's helm, and now its elder statesman as honorary chairman - visited the site to confirm that this was the body of his only son.

At the family villa outside Turin, at Villar Perosa, relatives came and went by helicopter through the day, preparing for the funeral that will follow a post-mortem examination.

Edoardo Agnelli, had shown little aptitude for the business world in which his family has played a leading role for more than a century. Rather, he went looking for spiritual illumination in India, having graduated in oriental religion and philosophy.

But his exclusion from the family's businesses - the closest he came to a responsible management role was as a director of the Agnelli-owned Juventus football club in the 1980s - caused him considerable unhappiness, as he showed in interviews where he protested at being marginalised when younger relatives got preferment.

"It's a tragedy," an unnamed woman friend in Rome was reported as telling the Italian media yesterday. "I was expecting him in the next few days. He certainly didn't seem depressed, but sometimes a moment of anguish can be enough."

Edoardo Agnelli hit the headlines in October 1990, when he was arrested in the Kenyan beach resort of Malindi for possession of heroin. "I feel exhausted," he said on leaving court after learning of his acquittal on the drug charges.

"It has been a tough battle, which I think I have faced fundamentally on my own." He found it hard to live up to the expectations of his father.

Gianni Agnelli, a former playboy who married Princess Marella Caracciolo, had abandoned a life of jet set dissipation to reveal an unexpected gift for business. Unlike his reclusive son he was at ease in the limelight occupied by a family that resembled royalty in republican post-war Italy.

Tension over the Fiat succession came to a head in 1986 when Edoardo - known by friends in New York as "Crazy Eddy" - announced his interest in taking charge of Italy's top industrial conglomerate.

In a newspaper interview in Assisi he criticised his family for seeing "my personal search as a voluntary abstention from the problems of the group, almost as though I were incapable of assuming responsibilities".

But there was no fulfilling role available for the family scion who was more at home in the company of Indian gurus or the denizens of psychedelic era New York than in a Turin boardroom.

In 1998 he again vented his frustration at being bypassed in favour of younger relatives."Part of my family has been taken over by a baroque and decadent logic," he said in an interview with the leftwing daily Il Manifesto. webTitle: Grateful Blair thanks voters

fields.headline: Grateful Blair thanks voters
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night attempted to counter accusations of arrogance by thanking voters for bringing him to power, as Labour's biggest campaign since the general election was launched.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night attempted to counter accusations of arrogance by thanking voters for bringing him to power, as Labour's biggest campaign since the general election was launched.

Attending a question and answer session in the marginal seat of St Albans, Hertfordshire, Mr Blair told supporters, many of whom had switched their allegiance at the last election, that he understood their frustration at the slow pace of change in areas like the health service, and urged them to "have faith".

The prime minister's admission came as his party sent out hundreds of thousands of letters to supporters thanking them for voting in the 1997 election to ensure that "Britain's moving in the right direction".

The letters also list the government's claims of success on the economy, employment and increasing the numbers of nurses.

Labour also launched a poster campaign, featuring the slogan "If you voted for change in 1997, thank you".

Mr Blair was later shown thanking voters in a Channel 4 programme that amounted to a party political broadcast.

In the three-minute programme, The Political Slot, Mr Blair was shown talking to five-year-olds at an infants school in Hove, East Sussex, before confessing to their teachers: "I want to say something unusual for a politician. I want to say thank you."

Addressing the camera, Mr Blair then extended his thanks to all working in the NHS and public services, together with the 11m who voted Labour at the last election. At the end of the short film, the same slogan used on the posters flashed up.

In St Albans, Mr Blair was given a standing ovation as he arrived and the audience laughed enthusiastically when, misunderstanding a question, he announced his determination not to have more children.

But Labour could not prevent one disgruntled voter from voicing her dissatisfaction. As Mr Blair entered his first class carriage to travel from King's Cross to St Albans, he suffered the wrath of Kim Rigg, a frequent traveller, who was ejected from his carriage.

"I said to the prime minister it's very, very fortunate he doesn't have to get a train every day. If he did like the rest of us he would get fed up with the squalor, the drunks, the unreliability and general inefficiency."

And she was in no doubt that this was Mr Blair's responsibility. "If anybody says they can run the country," she said, "then yes, the buck stops there."

webTitle: Labour allows Livingstone pro-Europe role

fields.headline: Labour allows Livingstone pro-Europe role
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has given the go-ahead for Ken Livingstone to become chairman of Britain in Europe's new regional campaign in the capital as part of the process of bringing the renegade mayor of London back into the Labour fold.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has given the go-ahead for Ken Livingstone to become chairman of Britain in Europe's new regional campaign in the capital as part of the process of bringing the renegade mayor of London back into the Labour fold.

Mr Livingstone, who broke with Labour to run an independent campaign which got him elected mayor last May, will head the London launch of Britain in Europe's efforts to boost the EU cause at a meeting on Monday.

Officials and MPs confirmed that Mr Blair had sanctioned the move.

It comes as both the prime minister and his foreign secretary, Robin Cook, made speeches this week to explain the importance of British EU membership in an increasingly interdependent world, which Mr Cook harnessed to an attack on the Eurosceptic media in the run-up to next month's Nice summit.

In Sheffield today he will take his case further by outlining the three principles on which Britain will conduct its negotiations in Nice, where Eurosceptics are already predicting a sell-out to Euro-federalism.

Mr Cook will say the principles are:

 That a strong Europe spells a strong Britain which enjoys greater bargaining power as a result

 That Europe is a union of democratic nations "which is not and will not become a superstate"

 That Britain "achieves more by playing a leading role than by standing on the sidelines".

The charismatic Mr Livingstone used to be an anti-European, but swung full circle like many other leftwingers in the 1980s and now advocates British membership of the single currency as vital to the economic interests of London - Europe's financial centre with 1m jobs in finance related services.

Since being expelled from Labour for running against Labour's official candidate, Frank Dobson, the Brent East MP has made no secret of his wish to heal the breach.

He has considerable grassroots support, but at the weekend conference of the Greater London Labour party, a Blairite loyalist, Chris Robbins, easily beat Geoff Martin, a Livingstone ally, for the vacant post of chairman.

Coincidentally or not, 24 hours later Mr Livingstone appeared on BBC1's current affairs programme, On the Record, and made a series of conciliatory remarks ranging across the policy spectrum, albeit with the exception of transport policy.

On John Prescott's public private partnership plans for the tube and his own plans for congestion charges for cars, Mr Livingstone insisted he is right, while making light of alleged rows with the deputy prime minister.

But on taxes for motorists, the need to prevent fuel protesters' lorries jamming up London's streets and the need to remain vigilant against dissident IRA bombers, he sounded on New Labour's message.

He even argued that the dome minister, Lord Falconer, should not be forced to resign.

"He had this mess dumped in his lap when it was unsaveable. I don't think anyone else would have actually spent less or managed it better."

He also predicted that he would be back inside the Labour party.

"As you can imagine, I am in regular contact with party officials and government ministers. This is something that bubbles along in the background. There will be a time when it is right."

The deal in Scotland which has allowed the veteran leftwing MP Dennis Canavan back into the fold after he ran for the Scottish parliament as an independent has also encouraged the mayor.

His prediction of a reconciliation will gain credibility now that he is on a platform backed by Mr Blair, sharing it with Tony Nelson, a Tory ex-minister and banker, Nick Raynsford, the minister for London, and with Susan Kramer, the defeated Liberal Democrat candidate for London mayor, who now works with him on transport policy.

In his speech at the Sheffield Star newspaper today, Mr Cook will say "you only score goals if you play in the team" and will liken Eurosceptics to the "bar-room bore sitting at a table in the corner, criticising the club committee for how badly they are running the show... but never actually running for election to the committee himself".

webTitle: EU and US square up for battle of the Hague

fields.headline: EU and US square up for battle of the Hague
fields.standfirst:
Europe says it is doing its bit to cut emissions, but accuses America of ducking the issue
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The prospects are bleak of preventing a total breakdown of the climate talks in the Hague where 180 countries are trying to conclude three years of negotiations designed to save the world from the fast increasing threat of global warming.
fields.body:
The prospects are bleak of preventing a total breakdown of the climate talks in the Hague where 180 countries are trying to conclude three years of negotiations designed to save the world from the fast increasing threat of global warming.

Politicians from around the world are flying in this weekend to put the final touches to what should be a legally binding treaty that would make Europe, the United States and the rest of the developed world cut greenhouse gas emissions in order to save the entire globe from the worst effects of climate change.

So far the talks have been a shambles with officials still trying to sort out half a dozen issues of principle that remain unresolved despite hundreds of hours of negotiations.

The Americans, who were always going to get the blame if the Hague talks collapsed, are central to the problem. US negotiators had already said they could not reach their targets to cut greenhouse gas emissions without exploiting a number of loopholes in the agreement, but last week's US elections have made matters far worse.

The US Congress and Senate have to ratify any agreement. Both are dominated by Republicans who have no interest in doing so.

The talks are about the same agreement which, in 1997 in Kyoto in Japan, was hailed as a breakthrough when targets were set for every developed country in the world for cuts in greenhouse gas emissions. The 5.5% reductions in carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions for the developed world were seen as the beginning of the long road to the 60% needed to give the world a stable climate.

Since then there has been deadlock on how to conclude this first step. The US and its allies Canada, Australia and Japan have back-pedalled desperately to avoid taking real domestic action. They are trying not to upset the profligate lifestyle of their consumers and face the sort of political backlash that high petrol prices have caused in Britain, Germany and France.

The astonishing fact is that 24% of the world's carbon dioxide is produced in the US - a nation used to the cheapest petrol in the developed world and the one with the least energy efficient economy.

All but a handful of people now accept that climate change is a real threat. But because they include the executives of oil giant Exxon, George W Bush, and many senior Republicans, the deal seems further away than it did three years ago.

The propaganda machine paid for by the oil lobby has been unrelenting in the US, and Opec members have done their best to hold up the talks for the last three years, but the real battleground in the Hague in the next week is now between the governments of the EU and the US and its allies.

The EU, led by Britain and Germany, has taken climate change seriously for the last 10 years. Helped partly by the closure of the coal mines in Britain and the shutdown of heavily polluting industries in the former East Germany, the two countries both have carbon dioxide reductions targets of 20% - a serious contribution to the EU total target of 8%. This allows less developed countries such as Spain, Greece and Ireland to grow and actually increase emissions on the 1990 baseline.

There is some doubt whether the EU will reach its target of 8% by 2010 without additional measures but at least there are serious efforts under way.

The US openly admits it cannot reach its 7% reduction target by 2010. The growth in the economy since 1990 is partly to blame, but the Clinton administration has always said that it never intended to make all the cuts at home.

There were a number of ways of using the might of the dollar and the technical know-how of the US to make reductions outside its borders that could be counted against domestic emissions. To the greenies and some in the EU these are loopholes which would allow the US to carry on business as usual, and the world would be no better off.

The stumbling blocks in the Hague that the talks have so far failed to overcome are about these loopholes. The EU refuses so far to budge on the demand that the US take at least half of all measures to reduce carbon dioxide at home. The US wishes to exploit them without limit to reach its entire target outside its borders if necessary.

There are three main loopholes. The first and best understood is carbon trading. If a country - Russia and Ukraine are the best examples - exceeds its targets of limiting carbon emissions, it can sell the surplus to a third country like the US that cannot reach its target. In this way the target for both countries is reached.

The collapse of industry in the former Soviet Union has meant emissions of carbon from Russia and Ukraine have gone down hugely since 1990. Both countries are supposed to peg extra emissions to zero on 1990 levels by 2010 but neither economy will recover sufficiently by then to have reached anything like the former level of emissions.

The US wants to buy these non-existent "saved" emissions to put towards its own target. Critics say this so-called "hot air" purchase is cheating because there will be no extra reductions in emissions than would have happened anyway.

The second and even more controversial loophole is "sinks". At its simplest, this is the US, or any other country, planting forests on its own land, or in other continents, and counting the carbon saved in the tree trunks against its own domestic emissions. This is superficially attractive but detractors say the carbon saved is difficult to measure and question what happens to the credits gained if the forest burns down.The third loophole is opened by a wealthy country paying for a project in a poor or less developed one with the aim of saving carbon.

"These loopholes that the US insists on fully exploiting will render the agreement meaningless," said John Lanchbery of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds. "The science of sinks is hardly developed so it is impossible to say whether the savings are real or imaginary."

Three years of argument have failed to resolve any of these issues. There are others, but it is the issue of loopholes on which the talks are most likely to founder. If anything, positions have become more entrenched.

Top Dodges

If countries can show they have saved carbon emissions by taking measures other than reducing energy consumption they can claim credit under the Kyoto climate treaty. Here are some of the loopholes:

• Spread iron filings or iron solution across the surface of Antarctic ocean and other seas to stimulate plankton growth . Calculate how much carbon is in the bodies of plankton when it dies and sinks to the bottom of the sea and claim credits

• Feed cattle, pigs and sheep special diets to reduce flatulence and so claim credits for reducing the amount of methane in the atmosphere

• Buy the carbon dioxide Russia and Ukraine have not emitted since 1990 as a result of the collapse of their economies. The " hot air " available for a few dollars a tonne means the US does not have to take domestic action to curb its ever increasing emissions but does nothing to help the climate

• Buy up forests and claim credits for not cutting them down, or plant forests at home or in foreign countries, and claim for the carbon dioxide captured in the trees and turned into wood

• Use modern farming techniques like direct drilling into the soil rather than ploughing which releases carbon into the atmosphere

• Pump carbon dioxide into the ocean to be absorbed by the sea, or pump it in liquid form into oil wells

• Build nuclear power stations in China and India and claim it as "clean" technology, thereby keeping the nuclear industry alive and using carbon credits to subsidise the costs

• Some Americans have suggested firing mirrors into space to reflect back the sunlight and so claim credit for slowing down the heating up of the planet

webTitle: Putin gained from Aeroflot scam, says media mogul

fields.headline: Putin gained from Aeroflot scam, says media mogul
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Boris Berezovsky, the controversial Russian magnate, launched a bitter attack on President Vladimir Putin yesterday, charging the Kremlin chief with ruinous policies and claiming that Mr Putin's election campaigns were funded by millions said to be embezzled.
fields.body:
Boris Berezovsky, the controversial Russian magnate, launched a bitter attack on President Vladimir Putin yesterday, charging the Kremlin chief with ruinous policies and claiming that Mr Putin's election campaigns were funded by millions said to be embezzled.

Refusing to return to Moscow to face questioning on his alleged involvement in a scam to embezzle almost $1bn (£700m) from the national carrier, Aeroflot, Mr Berezovsky said bluntly that Mr Putin was attacking him for political reasons.

He contended that the president was the beneficiary of the money that the businessman is alleged to have embezzled.

"When Putin was a presidential candidate, he was absolutely unperturbed when profits from Swiss companies working with Aeroflot were used to finance the Unity party and the presidential election campaign," Mr Berezovsky said in an open letter published in the Russian press yesterday.

He gave no evidence that the Aeroflot income was siphoned off to fund Kremlin politics.

Mr Berezovsky controls the main state television channel, ORT, which last year played a decisive role in promoting Mr Putin and his fledgling party, destroying his rivals for the Russian presidency.

The president is trying to silence media criticism to establish "a system of personal power", he said.
