webTitle: Schizophrenic knifeman whose illness was dismissed as side-effect of drug taking

fields.headline: Schizophrenic knifeman whose illness was dismissed as side-effect of drug taking
fields.standfirst: The background:  Harrison attack
fields.trailText: On a chilly day last December, a tall man with long, unkempt hair and staring eyes armed himself with a knife and set off on a mission.
fields.body:
On a chilly day last December, a tall man with long, unkempt hair and staring eyes armed himself with a knife and set off on a mission.

Michael Abram believed he was St Michael and had been ordered by God to kill George Harrison. He thought the former Beatle was a witch, a "phantom menace" who was possessing him.

He failed in his mission because Harrison's wife, Olivia, fought back so fiercely.

But it was not the only failure in this extraordinary case. A raft of psychiatrists saw Abram over 10 years and decided that his mental instability was caused by drug-taking. Doctors now say their colleagues failed to see what should have been obvious - that Abram was a schizophrenic who used drugs to suppress his symptoms.

There were few clues to the tragedy that was to follow in Abram's early life.

He was born in Liverpool, the son of labourer Raymond, now 54, and store worker Lynda, 52. Michael was the eldest of three children brought up in a three bedroomed council house. His mother describes him as a "normal lad" who liked football and pop music. Abram attended a Roman Catholic comprehensive school which he left aged 16, with three O-levels and a few CSEs.

He had met his girlfriend, Jeanette, at school. Later they had a daughter, Vikki, and a son, Michael junior.

Abram got a good job in telesales. He did well but found it high-pressured. Mrs Abram claims her son began smoking cannabis and later took heroin as a way of coping with the pressure to cope with stress.

But in the late 1980s Abram and Jeanette began to argue violently. In March 1990, his mother says, he was seen by a psychiatrist at Whiston hospital on Merseyside. He was diagnosed as psychotic with paranoid delusions. He was seen again the following year but then did not come into regular contact with psychiatrists.

He then split up with his girlfriend and moved into a dismal 10th floor flat in Huyton, Liverpool.

His mother said that at about this time he began having "unreal thoughts" and became obsessed with music. He was fixated on Oasis, believing the song Wonderwall was about one of the walls in his flat. He had quit work and began begging his family for money for drugs, saying this was the only way he could escape the "spooks".

From 1996 he had regular contact with doctors and psychiatrists. But the conclusion was that his problems stemmed from drug abuse.

At one point in 1997 he was admitted to hospital and stayed, according to his mother, for 11 days but was then discharged.

Mrs Abram said he turned up at the family home. She said: "He sobbed and said, 'Nobody can help me'. I could see the real fear in him."

He bought headphones and played music on a personal cassette player, apparently because it stopped the voices. And then one day he borrowed his mother's Beatles tapes. She said: "He became obsessed."

At one time he became convinced that he was the fifth Beatle. Standing 6ft 4in, he became a familiar sight in Liverpool walking down the street and singing Beatles lyrics. Finally, in January 1998 one doctor diagnosed Abram as being schizophrenic but he discharged himself. By April the psychiatrists who were treating him had decided he was not schizophrenic and his mental state was put down instead to his drug-taking. His mother said: "I was desperate for help with him so I looked up schizophrenia and to me it all seemed to fit with the things he said and did." Last year he became obsessed with the eclipse and began to believe he had been possessed by a "phantom menace", a figure who had been predicted by Nostradamus. He believed he had been chosen by God to rid the world of drugs and suddenly came off heroin, but this made his mental state even worse.

In October last year he first mentioned George Harrison. She said: "We were just chatting when he snapped his fingers and said, 'I've got it - Paul McCartney is a witch but George Harrison is the boss'." He linked Harrison with the phantom menace.

Abram was arrested three times within 10 days in November last year. The police realised something was badly wrong and took him to Whiston. But on November 17 there was a confrontation with a nurse and he was escorted out, to the horror of his family. Until the time of the attack he had no more contact with psychiatrists.

Mrs Abram said: "It is incredible that the nurses ignored his symptoms. He must have been talking about the Beatles while he was in there saying that he was on a mission." By Christmas, Mrs Abram said, her son was "desperately ill".At Christmas, Mrs Abram said, he made the trip from Liverpool to Harrison's home. He asked a priest about Harrison, peered over the fence of his mansion, and sang in the square hoping to provoke an uprising against the star.

On December 29 he returned, intending to kill Harrison. Later he told psychiatrists that he hoped he would be picked up by security guards. He used a stone angel to batter his way through a window in the early hours of December 30.

The intruder spotted Harrison on a first floor gallery. Abram later said that Harrison had asked him who he was. He replied: "You know who I am." Abram said he believed Harrison then spoke in "the devil's tongue".

The court was told that this was likely to be Harrison chanting "Hare Krishna, Hare Krishna", in a vain attempt to distract Abram.

The attacker later said that if Harrison had talked to him normally he probably would not have attacked him.

Abram told police that he had not broken any law because it said in the Bible that it was right to kill sorcerers and witches.

After the attack, Mrs Abram said, she had a call from a psychiatrist who had examined her son. He told her that Michael was very ill. She said: "This psychiatrist had only seen him for two half-hour sessions and it seemed he had diagnosed him that quickly. I was astonished: he was telling me he suspected that Michael was a paranoid schizophrenic and would need treatment."

Abram is now being treated at the Scott Clinic, a psychiatric unit in Merseyside. His mother said: "Now Michael is absolutely brilliant ... the son I had years ago." She said he had accepted he would be on medication for the rest of his life and feels huge remorse.

Mrs Abram is calling for a full inquiry into why her son did not receive proper treatment before the attack.

She said: "I realise that services for mental health are badly underfunded. It is the Cinderella of the NHS. It is time that was changed."

Letter of regret

Michael Abram's solicitor last night revealed a letter of apology the defendant had written to the Harrison family.

The letter, addressed to the crown prosecution service, read:

"I'm writing this in the hope that it will be passed on to Mr and Mrs Harrison. I wish to say how sorry I am for the alarm, distress and injury that I have caused when I was ill.

"I have seen many expert doctors prior to December 30, 1999, and yet I've never been told that I was suffering with schizophrenia or any mental illness.

"I thought my delusions were real and that everything that I was experiencing was some kind of witchcraft.

"I can see that all the things I believed then were not true and were just part of my illness.

"I know that Mr and Mrs Harrison fought for their lives on December 30, 1999, and that they must have been terrified by the lunatic in their house.

"I am very glad that I did not do any worse damage and I certainly do not blame them for any of the injuries I received myself.

"I am very sorry that this happened but I do not believe that it was all my fault as I was very ill at the time.

"I hope that Mr and Mrs Harrison can accept my sincere apologies. Yours sincerely, M. Abram."

webTitle: Bleak future for heart surgery in Oxford

fields.headline: Bleak future for heart centre 'riven by conflict'
fields.standfirst:
Oxford Management arrogance is denounced

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The future for heart surgery in Oxford, which was seen as a centre of excellence 10 years ago, is bleak unless its cardiac centre's five surgeons learn to work as a team, a report commissioned by the NHS executive has said.
fields.body:
The future for heart surgery in Oxford, which was seen as a centre of excellence 10 years ago, is bleak unless its cardiac centre's five surgeons learn to work as a team, a report commissioned by the NHS executive has said.

It denounced the "chaotic"' arrangements for operations, which included antagonism between surgeons, overbooked lists, apparent emphasis on putting private patients before NHS ones and failure to prioritise by clinical need.

The investigation concluded that the Oxford heart centre at John Radcliffe hospital had developed a culture in which there was a risk of cronyism.

Robust procedures for some aspects of patient care did not exist, the local NHS trust had failed to respond appropriately to nurses' concerns and management had not monitored arrangements to address weaknesses at the centre. "As a consequence, cardiac surgery levels are at their lowest for a decade, and robust clinical audit is still an aspiration rather than a reality," the report said.

In four years the number of adult open-heart operations carried out in Oxford fell from more than 1,400 to 800. In the past year alone, the number of operations cancelled on the day of admission rose by 20% to 130. The waiting list rose by 30% to 270, with those waiting for more than nine months up from 21 to 51.

Staff interviewed during the investigation divided into two camps - one still believing Oxford to be a world leader in various medical fields, with many of the problems down to lack of money and poor management, the other believing an "Oxford complacency, even arrogance" was hampering development.

The report noted that Stephen Westaby, the driving force behind cardiac surgery at the John Radcliffe, had "tended to isolate himself from others in the unit", building up his own research team for a separately funded, artificial heart programme.

The results of disciplinary investigations into the alleged behaviour of a surgeon at the centre, Ravi Pillai, are expected to be published soon. Oxford coroner Nicholas Gardiner is investigating the death of a two-year-old Aylesbury girl Safeena Begum in August last year.

webTitle: Comment: The treaty of Nice

fields.headline: Time for the sceptics to be trounced by the truth
fields.standfirst:
The British need a civics lesson from Tony Blair before they accept the euro

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The British need a civics lesson from Tony Blair before they accept the euro.
fields.body:
The treaty of Nice, whatever it contains, will be a political document. It will be about the functioning of the European union as a political organisation. The changes it's likely to enshrine could be called good housekeeping. They update the house rules to accommodate expansion of the membership. Revising the relative voting strengths of the members is necessary, as the numbers grow. So is reviewing the size of the management, the commission. Reconsidering the balance between majority and unanimous voting is highly sensitive, but essential if the enterprise is to have any chance of grappling with problems that need continent- wide solutions.

These are quite mechanistic issues. But they are also political, not just in the sense of requiring choices by political leaders but because they're meant to assist in an integrationist project. The EU is about nation states doing quite a lot of things together, and building a body of rules to make that possible. It's also, as Joschka Fischer said on Tuesday, about confining the EU within agreed limits, to which end a constitution would be helpful, a document that would inevitably describe a unique form of federalism. At the bottom of it is the need to make political sense of the aspirations and obligations in the treaty of Rome, in which Britain has been a major participant for nearly 30 years.

To call this a quest for a superstate is mere propaganda. Endless repetition in the hyperbolic output of British anti-EU politicians has given the word bogus recognition, but that is what it is: bogus. Portrayal of the EU as a demonic conspiracy against the people, especially the British people, by a bureaucratic SS has become a substitute for thought and a suppressor of creative speculation about how the experiment might best move forward.

Tony Blair, along with Robin Cook, is doing what he can to counter this. He did it with a significant speech in Warsaw, and again at Guild-hall on Monday. In the Commons yesterday he offered a few examples of how EU collective action has been in the interest of every European citizen, to which the paranoid hyperbolists across the House could offer no retort save a few juvenile jokes. But he does not really address the core of the antagonism, which derives from the inability of British governments from the start to explain with clarity that the EU is a political project, only capable of being accomplished by redefining what national sovereignty means.

Mr Blair is the inheritor of a 30-year history. It is not a history of lies. Ted Heath and the other creators of British membership were always very clear that the EU was not just about free trade. But they were not so clear about what it was. They could not find the words or the courage to present "Europe" in its full splendour as an integrationist process. They didn't confront the British with the reality of what they were getting into. They told them entry was absolutely essential, but also that nothing they cared about would change. The truth is all there in the small print of their speeches and answers. But the campaign to change the hearts and minds of a proud and anti-continental country never happened. I cannot recall a single speech by a British minister, let alone a series of them, which explained in enthusiastic terms why both parliament and the courts needed, for the greater good, to lose some of their independent powers.

This left a nation wide open to the sceptic rage that found its voice, and began to wield some power, under the Major government. John Major wanted to be European, but never escaped his entrapment in the pretence that Britain could be master of her fate come what may. After every successive summit, he said she had been. The dialogue of delusion was much enriched. There was no way Major could be straight with people. Fighting for survival, he had forgotten what straight, in this context, meant. Now the chickens coming home to roost darken the sky of a country that needs to be persuaded, from first principles, of the benefits of what it did 30 years ago.

That's what Mr Blair feels he has to do before the Nice conference. He is the only leader since Heath to address Europe with a measure of constructive enthusiasm, but even he finds himself on the defensive. He's still ensnared by the analysis of deception and betrayal. Though he makes a fierce case for the lunacy of detaching Britain from the centre of Europe, he still meets the phobic hallucination of the superstate with an extreme reluctance to concede that the EU has, or will have, any of the aspects of a state at all: a shared political identity or, for certain purposes, a shared government that diminishes the familiar sovereignty of the nation state.

His message is mostly about economics: jobs, trade, markets, growth. It is indispensable. So is continuity of commitment to the single currency, provided exchange rates converge. Peter Mandelson made an important private speech last night, pointing out the considerable benefits euroland is beginning to show for its investment in the currency, and the opportunities for growth which are likely to make it a success. The advances in Germany, France and Italy, which tend to be buried by the British press, are another harbinger for the never-in brigade, which it is no more willing to consider than the retreat of Japanese investors from a country trading into its major market with an over-valued currency.

So, contrary to the triumphalist certainties of the sceps, the British euro is not a dead letter. It remains at the centre of Mr Blair's second term strategy. But before he can hope to win a referendum, I think he needs to deal more candidly with an issue he doesn't talk about, yet which is the radioactive element at the core of anti-Europeanism: the pretence that this is not a political project. To be persuaded to accept the euro, the British people need a civics lesson that goes back beyond his chosen terrain. He thinks he has to begin the case for the euro by explaining why the EU itself is a good thing. I think what people need before that is to be reminded what the EU is: an integrationist enterprise, now at a stage where fundamental debate is beginning about what its final shape should be.

The sceps don't want such a debate. Uninterested in what other member-countries think, they already know their answer. Mr Blair would like the debate, but knows that unless Britain enters the euro, her voice will be more and more brusquely disregarded. It's right that at Nice he'll be defending, alongside 14 rival leaders, the national interest. But the only way to rebut the destruction-of-Britain-as-we-know-it already being announced as Nice's inevitable outcome is calmly to remind people that the EU is and always was about the invention of a new politics, which we are eager to be part of. This may sound painfully elementary. But there are decades of dissembling to correct. The way to beat the lies of the Sun is to start telling the truth which, for 30 self-destructive years, has dared not speak its name.

At the bottom of it is the need to make political sense of the aspirations and obligations in the treaty of Rome, in which Britain has been a major participant for nearly 30 years. To call this a quest for a superstate is mere propaganda. Endless repetition in the hyperbolic output of British anti-EU politicians has given the word bogus recognition, but that is what it is: bogus. Portrayal of the EU as a demonic conspiracy against the people, especially the British people, by a bureaucratic SS has become a substitute for thought and a suppressor of creative speculation about how the experiment might best move forward. Tony Blair, along with Robin Cook, is doing what he can to counter this. He did it with a significant speech in Warsaw, and again at Guild-hall on Monday. In the Commons yesterday he offered a few examples of how EU collective action has been in the interest of every European citizen, to which the paranoid hyperbolists across the House could offer no retort save a few juvenile jokes. But he does not really address the core of the antagonism, which derives from the inability of British governments from the start to explain with clarity that the EU is a political project, only capable of being accomplished by redefining what national sovereignty means. Mr Blair is the inheritor of a 30-year history. It is not a history of lies. Ted Heath and the other creators of British membership were always very clear that the EU was not just about free trade. But they were not so clear about what it was. They could not find the words or the courage to present "Europe" in its full splendour as an integrationist process. They didn't confront the British with the reality of what they were getting into. They told them entry was absolutely essential, but also that nothing they cared about would change. The truth is all there in the small print of their speeches and answers. But the campaign to change the hearts and minds of a proud and anti-continental country never happened. I cannot recall a single speech by a British minister, let alone a series of them, which explained in enthusiastic terms why both parliament and the courts needed, for the greater good, to lose some of their independent powers. This left a nation wide open to the sceptic rage that found its voice, and began to wield some power, under the Major government. John Major wanted to be European, but never escaped his entrapment in the pretence that Britain could be master of her fate come what may. After every successive summit, he said she had been. The dialogue of delusion was much enriched. There was no way Major could be straight with people. Fighting for survival, he had forgotten what straight, in this context, meant. Now the chickens coming home to roost darken the sky of a country that needs to be persuaded, from first principles, of the benefits of what it did 30 years ago. That's what Mr Blair feels he has to do before the Nice conference. He is the only leader since Heath to address Europe with a measure of constructive enthusiasm, but even he finds himself on the defensive. He's still ensnared by the analysis of deception and betrayal. Though he makes a fierce case for the lunacy of detaching Britain from the centre of Europe, he still meets the phobic hallucination of the superstate with an extreme reluctance to concede that the EU has, or will have, any of the aspects of a state at all: a shared political identity or, for certain purposes, a shared government that diminishes the familiar sovereignty of the nation state. His message is mostly about economics: jobs, trade, markets, growth. It is indispensable. So is continuity of commitment to the single currency, provided exchange rates converge. Peter Mandelson made an important private speech last night, pointing out the considerable benefits euroland is beginning to show for its investment in the currency, and the opportunities for growth which are likely to make it a success. The advances in Germany, France and Italy, which tend to be buried by the British press, are another harbinger for the never-in brigade, which it is no more willing to consider than the retreat of Japanese investors from a country trading into its major market with an over-valued currency. So, contrary to the triumphalist certainties of the sceps, the British euro is not a dead letter. It remains at the centre of Mr Blair's second term strategy. But before he can hope to win a referendum, I think he needs to deal more candidly with an issue he doesn't talk about, yet which is the radioactive element at the core of anti-Europeanism: the pretence that this is not a political project. To be persuaded to accept the euro, the British people need a civics lesson that goes back beyond his chosen terrain. He thinks he has to begin the case for the euro by explaining why the EU itself is a good thing. I think what people need before that is to be reminded what the EU is: an integrationist enterprise, now at a stage where fundamental debate is beginning about what its final shape should be. The sceps don't want such a debate. Uninterested in what other member-countries think, they already know their answer. Mr Blair would like the debate, but knows that unless Britain enters the euro, her voice will be more and more brusquely disregarded. It's right that at Nice he'll be defending, alongside 14 rival leaders, the national interest. But the only way to rebut the destruction-of-Britain-as-we-know-it already being announced as Nice's inevitable outcome is calmly to remind people that the EU is and always was about the invention of a new politics, which we are eager to be part of. This may sound painfully elementary. But there are decades of dissembling to correct. The way to beat the lies of the Sun is to start telling the truth which, for 30 self-destructive years, has dared not speak its name. hugoyoung@compuserve.com

webTitle: TheStreet turns bumpy for UK site

fields.headline: TheStreet turns bumpy for UK site
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: The future of TheStreet.co.uk was thrown into doubt last night as the financial news website became the latest high-profile online venture to run into trouble.
fields.body:
The future of TheStreet.co.uk was thrown into doubt last night as the financial news website became the latest high-profile online venture to run into trouble.

Shareholders in the company are understood to be at odds over future funding for the website, which was introduced in February.

TheStreet.com, the US company which owns a controlling stake in the business, has run into problems of its own and there are fears that the plug may now be pulled entirely in the UK.

Jagnotes, a rival US financial site, closed its British operation weeks ago.

Venture capital investors, led by Chase Capital Partners and Barclays Private Equity, are understood to have demanded a put option on part of TheStreet.com stake in return for putting up more cash.

However, TheStreet.com is thought to be reluctant to agree to their terms.

The British business is trying to raise between £5m and £10m. It has around £1m in the bank and is burning £500,000 a month, sources said.

An announcement is expected as early as today from the US outlining the extent of Thestreet.com's difficulties. In September, the US company said it was "evaluating opportunities" to link with other financial news providers after warning that its summer relaunch had flopped.

The business also conceded that advertising revenue had been "disappointing". TheStreet.com appointed investment bank Wasserstein Perella to advise on a possible joint venture or buyer.

Backing of £10.6m was provided by venture capital firms for the launch of the UK website. TheStreet.com did not inject any cash but retained more than half of the business.

The promise of wealth for journalists who accepted stock options in the company has been scuppered by the poor performance of its US affiliate. Shares in the US parent, which traded at up to $70 over the past year, have been changing hands for less than $5.

TheStreet.co.uk had an inasupicious start and parted company with editor-in-chief Martin Baker less than three months after the launch of service amid reports of low morale.

By the end of September TheStreet.co.uk had 150,000 registered users with an average of 4m page impressions a month.

webTitle: Sinn Fein to challenge exclusion in courts

fields.headline: Sinn Fein to challenge exclusion in courts
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland peace process took another turn for the worse yesterday when Sinn Fein announced that it will mount a legal challenge to nullify David Trimble's attempt to exclude republican ministers from meetings with their Irish counterparts.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland peace process took another turn for the worse yesterday when Sinn Fein announced that it will mount a legal challenge to nullify David Trimble's attempt to exclude republican ministers from meetings with their Irish counterparts.

The resort to the courts by Sinn Fein's president, Gerry Adams, caused alarm and dismay among rival parties at Stormont and in Hillsborough castle, where the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is struggling to keep the process afloat.

Mr Trimble angered nationalists and republicans last month - and alarmed Mr Mandelson - when he faced down a unionist revolt over the lack of progress in decommissioning IRA weapons dumps by trying to prevent the two Sinn Fein ministers, Bairbre de Brun and Martin McGuinness, attending a routine cross-border meeting.

The meeting was postponed. Without a deal another such meeting is set to be scrapped next Friday. But unionist frustration is matched on the nationalist/republican side.

Mr Adams spent 12 days in talks with Mr Trimble and with the Irish taoiseach trying to resolve the latest impasse before abandoning the political options in favour of a legal strategy. He accuses Mr Trimble of "playing for a suspension" of the entire process.

Mr Mandelson signalled his disquiet at Sinn Fein's threat by saying: "People have the right to use the courts but this is essentially a political problem and should be resolved politically." The leading unionist Sir Reg Empey was more blunt. He called the move "a protracted stunt" which would trigger "even more serious action" by unionists if it succeeded.

Neither side sounds as if it can give ground and Sinn Fein indicated that the precise form of legal action to overturn Mr Trimble's unilateralist ban will emerge later today. It could launch an action against either Mr Trimble or Mr Mandelson.

Mr Adams said: "We have tried to resolve this matter politically... we will continue in contact with both governments, but I have little confidence in the British government's management of this process...

"Our decision to take legal action, despite the lack of confidence by nationalists and republicans in the legal and judicial system here, is an indication of our grave dissatisfaction at how this British government, which promised so much, has pandered to a unionist veto."

The north-south strand of the peace process which culminated in the Good Friday agreement of 1998 is of special importance to nationalists because they believe it points to growing cross-border cooperation and the prospect of ultimate unity.

The other two strands were east-west, involving London and Dublin, and the internal settlement which made Mr McGuiness and Ms de Brun ministers in the fragile administration. Mr Adams argues that Mr Trimble's move breached the agreement and that Mr Mandelson should intervene to say so.

 Martin McGuinness is to hold talks on the peace process with the White House, Sinn Fein confirmed yesterday. The Mid Ulster MP, who is on a three day visit to the United States as Northern Ireland's education minister, is due to brief officials in Washington later today on the peace process, policing and demilitarisation.

webTitle: Elderly patients suffered cruel treatment

fields.headline: Elderly patients suffered cruel treatment
fields.standfirst:
Carlisle Nurses raised alarm but trust failed to act

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Patients with mental health problems were subjected to "unprofessional, counter-therapeutic and degrading, even cruel practices" at the former Garlands hospital in Carlisle, built as a Victorian asylum.
fields.body:
Patients with mental health problems were subjected to "unprofessional, counter-therapeutic and degrading, even cruel practices" at the former Garlands hospital in Carlisle, built as a Victorian asylum.

The CHI report reveals that one patient was tied to a commode. Others were fed while on commodes. Some were denied food, clothing and blankets. The CHI's chief executive, Peter Homa, said that elderly patients at the hospital, run by the North Lakeland NHS trust, had suffered appalling abuse. "At the time of our visit to the trust, we could not be sure that it would not happen again," he said. "The culture of this organisation needs to change fundamentally, so that the rights of patients are understood right across the trust."

The alarm was first raised in May 1996 by five student nurses concerned about physical abuse of patients. They alleged patients were being tied to commodes, but the trust concluded that "departures from accepted good practice" had been made with "good intent".

In December 1998, two nurses made fresh allegations. The trust investigated the incidents but did not explore wider issues. Three staff were disciplined, one was sacked and one resigned.

In March this year, an external review panel found that degrading practices had been used by some staff and condoned by others. Yesterday's report said it was clear that if the trust had responded positively to the whistle-blowing students in 1996, further abuse might have been prevented.

The CHI investigators said they were "deeply disturbed" by comments by a consultant - named yesterday as Chris Hallewell - that he felt like a visitor on the ward. Dr Hallewell was responsible for patients who were abused in 1996 and 1998 but told investigators he did not know of the abuse. "The CHI is deeply disturbed by the consultant's lack of awareness and passive acceptance of being treated like a visitor on the ward where the abuse occurred.

"This reflects an inadequate sense of medical accountability in so senior a figure. That the consultant is also the associate medical director and has joint responsibility for clinical governance across the trust, compounds CHI's concern."

The trust's chairman, Mary Styth, the director of personnel, Catherine McCreadie, and the chief executive, Alan Place, have been sacked but have the right of appeal. Other managers have received disciplinary warnings.

webTitle: Fatal kidney error

fields.headline: Fatal kidney error
fields.standfirst:
Llanelli: Confusion remains after patient's death

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Graham Reeves, a 70-year-old veteran of the Korean war, died on March 1 this year, five weeks after what should have have been a routine operation to remove a diseased kidney.
fields.body:
Graham Reeves, a 70-year-old veteran of the Korean war, died on March 1 this year, five weeks after what should have have been a routine operation to remove a diseased kidney.

Surgeons at the Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli, west Wales, were found to have removed the pensioner's one healthy kidney after allegedly failing to comply with established procedures.

In an official report yesterday, the Commission for Health Improvement said that Carmarthenshire NHS Trust, which runs the Llanelli hospital and the older West Wales general hospital in Carmarthen, had produced a comprehensive action plan in the aftermath of the tragedy.

But the plan had not been fully implemented and there was still confusion in the minds of some staff about the handling of critical incidents.

Separate investigations into the bungled operation have already been carried out by the Royal College of Surgeons and by the trust itself. Neither has been made public on the grounds that the inquest into Mr Reeves's death has yet to take place. Dyfed Powys police are continuing to investigate the incident.

The commission's chief executive, Peter Homa, said it could not be specific about the failures that led to Mr Reeves's death. But its report recommended that meetings should be arranged across the trust "as a matter of urgency" to ensure that common standards and practices are established for patients undergoing surgery.

It said the trust should review its method for marking x-rays to ensure a consistency of approach. It expressed concern that the action plan had not adopted the suggestion that an additional nurse should accompany patients to the operating theatre and provide a handover.

The report, which praises the enthusiasm and commitment of the trust's front line staff, found the two hospitals were struggling to work as one organisation. There was no overall programme for the continuous improvement of patient care.

The commission expressed particular concern at the trust's "outdated" way of managing nursing staff, its lack of a human resources director and its failure to share policies and procedures now in place in operating theatres at Prince Philip with its sister hospital in Carmarthen.

Mr Homa said these broader issues needed tackling urgently. "If the trust carries out all our recommendations, local people can again have confidence in the services it provides."

webTitle: Leader: When the NHS falters

fields.headline: When the NHS falters
fields.standfirst:
It is best for the truth to come out
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The trio of reports documenting serious failings in the health service yesterday is not entirely bad news. It signals more openness in what has too long been a stealth service... Perverse though it may seem, yesterday's reports are an advance.
fields.body:
The trio of reports documenting serious failings in the health service yesterday is not entirely bad news. It signals more openness in what has too long been a stealth service. Each report is alarming reading: a Carlisle hospital for elderly mentally-ill patients with "a shocking culture of cruelty"; a Welsh hospital where a man died after his one healthy kidney was removed; a heart unit in one of Britain's most famous hospitals, Oxford's John Radcliffe, "on its knees and riven by internal conflict". Even the BMA did not try to gloss over their seriousness. "Today's reports paint a picture of an NHS in trouble and under pressure," it said. "It could leave the public seriously concerned about the ability of the health service to deliver quality patient care, to learn from mistakes and to act swiftly when problems and concerns have been identified."

Perverse though it may seem, yesterday's reports are an advance. Four years ago, five student nurses blew the whistle on Carlisle's unacceptable procedures including tying patients to commodes. There was an inquiry, but nothing happened. The students' complaints were "lost". Nothing emerged publicly. All that has changed. Even before yesterday's report, the trust chairman had been dismissed, the chief executive suspended pending disciplinary hearings, senior managers warned. Similarly, Oxford's warring heart surgeons only came to light because a senior clinical nurse complained. She suffered severe harassment and an unacceptable two-year wait, but she finally succeeded.

What does emerge is that whistleblowers still need more protection; that hospital authorities need to move more quickly (10 months on in Wales the action plan is still not in place); and less obviously, that care needs to be taken in deploying the new health watchdog, the commission for health improvement. Using it in Wales made sense. It looked at wider issues than a single death. It might have made sense to use it in Oxford too, but that did not happen. But the CHI should not have been sent to Carlisle, where there had already been an external review. This was a diversion to deflect any political heat from ministers. The CHI is not a hit squad. It is a crucial monitoring unit, with a remit to visit every hospital and GP practice within the next four years. To raise standards, it needs their trust. Set up a separate hit squad if necessary, but the CHI's prime purpose must be protected.

webTitle: Damning reports expose hospital failings

fields.headline: Damning reports expose hospital failings
fields.standfirst:
Health trusts and leading heart centre criticised after failure to heed whistleblowers' concerns

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Public faith in the NHS's ability to deliver good patient care and act swiftly to correct mistakes would be tested by damning reports exposing failings within two health trusts and a leading heart centre, doctors warned yesterday.
fields.byline: James Meikle, Geoffrey Gibbs  and  David Ward
fields.body:
Public faith in the NHS's ability to deliver good patient care and act swiftly to correct mistakes would be tested by damning reports exposing failings within two health trusts and a leading heart centre, doctors warned yesterday.

Surgeons, nurses and management were severely criticised after official investigations highlighted the need for hospital authorities to take more heed of whistleblowers.

The commission for health improvement, the government's new watchdog on standards, criticised North Lakeland NHS trust, where elderly mentally ill patients were tied to commodes, and Carmar- thenshire NHS trust, where a patient died after having the wrong kidney removed. An independent report commissioned by the NHS executive said the Oxford heart centre was "on its knees and riven by internal conflict".

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said the reports might leave the public "seriously concerned about the ability of the health service to deliver quality patient care, to learn from mistakes and to act swiftly when problems and concerns have been identified."

Abuse of patients could never be justified "but staffing shortages, excessive working hours and poor facilities can turn other, genuine, errors into tragedy". The NHS as a whole would continue to struggle until the effects of new investment were felt.

The Oxford inquiry, by a panel of experts in cardiothoracic services, highlighted staff reports of a "drinking club" culture within the centre, based at the John Radcliffe hospital, and found failures of leadership, antagonism between surgeons, difficulties in retaining nursing staff, complacency and secrecy.

The report, which made 34 recommendations, said a policy for treating whistleblowers seriously must be introduced. A senior nurse, Colette O'Keefe, who has been on sick leave for a year, alleged she and her children had been threatened after raising concerns about public care.

The health minister, John Denham, said the report "paints a picture of a dysfunctional team and, more than that, a failure to deal with problems when they were first raised". David Highton, chief executive of Oxford Radcliffe hospitals trust, said it would be "a catalyst for improvements".

Degrading practices at the Garlands hospital in Carlisle, administered by the North Lakeland NHS trust, might not have been repeated if whistleblowers among student nurses had been heeded in 1996, a CHI report concluded. Patients were sworn at, tied to commodes, and denied food, clothing and blankets.

The trust's chairwoman, Mary Styth, the chief executive, Alan Place, and the director of personnel, Catherine McCreadi, have been dismissed, and other senior management have received warnings.

Peter Homa, chief executive of the CHI, said: "The abuse of elderly people was appalling ... The culture of this organisation needs to change so that the rights of patients are understood across the trust."

Nigel Woodcook, acting chief executive for the trust, apologised to patients and their families for the "inexcusable mistreatment" and praised the courage of students and health care assistants who drew attention to it.

The CHI also criticised Carmarthenshire health trust for being slow to correct procedures following the death of a Korean war veteran, Graham Reeves, 70, of Burry Port, south Wales, who died at the Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli in February, after having his one healthy kidney removed by mistake.

Surgeons, nurses and management were severely criticised after official investigations highlighted the need for hospital authorities to take more heed of whistleblowers. The commission for health improvement, the government's new watchdog on standards, criticised North Lakeland NHS trust, where elderly mentally ill patients were tied to commodes, and Carmar- thenshire NHS trust, where a patient died after having the wrong kidney removed. An independent report commissioned by the NHS executive said the Oxford heart centre was "on its knees and riven by internal conflict". Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said the reports might leave the public "seriously concerned about the ability of the health service to deliver quality patient care, to learn from mistakes and to act swiftly when problems and concerns have been identified." Abuse of patients could never be justified "but staffing shortages, excessive working hours and poor facilities can turn other, genuine, errors into tragedy". The NHS as a whole would continue to struggle until the effects of new investment were felt. The Oxford inquiry, by a panel of experts in cardiothoracic services, highlighted staff reports of a "drinking club" culture within the centre, based at the John Radcliffe hospital, and found failures of leadership, antagonism between surgeons, difficulties in retaining nursing staff, complacency and secrecy. The report, which made 34 recommendations, said a policy for treating whistleblowers seriously must be introduced. A senior nurse, Colette O'Keefe, who has been on sick leave for a year, alleged she and her children had been threatened after raising concerns about public care. The health minister, John Denham, said the report "paints a picture of a dysfunctional team and, more than that, a failure to deal with problems when they were first raised". David Highton, chief executive of Oxford Radcliffe hospitals trust, said it would be "a catalyst for improvements". webTitle: Brown's £450m aid for young

fields.headline: Brown's £450m aid for young
fields.standfirst: Society Unlimited
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday challenged the business community to join forces with local councils and the voluntary sector to help rescue the most vulnerable children from poverty, ignorance and crime.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday challenged the business community to join forces with local councils and the voluntary sector to help rescue the most vulnerable children from poverty, ignorance and crime.

Launching the government's £450m children's fund to target young people most at risk, the chancellor appealed for "a practical day-to-day partnership of parents, communities, professionals and voluntary organisations".

The programme involves older pupils or adults "mentoring" youngsters at risk of involvement in crime, parental education on the importance of listening to their children's anxieties, and a wide range of creative out-of-school activities. Much of it will be one-on-one.

Mr Brown used yesterday's launch at the children and young people's unit conference in north London to praise the skills that the voluntary sector can bring to social problems in ways that would have been unimaginable in the 1970s.

In contrast to old Labour's belief that the state should manage all social services if possible, the chancellor remarked on the strengths of voluntary action in its local roots: flexibility and freedom to innovate, and what he called its "capacity for the individual rather than the impersonal".

He argued that voluntary work "trains us in and strengthens our citizenship" - a theme which increasingly concerns ministers as they seek to create what Mr Brown called "not passive but active" engagement with society.

Mr Brown, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, and the home office minister Paul Boateng have joined forces to create the children's fund, which embraces £380m worth of preventive work over three years, plus a £70m budget to create a local network of voluntary and community groups.

Urging businesses to get involved, Mr Brown invoked "a new relationship between individual community and government that involves real devolution of power from government to self-governing communities. Instead of just the state running these programmes, these can be in partnership with volunteers, charities and community organisations."

webTitle: Jungle trek leads to architect's urban battle cry

fields.headline: Jungle trek leads to architect's urban battle cry
fields.standfirst:
Lord Rogers sees task force proposals adopted as white paper on cities is published
Society Unlimited
fields.trailText: Richard Rogers, the architect and Labour peer, is used to his ideas moving from the drawing board to the building site with some speed.
fields.body:
Richard Rogers, the architect and Labour peer, is used to his ideas moving from the drawing board to the building site with some speed.

So today he will feel some relief after three years battling in the Whitehall jungle as a near one-man urban lobby. His efforts will finally be realised with the publication today by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, of the much delayed urban white paper.

Taken alongside measures designed to stimulate inner city regeneration, announced by the chancellor in the pre-budget report, Lord Rogers can reasonably claim that the vast bulk of the proposals laid out in his Urban Task Force 18 months ago have now been adopted as official government policy.

Rogers admits to some frustration in recent months as he urged ministers to "go further and faster". The wheels of Whitehall grind slowly for someone like Rogers, now eager to move on to helping to resdesign London with Ken Livingstone.

Rogers baldly states the issues the urban white paper must now address. "Vast areas of our cities are really crumbling in terms of sustainable development and vitality. We have to attract people back into the city and end the so-called doughnut effect wherby everyone gets out of the city and into the suburbs. We have to find ways to reuse the land that has already been used, the so-called brownfield sites.

"The most frightening thing about going to Copenhagen or Barcelona is the difference in the quality of the street - the whole public domain. The whole physical environment ranging from the quality of design, safety or cycle ways is just years ahead of us".

And he remains daunted by the lack of architectural design skills in this country, an issue Mr Prescott will address through a proposed new national design school.

Rogers admits to disappointment at the chancellor's decision not adopt his proposal for the harmonisation of VAT on the development of greenfield and brownfield sites. Rogers refuses to predict whether the absence of this measure will mean the government will not reach its key strategic target of 60% new build on brownfield sites. He prefers to concentrate on how much the government has accepted the urban task force's agenda.

Rogers' adviser Tony Travers said: "Defining the derelict zones will be important. It will have to avoid the problem of going for Manchester and picking up Didsbury."

Rogers added: "It is also critical we have incentives to remove the deterrents from developers improving contaminated land." He also predicts that the proposal to offer 100% capital relief for the costs of converting redundant space over shops into flats for letting will mark a real shift.

Rogers and Travers end by calling for a single minister to thread this altogether and retain the sense of urgency.

Travers intercedes: "Richard cannot say this, but I can. We all know there is a powerful rural lobby and it has very useful allies in the Lords. There is no urban lobby in the same way. We need a Council for the Protection of Urban Britain."

webTitle: Good day bad day

fields.headline: Good day bad day
fields.trailText: Yesterday
fields.body:
Yesterday

Drink of the day

Guinness. Tony Blair relived his Irish roots in a book entitled Being Irish, which is on sale in Britain later this month. "It was in the seas off the Irish coast that I learned to swim and my father took me to my first pub, a remote little house in the country, for a Guinness, a taste I have never forgotten and which is always a pleasure to repeat," he recalls. Presumably not 14 times a day however.

Mystery of the day

Tory MP Nigel Evans showed the BBC round his plush office in Portcullis House. Great view of the Thames and the Millennium Eye. Lots of storage space. And a personal fridge. Curiously the only item in it was a tub of margarine.

Quote of the day

"Isn't the only reason that you cling on to the discredited dome minister, that he may be a useless minister but he's very convenient as a human shield?" William Hague to Tony Blair on Lord Falconer.

Today

Commons: Insolvency bill, remaining stages. Lords: Energy conservation bill, third reading. Countryside bill, report.

webTitle: Autonomy plans move to digital TV

fields.headline: Autonomy plans move to digital TV
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the Cambridge software firm, yesterday said it plans to move its technology into digital television.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the Cambridge software firm, yesterday said it plans to move its technology into digital television.

Mike Lynch, Autonomy's chief executive, said the company's new applications would link on-screen action with background information on products. For example, if a viewer is watching X Files and Mulder is drinking a beer, the viewer will be able to click on the beer and buy one.

Mr Lynch said the technology would also be able to connect viewers with commentary on programmes carried in chat rooms.

Autonomy, which develops software that captures ideas and concepts within texts by looking at the mathematical patterns in prose in order to send information to designated users, also plans to announce new voice recognition applications during the fourth quarter of the year.

The announcement came as the company reported its interims - the first set of results since the company floated in London just over two weeks ago.

Revenues increased by 191% over the year to $17.6m (£12.3m), up from $14.6m for the second quarter of the current financial year. Pre-tax profit excluding exceptional gains was $6.2m, up from $5.1m in the second quarter and about $2.5m higher than industry analysts predicted.

Stephen Bersey, a senior software analyst at SG Cowen, said: "These positive results are a strong testament to the company's technology."

The company reported continued growth of its blue chip client base, including BP Amoco, the World Bank and KPMG, and said it had seen the first revenues from royalties on products it has licensed to other software companies.

The share price yesterday fell 36p to close at £33.25 - partly in response to the technology sector rally seen on Tuesday.

webTitle: Greek protest at fate of Elgin Marbles

fields.headline: Gods of the underground demand statues' return retribution
fields.standfirst: Replicas in the Athens metro silently protest at fate of Elgin Marbles
fields.trailText: At first glance, the exquisite figures which greet passengers on their descent into the cool interior of the new Acropolis underground station in Athens look like the real thing: Helios rushes out of the sea on a chariot pulled by four horses; next to him, Dionysus, the god of good times, reclines on a rock. Then come the seated goddesses Demeter and Kore and the fine upstanding figure of Artemis the hunter.
fields.body:
At first glance, the exquisite figures which greet passengers on their descent into the cool interior of the new Acropolis underground station in Athens look like the real thing: Helios rushes out of the sea on a chariot pulled by four horses; next to him, Dionysus, the god of good times, reclines on a rock. Then come the seated goddesses Demeter and Kore and the fine upstanding figure of Artemis the hunter.

However, these larger-than-life gods and goddesses, which once adorned the east pediment of the Parthenon and now stare out from a wall in an underground station, were not carved in white Pentelic marble by the 5th century BC sculptor Phidias, but made from gypsum and polyurethane.

They are modern-day replicas of the Parthenon Marbles-known as the Elgin Marbles - currently housed in the British Museum. The original sculptures have been a bone of contention between Britain and Greece ever since they were removed from the Acropolis at the beginning of the 19th century by Lord Elgin.

Together with the two marble friezes depicting scenes from the Panathenaic procession - the originals of which are also in the British Museum - which run along the station's platforms, the replicas are probably the world's most elegant examples of agitprop art.

"This is a silent protest that speaks for us all," said Triantafyllia Lagoudakou, head of the metro's art committee. "This subway station sends a message to the thousands of commuters and tourists who will use this station every day: The Parthenon Marbles should be returned to their homeland."

The station, which opened for business yesterday, is one of five new underground stations in the Greek capital that are doubling up as mini museums, displaying a selection of the 30,000 ancient objects unearthed during a decade of excavations for the metro network.

Each station has a cutaway wall, framed behind thick glass, showing the actual strata through which the archaeologists dug. At the Acropolis station, more than 80 other relics, including toys, oil lamps, and wine pitchers, are also on display.

"This proves that Greece is able to look after its own heritage and antiquities and present them in an imaginative and creative way," said George Ieromninon, the architect responsible for designing the metro network's artistic displays

"We're bringing art to the the people. And the idea that we won't look after our marbles is a thing of the past."

Greece's alleged inability to properly conserve the marbles in heavily polluted Athens has been one of the main arguments used by opponents of return. The British Museum also claims the marbles were removed legally, and that it would take an act of parliament to hand them back.

But research by the historian William St Clair has questioned the British Museum's stewardship of the masterpieces. In his book Lord Elgin & The Marbles, Mr St Clair claimed the marbles were badly damaged during a botched cleaning operation during the 1930s.

The historian also charged the British Museum hierarchy with a cover-up, hiding the affair from parliament and academics. The revelations forced the museum to admit last December that the botched cleaning operation had happened, but it denied causing the marbles serious damage.

The new Acropolis station stands next to the empty site of a museum Greece plans to house the Elgin Marbles by 2004, when the city is to host the Olympic Games.

The building of a new Acropolis museum has become central to any discussion about returning the marbles to Greece.

"It's my number one priority," said the culture minister, Theodorus Pangalos, promising that a final design would be ready by June. He said that the museum would include a special space to accommodate the marbles, and that "that space would remain empty until the day they came home".

But that doesn't look likely to be any time soon.

The British government remains firmly opposed to returning the marbles, and has poured cold water on a recent suggestion by some Labour MPs that the stones be returned to the Greek capital on a lease arrangement, under the supervision of the British School in Athens.

For the Greeks, it is a battle for hearts and minds. The notice on the wall next to the replica sculptures in the Acropolis station reads simply: "They [the marbles] were almost entirely removed by Lord Elgin from 1801 onwards, and since 1816 they are in the British Museum where they are exhibited."

Mrs Lagoudakou said: "We've tried diplomacy, we've tried political pressure, we've tried conferences, and demonstrations. Now we're letting the art speak for itself."

webTitle: Comment: The great climate sell-off

fields.headline: The great climate sell-off
fields.standfirst:
Big corporations are buying their way out of environmental curbs

Special report: transport in the UK
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: The privatisation of Britain's air traffic control systems is rather like the Millennium Dome. First the government backs it, then it tries to figure out what on earth it is for.
fields.body:
The privatisation of Britain's air traffic control systems is rather like the Millennium Dome. First the government backs it, then it tries to figure out what on earth it is for. Ministers' attempts to explain the inexplicable have not been helped by an unequivocal promise the Labour party made in opposition: "Our skies," it announced, "are not for sale."

The government is clearly trying to beat its own egregious record, for in one week it is planning to break this promise not once, but twice. It is currently trying to sell not only our flight paths, but also the sky itself. The world's weather is on the brink of being privatised.

The original purpose of the climate change negotiations taking place in the Hague this week was to cut the amount of greenhouse gases the world produces, in order to avert more catastrophic weather of the kind Britain has suffered over the past few weeks. But corporations have discovered in the world's disasters a marvellous opportunity for making money. Thanks to their lobbying, the climate saving talks have been turned into a surreal discussion about how the atmosphere can be bought and sold.

Under the Kyoto protocol on climate change, countries are allowed to reduce their emissions through something called "flexibility mechanisms". Instead of cutting carbon dioxide at home, they can either buy "carbon credits" from countries which have exceeded their own targets for cuts, or invest in carbon-reducing technologies elsewhere in the world. At first sight, this looks like a fine idea. It places a financial premium on cleanliness, and encourages the transfer of environmentally-friendly technology to the developing world. In practice, it promises to exacerbate both climate change and inequality.

Flexibility mechanisms could enable countries to trade in hot air. A nation's entitlement to pollute depends upon how much carbon dioxide it was producing in 1990. Since then, heavy industry in Russia, Ukraine and Kazakhstan has all but collapsed, with the result that they have accidentally achieved far greater carbon cuts than anticipated. The United States is hoping to avoid cutting its own emissions by buying unused entitlements from these countries, thus making no net contribution to carbon reduction.

The UK wants to engage in a similar scam, by selling the carbon dioxide we would have produced if we hadn't shut the coal mines. The government has also offered state aid for the privatisation of the climate. In July it laid down £30m to help private companies start bidding for each other's reduced emissions. A research institute in the United States calculates that the weather market will be worth $13 trillion by 2050.

But the subtler plans are still more hazardous. As a new report by the Corporate Europe Observatory shows, they amount to subsidies for northern corporations seeking to exploit developing countries. The British government is insisting, for example, that if BNFL builds nuclear power stations in China it should be able to obtain a carbon discount for the UK, on the basis that they will emit less greenhouse gas than coal-burning plants. The discount could be used to subsidise their construction, thus saving a dangerous technology from extinction.

Monsanto is hoping to find new markets for its unpopular herbicide-tolerant crops by promoting them as "carbon friendly", on the basis that they leave more organic matter in the soil than conventional crops (though far less, of course, than organic farming). A Malaysian logging company is already selling pollution permits to an electricity firm in the US, claiming, in the looking-glass world of carbon trading, that it is sucking carbon out of the atmosphere by replacing the virgin forests it is cutting with plantations.

Such schemes not only finance environmental destruction; they are also grossly unjust. If first world countries can buy their way out of their commitments by funding carbon-saving projects in the third world, then developing nations will have trouble making reductions of their own, when, in the future, such cuts are demanded of them.

Indeed, when the amount of carbon dioxide a country or a company generates is used to determine how much it should be allowed to produce, then the worst polluters acquire the greatest rights. The greater your right to pollute, the more carbon credits you can sell to other people. Those least responsible for the problem, in other words, benefit least from the solution.

The polluters meeting in the Hague this week claim that they are saving the planet. In truth they are selling it.

But corporations have discovered in the world's disasters a marvellous opportunity for making money. Thanks to their lobbying, the climate saving talks have been turned into a surreal discussion about how the atmosphere can be bought and sold. Under the Kyoto protocol on climate change, countries are allowed to reduce their emissions through something called "flexibility mechanisms". Instead of cutting carbon dioxide at home, they can either buy "carbon credits" from countries which have exceeded their own targets for cuts, or invest in carbon-reducing technologies elsewhere in the world. At first sight, this looks like a fine idea. It places a financial premium on cleanliness, and encourages the transfer of environmentally-friendly technology to the developing world. In practice, it promises to exacerbate both climate change and inequality. Flexibility mechanisms could enable countries to trade in hot air. A nation's entitlement to pollute depends upon how much carbon dioxide it was producing in 1990. Since then, heavy industry in Russia, Ukraine and Kazakhstan has all but collapsed, with the result that they have accidentally achieved far greater carbon cuts than anticipated. The United States is hoping to avoid cutting its own emissions by buying unused entitlements from these countries, thus making no net contribution to carbon reduction. The UK wants to engage in a similar scam, by selling the carbon dioxide we would have produced if we hadn't shut the coal mines. The government has also offered state aid for the privatisation of the climate. In July it laid down £30m to help private companies start bidding for each other's reduced emissions. A research institute in the United States calculates that the weather market will be worth $13 trillion by 2050. But the subtler plans are still more hazardous. As a new report by the Corporate Europe Observatory shows, they amount to subsidies for northern corporations seeking to exploit developing countries. The British government is insisting, for example, that if BNFL builds nuclear power stations in China it should be able to obtain a carbon discount for the UK, on the basis that they will emit less greenhouse gas than coal-burning plants. The discount could be used to subsidise their construction, thus saving a dangerous technology from extinction. Monsanto is hoping to find new markets for its unpopular herbicide-tolerant crops by promoting them as "carbon friendly", on the basis that they leave more organic matter in the soil than conventional crops (though far less, of course, than organic farming). A Malaysian logging company is already selling pollution permits to an electricity firm in the US, claiming, in the looking-glass world of carbon trading, that it is sucking carbon out of the atmosphere by replacing the virgin forests it is cutting with plantations. Such schemes not only finance environmental destruction; they are also grossly unjust. If first world countries can buy their way out of their commitments by funding carbon-saving projects in the third world, then developing nations will have trouble making reductions of their own, when, in the future, such cuts are demanded of them. Indeed, when the amount of carbon dioxide a country or a company generates is used to determine how much it should be allowed to produce, then the worst polluters acquire the greatest rights. The greater your right to pollute, the more carbon credits you can sell to other people. Those least responsible for the problem, in other words, benefit least from the solution. The polluters meeting in the Hague this week claim that they are saving the planet. In truth they are selling it. g.monbiot@zetnet.co.uk

webTitle: Scientists claim breakthrough monkeying about with robots

fields.headline: Scientists claim breakthrough monkeying about with robots
fields.trailText: Monkeys with electrodes in their brains in Durham, North Carolina, have been able to manipulate a robot arm 600 miles away in Cambridge, Massachusetts, scientists report today.
fields.body:
Monkeys with electrodes in their brains in Durham, North Carolina, have been able to manipulate a robot arm 600 miles away in Cambridge, Massachusetts, scientists report today.

This example of what science fiction writers call telekinesis - the moving power of thought - could one day help paralysed people control prosthetic limbs.

The scientists, from Duke University report in Nature that they implanted up to 96 electrodes, each thinner than a human hair, into the brains of two owl monkeys. The researchers selected a region of the brain called the motor cortex, which controls movement of the limbs. They took readings of the electrical activity of the monkey brain cells as they performed various arm movements, in reaching for food.

Once the scientists found that they could predict arm movements by looking at the pattern of signals in the brain, they linked the monkeys to a robot arm in the Duke laboratory, which could move in three dimensions to reach for food. They then used the internet to link the monkeys to another robot arm at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

"It worked out beautifully," said Mandayam Srinivisan, of the MIT laboratory. "It was an amazing sight to see the robot in my lab move, knowing that it was being driven by signals from a monkey brain at Duke. It was as if the monkey had a 600 mile long virtual arm."

The research was led by John Chapin of the New York health science centre, and Miguel Nicolelis of Duke University medical centre. In 1999, Dr Chapin showed that rats wired to a robot arm could use nerve cell activity to control a robot arm to serve themselves water. "At the beginning of the experiments, the animals had to press down a lever to generate the brain activity needed to move the robot arm," Dr Chapin said. "Over continued training, however, their lever movements diminished while their brain activity remained the same."

There have already been separate experiments with humans in the application of brainwaves to computer connections. At Tubingen in Germany, two patients with "locked-in syndrome" - complete paralysis barely distinguishable from coma - wore electrodes and learned to manipulate letters on a computer.

The hope is that humans could become adept at this electrical link between thought and deed. The researchers are planning to implant up to 1,000 electrodes, to get a more precise picture of the electrical brain activity, and develop a "neurochip" that might link humans to machinery.

webTitle: US takes the low road at a high cost

fields.headline: US takes the low road at a high cost
fields.standfirst:
What the world needs to know: can Americans kick the gas-guzzling habit before 1.2bn Chinese get hooked?
Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: When it comes to polluting the atmosphere, the US rules the world, mainly because the car is king. There are 1.3 people per car in the US compared to 125 people per car in China, and the scope of the problem from the consequent emissions is proportionately as great.
fields.body:
When it comes to polluting the atmosphere, the US rules the world, mainly because the car is king. There are 1.3 people per car in the US compared to 125 people per car in China, and the scope of the problem from the consequent emissions is proportionately as great.

While some individual states have made serious efforts to deal with the problem, there has, to environmentalists, been a lack of effective leadership on the issue at government level. Green groups argue that the state has done little to check the proliferation of "gas-guzzlers" and could have done much more to encourage domestic and commercial energy savings.

"Increasing the fuel efficiency of automobiles is the biggest single step that could be taken by the US government," said Dan Becker, Sierra Club spokesman on global warming. "But this administration has done almost nothing to offend the automobile industry. We don't have time to spare. We have to act now."

The Sierra Club and other environmentalists argue that there is a tool to achieve this goal in the form of Corporate Average Fuel Economy (Cafe) standards. Raising Cafe standards to 45 miles per gallon for cars and 34 mpg for trucks, vans, and sport utility vehicles (SUVs) is what they seek. For the past decade, the standard has been set at 27.5 mpg for cars and 20.7 mpg for light trucks. Particularly damaging to the environment are the SUVs - heavily marketed in the US and the most fashionable vehicles to own - which achieve just 13 mpg.

Ford, Chrysler, and General Motors have successfully lobbied against changes in the Cafe standards; actions that the Sierra Club calls "reprehensible. They are not only damaging the environment and increasing the risk of a dangerous global warming, but their gas-guzzlers are also worsening America's trade deficit and exporting more money from US consumers into the bank accounts of multinational oil corporations."

Some states have taken their own action. In Arizona, a clean air act came into force in April but it has been catastrophic for the state government. Grants and tax relief were given to motorists who switched from petrol-fuelled cars to propane powered vehicles. The move was meant to cost up to $10m (£6.9m) a year. Within six months the bill had reached $420m and could cost up to 10% of the annual state budget of $6bn.

Less dramatically, California has decided that by the year 2003 some 10% of all cars offered for sale in the state must emit little or no pollution. The states of New York, Maine, Massachusetts and Vermont have voted to follow suit. The California Air Resources Boards which regulates air pollution in the state - key bodies in the battle for cleaner air in the US - voted to impose the requirement last month. The move was denounced by the automobile industry. Currently an electric-powered car would cost $20,000 more than a petrol-fuelled car to buy.

But green pressure is having some effect. On October 18, seven companies including Shell, BP, Alcan and DuPont committed themselves to voluntary cuts in releases of greenhouse gases, cutting by 2010 the companies' annual emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases by 15% of the 1990 figure. Environmentalists say this is a recognition that limits may soon be imposed by climate treaties. The move also makes business sense as it attacks a wasteful use of energy.

webTitle: Leader: The EU cannot thrive without change

fields.headline: Nice is only the start
fields.standfirst:
The EU cannot thrive without change
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Next month's European Union summit in Nice will drag Britain ever deeper into the mire of a federal super-state. That, in sum, is the simplistic Tory view, backed by a largely eurosceptical press already anticipating a Labour "sell-out".
fields.body:
Next month's European Union summit in Nice will drag Britain ever deeper into the mire of a federal super-state. That, in sum, is the simplistic Tory view, backed by a largely eurosceptical press already anticipating a Labour "sell-out". They will portray the reduction of Britain's veto powers and, for example, the proposed charter of rights, as serious derogations of national sovereignty. They will deliberately confuse other, modest reforms designed to facilitate the EU's most important, historic priority - European reunification through enlargement - with petty concerns about Britain's place in the pecking order.

The Eurosceptics will persist in characterising plans for a shared European defence capability, also on the Nice agenda, as a French plot to wreck Nato. If Tony Blair formally accepts the idea of "core" or "pioneer" groups, they will say Britain is being left behind in a two-speed Europe, whatever assurances are obtained. But paradoxically, they will also continue to oppose aspects of enhanced EU cooperation, even efforts to combat drugs and people trafficking through community-wide judicial and investigative agencies, as contrary to the British interest. And although some of this criticism will be based on principle, most will have more to do with short-term calculations about soft targets at the next general election than the long-term future of Britain or Europe.

It was in order to pre-empt, or at least deflect, this impending deluge of abuse that Mr Blair and Robin Cook launched their pro-Europe offensive this week. But neither man addressed the wider question raised a day later by Germany's foreign minister, Joschka Fischer: that the Nice reforms, rather than going too far, do not go nearly far enough. And here is the nub. If Europe is to be made to work for the British (and the citizens of other member and candidate countries), and if the Eurosceptics are to be put to flight, then much more far-reaching and radical reform of existing EU institutions than currently envisaged may be required. This is where Mr Blair, who aspires to lead in Europe, is ahead of the game, if only he can find the will to win.

Mr Fischer's proposal that the EC president be directly elected, for example, is way off the mark. Giving more power to Romano Prodi and his commission would be an undeserved reward. Far better, perhaps, to elaborate on Mr Blair's idea, in his Warsaw speech last month, that the leadership role of the European council (heads of state) and the various councils of ministers be confirmed and enhanced. These people are already elected, responsible, and accountable at home. They would perhaps be better served by a commission that acted as a depoliticised, unifying secretariat (as with the UN) rather than, as now, a rival power base with great pretensions and an amazing talent for dropping clangers.

In proposing in Warsaw a second chamber for the European parliament, Mr Blair recognised the need for greater EU democracy. But this will arguably only be achieved if parliament (meeting in one place, not two) has true legislative powers and increased oversight of the council: in other words, a real job. Lacking this, the work of MEPs will remain a mystery to ordinary Britons and European elections will be unlikely ever to have much meaning. If, in addition, the 1997 Amsterdam treaty pledge enshrining the public's right to freedom of information were to be fully honoured, the British public might have a lot more confidence about Mr Blair's Nice outing and the success of enlargement - and a lot less time for europhobe sniggering.
