webTitle: Analysis on  air traffic control systems

fields.headline: Winging it
fields.standfirst:
Profit and safety need not be incompatible in the sell-off of the national air traffic control systems but other options need consideration

Special report: transport in the UK
fields.trailText: Profit and safety need not be incompatible in the sell-off of the national air traffic control systems but other options need consideration
fields.body:
The government had the votes last night to secure the bit of the transport bill dealing with air traffic control but it failed to win the argument. The "public-private partnership" for National Air Traffic Services (Nats) is a privatisation by any other name. You might think there would be lessons about finance or safety from what we now know about rail, but no: the government seemed determined to plough on regardless.

But as the government gets the legal power to privatise air traffic control, will it? With the election looming, decisions may be deferred - Gordon Brown hardly needs the money to balance his budget - and after May all bets are off.

The plan had its origins in a squabble during the 1997 campaign. At the 1996 Labour conference, shadow transport secretary Andrew Smith had declared "our air is not for sale". But Tory spending plans included a notional receipt from selling Nats and claimed that without it that there was a "black hole" in Labour's figures. Labour said the sale of Nats had not, after all, been ruled out.

The decision to proceed with part-privatisation was taken in 1998. The state would retain 49%, selling 46% to a "strategic partner" for about £350m and offer 5% to employees. But legislation (part of an omnibus bill, which also at last makes the shadow strategic rail authority legitimate) was not introduced until this parliamentary session. It met strong resistance so three and a half years on, there has been no sale. No black hole has appeared in Labour's budget.

So why persist? It used to be a shibboleth that there were no no-go areas for new Labour. There was consensus that safety regulation by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) should be separated from the operation of navigation services. The government's plan achieves that. As a wholly-owned subsidiary of the CAA, Nats has made a bad job of the new air traffic control centre at Swanwick, which is many years late and over budget. The private sector - so it was said - might do a better job of managing such complex investment projects.

But faith that the private sector is necessarily more efficient is misplaced. The public sector had to step in with £5bn of taxpayers' money to rescue the high-speed Chan nel tunnel rail link. Railtrack has revised its estimate of the cost of upgrading of the west coast main line from £2.2bn to £5.8bn and again the taxpayer is footing the bill. Railtrack's poor performance in track maintenance, revealed by the Hatfield rail crash, shows private sector management can leave much to be desired.

Privatisation may work if it introduces competition as a driver for greater efficiency. This is not so with Nats, which is a natural monopoly, with what it can charge airlines regulated at European level. Other than buying out other countries' air navigation services, the only way to grow its market is through the expansion in air travel (which is growing, as the table shows). In safety terms, this raises a potential conflict of interest.

Belief that the public sector is always inefficient is also nonsense. The government clearly does not believe it, since it has established the Post Office as a public limited company and a number of publicly-owned airports, including Manchester, have been allowed to borrow in the financial markets without the normal recourse to Treasury permission. In the case of London Underground, it is not the ownership of the system or the operation of services that is potentially to be handed over to the private sector but long-term contracts for the modernisation and maintenance of the tunnels, track, trains, stations and signalling.

Safety has to be maintained and to be seen to be maintained. On the railways Railtrack has been required to set up a new non-profit company to carry out safety assessments. An indepen dent rail safety authority is in the offing.

Profit and safety are not incompatible: British Airways has a good safety record and air traffic control at some airports is in private hands. The problem is one of public perception. Any increase in near misses in the already crowded skies, or worse still the first mid-air collision, would inevitably be blamed on cutting corners as a result of Nats privatisation.

The government has plenty of escape routes. One option is to keep the format but choose only non-profit partners. Of the four current bidders, an airline consortium including British Airways, Virgin Atlantic and British Midland comes into this category. It is questionable whether this would satisfy the public, since these are otherwise profit-making companies with a vested interest in the growth of air traffic.

Another option is for the government to remain the sole shareholder in Nats, as it is for the Post Office. It could allow Nats access to private capital for new investment, as it has local authority airports. Yet a third alternative is to transfer ownership of Nats to a non-profit trust, along the lines of NavCanada. As a public interest but private sector body, the trust would be able to raise funds from the private sector and invest in air traffic services overseas, which is one aim of the public private partnership.

The government will now pause for thought. Rail privatisation shows the dangers of rushing to judgment, where the Tories raced to complete the sell off in advance of the 1997 election. Only now are they admitting that mistakes were made.

 Tony Grayling is a transport specialist at the Institute for Public Policy Research. t.grayling@ippr.org.uk

webTitle: Letter: Mutual benefit from credit unions

fields.headline: Mutual benefit from credit unions
fields.trailText: Larry Elliot's otherwise excellent article on the potential for new mutuals (Kick off for mutuality fightback, November 13) failed to highlight the quiet growth in mutuals in other parts of our economic and social life or the potential for mutuals to drive, for example, the regeneration of our cities and areas of deprivation.
fields.body:
Larry Elliot's otherwise excellent article on the potential for new mutuals (Kick off for mutuality fightback, November 13) failed to highlight the quiet growth in mutuals in other parts of our economic and social life or the potential for mutuals to drive, for example, the regeneration of our cities and areas of deprivation.

Credit unions, groups of people organised either by parish, employment or other common bond to gain a mutual benefit from pooling financial resources, have been steadily increasing in members and assets over the last five years. Successful credit unions demonstrate the hard-headed business acumen of the market, whilst delivering significant financial benefits to their members in the form of cheap loans and secure savings. The numbers joining credit unions in Britain has grown from 138,000 in 1994 to 255,000 in 1998, an increase of over 80%.

After work by the social exclusion unit and a Treasury established credit union taskforce, a new central organisation to support credit unions is being developed. Together with a package of measures improving the regulatory framework in which credit unions operate, there is genuine hope for a further considerable expansion in both the number and members of this form of financial mutual.

Other forms of mutual organisation also have considerable potential to aid and drive regeneration. webTitle: Letter: Short people

fields.headline: Short people
fields.trailText: Darren Fern's defence for this surgery baffled me (Girl 'stretched' in £12,000 operation, November 14). At 4ft 10in I may not be able to reach a high cupboard, but I can reach the kitchen taps! He reckons "...everyone thinks she is a child". I laughed yet resented the implication that people of my height cannot live a "normal life". I'm 19 and at university, and when I get on buses I get away with a child's ticket!
fields.body:
Darren Fern's defence for this surgery baffled me (Girl 'stretched' in £12,000 operation, November 14). At 4ft 10in I may not be able to reach a high cupboard, but I can reach the kitchen taps! He reckons "...everyone thinks she is a child". I laughed yet resented the implication that people of my height cannot live a "normal life". I'm 19 and at university, and when I get on buses I get away with a child's ticket!

If Miss Richards wanted to be taller, let her parents pay for a private operation. To spend the NHS's money on the op is unjustifiable. Are broken and infected legs and long bedridden periods worth being a little bit taller? Did her classmates taunt her? Surely a strong personality helps us shorter people more than treating our height as a disease, a disorder to be "treated" by a doctor and a lot of money. Live short and prosper!
L Wisbey
Brighton, E Sussex opalbeetul@hotmail.com

fields.trailText: I too was disturbed by Madeline Bunting's article (Letter, November 15). It seems that the TV schedules are filled with the tone and content of a women's magazine of the 50s and 60s - recipes, advice on fashion, "problem pages", and romantic dramas, all designed for those with small children. I think it is a retrograde step, not something to crow about.

webTitle: Letters: Rail against tube sell-off

fields.headline: Rail against tube sell-off
fields.trailText: Just as Polly Toynbee (Comment, November 15) is right to caution the government against repeating the fiasco of rail privatisation on the London Underground, ministers are wrong to claim their proposals for the tube are somehow different from the rail sell-off. The similarities between the two systems are alarmingly familiar.
fields.body:
Just as Polly Toynbee (Comment, November 15) is right to caution the government against repeating the fiasco of rail privatisation on the London Underground, ministers are wrong to claim their proposals for the tube are somehow different from the rail sell-off. The similarities between the two systems are alarmingly familiar.

The Southall rail inquiry questioned whether "fragmentation compromised safety". Yet the underground public private partnership will also break up a unified railway, separating the operations from infrastructure and handing maintenance to numerous contractors and sub-contractors.

The PPP will also have an in-built punitive performance regime, when only this week Gerald Corbett told the Cullen enquiry that, following Hatfield, such a mechanism could be in "direct conflict" to meeting safety standards. Add to this the fact that PPP shareholders will profit from billions of pounds of public subsidy and the proposals are being imposed in the face of overwhelming expert and popular opposition, then it is a case of déjà vu.

There are two differences. Firstly, the intensive service levels on the underground and narrow margin for error means any breakdown in safety arising from privatisation will have even more dire consequences for the tube. Secondly, whilst the government inherited rail privatisation, the future of the underground is entirely in their own hands. I hope the lesson has been learned.
Jimmy Knapp
General secretary, RMT

 It has been mentioned that there was no contingency plan in case of fire at the funicular train in Austria (Experts find first clue to Austrian tunnel fire, November 15). Is the underground not in the same position? Anyone travelling on the Piccadilly line must have noticed the tight space between the carriage and the tunnel, just a few inches gap. If a fire cut off the power, the train would not be able to move to the next station. Because the only escape route is at the front and back ends of the train, just a few people would manage to survive.
Gabriel Castano
Brussels

 Arriving at work on another day of delay and overcrowding on the tube, Seumas Milne (Comment, November 15) hits the spot. The tube feels to be near collapse and must suffer petty bickering by politicians. On the day after the latest fuel protest and despite its "low-key end", these protesters have been "listened to" and achieved some concessions. But what can public service users do? How can I protest? I feel completely impotent to effect any immediate difference to the service I receive on the underground.
Celia Read
London

 After Gerald Corbett tells us that safety must come before punctuality, he shows us quite clearly that profit to shareholders comes before both of them (Railtrack raises dividend, November 14).
David Abrams
Maidstone, Kent

 There must have been many others who read Mick Rix's piece (Take back the track, November 14) with shouts of approval. What can we do in a situation where no major political party seems willing even to consider the obvious step of taking back into public ownership the infrastructure of our rail system? A public campaign - initiated by Aslef? Given publicity by the Guardian? - would get widespread support. Six months before a general election is not a bad time to start.
Peter Fisher
Banbury, Oxon nhsca@pop3.poptel.org.uk

webTitle: Letter: More information

fields.headline: More information
fields.trailText: Hugo Young's polemic against the Liberal Democrats in the Lords for coming to an agreement with the government over the freedom of information bill (Comment, November 14) fails to understand the importance of what has been achieved. The vital element in the deal is the change in the burden of proof from those seeking disclosure to those resisting disclosure.
fields.body:
Hugo Young's polemic against the Liberal Democrats in the Lords for coming to an agreement with the government over the freedom of information bill (Comment, November 14) fails to understand the importance of what has been achieved. The vital element in the deal is the change in the burden of proof from those seeking disclosure to those resisting disclosure. As is clear from the debate on Tuesday evening, this is of central importance. Except for the limited class of information, such as security, which is subject to "absolute exemption", all exempt information must now be disclosed unless the information commissioner decides the public interest in withholding information outweighs the public interest in disclosing it. Disclosure will be the norm.

This means that all exemptions (other than absolute exemptions) are in effect subject to a "harm test". This has been the main demand of the Campaign for Freedom of Information and other organisations. As a result of our amendments, they have now achieved the objectives - with one exception: the ministerial veto in clause 52. This is an important exception, but there are two reasons why the veto will probably be exercised rarely, if at all. One is that it will be vulnerable to judicial review and the courts are likely to look very closely at any cabinet minister who overrides a decision of the information commissioner. Second, any exercise of the veto will put a powerful weapon in the hands of the opposition parties and the media.

As a result of our latest amendments, it has become a bill which can be welcomed by all those with serious interests in freedom of information. It is also, however, an excessively complex bill. This makes it particularly unfortunate that Hugo Young and some others have chosen to shoot from the hip.

Lord Goodhart
Lord Lester

webTitle: Church condemned for anti-gay views

fields.headline: Church condemned for anti-gay views
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The majority of homophobic abuse in Britain is supported by the words and actions of the Christian church, according to a report published today.
fields.body:
The majority of homophobic abuse in Britain is supported by the words and actions of the Christian church, according to a report published today.

The report, from the Commission of Christian Homophobia, accuses the church of institutional homophobia and claims that discrimination by the church against lesbian and gay Christians is widespread.

The report will cause embarrassment to the church, which wants to be seen to be inclusive.

The report claims that lesbian and gay church members are being expelled from congregations; lesbian and gay groups have been refused the use of church premises; and welfare and housing organisations run by the church have excluded gays and lesbians.

The report recommends that church leaders attend homophobia awareness courses, among 75 suggestions for good practice.

Richard Kirker, general secretary of the Lesbian and Gay Christian Movement, said: "If our churches are ever to become safe places for lesbian and gay people, they will have to act as is they know homophobia is evil and must be confronted whenever it surfaces."

The report found that homophobia seriously affected the health of gays and lesbians, which could lead to absence from work, depression and suicide. As a result of the commission's findings, a hotline has been set up.

webTitle: Second sight

fields.headline: Second sight
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Earlier this year, I bought something from a chap in Frankfurt. The transaction was very efficient but, more importantly, it would never have happened at all without the internet in general and eBay in particular. Score one for free trade: I got something I wanted and so did he. A willing buyer and a willing seller were matched by an electronic marketplace that didn't exist a couple of years ago. We were better off and so, by an imperceptibly small amount, was the European economy.
fields.body:
Earlier this year, I bought something from a chap in Frankfurt. The transaction was very efficient but, more importantly, it would never have happened at all without the internet in general and eBay in particular. Score one for free trade: I got something I wanted and so did he. A willing buyer and a willing seller were matched by an electronic marketplace that didn't exist a couple of years ago. We were better off and so, by an imperceptibly small amount, was the European economy.

Using the web and e-mail, I searched on eBay, found what I wanted, bid for it and won the auction, agreed the shipping method and postage costs. The total came to around € 40. Then came the question of payment. A bank transfer seemed rather expensive. A cheque wouldn't work, since I have only sterling accounts and he had a Deutschmark account.Free and fast (in fact instant) person-to-person small payment solutions widely used in the US - Paypal, for example, or Billpoint - don't (yet) work in Europe. PhonePaid, however, a European rival to PayPal, is launching a similar emailing system for GSM phones in Europe this week.

The European banks' principal thrust in this area, the smart card-based electronic purse was useless here. Being in the UK, I don't have one (Visa recently shut down its only scheme in Leeds, Mondex in Edinburgh closed earlier this year, and so on).

Being in Germany, my counterparty did have one (as do more than 50 million of his fellow citizens) but he couldn't use it on the internet. Even if he had been in possession of a smart card reader connected to his PC, his Geldkarte would not have worked with my British bank account so it would have been pointless (and the situation would have been no different if my bank account was in euros and his Geldkarte could store euros, which it cannot).

Banks have, in fact, probably done more harm than good with their botched launch of e-cash. The threat of non-bank competition for the retail payments franchise, and enthusiasm for hi-tech, led them to ignore poor feedback from pilot schemes. Instead of re-focusing on areas where the market wanted solutions (eg, the internet, mobile phones and so on) they kept pushing e-cash where it wasn't wanted: shops.

Eventually, I emailed my German seller and asked him for his preferred payment method: he said cash! So in the year 2000, to execute a transaction between two of the most advanced economies in the world, on the dawn of the single currency, I put two $20 interest-free loans to Uncle Sam in an envelope and handed it over to the Royal Mail. A few days later my goods arrived.

Now this strikes me as odd: one of the most computerised, electronic, global businesses imaginable (ie, banking) is incapable of supporting intra-European cross-border trade and causes trading partners to use US banknotes and the postal service.

The European Central Bank (ECB) is now getting involved, and its work may yet bear fruit. But this problem needs addressing outside of the banking sector. The US wants action in this area as well - the Clinton administration has called for a new "standard-based mechanism" to handle retail payments on the net-but in the US market non-banks have been quick to move in with new payment products: not just email payment by PayPal, but phone billing by eCharge, ISP billing by iPin, pre-paid schemes (like mobile phone vouchers) such as the American Express Internet Shopping Card and so on.

I am not arguing that we need more regulation or legislation in Europe: far from it. But we do need to work hard at stimulating competition by removing regulatory barriers to non-bank entrants in the retail payments business.

Just to pick one example, mobile operators are an obvious potential provider of payment services, not least because the world of m-commerce is as hampered by the lack of appropriate payment technology as much as the internet is. The idea of the mobile phone as some kind of electronic wallet is, in any case, already widespread.

Until someone in the UK can email € 40 to Frankfurt as easily as someone in San Francisco can to someone in New York (ie, very easily), the European e-economy cannot grow like it does in the US. Who cares whether it is NatWest, Vodafone or Canal+ that provides the service?

webTitle: Pharaohs' reigns written in the sky

fields.headline: Pharaohs' reigns written in the sky
fields.trailText: A Cambridge scientist believes she has more accurately dated the reigns of pharaohs 4,500 years ago by taking a closer look at their pyramids.
fields.body:
A Cambridge scientist believes she has more accurately dated the reigns of pharaohs 4,500 years ago by taking a closer look at their pyramids.

Kate Spence, an architect who turned to Egyptology at Cambridge University, reports in Nature today that she matched the orientation of the pyramids to the north celestial pole, and then worked back to calculate where the north celestial pole would have been in 2467BC.

The planet wobbles like a top as it circles the sun. This wobble is very slow - a little circle every 26,000 years - but it means that Polaris, the pole star now, was not the pole star when the pyramids were built between 2,600BC and 2,300BC. Each pyramid was started during the reign of its pharaoh and, until now, Egyptologists have been able only to guess at dates to within 100 years. But Dr Spence says that she can narrow the dates of the pyramid-building pharaohs to within five years. The alignment of the great pyramid of Cheops at Giza, for instance, could be put at around 2478 BC.

More than a century ago, archaeologists observed that all the pyramids were aligned to the north. The slight differences, Dr Spence thinks, reflect a change in the direction of north. North was important to the Egyptians: they believed the afterlife was there.

"You wanted to be with the northern stars and you wanted your pyramid to help you get there," Dr Spence said.

She has calculated that the early pyramid builders fixed north by an imaginary line between two stars in the Ursa major and minor constellations - the Big and Little Dippers. Kate Spence, an architect who turned to Egyptology at Cambridge University, reports in Nature today that she matched the orientation of the pyramids to the north celestial pole, and then worked back to calculate where the north celestial pole would have been in 2467BC. The planet wobbles like a top as it circles the sun. This wobble is very slow - a little circle every 26,000 years - but it means that Polaris, the pole star now, was not the pole star when the pyramids were built between 2,600BC and 2,300BC. Each pyramid was started during the reign of its pharaoh and, until now, Egyptologists have been able only to guess at dates to within 100 years. The alignment of the great pyramid of Cheops at Giza, for instance, could be put at around 2478 BC. More than a century ago, archaeologists observed that all the pyramids were aligned to the north. webTitle: Huge grant lures Peter Hall back to UK for Trojan epic

fields.headline: Huge grant lures Peter Hall back to UK for Trojan epic
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Hall, widely reported a year ago as turning his back on Britain in disgust at state support of the arts, is coming roaring back with a tour of a 10 hour drama about the Trojan wars, supported by the largest ever Arts Council touring grant.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
Sir Peter Hall, widely reported a year ago as turning his back on Britain in disgust at state support of the arts, is coming roaring back with a tour of a 10 hour drama about the Trojan wars, supported by the largest ever Arts Council touring grant.

Tantalus, a project which Sir Peter has been discussing with author John Barton for over 20 years, is directed by Sir Peter and his son Edward, and has a Greek designer, Japanese lighting designer, Irish composer, American choreographer and British and American cast. It will tour for four months from January, before going to the Barbican in London.

The show has been a sensation since it opened in Denver last month, after an unprecedented six months' rehearsal. The plays are shown in groups of three on separate evenings, but the box office has been under siege for the marathon sessions when all are played in a single performance lasting just over 10 hours.

Sir Peter said: "It is something that will enter the Guinness Book of Records, either because it is the most awful thing that has ever happened, or the longest, or the best."

The Arts Council touring grant of £500,000, announced yesterday for the co-production between the Royal Shakespeare Company and the Denver Centre for Performing Arts, is the largest for a single production.

Launching the British tour yesterday, Greg Doran, associate director of the RSC, called the show epic in every respect. "It's been clobbered by the odd cyclops and lured by the odd siren, but in the end we have reached home."

The show will be seen in the new theatres backed by arts lottery money in Milton Keynes and Salford, as well as Nottingham, Norwich and Newcastle.

The show has been 20 years in gestation at the RSC, since Sir Peter's days there as co-founder. Adrian Noble said that when he took over as artistic director, he inherited the dream of the production from his predecessors Terry Hands and Trevor Nunn. "At that point John Barton was said to have been working on it for 15 years, but there was no material evidence that he had actually written a single page".

The script led to a temporary falling out in Denver between Barton and Sir Peter, who have been friends and colleagues for half a century.

When Sir Peter decided the gigantic text was more than an audience could cope with, and would have to be cut by a third, Barton left. He did not attend yesterday's launch of the UK tour, but sent a message of good will.

Sir Peter said: "I don't feel guilty, I feel sad". The show was an adaptation of his friend's magnificent text, he said, but that text has also been published in its entirety.

Sir Peter said he had chosen his son as co-director "not for family reasons but because he is very good".

A third director, Mick Gordon of London's tiny Gate Theatre, a former protege of Sir Peter, left the production during rehearsals.

Sir Peter denied that he ever intended to leave Britain for good.

"I would much rather be here. I have six children and five grandchildren, and I am going to be 70 next Thursday. I would much rather stay home doing the work that I want to do, but if the work is in America, that's where I go."

webTitle: Peace campaigner buried

fields.headline: Peace campaigner buried
fields.standfirst:
Israel mourns Leah Rabin

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israel buried an icon of peace yesterday, as Leah Rabin, widow of its assassinated prime minister, was laid to rest amid the pine trees of Jerusalem's Herzl cemetery.
fields.body:
Israel buried an icon of peace yesterday, as Leah Rabin, widow of its assassinated prime minister, was laid to rest amid the pine trees of Jerusalem's Herzl cemetery.

In a simple service, attended by dignitaries including the US first lady and senator elect, Hillary Clinton, the flag-draped coffin of Leah Rabin was lowered into the ground beside her husband of 47 years, Yitzhak Rabin, shot dead by a rightwing Jewish extremist five years ago at a peace rally.

"Their lives were and are Israel's history. Now their legacy must be Israel's future," Mrs Clinton said.

For outsiders, Leah Rabin was a symbol of courage, eager to take up the baton of peace left by her husband. But her outspokenness alienated many Israelis.

Just weeks ago, she fired off a letter to Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, from the hospital bed where she died of lung cancer on Sunday, criticising him for blocking efforts to reopen a dialogue with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and end the violence consuming both peoples.

Despite such controversies, Ms Rabin was a respected figure. In Tel Aviv yesterday morning, thousands of people filed in silence past her casket, placed at the spot where her husband was shot down, beside a fashionable shopping centre.

Many were elderly, including comrades from Ms Rabin's days in the Palmach which fought for Israel's independence. Some were in tears because of private sorrows like Bracha Bezalel, whose conscript son, Erez Eitan, 19, was killed in Lebanon two years ago.

Despite the bloodshed of the last seven weeks, Ms Bezalel believes in Yitzhak Rabin's mission, and wears a dove-shaped broach with the date of his assassination to prove it. "Despite what has happened today, no matter how many they kill of us, or we kill of them, we will still arrive at the same point, and that is peace," she said.

Speaking at the graveside, Mr Barak said peace would be the Rabins' joint legacy. He called Mrs Rabin "an untiring fighter in the difficult campaign for peace".

webTitle: Games watch

fields.headline: Games watch
fields.trailText: Play off | X factor
fields.body:
Play off
Sony UK says it will not be receiving as many PlayStation 2 games consoles as had been expected. Pre-Christmas deliveries are now expected to amount to 165,000 instead of 200,000.

However, the cut is not as bad as that inflicted on the US, where shipments were halved to 500,000 units, which sold out on October 26, the first day on sale.

The PS2 is being released a week tomorrow with the first deliveries going to those who pre-ordered systems.

X factor
At one time there seemed to be a new release of DirectX, Microsoft's games programming interface in Windows, every month. That has changed, and after a long wait, the company has finally released DirectX 8.0, which will be the version used in next year's Xbox games console.

Much of the effort has gone into simplification. However, new features include DirectPlay, which provides "voice over IP" support, so that online gamers can talk to one another.

Also, DirectShow now supports reading and writing Windows Media Audio and Video (WMA and WMV) files, while Microsoft TV supports digital television. For developers, the DirectX 8.0 Software Development Kit can now be downloaded free from http://msdn.microsoft. com/directx/

Users will normally have their systems upgraded by new games but can download the code from the DirectX Home User page at www.microsoft.com/directx.

Get a life
If Half Life was top of your Christmas present list, you are out of luck: the launch has been postponed from December 8 to "early next year". To avoid picking something else you can't have, consult Gameplay's Release Radar, which claims to be "the definitive games release guide".

Pick the games you want to track and the site will email you if and when the release date changes. Games aren't the all it tracks, either: the listing also includes DVD films.

Game on
3DO Europe plans to release Alex Ferguson's Player Manager 2001 for the Sony PlayStation on November 24 for £29.99, with PlayStation 2 and PC versions following early next year.

Fans will be looking to see how Fergie fares through the rest of the year, because earlier football management games have been endorsed by Kevin Keegan and Gianluca Vialli.

webTitle: Is Microsoft's tablet the wonder drug?

fields.headline: Is Microsoft's tablet the wonder drug?
fields.standfirst: Bill Gates has stolen the show at the computer show in Las Vegas with a write-on PC
fields.trailText: Bill Gates has stolen the show at the computer show in Las Vegas with a write-on PC
fields.body:
The PC industry, neglected during the past two Comdex/Fall computer trade shows in Las Vegas, Nevada, returned to prominence with a vengeance.

Both Microsoft and Intel showed products that will take the PC to a new level of capability, while those promoting appliances and other alternatives were faced with what Bruce Stephens, group vice president of worldwide personal systems research at the US-based International Data Corporation, called "a business model conundrum". Everybody thinks appliances - simplified, dedicated systems - have great potential, but hardly anyone has managed to make any money out of them.

The highlight of the show was undoubtedly "the tablet", a flat pen-operated personal computer unveiled by Bill Gates, Microsoft's chief software architect, during his show-opening keynote presentation. The tablet uses "digital ink", which lets users manipulate their handwritten text in exactly the same way as word-processed characters. The demonstration showed how text, written on the LCD screen, could be moved around and even turned into slanting "italics".

The tablet PC is still a PC with memory and hard drive, running Whistler, the codename for the next version of Microsoft Windows 2000.

However, it seemed to be the closest device so far to the Dynabook (Dynamic Book) computer proposed by Alan Kay, a Xerox Parc researcher, in the late 1970s.

Most of the ideas developed at Parc, Xerox's Palo Alto Research Centre, have already become commonplace. These include graphical user interfaces (in the Apple Macintosh, Microsoft Windows and other systems), laser printers, and computer networks. Kay was confident that continuous annual increases in the power of microprocessors would eventually make the Dynabook feasible, and that day may now be in the foreseeable future. A large batch of prototype tablets has been produced for testing and Gates said systems could be on sale in about two years.

The unfortunate part of the tablet demonstration was that it was not possible to get a good view of the operating system. Whistler is destined to replace both Windows 95/98/Me and new technology Windows NT/2000. It will also give Windows a new interface, which has not been seen before, though users will have the option to stay with the "Windows classic" look, if that is what they prefer.

Whistler will run on any PC capable of running today's Windows 2000, but it is a safe bet that it will also trigger another "upgrade cycle". And users in the market for a new PC to run Whistler will be encouraged to opt for systems based on the new, more expensive Pentium 4 processors that Intel previewed at the show.

In the past year, Intel has had its nose bloodied by the much smaller AMD, which has been selling faster, cheaper Athlon processors. Intel hopes the Pentium 4, along with price cuts on the Pentium 3 line, will shift the balance back in its favour.

Although the PC market has also been getting a relatively bad press recently, IDC's Bruce Stephens said: "the fact is, the growth rate is still pretty good". The PC market grew by 19% this year, with about 140 million units sold, and Stephens expected 17% growth next year.

According to IDC's research, said Stephens, the growth of the internet was "benefiting the PC market, not appliances". Only 28 million appliances had been sold in the past year, though he was predicting sales of 48 million units in the next year.

Stephens said PC growth was particularly healthy in "new markets" (less developed countries), and that the growth rate for sales of portable PCs was above 30%. "What's driving this is students, home offices and small business users responding to lower prices," he said.

Jerry Purdy, president and chief executive of Mobile Insights, a Californian research company, agreed that the notebook PC was "becoming the standard in two major markets: the enterprise and the college market". Notebook PCs were replacing desktops as business professionals became more mobile.

Purdy said this trend would be encouraged by the rapid acceptance of wireless networking. "Wireless LANs [local area networks] have arrived and are going to become pervasive, thanks to the interoperability of the 802.11b standard."

However, Purdy predicted that "wide area wireless" - based on cellular telephony - would "continue to be a disappointment" because of low connection speeds, while Wap (wireless application protocol) "in its present form is never going to have wide adoption". Purdy thought the mobile market would be a lot better when 3G (third generation) networks arrived.

Some manufacturers have seen the appliance market and mobile computing as ways to avoid competition from PC industry giants. But the PC industry giants see these new areas as good places to expand their sales.

Intel, for example, is targeting mobiles with its StrongArm processors, a design it acquired when Digital Equipment was taken over by Compaq, and which was ultimately derived from the British ARM (Acorn Risc Machine).

Microsoft is also competing hard - with limited success - in the mobile markets with handheld PocketPC palmtops made by Compaq, Hewlett- Packard and Casio, and a mobile phone just launched in France by Sagem. During his keynote speech, Gates also showed a powerful prototype phone codenamed Stinger.

The computing and telephony markets are obviously starting to overlap but this does not necessarily mean the computing companies will suffer. "It's just as likely we'll see the death of the cellphone," says Jerry Purdy. He does not mean that people will stop using mobile telephony, but that more calls may be made using handheld electronic organisers - like the PocketPC-based Sagem - held up to the face, rather than with the primitive devices people nowadays hold to their ears.

webTitle: What's new

fields.headline: What's new
fields.trailText: Video phone | Do it digitally
fields.body:
Video phone
Samsung is claiming a world first with its new streaming video mobile phone, below.

The device, powered by a GEO Emblaze chip, has just been launched in Asia and is due to appear in Europe next year. It will allow users to tap into libraries of information and entertainment stored in the Mpeg4 format, as well as watch video mail.

Most remarkably, GEO claims the technology can work over today's 2G networks - running as slow as 9.6kbps - as well as future 2.5G (GPRS) and 3G systems. (NM)

Ripping idea
Samsung is claiming to have liberated MP3 from the clutches of the PC.

Three of the Korean company's new hi-fi systems feature an MP3 encoder which directly rips tracks from CDs on to a 32MB SmartMedia card. These can be played back either via the hi-fi system or on a supplied Yepp MY-MP200 MP3 personal.

Top of the range is the £500 NA-CP70, which houses a CD player, FM/AM radio tuner, amplifier and MP3 encoder in a PC-inspired tower configuration.

In addition to a docking bay which is home for the 32MB Yepp personal player, the system features a parallel port that enables it to download music from a PC.

The £400 S-P2450 integrates a similar line up of facilities in a more conventional mini system line-up.

For music lovers who want to keep their options open, Samsung is offering the £350 MM-N7SM, a micro hi-fi that features both an MP3 encoder and a cassette deck.

The three models, plus several MP3 playback-only hi-fi systems, go on sale later this month.

Do it digitally
Sanyo is hoping to further blur the line between digital cameras and camcorders with a hybrid model now out in Japan.

The IDC-1000Z iDshot uses a unique 5cm magneto-optical iD Photo technology developed by Sanyo, Hitachi and Olympus to store up to two hours of moving images complete with mono soundtrack on a single disk.

With a resolution of 640x480 pixels the camera's video picture quality won't worry Hollywood too much, but it's more than good enough for use on the net.

Alternatively, snap-happy photographers can archive up to 11,000 VGA-quality images on the disk.

Sanyo also claims that the IDC-1000Z is the first digital camera on the market to feature an IEEE1394 interface for high-speed image transfer to a PC.

Expect to see the model in the UK in the new year.

In-car MP3
Panasonic has found an unusual home for its new high capacity SD (Secure Digital) storage media. From next month, Japanese buyers will be able to install a SD-equipped audio system, the SRX7000, in their cars.

The system features a slot for the tiny SD card which can store music in both MP3 and the new, higher quality music compression format AAC.

And just in case the SD card's capacity of 64MB does not deliver enough music for the owner's liking, the SRX7000 also comes with a CD player and radio tuner.

In the UK, Panasonic is about to launch its first SD-compatible products. Very shortly stores in Britain will be able to display a trio of digital camcorders, the NV-MX300B, NV-MX7 and NV-MX5. These models offer videographers the option of using SD for storing still and moving images or music files. Prices for the models have not yet been made available.

Panasonic is also poised to make its debut in the UK digital camera market with a model that is already on sale in Japan.

Due in the UK some time next year is the 3.4 Megapixel PV-DC3000.

The camera boasts a wide selection of facilities, including a 1.5 inch LCD display, 2 x optical and 3 x digital zooms, video capture, a playback speaker, built-in flash and manual controls for exposure and white balance and focus.

It is compatible with both SD and MultiMedia cards. (AN)

Three of the Korean company's new hi-fi systems feature an MP3 encoder which directly rips tracks from CDs on to a 32MB SmartMedia card. These can be played back either via the hi-fi system or on a supplied Yepp MY-MP200 MP3 personal. Top of the range is the £500 NA-CP70, which houses a CD player, FM/AM radio tuner, amplifier and MP3 encoder in a PC-inspired tower configuration. In addition to a docking bay which is home for the 32MB Yepp personal player, the system features a parallel port that enables it to download music from a PC. The £400 S-P2450 integrates a similar line up of facilities in a more conventional mini system line-up. For music lovers who want to keep their options open, Samsung is offering the £350 MM-N7SM, a micro hi-fi that features both an MP3 encoder and a cassette deck. The three models, plus several MP3 playback-only hi-fi systems, go on sale later this month. Do it digitally Sanyo is hoping to further blur the line between digital cameras and camcorders with a hybrid model now out in Japan. The IDC-1000Z iDshot uses a unique 5cm magneto-optical iD Photo technology developed by Sanyo, Hitachi and Olympus to store up to two hours of moving images complete with mono soundtrack on a single disk. With a resolution of 640x480 pixels the camera's video picture quality won't worry Hollywood too much, but it's more than good enough for use on the net. Alternatively, snap-happy photographers can archive up to 11,000 VGA-quality images on the disk. Sanyo also claims that the IDC-1000Z is the first digital camera on the market to feature an IEEE1394 interface for high-speed image transfer to a PC. Expect to see the model in the UK in the new year. In-car MP3 Panasonic has found an unusual home for its new high capacity SD (Secure Digital) storage media. From next month, Japanese buyers will be able to install a SD-equipped audio system, the SRX7000, in their cars. The system features a slot for the tiny SD card which can store music in both MP3 and the new, higher quality music compression format AAC. And just in case the SD card's capacity of 64MB does not deliver enough music for the owner's liking, the SRX7000 also comes with a CD player and radio tuner. In the UK, Panasonic is about to launch its first SD-compatible products. Very shortly stores in Britain will be able to display a trio of digital camcorders, the NV-MX300B, NV-MX7 and NV-MX5. These models offer videographers the option of using SD for storing still and moving images or music files. Prices for the models have not yet been made available. Panasonic is also poised to make its debut in the UK digital camera market with a model that is already on sale in Japan. Due in the UK some time next year is the 3.4 Megapixel PV-DC3000. The camera boasts a wide selection of facilities, including a 1.5 inch LCD display, 2 x optical and 3 x digital zooms, video capture, a playback speaker, built-in flash and manual controls for exposure and white balance and focus. It is compatible with both SD and MultiMedia cards. (AN)

webTitle: At this price?  Scottish Radio

fields.headline: At this price?  Scottish Radio
fields.trailText: In March, Scottish Radio Holdings kick-started one of the year's more intriguing bidding wars - if not the largest that has graced the City.
fields.body:
In March, Scottish Radio Holdings kick-started one of the year's more intriguing bidding wars - if not the largest that has graced the City.

SRH ultimately lost what became a hard-fought battle for Border Television. The victor was Capital Radio, leaving SRH to pick up the pieces and wonder what to do next with the £75m it had raised for acquisitions at the beginning of the year.

From yesterday's full-year results it would appear the company has not done a bad job. Revenues were ahead by 30% to £71.7m and pre-tax profits 27% better at £20m.

The business has three divisions - radio at the core plus outdoor advertising sites and a growing number of newspapers.

After losing Border it paid £6m for Title Media, owner of the Ireland on Sunday newspaper, and quickly followed the deal with the £28.2m acquisition of KPH, a publisher of paid-for weekly titles. After reducing debts it has £25m left in the bank.

The group managed to shrug off a weaker radio advertising market in late summer which had caused some analysts to lower their forecasts for year-end. A strong recovery meant radio maintained revenue growth at 6% in the second half. SRH had been aggrieved at the dot.com advertisers neglecting Scotland, but with the boom over it won't suffer by comparison. Given recent sentiment, chief executive Richard Findlay is probably right in feeling vindicated by the decision to spend only £400,000 on digital radio and the internet in 2000.

The better than expected results yesterday added 4.5% to the shares which closed at £12.12. West LB Panmure has a target price of £14.20 while Investec Henderson Crosthwaite is higher at £16.25.

Part of the reason for picking the shares, though, is the forthcoming communications white paper. At least one analyst is betting on a merger with its Scottish rival SMG to create a dominant force in Scotland.

webTitle: FKI seeks torque tweak

fields.headline: FKI seeks torque tweak
fields.trailText: Throughout the land, chief executives of engineering firms can be heard complaining about the share price of their groups.
fields.body:
Throughout the land, chief executives of engineering firms can be heard complaining about the share price of their groups.

Bob Beeston, boss of FKI, is no exception. But, unlike some of his peers, he may have a case.

FKI presents interim figures a week today, and according to the whispers they are going to be much stronger than expected. Not only that, but CSFB yesterday also lifted its recommendation to "buy" and slapped a 260p target on the stock; last night FKI shares closed at 190p.

According to CSFB, FKI has transformed itself during the past two years into a company focused on margin expansion and acquisitive growth.

Moreover, CSFB reckons that the market has yet to fairly evaluate the growth potential of its sector-leading Logistex technology - a sort of hi-tech baggage-handling system which can be used in any part of the supply chain.

webTitle: Lateral thinking wide of mark

fields.headline: Lateral thinking wide of mark
fields.trailText: Too much spare time can be a dangerous thing, especially in the Square Mile. With traders waiting patiently for Fed chairman Alan Greenspan to deliver his latest judgment on US interest rates, it was time to indulge in a spot of lateral thinking. The City being the City, two plus two was coming out as five.
fields.body:
Too much spare time can be a dangerous thing, especially in the Square Mile. With traders waiting patiently for Fed chairman Alan Greenspan to deliver his latest judgment on US interest rates, it was time to indulge in a spot of lateral thinking. The City being the City, two plus two was coming out as five.

But first let us look at events in the wider the market. After Tuesday's fireworks, the FTSE 100 closed a subdued session a mere 19.4 points up at 6,432.3, thanks largely to good performances from Cable & Wireless , up 37p to 887p on the back of strong interim figures, and oil majors BP , 12p higher at 603p, and Shell , 13.5p better at 583.5p, as the oil price remained firm.

Market turnover slowed as investors paused to take stock of what has so far been a busy and volatile week. Elsewhere, the FTSE 250 pushed on 21.7 points to 6,719.9 and the Techmark 100 added 17.16 to 3,194.37.

Among the leaders most of the action was again in the telecoms sector and the reason was to be found round at the Fenchurch Street headquarters of Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

Yesterday the German broker published a weighty note on the telecom sector, arguing that the recent de-rating of the sector had thrown up some excellent buying opportunities. Its favourites in the UK are Energis , up 25p to 515p, Vodafone , 1p better at 263.5p. Dresdner is not a fan of BT , which eased 21p to 677p.

Back in the speculative world, dealers were getting excited about Great Portland Estates , one of the grand old names of the property sector. The property company delivers interim figures next week and according to the gossips Great Portland will "do an MEPC".

What they are referring to is the deal that saw MEPC taken private in June. That decision to go private in a £1.92bn agreed deal was announced with interim results.

The same, it is claimed, is go ing to happen with Great Portland, although in this case the buyer will be the management and the offer will be pitched at just under 400p per share.

Apparently Great Portland, which is now focused on property in the West End of London and shopping centres, has given up trying to close the gap between its share price and the value of its assets, which has risen to levels that suggest a recession is on the way. The company has tried various tricks to narrow the discount, including selling assets and returning cash to shareholders and buying back shares, but all to no avail.

When reporting full year figures in June, managing director Patrick Hall admitted that if the company's share price remained at too deep a discount to net asset value the board would be forced to review the situation. Great Portland shares closed 11.5p higher at 272p after 1.5m had changed hands.

Dealers were also trying to apply this logic to another property company, Frogmore Estates , but the shares fell 2.5p to 533p.

There was also some fuzzy thinking about controls and automation group Invensys , up 1.5p to 153p. Bid speculation in the stock has been rife for the past month and got another outing yesterday based on hopes that acquisitive US conglomerate Tyco will make an offer. As far as anyone could tell these hopes were based on the fact Tyco raised around £3bn though a convertible bond issue earlier this week.

However, far from using the proceeds to make an offer for Invensys, Tyco intends to apply the cash to financing its recent purchase of Lucent Power Systems. Invensys reports half-time figures next week.

Back on firmer ground, magazine publisher Future Network dived 47.5p to 197.5p after downgrade from Merrill Lynch, while Carphone Warehouse moved up 9p to 197.5p after JP Morgan initiated coverage with a buy rating and said fair value for the shares was 240p.

webTitle: A Country Diary

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Moray Firth
fields.body:
Moray Firth

The scenery and wildlife of the Highlands is always stimulating and exciting, but sometimes there is that something special that "takes my breath away", and this can happen even on the few miles' drive into Inverness. As we reach the crest of the hill on Drummossie Moor, the most dominant feature to the north is Ben Wyvis, at over 3,000 feet. The Moray Firth is the next outstanding sight. For the next few months it will be home to thousands of wildfowl and waders whose lives are ruled by the ebbing and making of the tides. Watching the birds from the public hide on the north side of Inverness is always a thrill; especially when a peregrine falcon appears and scatters them.

Viewing the Firth from a distance, it's hard to imagine that a few years ago there were ambitious plans to reclaim the land for agriculture, until someone pointed out that all the crops that would be grown already had their food mountains - and common sense prevailed. Not so, however, with the Longman rubbish tip, which has been covering valuable feeding grounds for summering and wintering birds for many years, and is still expanding.

Another thrill is when a haar, a cold sea mist, moves in from the east and filters up the Firth. In the right conditions, from the crest of the moor, none of Inverness is visible, and only the hills are in view as they rise almost Wagnerian out of the dense mist. Then in the summer there's that unforgettable fragrance that hits you before you reach the moor, as hundreds of acres of gorse are in flower. All this in just a short drive into Inverness, which is what the Highlands are all about. Thank goodness!

webTitle: Passnotes: Chris Heinz

fields.headline: No: 1762
fields.standfirst: Chris Heinz
fields.trailText: Chris Heinz
fields.body:
Are we talking 57 varieties? We are indeed. This is none other than the 27-year-old Harvard-educated heir to the Heinz dynasty.

Sounds quite the eligible bachelor. No. Bachelors are responsible for the delightful beverage which is Cup-a-Soup. Heinz Means Beanz.

And spaghetti hoops. Yes, and spaghetti hoops.

And ketchup. Yes, ketchup too.

And ... Look, we don't have enough space to list all 57 of their delightful tomato-based products. What I really want to tell you is that he's snogging Gwyneth Paltrow.

Gwyneth who? Paltrow. Swannish blonde actress who won an Oscar and cried about it.

Once dated Brad Pitt? Ssh, we're not supposed to mention that little interlude. Or the fact that he wed Jennifer Aniston earlier this year. She might start blubbing again. So keep your lips sealed.

Right. But won't that make it rather difficult to consume my delicious Heinz Baked Beans in Tomato Sauce with Six Pork Sausages? I've told you before about product placement.

Sorry. Please do tell me more about this Heinz chappie. He's intelligent, handsome, well-connected and stands to inherit some £430m.

That's a heap o' beans. Certainly is.

But I bet she's not short of a bob or two. A Brad and a Ben but definitely not a Bob.

And they are officially an item? Well, he and Gwynnie were recently spotted together at a swanky New York art show and dining at some hoity-toity restaurant. They're quite the toast of the town.

Two slices lightly buttered? Mmm, the perfect canvas for some scrumptious Heinz canned spaghetti ... Oi!

Sorry. But no saucy gossip to report? Only a spot of "canoodling".

So nothing too fruity? No, we're talking strictly legumes here. Chris Del Monte is spoken for.

Don't say: "Empty contents into saucepan and stir gently while heating."

Do say: "Full of beans."

webTitle: Women: Pregnancy and abortion

fields.headline: Moral minors
fields.standfirst: What do teenagers really think about pregnancy and abortion? A new survey suggests that they are far less feckless than we are led to believe, report  Esther Addley  and  Crystal Mahey
fields.trailText: What do teenagers really think about pregnancy and abortion? A new survey suggests that they are far less feckless than we are led to believe, report  Esther Addley  and  Crystal Mahey.
fields.body:
"Teenagers should not allow themselves to get into situations where they even need to consider having an abortion. The only time it is right to have a child is in a stable relationship, when you can support your child both financially and emotionally. Unless you are at that stage, you should be careful and not get yourself pregnant. Otherwise you are just being irresponsible and selfish."

Are these the words of a right-wing leader writer? Or a pro-life organisation spokesperson? You would be wrong to assume either was the right answer. This is the opinion of Victoria, a 14-year-old schoolgirl from London. Teenagers are not meant to talk like this, at least not according to the well-rehearsed national debate over teenage pregnancy. Even adults prepared to credit teenagers with maturity in taking decisions about reproduction may assume that school-aged sex is free and easy, and the possibility of creating life considered in a cavalier fashion, if it is considered at all.

So the findings of a new study published this week will come as a surprise to many. The survey, by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, talked to 41 young women in Doncaster who had become pregnant at a young age and, in the vast majority of cases, continued with the pregnancy to full term. It found that almost all had been shocked to discover they were pregnant. They were not trying to please their boyfriends, and most took the decision on whether or not to keep their baby without much reference to the child's father.

Most tellingly, they were far from irresponsible. In fact, the teenagers were so convinced of the need to take responsibility for their own actions that terminating the pregnancy was not an option considered. Getting pregnant may be frowned upon by the moral majority, but even the report's authors confessed to surprise at the force of moral disapproval displayed by girls towards their peers who had had abortions.

What would happen if everyone at school knew that someone had had an abortion? "You wouldn't be able to go to school," replied one girl. "You would get called names. You would probably get hit and all."

One teenager, Lucy, had decided not to continue with a pregnancy. "I told this woman I knew who I worked with and she turned round and called me a murderer."

The strength of feeling against abortion on the Doncaster housing estates where these women were interviewed surprised Sharon Tabberer, one of the researchers. "They said it was nothing to do with religion, but that it was 'wrong'. It just wasn't something that people like them did."

"What is so interesting is this incredible difference when it comes to social groups and abortion," says Anne Weyman, chief executive of the Family Planning Association. "Middle-class girls, we know, are less likely to get pregnant than less well-off girls, but they are also much more likely to have abortions. The two groups just don't have the same sort of views.

"It is interesting that in a group of young women who have less control over their lives than other young women, that is being reinforced by the fact that they feel abortion is not an option for them either."

So how did we get to the point where only well-off, well-educated girls tend to consider termination? Education on family planning and sexual health simply tries to sweep abortion under the carpet, argues Weyman. "There has been a real reluctance to consider that abortion is an important option for young women, and to make sure that it is offered to them. Everything is about prevention - which is good - and support for new parents - also good - but there is nothing about the choice you can make in the middle of these two options."

She points out that government guidelines on sex education have not, until this year, included a recommendation that girls be given advice on terminations. The DfEE's advice, published in June, tentatively suggested that "young people need to be aware of the moral and personal dilemmas involved in abortion and know how to access a relevant agency if necessary".

By "relevant agency" it may be assumed that the department means impartial advice on termination - but even couched in such language the recommendation attracted howls of protest from the pro-life lobby.

There is little doubt that the Doncaster study teenagers are aware of the troubled morality involved in abortion. "It was about taking responsibility for their actions," says Tabberer. "They said things like: 'It was me who made the mistake and why should the baby have to suffer? I didn't use protection, it's not the baby's fault.'"

James is 19 and already the father of a one-year-old son. While he does regret his role in the pregnancy, he is convinced of the importance of taking responsibility for creating a life. "It happened, and now I have a responsibility to my child. It is difficult trying to bring up a baby on my own, they are expensive and it limits the things I can do in my life. But it is not me that is important any more, my child is my priority."

"In this country we have a very censorious view about the unwanted consequences of sexual activity," says Weyman. "It makes young people believe that, well, I've had sex, so I have to live with the outcome. It's a lack of being able to say, well I do have a choice."

For teenagers who do decide to have an abortion, the decision is tough, argues 16-year-old Aisha. "When I realised I was pregnant, I just cried and cried and cried. It's like, when you're young, you dream about having children and being with someone you love, and all that is taken from you in 10 minutes and a pregnancy test."

Aisha lives in London and is at college taking A-levels. "Having an abortion was the hardest thing I have ever had to deal with, and I don't think there can ever be anything worse. Some people are like, how can anyone kill their child? That's how I felt about myself, afterwards, but it wasn't like that. I'm 16, I couldn't support a little child financially, and I wasn't ready emotionally. How could I bring a life into this world when I knew it would suffer."

Aisha explains that her background made the decision even more difficult for her. "For any daughter to tell her parents she is 15 and pregnant is hard. But when your parents follow traditional Indian beliefs and are obsessed with keeping the family name respectful ... at least some people have their families support when they have abortions, I had nothing."

"Middle-class girls, we know, are less likely to get pregnant than less well-off girls, but they are also much more likely to have abortions. The two groups just don't have the same sort of views. "It is interesting that in a group of young women who have less control over their lives than other young women, that is being reinforced by the fact that they feel abortion is not an option for them either." So how did we get to the point where only well-off, well-educated girls tend to consider termination? Education on family planning and sexual health simply tries to sweep abortion under the carpet, argues Weyman. "There has been a real reluctance to consider that abortion is an important option for young women, and to make sure that it is offered to them. Everything is about prevention - which is good - and support for new parents - also good - but there is nothing about the choice you can make in the middle of these two options." She points out that government guidelines on sex education have not, until this year, included a recommendation that girls be given advice on terminations. The DfEE's advice, published in June, tentatively suggested that "young people need to be aware of the moral and personal dilemmas involved in abortion and know how to access a relevant agency if necessary". By "relevant agency" it may be assumed that the department means impartial advice on termination - but even couched in such language the recommendation attracted howls of protest from the pro-life lobby. There is little doubt that the Doncaster study teenagers are aware of the troubled morality involved in abortion. "It was about taking responsibility for their actions," says Tabberer. "They said things like: 'It was me who made the mistake and why should the baby have to suffer? I didn't use protection, it's not the baby's fault.'" James is 19 and already the father of a one-year-old son. While he does regret his role in the pregnancy, he is convinced of the importance of taking responsibility for creating a life. "It happened, and now I have a responsibility to my child. It is difficult trying to bring up a baby on my own, they are expensive and it limits the things I can do in my life. But it is not me that is important any more, my child is my priority." "In this country we have a very censorious view about the unwanted consequences of sexual activity," says Weyman. "It makes young people believe that, well, I've had sex, so I have to live with the outcome. It's a lack of being able to say, well I do have a choice." For teenagers who do decide to have an abortion, the decision is tough, argues 16-year-old Aisha. "When I realised I was pregnant, I just cried and cried and cried. It's like, when you're young, you dream about having children and being with someone you love, and all that is taken from you in 10 minutes and a pregnancy test." Aisha lives in London and is at college taking A-levels. "Having an abortion was the hardest thing I have ever had to deal with, and I don't think there can ever be anything worse. Some people are like, how can anyone kill their child? That's how I felt about myself, afterwards, but it wasn't like that. I'm 16, I couldn't support a little child financially, and I wasn't ready emotionally. How could I bring a life into this world when I knew it would suffer." Aisha explains that her background made the decision even more difficult for her. "For any daughter to tell her parents she is 15 and pregnant is hard. But when your parents follow traditional Indian beliefs and are obsessed with keeping the family name respectful ... at least some people have their families support when they have abortions, I had nothing."

webTitle: C&W in search of outfits to buy

fields.headline: C&W in search of outfits to buy
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless, the business telecoms group, is planning to spend a large part of its £4bn cash pile on small acquisitions to bolster its internet-related business, especially in the US.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless, the business telecoms group, is planning to spend a large part of its £4bn cash pile on small acquisitions to bolster its internet-related business, especially in the US.

Chief executive Graham Wallace ruled out a mega-bid or the purchase of any of the businesses which British Telecom, its old rival, is putting up for sale.

Mr Wallace said that large companies tended to have legacy systems which were of no use to C&W which aimed to be the leading global supplier of internet protocol (IP) solutions to business customers.

The company, which expects to announce two deals within the next three months, is looking at companies worth tens or hundreds of millions of pounds, rather than those worth a billion or more, he said.

Mr Wallace said C&W was interested in buying the data operations of Optus, the Australian telecom business in which it has a 52.5% stake. Optus, which also has mobile and consumer divisions, yesterday put itself up for sale, in whole or in part.

C&W ended the year with net cash of £4.2bn, mainly as a result of its sale of its consumer business to NTL and the sale of its Hongkong Telecom stake to Pacific Century Cyber Works. It also received shares in NTL and PCCW, which if sold would add a further £1bn to its cash pile.

The sales of the two businesses resulted in a £4.27bn exceptional profit which has distorted C&W's first half figures. Pre-tax profits rose 33% to £4.59bn, though the underlying profit - after allowing for the gains on disposals - was £537m, against £539m for the same period last year. The interim dividend has been raised by 10% to 4.95p per share.

Mr Wallace said the group was expecting continued strong growth. "We operate in a market place expected to grow by 15% to 20%, he said. "That is our stated growth target as well. Most of the growth will come from IP services."

He said C&W was now benefiting from its recent reorganisation - which included the sale of non-core businesses and focus on IP-related activities - while competitors were still restructuring.

C&W was only interested in the full acquisition of IP-related businesses which brought products, customers and brain power to the group. Mr Wallace said the IP standard meant telecom groups could quickly roll out products globally for the first time.

webTitle: Centrica still stepping on the gas

fields.headline: Centrica still stepping on the gas
fields.trailText: Ian Russell is bound to feel a trifle exposed when he addresses an Institute of Economic Affairs conference on energy policy next week. Scottish Power's deputy chief executive last week dared to speak out loud the private gripes of many of his colleagues in the gas and electricity industry: British Gas, the former state monopoly now part of Centrica, controls a huge slice of what is supposed to be an open, free and competitive market.
fields.body:
Ian Russell is bound to feel a trifle exposed when he addresses an Institute of Economic Affairs conference on energy policy next week. Scottish Power's deputy chief executive last week dared to speak out loud the private gripes of many of his colleagues in the gas and electricity industry: British Gas, the former state monopoly now part of Centrica, controls a huge slice of what is supposed to be an open, free and competitive market.

Mr Russell, who takes over as chief executive from Sir Ian Robinson in April, suggested that Centrica's share of the retail market was 80% and the group was so dominant that the industry regulator Ofgem ought to step in. "If we are really interested in having a strong, competitive market there have to be several strong competitors, but there are not many markets where one player has 80% and the regulator is supposed to be encouraging competition."

He now regrets his comments, which are common currency among other Centrica rivals, but he has a point. Scottish Power, which also owns Manweb, the electricity company based in Manchester, has lost 200,000 customers in the past six months - almost entirely to British Gas - and now has 3.5m accounts. But Mr Russell thinks 6m to 7m is the optimum base on which to take on Centrica, and rivals can hardly match the £150m national advertising campaign British Gas is running to capture new electricity or "dual fuel" customers and win back those who have switched to other suppliers.

There are 26m electricity customers and 20m gas customers in Britain and British Gas has 3.5m of the former and 14m of the latter, giving it 15% and 70% of those respective markets. "No other company in British history has ever had so many customers - apart from BT," says Nigel Hawkins, utilities analyst at Williams de Broe. "We have always argued that Centrica is so much in pole position that anybody competing has to face the fact they are very hard to dislodge ... It's like a horse race in which Centrica is way out in front by the first furlong."

Mr Russell's problem is partly to do with his group's name, which plays well in the old South of Scotland Electricity Board region it inherited and, as Manweb, in parts of the north-west of England. But it scarcely works as a brand in other regions. Centrica can trade as British Gas in England, Scottish Gas in Scotland and Nwy Prydain in Wales. Scottish Power owns Southern Water which gives it a customer base of 5.5m but admitted last week only 8% of Southern's clients take its energy offering. Most of the 14 privatised regional electricity companies in England and Wales, now often in foreign hands, remain trapped in their original franchise area.

Powergen, which bought East Midlands Electricity to move into the retail energy market, can happily trade, however, on its national brand image through sponsorship of the weather forecast on ITV. "It's a three-horse race wherever you go," officials say. "There's British Gas - the people to beat - and the regional incumbent."

Powergen has 2.8m customers and is prepared to pay £30-£40 each to attract new ones on its way to reaching its target of 5m by the end of 2002 - compared to the cost of up to £250 per customer involved in acquisition. It offers £30 to switch to its dual-fuel offering and claims it can undercut British Gas or the electricity incumbent. But the fact remains that, even if switching can offer savings of up to £57 a year to former British Gas customers, Centrica retains what some rivals see as a stranglehold on the market.

One reason, voiced by Mr Russell last week, is that it can take up to three months to switch from British Gas and many run out of patience, while new entrants have suffered from exposure of over-aggressive doorstep-selling (outsourced to contractors). Centrica will have none of this, arguing that it kick-started competition in the electricity market and remains highly competitive in gas. "Customers are aware they have a choice of supplier."

The group's strongest card is that so far Ofgem, headed by Callum McCarthy, sees no reason to intervene because it has found no evidence that Centrica is abusing its position. If it did "something silly", as Mr Hawkins puts it, Ofgem could use its powers under the Competition Act, investigate and ultimately impose penalties worth up to 10% of relevant turnover.

Another outcome, according to Mr Hawkins, is for the competition authorities to order a break-up of Centrica, forcing it to sell its Scottish or Welsh businesses in the event of proven abuse, but he sees that as unlikely.

Ofgem says it is conducting reviews of customer competition in gas and electricity but believes the liberalisation of the market, begun three years ago, is working. Its latest tally shows 5.7m customers leaving British Gas for other suppliers while 5.2m electricity customers have switched. But there is a new source of worry for Centrica's rivals in the utilities sector: telecoms, which the group is entering in an aggressive manner, determined to have 1m fixed-line and mobile subscribers by the end of next year.

British Gas, which promises to undercut BT, is challenging an incumbent's 80% dominance of a domestic market opened up to competition as long ago as 1982 . Contrast, too, the 96% awareness of the option to change supplier in home energy after two years of full competition with the 67% awareness in telecoms after 18 years. British Gas can draw on not only its huge domestic energy customer base but also the AA's 9m-plus members and the 1m holders of its Goldfish credit card to punch its way into telecoms, at marginal extra cost.

Small wonder analysts such as Mr Hawkins rate Centrica, with its strong balance sheet and minimal capital spending, a "buy" and see little reason to doubt its continued dominance of its markets.

British Gas, reviled for its lack of customer care and boardroom excesses on pay just five years ago, is on the verge of becoming Britain's most popular company. Exasperated rivals may have reason to complain but so far they are crying in the wind.

webTitle: SSE sets its sights on being No2

fields.headline: SSE sets its sights on being No2
fields.trailText: Scottish and Southern Energy, the multi-utility, yesterday set out ambitious plans to become Britain's largest supplier of gas and electricity after British Gas by taking over another energy company.
fields.body:
Scottish and Southern Energy, the multi-utility, yesterday set out ambitious plans to become Britain's largest supplier of gas and electricity after British Gas by taking over another energy company.

The Perth-based group said it aimed to win 5m electricity and 2m gas customers, overtaking TXU (Eastern Electricity) which has 5.6m accounts. SSE has 5.4m combined customers, including 1m gas accounts - well behind British Gas's 14m gas and 3.5m electricity customers.

Ian Marchant, finance director, said the group was looking to expand into the US market, preferably through a merger. He announced an 8.2% rise in pre-tax profits for the first half to £213.3m and a revised cost-savings target of £140m, up from £95m.

Earlier this year SSE, formed from the merger of Scottish Hydro-Electric and Southern Electric, paid £210m - £180 per customer - to buy south Wales energy supply company, Swalec from British Energy. Mr Marchant said it could now raise its customer targets by "a combination of organic growth and acquisition, probably another acquisition in the medium term".

Tighter price controls by regulators have prompted a new wave of consolidation in the industry and analysts indicate that US investors could be ready to sell on three smaller companies - Yorkshire Electricity and Seeboard, owned by AEP, and Northern Electric, owned by a consortium including Warren Buffett's Berkeley Hathaway.

SSE sees earnings potential in three other areas: telecoms, water and overseas. Targeting the business market, it is investing £45m in 2,000km of fibre optic cable along its power network and now plans to install up to 800 mobile phone masts in deals with Vodafone and One2One.

Mr Marchant said the group could enter the expected bidding war to operate and manage another group's water assets.
