webTitle: Obituary: Keith Mant

fields.headline: Keith Mant
fields.standfirst: A 1946 posting to probe war crimes led to a prominent career in forensic medicine
fields.trailText: Professor Keith Mant, who has died aged 81, was one of London's leading forensic medicine experts, and probably the last of the generation who entered medical school before the second world war.
fields.body:
Professor Keith Mant, who has died aged 81, was one of London's leading forensic medicine experts, and probably the last of the generation who entered medical school before the second world war.

Both here and overseas, he was one of the most sought after expert witnesses in forensic matters, both for the prosecution and the defence. He had flair and expertise, and his evidence was always given to the court without prejudice to either side.

He was born in Purley, Surrey, and educated at Denstone College, where he excelled in rugby and fullbore rifle shooting. Although his father was a solicitor (the 10th generation of his family to go into law), Mant turned to medicine, and in 1939 won an exhibition to St Mary's Hospital, Paddington; he claimed that it was more for his rugby skills than his academic attainments. As a medical student during the war, he worked as an ambulance driver and plane spotter.

After qualifying in 1943, Mant's first job was in obstetrics and gynaecology at St Mary's, until he joined the Royal Army Medical Corps in 1944. Then, in November 1945, he was posted as officer in charge of the pathology section to the war crimes investigating team covering North Western Europe. He later became the pathologist in charge of the special medical section of the war crimes group created in 1946.

Until 1946, his duties had been restricted to undertaking exhumations on bodies of Allied airmen and airborne personnel who had been buried either in cemeteries or in unmarked graves; he concentrated on cases where German personnel were either in custody or where the investigating team considered that a suspect could be arrested.

After 1946, much of Mant's time was taken up in interviewing medically qualified suspects who had either been SS members or who had worked on behalf of the SS conducting medical experimentation in a number of concentration camps, in particular in Ravensbruck. He remained with the special medical section until it was dissolved in August 1948.

The experience gained from working in this group was extremely valuable to him in providing the stimulus for his future career in forensic pathology and material for his MD thesis. And in 1948 he joined Keith Simpson, then head of the department of forensic medicine at Guy's Hospital medical school. On Simpson's retirement in 1972, Mant became head of the department and was awarded a personal chair in 1974. He also became an honorary senior lecturer in forensic medicine at King's College hospital school and at St Mary's Hospital medical school. He retired from Guy's in 1984.

He was an inspiring teacher, well-liked and respected by his post-graduate students, who were mainly from the Middle East, the Indian sub-continent and the Far East. One of his favourite visiting venues was Richmond, Virginia, where he claimed he was allowed to lecture while puffing on one of his large cigars.

Mant was a warm and charming man who enjoyed trout fishing, growing orchids and his garden. He was also a fine cook - his flat-mate during the war had been an Armenian chef - and he loved to entertain. He could carve a Sunday roast with consummate skill, although his wife always warned against allowing a forensic pathologist to carve a joint - he regarded it as an autopsy dissection.

His wife, Heather, a teacher, whom he married in 1947, died in 1989. He is survived by their two sons and one daughter.

 Arthur Keith Mant, pathologist, born September 11 1919; died October 11 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Willie Taylor

fields.headline: Willie Taylor
fields.standfirst: A life filled with the rhythms of the Borders - the yearly cycle of sheep-rearing and traditional melodies played on his fiddle
fields.trailText: I first met the Cheviot shepherd, fiddle player and composer Willie Taylor, who has died aged 84, at the Alnwick music gathering in the late 1960s. I then played alongside him at many charity concerts around the Border country. During the last 20 years or so, along with fellow shepherds Joe Hutton and Will Atkinson, he brought the authentic sound of traditional music from Northumberland and the Borders to festival audiences from Cambridge to Sidmouth, from Whitby to Shetland, and to the Queen Elizabeth Hall, in London.
fields.body:
I first met the Cheviot shepherd, fiddle player and composer Willie Taylor, who has died aged 84, at the Alnwick music gathering in the late 1960s. I then played alongside him at many charity concerts around the Border country. During the last 20 years or so, along with fellow shepherds Joe Hutton and Will Atkinson, he brought the authentic sound of traditional music from Northumberland and the Borders to festival audiences from Cambridge to Sidmouth, from Whitby to Shetland, and to the Queen Elizabeth Hall, in London.

Aly Bain, the internationally renowned Shetland fiddler, described Willie as the finest player of jigs he had ever heard. He injected a dynamic drive into every tune he played, achieving much of his attack by the use of very strong up-bows at points where most fiddlers would use a down-bow, producing some of the most rhythmic music around.

Willie's playing has had a tremendous influence on musicians of my generation, and on Kathryn Tickell, Nancy Kerr and other younger performers. Many of the tunes he composed are now established favourites in the repertoire of musicians the length and breadth of the country. He recorded a solo album, Welcome To The Dene (1991) and with his fellow shepherds, the classic, Harthope Burn (1983). He is also featured on the Topic 20 CD set, Voice of the People (1998).

He was born at Lilburn near Wooler, grew up in upper Coquetdale and lived all his life in north Northumberland. He learned to play fiddle as a youngster, but as a result of an accident while slicing turnips for the sheep, he lost the first finger of his left hand. He transferred his music-making to the melodeon and became a fine exponent on the box, but eventually returned to the fiddle and, with a single-minded tenacity that was characteristic of him, completely re-learned how to play, using his remaining fingers.

As a young man, Willie worked alongside fellow hill shepherd Geordie Armstrong and lodged with him at High Bleakhope, an isolated cottage at the head of the Breamish valley. Geordie was also a fiddle player, and Willie always attributed his own style of playing to the hours they spent whiling away the long winter nights learning new tunes and going over old favourites until they achieved just the "lift" they wanted.

Willie played mainly within his own community, walking miles over the hills to play at village dances, which would often continue through the night until it was light enough to walk back over the hills, arriving home just in time to start work the next day.

All his working life was spent in the heart of the Cheviots, herding large flocks in wild hill country. He often had such a large area to cover that he used a pony to "look" the sheep, and it was while riding home after a hard day on the hills that he would work on the melody of his latest composition in his head, allowing the pony to find its own way home.

The conversations in the car with Willie, Joe Hutton and Will Atkinson as we drove to engagements were always fascinating. We would start with a litany of every field we passed, discussing who had worked there, who they worked with, went to school with or were related to - keeping a mental map of their community and family links fresh in their minds. As we moved out of their home area, they would note any new agricultural practices - some of which would be welcomed whole-heartedly, others dismissed as short-term cost savings that would store up trouble for the future.

A man of wide interests and a voracious reader of books of travel and exploration, Willie seemed to like to know how his corner of the Borders fitted into the jigsaw of the world. He would sit for hours reading an atlas and, although he travelled little himself, whenever he met someone who had been travelling abroad he would amaze them by his precise knowledge of the geography of some far distant land.

A man of independent spirit, Willie took a deep interest in anything to which he turned his hand. His life was filled with the rhythms of the Borders: the yearly cycle of rearing sheep, the seasonal tasks of his highly productive garden and, of course, the rhythms and melodies of the music of the Borders. He will be greatly missed by lovers of traditional music throughout the country, but his music will live on.

Willie is survived by his wife Nancy, son Neil, grand-daughters Kerry and Emma and great grand-daughters Lucy and Sumer.

webTitle: Obituary: Bill Wainwright

fields.headline: Bill Wainwright
fields.standfirst: Ideals that survived communism's ups and downs
fields.trailText: Bill Wainwright, who has died aged 91, was one of the Communist Party of Great Britain's most effective journalists, pamphleteers, and speakers for nearly 60 years.
fields.body:
Bill Wainwright, who has died aged 91, was one of the Communist Party of Great Britain's most effective journalists, pamphleteers, and speakers for nearly 60 years. He was elected to the CPGB's executive and political committees and became the party's assistant secretary when John Gollan replaced Harry Pollit as general secretary in 1956. His final years of full-time party work were spent as assistant editor of the Daily Worker and the Morning Star, with myself as editor.

Raised in London's East End, after leaving school he studied chemistry at Chelsea Polytechnic, and became an associate of the Institute of Chemistry of Great Britain. He walked from his home in Stepney to Chelsea during the general strike to avoid using the blackleg trains.

It was the rise of fascism in the early 1930s which was the turning point for him. The Labour party leadership did virtually nothing to mobilise opposition to Sir Oswald Mosley's British Union of Fascists, whereas the CPGB was militant and uncompromising in organising resistance.

Bill took an active part in this from his flat at World's End, Chelsea, protecting open-air meetings from fascists armed with knuckle-dusters and truncheons. He went to heckle Mosley at the notorious 1934 BUF meeting at the Olympia in west London, where he was recognised, frog-marched out, and beaten up.

He then became editor of the Young Communist League paper Challenge and the YCL's national organiser. He also met and married his wife Molly, and began a happy political and personal relationship which lasted until her death in 1991.

During the war he served in the Home Guard and from 1941 worked on publicity for the war effort at the CP's headquarters in Covent Garden. Soon after the war he became general secretary of the British Soviet Friendship Society. Though he recognised after the 1956 revelations about Stalin that the party had made terrible mistakes in defending actions of the Soviet leadership which subsequently proved indefensible, he never regretted his opposition to the war propaganda directed against that country, and he continued with his work for the British Peace Committee.

No one could have worked harder or with more dedication at the Morning Star, putting in excessively long hours for a pittance. But nothing that was done stemmed the decline in the paper's circulation, and the party's loss of membership, especially after its support of the suppression of the 1956 uprising in Hungary. Bill became increasingly critical of the Soviet Union, and, like the majority of the party, opposed its 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia. But by then, the CPGB was becoming more and more divided, with hardliners taking over the Morning Star, and sacking Bill, its part-time science editor, and myself, the unpaid opera critic. We were reinstated some months later after widespread protests.

Though sadly disappointed by the party's failure and its winding-up, he remained committed to the ideals which led him to join it nearly 60 years before.

In 1991, supporting the transformation of the party into the Democratic Left, he wrote, "My hope is that younger generations will not write off our history but learn its valuable lessons, its honourable record as well as its tragedies, and the fine people who made it. I hope that the ideals and moral values that inspired us to turn to communism in the hope that this would help us to build a better world will be carried forward in future years."

He is survived by a son, a daughter and three grandchildren.

webTitle: Obituary: Robert Sherlaw-Johnson

fields.headline: Robert Sherlaw-Johnson
fields.standfirst: Teacher, composer and pianist whose output reflected his affinity with Messiaen
fields.trailText: The composer and pianist Robert Sherlaw-Johnson, who has died aged 68, belonged to the enlightened generation of British composers of the 1950s.
fields.body:
The composer and pianist Robert Sherlaw-Johnson, who has died aged 68, belonged to the enlightened generation of British composers of the 1950s that embraced modernist musical developments from continental Europe, transforming the musical landscape into the one we now take for granted. This change was not due solely, as is often suggested, to Sir William Glock and his team at the BBC. Even before the Glock ascendancy, these young composers, who had not yet made their mark, were studying in various parts of Europe, and they brought back new ideas, new techniques, and different aesthetics.

Born and brought up in Sunderland, Sherlaw- Johnson went to Gosforth grammar school, Newcastle upon Tyne, was a student at the University of Durham from 1950-53, and studied piano and composition at the Royal Academy of Music from 1953-57. He then went to Paris to study composition with Nadia Boulanger, to attend Messiaen's epoch-defining analysis class at the Paris Conservatoire, and to study piano with Jacques Février.

At that time, Messiaen's music was little known in Britain, but Sherlaw-Johnson had phenomenal facility as a pianist, and was able to tackle some of the most demanding works in the repertory, including Messiaen's monumental cycle, the Vingt Regards sur l'Enfant Jésus, which he often performed (but never recorded). However, he did record the whole of Messiaen's Catalogue d'Oiseaux for solo piano, and Harawi (with the soprano Noelle Barker). His doctoral thesis on Messiaen's music (Leeds, 1970) was followed by his book Messiaen (1974, revised 1989), the first major study of Messiaen's music published in English. It remains a classic of an unusual kind, replete with the insights that can come when one composer retraces the steps of another.

Inevitably, his work on Messiaen had an impact on his own music, and perhaps even more so on others' perception of it. Some early works show the influence of Messiaen, as well as of Varèse and Boulez, but later works transcend these influences. He leaves some important (and technically very demanding) piano works, including three piano sonatas, and Asterogenesis (1973). There is an opera (The Lambton Worm, 1977), and a Symphony (1999). Two works for soprano, piano and tape result from his notable collaboration with Noelle Barker: The Praises of Heaven and Earth, and Green Whispers of Gold.

He also leaves a significant body of religious and liturgical pieces (he converted to Roman Catholicism), the most recent of which, a Mass, will be premiered next year. Sherlaw-Johnson held several teaching positions: Leeds University (1961-63); director of music at Bradford Girls' grammar school (1963-65); and the universities of York (1965-70) and Oxford (1970-99). Although he spent the last 30 years in Oxford, as university lecturer in music (latterly reader) and fellow of Worcester College, it should not be forgotten that he was a member of that "Camelot" of composers which Wilfred Mellers brought together at York in the 1960s (including Bernard Rands and David Blake). By comparison, Oxford was not known as a centre for composition, but Sherlaw-Johnson's arrival (succeeding Kenneth Leighton and Edmund Rubbra) certainly helped, and he was to act as mentor for many musicians who have passed through Oxford.

In 1988, he was awarded the Oxford DMus, and was thus the only person in the country to have two "earned" higher doctorates of music. Robert Saxton, his successor at Worcester College, and I made the journey from Cambridge to Oxford to study with Sherlaw-Johnson at about the same time. I recall his tutoring as rigorous but not dogmatic, encouraging and constructive in its criticism: he considered the work presented to him in its own terms, and did not seek to impose his own creative ideas or personality. His death was sudden and poignant, like that of an actor who dies on stage.

For some years, he had been a keen bell-ringer. The interest had grown from his own compositions and his playing of bell-inspired piano works by other composers (one recent work of his was inspired by the bells of Rennes Cathedral). He regularly rang at his local church at Stonesfield, near Woodstock, but on this occasion was ringing at the historic tower of Appleton, south-west of Oxford. A full ring of Stedmans was giving way to Yorkshire Surprise Major when he collapsed and died in the bell tower.

He leaves a widow, Rachael (an accomplished painter), their three sons, two daughters and four grandchildren.

fields.trailText: In an article about a £150m placing of shares by the drugs company Oxford Glycosciences (page 27, November 14), we said the fundraising would be abandoned unless the company achieved a price of £20.92 for each new share. webTitle: EU funds still misspent, report says

fields.headline: EU funds still misspent, report says
fields.standfirst: Special report: EU commission
fields.trailText: There is evidence that spending by the European commission is still being mismanaged despite improvements made by its president, Romano Prodi, the EU's independent auditors reported yesterday.
fields.body:
There is evidence that spending by the European commission is still being mismanaged despite improvements made by its president, Romano Prodi, the EU's independent auditors reported yesterday.

"There was an unacceptable incidence of errors which affected the legality and the regularity of payments from the budget," said the 1999 report by the European court of auditors.

Neil Kinnock, Mr Prodi's vice president for reform, said the findings proved the need for changes to improve the performance of the EU's supranational bureaucracy.

"The court is right to say that there is more to be done but, as they acknowledge, we are definitely heading in the right direction," he said. "There are many staff who deserve credit for their efforts in helping to make huge changes."

The audit blamed the misuse of funds on EU national and regional authorities which dole out money from the annual budget. But MEPs called for the auditors to "name and shame" the guilty countries.

Allegations of fraud, cronyism and mismanagement were at the heart of the scandal that led to the downfall of the previous commission, led by Jacques Santer of Luxembourg, last year.

The court's 480-page report pointed to persistent weaknesses in the control of farm subsidies. It also highlighted problems with aid progammes run by Chris Patten's external relations directorate, including work in Bosnia; slow payments to non-governmental organisations and problems with joint programmes on humanitarian aid.

Eluned Morgan, socialist spokeswoman on the budget, said: "It was never realistic to expect that the commission could be transformed from an outdated 1950s institut- ion into a streamlined and efficient administration overnight."

Michaele Schreyer, the EU's budget commissioner, admitted that many of the proposed reforms have yet to take effect. "We have a very difficult path ahead of us. Many of these reforms only exist on paper," she told MEPs in Strasbourg.

In March the commission approved a 60-page plan which sets a strict timetable to implement 84 specific changes within the bureaucracy to be completed by the end of 2001. It includes a code of conduct for all EU officials and employees, supervised by an independent watchdog committee. An independent internal audit office which will be responsible for financial regulation and evaluation of commission contracts has also been implemented.

In Britain, the auditors' report brought a predictably negative reaction from the Conservative opposition. "Sad to say, EU fraud and mismanagement are rife," said the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude.

"The key lesson to be learned is that the EU must learn to do less and do it better. Despite this obvious conclusion, the EU institutions and some member states are intent on pursuing a superstate agenda which would make the problems of fraud and unaccountability even worse.

"There is an alternative vision of Europe to the one-size-fits-all superstate. It is of a flexible and dynamic EU that the British people want and the EU badly needs. A flexible EU will be the only way to protect democracy and promote prosperity in future years," he said.

webTitle: The rebellious seven who could decide the election

fields.headline: The rebellious seven who could decide the election
fields.standfirst: Special report: US elections
fields.trailText: The seven men and women whose legal decisions may now hand the White House to Al Gore or George W Bush are Democratic appointees and the veterans of nearly two years of political and rhetorical battles with Mr Bush's brother Jeb, the state's Republican governor.
fields.body:
The seven men and women whose legal decisions may now hand the White House to Al Gore or George W Bush are Democratic appointees and the veterans of nearly two years of political and rhetorical battles with Mr Bush's brother Jeb, the state's Republican governor.

The justices of Florida's supreme court - five men and two women - now find themselves at the centre of the presidential election contest.

Yesterday, both Republicans and Democrats made separate appeals to the court to bring some order to the increasing tangle of election-related legal actions in Florida's lower courts. Even before that, Florida's county election supervisors had already asked the court to intervene in the disputes over manual ballot recounts.

Five of the seven justices - Harry Lee Anstead, Major Harding, Fred Lewis, Barbara Pariente, and Chief Justice Charles Wells - were appointed by Florida's late Democratic governor Lawton Chiles, Jeb Bush's predecessor as governor.

The most recent appointee, Peggy Quince, one of two black members of the court, was jointly appointed by Mr Chiles and Mr Bush. webTitle: Three police guilty in LA corruption trial

fields.headline: Three police guilty in LA corruption trial
fields.trailText: After four days of deliberation, a jury yesterday convicted three out of four Los Angeles police officers charged with corruption, in the first of a series of trials arising from the LAPD's largest internal scandal.
fields.body:
After four days of deliberation, a jury yesterday convicted three out of four Los Angeles police officers charged with corruption, in the first of a series of trials arising from the LAPD's largest internal scandal.

The three, officer Michael Buchanan and sergeants Brian Liddy and Edward Ortiz, were convicted of conspiracy to obstruct justice. Buchanan was also convicted of perjury, and Liddy and Ortiz of filing false reports. The fourth officer, Paul Harper, was cleared of all charges.

The verdicts were a surprise because the main prosecution witness, former officer Rafael Perez, did not give evidence. Just before the trial started last month, Perez, already sentenced for stealing cocaine, was accused of three murders by his former girlfriend, Sonia Flores. Perez refused to give evidence if he was going to be questioned about the alleged murders.

Ms Flores has since withdrawn the allegations.

The main witnesses against the officers were former gang members who gave details about a series of incidents between 1996 and 1998, when the officers were alleged to have fabricated evidence and beaten gang members.

More than 100 convictions have been overturned as a result of the evidence of malpractice and $11m (£7.7m) has been agreed as payments to 29 people wrongly convicted or injured by the police.

webTitle: When all else fails there is still poker

fields.headline: When all else fails there is still poker
fields.trailText: There is talk of scorched earth, of hills of beans and fool's gold. The police have impounded ballot boxes and there are hints of big-hitting lawyers in town.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell  in Albuquerque, New Mexico
fields.body:
There is talk of scorched earth, of hills of beans and fool's gold. The police have impounded ballot boxes and there are hints of big-hitting lawyers in town.

For a while this week George W Bush's entire state electoral majority could have sat nursing their margaritas round a single table. In New Mexico the vote is even tighter than in Florida, with the lead having changed hands three times and Al Gore currently ahead by 374 votes after someone realised that they had mistaken a figure six for a figure one.

Now there is talk of the ballot being decided on the toss of a coin or the drawing of a card. The state decrees that, should the vote end in a tie, the winner will be decided by an agreed game of chance.

Normally New Mexico, with only five electoral votes, would not be under such scrutiny. But if Florida were to go to Mr Gore, then it could find itself having to go through the same painful recount process.

"The Republicans have what I call a 'scorch the earth' strategy," said Diane Denish, the state Democrats' chairwoman. "They already have several lawyers in place in case they lose in Florida. When they heard they had the lead here, they impounded the ballots because they didn't want any threats to their lead but now we are cautiously optimistic."

Ms Denish, who is 51, said she had never seen a race so close. She is aware it could be decided by a game of chance. "I'm not much of a gambler," she said, "but that's what is meant to happen if it's a dead tie."

"In a normal election, 500 votes wouldn't amount to a hill of beans," said the state Republican chairman, John Dendahl, of the 500 votes suddenly counted for Mr Gore. "In this race, it's a gold mine. I hope it's fool's gold".

The marginal states in the election are called the toss-up states. No one had considered this might be the real thing.

webTitle: New air control clash likely

fields.headline: New air control clash likely
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The stage was set for a constitutional clash between the Lords and the Commons over the privatisation of Britain's air traffic services after a backbench rebellion by Labour MPs last night saw the government's Commons majority halved.
fields.body:
The stage was set for a constitutional clash between the Lords and the Commons over the privatisation of Britain's air traffic services after a backbench rebellion by Labour MPs last night saw the government's Commons majority halved.

MPs voted by 321 to 228 to overturn a Lords vote last week to delay privatisation until after the general election. Labour whips said 37 Labour MPs voted against the government, 10 fewer than the last vote on the issue.

The prime minister, returning from a party meeting in St Albans, Hertfordshire, was caught in traffic and had to run down Whitehall to make the 7.30pm vote.

But Tory peers claimed the small size of the government majority last night gave them a legitimate right to vote again to delay privatisation. The issue will go back for reconsideration by the Lords in 10 days' time.

Despite time running out before the end of the parliamentary session, ministers are determined to make the Lords back down on what they regard as a central plank of their budgetary and transport strategy.

The rebel MPs claim 76% of the public oppose the sell-off of the National Air Traffic Control Service, making it less popular than fox hunting.

webTitle: Sketch: Greaser slips in the ultimate surprise

fields.headline: Greaser slips in the ultimate surprise
fields.trailText: All through Prime Minister's Questions yesterday, Caroline Flint, the Labour MP for Don Valley, had been bobbing up and down, desperate to catch the Speaker's eye and ask a question.
fields.body:
All through Prime Minister's Questions yesterday, Caroline Flint, the Labour MP for Don Valley, had been bobbing up and down, desperate to catch the Speaker's eye and ask a question.

Even in the new Labour party Ms Flint is regarded as something of a hardline toady, an aardvark-tongued bootlicker, a member of an active service unit in the greasers' provisional wing.

Colleagues mused idly what form her question to Mr Blair might take. "Is he aware that my constituents are ecstatic about the new spending on health care? And that there have been several examples of the dead rising from their graves to praise my rt. hon. friend?" Or something about walking on the flood water. Both would have been choice examples of the Flint genre.

So when she was called there was a frisson in the air. Like experts in the work of Fabergé, we connoisseurs look to see just how many jewelled words she can cram into a single question, the way her craftspersonship lets the phrases sparkle and gleam from every angle, each reflecting back the glory of her leader.

Instead Ms Flint rose and said simply: "My question has already been asked, so I'll sit down."

Sit down? Without a single congratulation, felicitation or compliment to anyone? Resume her seat, in silence? The reaction of the House was gratifying. I saw members literally slack-jawed, their chins slumped onto their chests. Some raised the energy to flap an astonished arm in Ms Flint's direction. In an H.M. Bateman "the man who..." cartoon, the Tory front bench would have been depicted with vast, bulging eyes. Other MPs merely looked very, very bewildered.

And no wonder. Imagine the late Oliver Reed saying, "no thank you, I've had more than enough." Or Tam Dalyell saying, "Sod the Belgrano, the Argies had it coming." The stars shift slightly in their courses and the earth seems to tremble beneath us.

As it also does when the Speaker makes a contribution. Ragging Mr Martin is now a favourite sport of Tory backbenchers (they think he is a party political choice, designed largely to annoy them), and at the moment their pastime seems quite easy. Yesterday Alan Duncan asked him about his decision last week to expel John Butterfill, also a Tory, who had dared challenge his selection of questioners - in a private conversation.

Mr Duncan asked a question designed to be very hard to follow. "May I ask you to advise the House on the basis on which, and under which standing order this might occur, when a member has not said anything on the record of the House in violation of its procedures or standing orders, he might yet be evicted for it?"

Mr Martin spent a few anxious moments picking the bones out of that with the clerks, the chaps in wigs who sit in front of him. Then he gave his ruling, which went as follows: "I have spoken to the hon. gentleman [Mr Butterfill] ... I've explained to him, and we have come to an understanding. What I will ensure is, I will ensure good order in this House. There will be occasions when perhaps a request to an hon. member might be to leave the Chamber in spite of the fact that he has not broken any rule, but for the sake of good order, I will ask him to perhaps leave, but there again, that's a request and it's up to the hon. gentleman or lady to accept that particular request."

Got that? Judges do not "request" a convicted prisoner to spend a year in chokey.

But on a day when Caroline Flint failed to ask a question, even the Speaker's convoluted, Prescottian analysis could not surprise us.

webTitle: Climate talks stalemate as EU rejects US forests plan

fields.headline: Climate talks stalemate as EU rejects US forests plan
fields.standfirst: Special report: global warming
fields.trailText: US and EU at loggerheads in Hague climate talks over "loopholes" to allow countries to plant forests and change farming practices to avoid cutting fossil fuel consumption
fields.body:
America and the European Union were at loggerheads yesterday in the vital climate talks in the Hague over "loopholes" which would allow countries to plant forests and change farming practices to avoid cutting the use of fossil fuels.

The US said - on the third day of two weeks of talks among 180 countries to curb greenhouse gases - that its proposals must be accepted before it can sign up to a legally-binding agreement to curb emissions.

The scheme was described as "quite outrageous" by environment groups. They said it would undermine the Kyoto agreement in which the US would cut greenhouse gas emissions by 7%.

By planting forests and changing farming practices both at home and in developing countries the US calculates it can capture carbon from the atmosphere and in doing so avoid reducing domestic energy consumption. It claims sticking to the Kyoto agreement by domestic action alone would mean cutting fuel use by 30%.

The EU believes the US plan is scientifically unproven and close to cheating - at least ducking the real issue, which is the world's overdependence on fossil fuels.

All sides realise that failure to reach agreement on this issue in the next 10 days could wreck the talks but yesterday there was no sign of movement.

On one side is the "umbrella group" of US, Japan, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Russia, which want these so-called carbon sinks to play a large part in their emission reduction targets and on the other the EU, which says there is no substitute for domestic action. On the EU's side is practically every environmental group in the world and many of the developing countries.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister who will spend next week in the Hague, said yesterday: "The EU position is firm. As far as we are concerned there is no substitute for taking domestic action to reduce the emissions by burning less fossil fuels."

Jos Delbeke, the EU's negotiator, said the EU was still unconvinced about many elements of the US ideas, including the scientific uncertainties on how much carbon is soaked up by trees.

John Lanchbery of the RSPB, who is also at the talks, said: "The US position is quite outrageous, and allows the US and its allies to carry on business as usual while claiming credits for forests and all sorts of other land use options. These proposals should be rejected out of hand."

Michel Raquet, from Greenpeace International, said: "If the EU gives way on this then the Kyoto agreement will be so full of loopholes it will lose all environmental integrity. The Americans want credits if they chop down a forest then replant it with fast growing trees. It is nonsense."

webTitle: Rock star's family shows sympathy for attacker

fields.headline: Rock star's family shows sympathy for attacker
fields.trailText: The family of George Harrison yesterday expressed sympathy for the man who tried to kill the former Beatle and his wife as he was ordered to be detained indefinitely in a secure psychiatric hospital.
fields.body:
The family of George Harrison yesterday expressed sympathy for the man who tried to kill the former Beatle and his wife as he was ordered to be detained indefinitely in a secure psychiatric hospital.

The pop star's son Dhani, speaking on behalf of the family, said that it was "tragic that anyone should suffer such a mental breakdown to commit such a brutal act" after it emerged that Michael Abram, 34, had been misdiagnosed for years by a string of psychiatrists and had not received proper treatment.

The jury at Oxford crown court was directed to return a verdict of not guilty due to in sanity on the charge of attempted murder of Mr Harrison and his wife Olivia.

Abram had set out to kill Mr Harrison because he believed the pop star was a witch who had possessed him.

Abram's mother Lynda said it was "appalling" that her son's schizophrenia had not been diagnosed. Calling for an inquiry she said: "All the alarm bells were ringing but they were dismissed."

Last night it was revealed that Abram wrote a letter of apology to the Harrison family. "I wish to say how sorry I am for the alarm, distress and injury that I have caused when I was ill," he wrote.

"I thought my delusions were real and that everything that I was experiencing was some kind of witchcraft."

Abram and his family had tried to get help for 10 years but psychiatrists believed his disturbed state stemmed from heroin abuse. Doctors now believe he was using the drug to try to suppress the symptoms of his illness. Only the month before the attack on December 30 last year he was admitted to hospital but released.

Consultant forensic psychiatrist Dr Philip Joseph said that the severity of Abram's illness appeared to have been missed. At the time of the attack he was legally insane.

Dhani, 22, speaking on the steps of the court, said: "The prospect of him being released into society is abhorrent to us and we hope that the authorities will act with the utmost responsibility in avoiding it in future and allow us to be consulted before reaching any conclusion."

The court had heard how Harrison, 57, and his 52-year-old wife had fought for their lives after finding the intruder, armed with a knife and a stone sword broken from a statue, in their gothic mansion in Henley-on-Thames, Oxfordshire.

Abram, believing he was on "a mission from God", stabbed the guitarist at least 10 times before battering him with a table lamp and threatening to kill Mrs Harrison with the flex. Harrison suffered a punctured lung and said that he thought he was going to die. Abram is now considered "stable" but will need treatment with drugs for the rest of his life.

webTitle: Ranatunga empire close to collapse

fields.headline: Ranatunga empire close to collapse
fields.trailText: The power base in Sri Lankan cricket of the Ranatunga family is under threat after the suspension of the Sri Lankan Board's chief executive.
fields.body:
The power base in Sri Lankan cricket of the Ranatunga family is under threat after the suspension of the Sri Lankan Board's chief executive, Dammika Ranatunga, pending investigations by the board into the handling of TV rights for England's series in the country this winter.

Dammika Ranatunga, who owed his appointment largely to the influence of his brother, the former Sri Lankan captain Arjuna, has already told Sri Lanka's sports ministry that he should not be held accountable for any irregularities that might be discovered in TV negotiations involving the England series.

"The executive committee has decided to relieve chief executive Dhammika Ranatunga of all his duties pending the completion of a preliminary investigation," said the board spokesman.

The Ranatunga family, which possesses considerable political clout - Dammika's father Reggie is a minister - have long held sway in Sri Lankan cricket. But with Arjuna also having to deny match-rigging allegations in last month's Indian CBI report, their power base has never been closer to collapse.A former Sri Lanka captain Anura Tennekoon will act as temporary chief executive.

Pakistan have been invited to play Bangladesh on a home and away basis after their Test series with India was called off yesterday. Bangladesh, who were awarded Test status in June, played their maiden Test against India this week.

India have not played a full Test series in Pakistan since 1989 and the tour had been in doubt due to mounting tension between the two countries over the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir.

Pakistan are proposing Yawar Saeed, a director of the Pakistan Cricket Board as the next chief executive of the International Cricket Council.

India have not played a full Test series in Pakistan since 1989 and the tour had been in doubt due to mounting tension between the two countries over the disputed Himalayan region of Kashmir. Pakistan are proposing Yawar Saeed, a director of the Pakistan Cricket Board as the next chief executive of the International Cricket Council.

webTitle: No dancing at the spinner's mystery ball

fields.headline: No dancing at the spinner's mystery ball
fields.standfirst: Reading Saqlain - let alone playing him - is mission impossible, writes  Paul Allott
fields.trailText: Reading Saqlain - let alone playing him - is mission impossible, writes Paul Allott.
fields.body:
There is a surefire way to tell how important a toss is; just watch the captains' reactions. Nasser Hussain's call of "heads" yesterday was followed immediately by his one-man stampede across the pitch to see the coin fall. Hussain said "We'll bat" almost before Moin Khan had realised he'd lost it.

And so began England's biggest Test in years on a pitch tailor-made for the Pakistan spinners, all four of them if you include the debutant Qaiser Abbas, which was bound to turn almost from the first ball. That is why batting first was so crucial to England's hopes and the toss was seen to be so significant.

Ever since spin proved England's undoing in the one-day series, Pakistan have waited for Hussain's men with a clutch of spinners ready to weave a web to sabotage their chances. Predictably Saqlain Mushtaq, the unorthodox off-spinner, proved England's chief antagonist yesterday. He is only 23 and this is just his 30th Test, but already Saqlain is a master of his art. The amount of off-spin he generates is prodigious at times, his change of pace is deceptive, and he varies his angle and position of delivery on the crease as much as that other fearsome off-spinner, the Sri Lankan Muthiah Muralitharan.

If all this was not enough to perplex the England batsmen, Saqlain can also muster a mystery ball to furrow the brow of the best. This is the delivery that appears to be bowled with the same action as his off-spinner but in fact turns the other way, or goes straight on, quickens up and bounces a touch more. It seems that no matter how often you face him, or how fa miliar you are with his action, this ball will still catch you unawares.

Graham Thorpe naturally knows the repertoire of his Surrey team-mate Saqlain better than most and plays him well. But this variation takes even him by surprise. Thorpe was nearly caught at silly point by Salim Elahi in the last 15 minutes of play yesterday, looking to leave a ball that should by rights have spun harmlessly away to the wicketkeeper. Instead the ball reared and went straight on, cannoning off pad and bat just short of Elahi, who was on his heels. Earlier Thorpe was dropped at slip by Abbas when he cut at Saqlain.

After watching this it was no wonder that Saqlain managed to outfox Marcus Trescothick, Alec Stewart and Hussain, who charged down the pitch and slewed a catch to cover. Even Mike Atherton succumbed, sweeping Saqlain's mystery ball into square leg's hands, when the same shot to the off-spinning delivery would have sailed harmlessly away to fine leg.

Spare a thought for Saqlain's compatriot in all this, Mushtaq Ahmed, who went wicketless. Before yesterday, these two had taken 297 wickets in 76 Tests between them, and they form a force that England did well to resist for most of the day.

Mushtaq really deserved a wicket or two as he teased and tormented with his leg-breaks and googlies. The combination of the two different types of spinner, with all their variety, was an enticing prospect for the spectator, if not for the batsmen, and they will make fascinating viewing for the early part of the winter.

A word of praise too for the umpires, Darrell Hair from Australia and the local Riazuddin, who did not put a foot wrong in the face of concerted but fair appealing from the Pakistanis. The umpire's job is at its most difficult with fielders clustered around the bat and regular appeals for catches close to the wicket, and both men performed admirably yesterday. The two sides will be hoping that standard is maintained throughout what promises to be a high-standard series all round.

webTitle: England fall in a heap after Atherton heroics

fields.headline: England fall in a heap after Atherton heroics
fields.standfirst:
Mike Selvey in Lahore sees a promising start undone by Pakistan's four late strikes
England 195-4
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey in Lahore sees a promising start undone by Pakistan's four late strikes.
fields.body:
Mike Atherton, if it was not already evident to those who have watched him throughout his career, is someone who tends to regard records as something you put on a gramophone and milestones as something for Dick Whittington to sit on. He is proud of achievement but does not wish to bask in the afterglow of it.

So when shortly before tea yesterday afternoon he latched gleefully on to a full toss from Saqlain Mushtaq and forced it past mid-on to the boundary, he was not aware of the significance until the England scorer pointed it out during the interval.

Those four runs had taken Atherton's individual total to 61 and his aggregate from 103 Test matches to precisely 7,000. In reaching that figure he joins illustrious company: Graham Gooch, David Gower and Geoff Boycott, all of whom were in the Gaddafi stadium to see him reach the landmark, Colin Cowdrey and Walter Hammond.

Earlier, another boundary had taken him past Sir Len Hutton's aggregate of 6,971 and put him more than 100 runs clear - and how this must please him, friendly rivalry being what it is - of the career tally of Alec Stewart, to whom he has often seemed joined at the hip.

Atherton's 73 and 71 from Marcus Trescothick - both innings worth almost three figures on a ground featuring lush growth in the outfield - gave England the perfect foundation for a sizeable first-innings lead after Nasser Hussain had won a vital toss.

The pair, in little more than 3 hours together, put on 134 for the first wicket, the third highest opening partnership for England in Pakistan. It was also their second century stand in successive Tests, following their partnership of 159 against West Indies at the Oval.

But this Pakistan side, crammed with brilliantly versatile and instinctive bowling, is capable of wresting the initiative first through attrition and then, once a hold has been gained, by squeezing tightly.

Their captain Moin Khan spent the morning and most of the afternoon yesterday switching his bowling around - a twirl from Saqlain here, a whirl from Mushtaq Ahmed there, a burst from Wasim Akram or Abdur Razzaq, or some brisk leg-spin from the floppy-haired frontiersman Shahid Afridi. He finally settled on Saqlain's off-spin from the north and a mixture from the south. It proved decisive.

Saqlain found his rhythm, removed Trescothick with the last ball of the opening over of his new spell, and by the day's close had added the wickets of Atherton, Stewart and Nasser Hussain, who came in down the order after receiving treatment on his back.

In a spell of 15 overs, broken only by the tea interval, Saqlain took four for 19 and finished with four for 61 overall - deserved reward for bowling of the highest class.

As a result, the day ended as an even contest. Much now depends on Graham Thorpe, dropped at slip by Qaiser Abbas off Saqlain when he was two during the course of almost two gritty hours at the crease, and Graeme Hick. To give their own spinners a chance, only a total of more than 300 will suffice.

According to Atherton, the pitch offered a little help to the spinners all day and not dramatically more at the end than it had at the start. So the ease with which he and Trescothick played for the first two sessions may be a tribute to their preparation, which included much roughing of nets to try and replicate conditions.

"It is a different challenge here to that we are used to," Atherton explained. "It is all very new for most of us. With spinners operating there are so many balls coming at you in a short space of time; it requires more intensive concentration.

"A key is to have a game plan but not to be too predetermined, to rely on instinct, to be aware of the field placings and to play on the hoof to some extent."

Neither Atherton nor Trescothick used their feet. Both men played from the crease with Atherton, in particular, judging length immac ulately and, apparently, reading Saqlain's mystery ball - the one that is bowled with an off-spin action but actually turns away from the bat.

Pressure eventually told on Trescothick, who is always anxious to get on with things, and he lost concentration when a century was there if he could only have grafted a little longer. Instead he executed a leg-side swing and top-edged the ball to short fine leg. It was his third half-century in six Test innings, but he will look back and see opportunities missed.

Now Saqlain took charge. Atherton survived a confident, that is fervent, appeal for a catch at silly point off bat and pad and then swept the next straight to square leg. Stewart, who as Surrey's wicketkeeper ought to be able to read Saqlain's game better than most, got nowhere against a quicker ball and was lbw.

Finally Hussain, after one briskly confident excursion down the pitch to deposit the off-spinner over mid-on and almost for six, tried to repeat the shot, picked the wrong ball and skewed high to cover, where Wasim Akram held an awkward catch with ease.

As the Pakistan State Oil television advert that accompanies the fall of wickets so aptly puts it: "Better luck next time".

webTitle: Brown laments a bad night for Scotland the grave

fields.headline: Brown laments a bad night for Scotland the grave
fields.standfirst: Emerton 12, Zdrilic 66
fields.trailText:
Scotland 0 - 2 Australia
It was a sobering night for the faithful last night as an accomplished Australia left Scotland shame-faced, all without Mark Viduka.
fields.body:
Craig Brown, the Scotland manager, does not like losing any match and he will surely be embarrassed by this friendly. It is no disrespect to Australia to say that the Scots should have offered better than they did last night.

A dejected Brown said afterwards: "It was arguably one of the worst Scotland performances that I can remember and we deserved to lose."

A dismal evening ended with the home support scarcely able to recall a single montage of Scottish attacks, so lethargic were the home side. In comparison a goal in each halfallowed a muscular Australian side to walk away with pride. Their team of Emertons, Agostinos and Muscats are not exactly household names, but their cohesive play was a tribute to Frank Farina, their young coach.

Brown, by contrast, was not able to bluster past this one. His team now have a break before their World Cup qualifier against Belgium in March and on this evidence it is just as well.

Before then, some of his players should maybe shake hands and get acquainted.

"We're very disappointed," said Brown afterwards. "If there's one positive it is that this should dispel any possibility of complacency setting in following our reasonable World Cup start. We have our limitations and our only way of succeeding is if we all pull together."

And this was Australia minus their magical "man of the moment". A cynical Glaswegian crowd had its vocal chords ready for a goad ing welcome of Mark Viduka, but the former Celtic player cried off injured, did a spot of pre-match television and plumped himself in the stand. Not that it mattered: the Australians' dominance had them ahead in 12 minutes.

The Scots were a scattered bunch in the centre of the park when Brett Emerton took Paul Okon's pass nicely in his stride to burst into the Scottish penalty area and prod the ball beneath Jonathan Gould. Gould, lately displaced as Celtic's No1, is a man of frequently eccentric positioning, although on this occasion he could do little as his defence was simply sliced open.

The home side did manage to contrive some openings. Don Hutchison allowed Mark Schwarzer, the not overly flustered Australian goalkeeper, to block his effort from eight yards, and a Christian Dailly header flew three feet over the bar. But even given its friendly status, this match still represented a poor night for Scotland.

The Australians confirmed their rather worrying superiority with a second goal after 66 minutes. Following Kevin Muscat's high cross on the right, none of the Scottish defence's two or three strapping sentries could respond, allowing David Zdrilic to drift in and head beyond Gould. It was a strike that hardly went against the grain of this match. Emerton, Australia's best player on the night, said: "I thought it would be tougher but we played exceptionally well."

Scotland (3-5-2): Gould; O'Neil, Dailly, Weir; Boyd, Burley, Ferguson, Cameron, Matteo; Dodds, Hutchison.

Australia (4-4-2): Schwarzer; Muscat, Murphy, Popovic, Lazaridis; Emerton, Skoko, Okon, Tiatto; Agostino, Zdrilic.

Referee: P Garibian (France).

webTitle: 'I couldn't ask for any more'

fields.headline: 'I couldn't ask for any more'
fields.trailText: Peter Taylor, David Beckham and Emile Heskey have their say on last night's performance.
fields.body:
England's caretaker coach Peter Taylor used the tried and trusted "it's not the winning but the taking part" formula to explain his young side's 1-0 defeat by Italy in Turin last night.

"For me the result is not important because it's a friendly," he said. "The performance is the most important thing and that's what we've got out of the game.

"The players are a little bit disappointed because they think they deserved to win the game and I thought we should have got something out of it.

"The players worked very hard. They were very solid at the back and they passed it all right at times. I couldn't ask for any more from them."

The England coach-elect Sven-Goran Eriksson watched the game from the stands, but Taylor said he would have no chance to talk to the Lazio manager about the game before heading back to England. Taylor said: "I think he's [Eriksson] got lots of people from Lazio with him so I'm going to get on the coach back to the airport."

David Beckham, in his first match as England captain, kept his head under provocation from the Italian goalscorer Gennaro Gattuso and afterwards diplomatically played down the incident. Gattuso appeared to barge Beckham to the ground inside the penalty area and then reacted angrily, aiming a slap at Beckham as the pair walked away.

Beckham, who was denied a penalty for the original challenge, was asked whether Gattuso had swung an arm at him. He said: "Yes, he did, but there's always arms raised in games and things happen off the ball. But the referees doesn't see them - or chooses not to see them.

"I think there were a couple of times when we should have got decisions, they should have been fouls. But they scored a great goal. We played some good football in the first half and we can take some good things out of it.

"We are disappointed we have lost the game. I felt it worked quite well for me in central midfield. I passed it well and kept it well. It was one of the best feelings coming out of the tunnel as captain. I loved it."

Emile Heskey, who along with Beckham was one of England's most effective players, gave Italy's back three of Paolo Maldini, Alessandro Nesta and Fabio Cannavaro an uncomfortable night. After the game he said: "It was nice to be playing against three of the best defenders in the world and pit myself against them. Our midfield did brilliant - they got through a lot of running."

The goalkeeper David James had no chance of stopping Gattuso's stunning strike and said: "If you are going to let a goal in ... well, it was a good strike."

webTitle: Irish run goes on as Finns send England a message

fields.headline: Irish run goes on as Finns send England a message
fields.standfirst: Finnan 14, Kilbane 84, Staunton 90
fields.trailText:
Republic of Ireland 3 - 0 Finland
This may have been a heavy defeat, but England will do well to note the quality of Finland's football on the night.
fields.body:
Finland may have lost this low-key friendly but England's next opponents in World Cup qualifying were much better than the scoreline suggests, producing a performance that combined equal measures of fluency and counter-attacking flair. They produced everything, in fact, apart from a goal.

In the end Ireland maintained their rousing sequence of recent results courtesy of Steve Finnan's first-half strike and two goals in the last five minutes from Kevin Kilbane and the substitute Steve Staunton. But if it is possible for a team to play well and lose 3-0, Finland managed it here.

"I think Finland will go home feeling hard done by," admitted the Irish manager Mick McCarthy. "They certainly will not feel like they deserved to have been beaten 3-0. You have to hold up your hands and say the scoreline flattered us."

It is not beyond the realms of possibility that Eriksson will have some kind of hands-on role by the time Finland roll into Anfield next March and the Swede is said to have asked the Football Association for a video of this match. The footage will show that whoever is in charge of England will underestimate the Finns at their peril.

Hannu Tihinen and Aki Riihilahti both squandered decent opportunities to reward the Finns for their greater sense of adventure throughout the opening exchanges and it was totally against the run of play when Finnan put the hosts in front.

For the first 15 minutes the biggest threat facing Jussi Jaaskelainen in the Finland goal was the risk of pneumonia from standing inactive in the teeming rain. But when Mark Kinsella's long and measured pass split the defence and tempted the Bolton goalkeeper from his lines he was beaten to the pass and left in no man's land as Finnan stroked the ball into an open net.

Suddenly it had dawned on Ireland that they were, indeed, the home side. But depleted by injuries, and with McCarthy clearly in experimental mode, their fluency seemed to have been lost with the number of changes to his usual line-up and the attacking thrusts of Jari Litmanen and Jonatan Johansson, aided and abetted by the nimble Mikael Forssell, continued to cause problems. How Litmanen, honoured as the Finnish player of the year for the ninth time on Sunday, remains on the periphery at Barcelona remains a mystery.

The better news for England is that, on the few occasions the Irish worked up a head of steam, the Finnish defence had a porous, brittle appearance. Kilbane doubled the lead with a powerful header from Jason McAteer's right-wing cross and the Blackburn midfielder also teed up Steve Staunton for the game's finest moment, a venomous stoppage-time drive that gave Jaaskelainen no chance.

"All three goals were worth the admission," said McCarthy, but the Irish clearly still have a few things to work upon. Even the two streakers who did their best to illuminate the second half forgot to remove all their items of clothing.

Finland (4-4-1-1): Jaaskelainen; Nylund, Pasanen (Murmel, 77), Tihinen, Saarinen; Johansson (Kuqi, h-t), Riihilahti, Tainio (Kuivasto, 66min), Kolkka; Litmanen; Forssell (Grunland, h-t).

Referee: P Durkin (Dorset).

webTitle: Germans fall to Denmark

fields.headline: Germans fall to Denmark
fields.trailText:
Denmark 2 - 1 Germany
England's World Cup qualifying group opponents Germany lost 2-1 to Denmark while Greece went down 2-0 to Slovakia.
fields.body:
England's World Cup qualifying group opponents had mixed fortunes in last night's friendlies.

Germany, 1-0 winners at Wembley last month, were beaten 2-1 in Copenhagen by Denmark with Dennis Rommedahl of PSV Eindhoven scoring both goals in a 10-minute second-half spell. Mehmet Scholl pulled one back for the Germans with an 81st-minute free-kick.

"We must learn from negative experiences as well and this was a good lesson for the team and myself," said Germany's coach Rudi Völler.

Slovakia scored two goals in counter-attacks to beat Greece 2-0 even though the Greeks, whom England first face next June, dominated possession. Greece rarely threatened the visitors' well organised defence and Szilard Nemeth and Peter Nemethscored for Slovakia.

Two goals by the substitute Erjon Bogdani helped 10-man Albania, where England go in March, to a 3-0 win over Malta. Albania's captain Rudi Vata opened the scoring on half-time with a spectacular volley.

 The Brazilian midfielder Ze Elias has been banned for 10 months and his Greek club Olympiakos fined £70,000 for incidents at last week's Champions League match against Lyon.

webTitle: Bradford looking to Baxter to take the reins

fields.headline: Bradford looking to Baxter to take the reins
fields.trailText: Former AIK Stockholm coach Stuart Baxter has emerged as a surprise front-runner for the managerial vacancy at Bradford.
fields.body:
The Bradford City chairman Geoffrey Richmond is hoping to have the club's new manager installed in time to watch Saturday's Premiership match at Derby, and the former AIK Stockholm coach Stuart Baxter has emerged as a surprise front-runner.

In the wake of Chris Hutchings' departure, Richmond made a shortlist of three, with the former Hearts manager Jim Jefferies the first to have been interviewed yesterday.

It is thought the third man is either the former Liverpool manager Roy Evans or the FA technical director Howard Wilkinson.

The Wolverhampton-born Baxter, who resigned at Stockholm last Monday, the day Hutchings was sacked by Bradford, played for Preston, Dundee United, Blackpool and Stockport. The 47-year-old guided AIK to the Swedish title in 1998, with the club competing in the Champions League for the first time last season.

Luton Town's manager Ricky Hill has parted company with the struggling Second Division club, who have had only two wins in 17 league matches. The club are understood to be ready to announce today that Hill, in charge for five months, will be replaced by his assistant Lil Fuccillo.

Fuccillo, 44, was an apprentice at Luton and had eight years with the club before leaving in 1983. He returned a month ago, becoming Hill's assistant after Chris Ramsay was sacked. Hill and Fuccillo are both former Luton players with Hill playing more than 500 games for the club.

Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, Chelsea's Holland striker, has failed to deny reports in the Spanish media linking him with a move to Barcelona, perhaps even this winter.

"Barcelona are a great club with some excellent players, but I can't say anything at the moment," said Hasselbaink. "I don't know anything concrete, although there are only two countries where I would play now - Spain and England." Hasselbaink, meanwhile, returned to Spain with the Dutch side last night, scoring in Holland's 2-1 win in a friendly in Seville.

Wes Brown could make a surprise comeback from his knee injury for Saturday's derby against Manchester City. Manchester United feared their young defender, who has just returned after 12 months out with cruciate ligament damage, could be out for longer after appearing to aggravate the injury last weekend. United's assistant manager Steve McClaren said: "It is not as serious as we first thought."

Aston Villa's 23-year-old Finnish international goalkeeper Peter Enckelman has signed a new long-term contract until the summer of 2005.

Sheffield United have turned down a deal worth £2.5m for Marcus Bent from their First Division rivals Crystal Palace.

webTitle: Art: Ian Davenport

fields.headline: Ian Davenport
fields.standfirst:
Tate
Liverpool
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Tate
Liverpool
Rating: ***
fields.body:
There is no way in. Ian Davenport's paintings stand there flat against the wall, impenetrable. They stick to the wall. They do not reach out into the atmosphere, nor do they draw you into some other pictorial place. There is none of what the influential American abstract painter Hans Hofmann called the push and pull of space.

Davenport's high, glass abstract surfaces are all full-frontal and up front. Words such as deep or shallow do not apply. Their space is as deep as the paint is thick, and he tends to lay it on pretty thin.

We might read that the artist puts his panels flat on the studio floor, pours the paint on, tips them up and lets the colour settle into pools. But the exhibited works bear as little trace of any action or movement as they do of the human hand or brush. They are paintings made of paint, pure and simple. This is, of course, their strength or failing.

Davenport's Project Space is the first exhibition in a new Tate Liverpool initiative. Contemporary artists are being invited to make new work specifically in response to the distinctive ground-floor gallery, with its stone-slab floors and warehouse columns. Davenport goes for a pure aesthetic complement. His immaculate images are in a different world from the rest of the room, which somehow now looks deserted.

Can we call these thin things images? As is to be expected, the titles give nothing away: Untitled, Orange. Untitled, Red. Untitled, Green and Magenta.

What we are confronted with is towering walls of colour, arranged into groups of two, three, four or six. The colours are paint colours rather than real world colours.

'Paint Donated by ICI Dulux Decorator Centres' reads a sign in bigger and bolder print than the artist's name. On to each field of straight-from-the- tin paint is inscribed a slim, linear arch. The panels stand there like sentinels. But that is not right either. They stand there like paintings, nothing else. They are certainly the kind of paintings about which it is near impossible to say, or write, anything.

 Until January 21. Details: 0151-702 7400.

webTitle: Elvis Costello and Deborah Harry go jazz

fields.headline: Elvis Costello and Deborah Harry go jazz
fields.standfirst:
Roy Nathanson
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Roy Nathanson
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Did the young Elvis Costello once dream of fronting a 21-piece band, swinging and singing his heart out, just like his dad, Ross MacManus, or Frank Sinatra, with a hat on the back of his head? If so, his dream came true at the end of Tuesday night when he sang the role of Singleton, the narrator of Roy Nathanson's Fire at Keaton's Bar and Grill, which had its UK premiere at the London jazz festival.

But though this magnum opus used a big band, with a six-piece rhythm section, six horns, eight singers and an accordion (Karen Street), they only appeared together on stage for the final Fire Suite Reprise, with Costello on terrific form while the band wailed and images of smoke, bars and close-ups filled the video screen behind in what was also a live, global webcast.

Nathanson, the saxophonist and co-founder (with trombonist Curtis Fowlkes) of the Jazz Passengers, deployed his augmented forces sparingly. Smart changes of mood, tempo and timbre meant singers such as David Driver, Darius de Haas, Nancy King and Kenny Washington had only a few minutes to shine before making way for the next line-up.

Nathanson apart, the most constant presence was JT Lewis, a terrific drummer whose sure-footed swing was teamed with Brad Jones on double bass and organist Reuben Wilson's bass pedals. Guitarist Adam Roberts and pianist Deidre Rodman fleshed out the chord changes and percussionist Bosco d'Oliveira was a great asset.

Ashley Slater, suitably villainous, sang Last Call and Cleveland Watkiss, yet another local hero, led a male voice quintet for Carol Ann, a driving groove augmented by the banshee sax wails of Nathanson and Marty Ehrlich.

Carol Ann is "Cups", the Keaton's bartender and a character sung by Jazz Passenger regular Deborah Harry, who delivered a couple of songs - Imitation of a Kiss, with its live fade, and the closing Cups (for which she wrote the lyrics). Harry announced Jazz Night at Keaton's in brisk, barkeep style: she has a certain iconic presence, which Nathanson deploys as skilfully as he directs his improvisers.

His achievement is to make his show sound something like a Broadway one. Both music and lyrics are shot through with nostalgia and loss and a remembrance of good times that couldn't possibly last - something with which every greying jazz and punk fan in the audience could identify.

webTitle: Dance: Rambert enter the odd world of Ek

fields.headline: Rambert enter the odd world of Ek
fields.standfirst:
Rambert Dance Company
Sadler's Wells
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Rambert Dance Company
Sadler's Wells
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Until now, Swedish choreographer Mats Ek has been known to British dance fans largely through television. We may have seen his artfully grotesque rewrites of 19th-century ballet on the screen, but apart from a season at Edinburgh a year and a half ago, we have neither felt their impact live, nor seen the full range of Ek's work.

It is a real coup for Rambert, then, that they've become the first British troupe to acquire one of his dances for their repertory. She Was Black (1995) looks from the start like vintage Ek in its presentation of a murky fantasy world fraught with incoherent desires. The stage is furnished with fragments of a domestic interior - a truncated staircase, an odd section of wall - while its cast of raffish deviants, including a fey, bowler-hatted man who dances on point, represent what Ek picturesquely describes in a programme note as "human litter".

Their dance language is deliberately bestial, comic and gauche. A pair of lovers lose the plot of their initially decorous duet as the man tries to waddle along on his knees with his head rammed between his girlfriend's legs, and the woman in a subsequent confusion of erotic roles starts pounding her groin against his backside. Dancers sniff and rummage around each other's bodies like thieving dogs; they launch into flights of dance that lead nowhere and their bursts of hyperactivity, goaded by Gorecki's 2nd String Quartet, are stalled by fits of bewildered disorientation.

Ek favours certain self- conscious oddities of style - duck-footed walks, waggling buttocks - that can seem like so many irksome jokes and there is a veneer of Chaplinesque goofiness that can overwhelm serious dance and psychology.

The dancing in She Was Black may be dysfunctional but weird beauties blossom from its rich and witty bending of choreographic logic. And if the characters start out looking theatrically eccentric they become, increasingly, compellingly strange as Rambert's dancers get under the skins and into the steps of their characters with magnificent conviction.

The company dance equally well in the revival of one of their old signature works, Christopher Bruce's Sergeant Early's Dreams. This setting of Irish, American and English folk songs was created in 1984 and, at first sight, Bruce's reflection of the mournful, ardent, comic stories contained within their lyrics may look homespun, even naive. Yet these are songs that Bruce clearly loved - and one of his greatest talents as a choreographer has always been to communicate the heart of his inspiration.

Ballads like Barbara Allen and Geordie, performed live by the excellent Sergeant Early's Band, carry a potent emotional charge which is all the more intense for the half-disclosed secrecies of their narratives.

And because Bruce's choreography is so direct (but also so much more knowing than it appears) the dancing always amplifies rather than muddies the effect.

It is a work that makes Riverdance and all its Celtic fusion spin-offs look like so much cynical packaging.

 Ends Saturday. Box office: 020-7863 8000.

webTitle: Abbey and BoS admit to top level merger talks

fields.headline: Abbey and BoS admit to top level merger talks
fields.trailText: Abbey National and Bank of Scotland admitted yesterday they had held top level talks about a possible merger as speculation mounted that Lloyds TSB or Barclays would enter the fray, writes Jill Treanor .
fields.body:
Abbey National and Bank of Scotland admitted yesterday they had held top level talks about a possible merger as speculation mounted that Lloyds TSB or Barclays would enter the fray, writes Jill Treanor .

Neither the Abbey nor the BoS chief executive attended yesterday's negotiations, a fact interpreted by City sources as an indication of the deep differences between the two banks.

The fact that the meeting was held at all, with both banks' chairmen and deputy chairmen, and the decision to issue a joint statement were described by one senior source last night as "highly significant".

The management of a combined BoS and Abbey is said to be the main stumbling block, with BoS convinced that Peter Burt, its chief executive, should remain while Abbey wants to "take over" BoS, suggesting Ian Harley, its chief executive, would be at the helm.

Neither bank would expand on yesterday's four-line statement to the Stock Exchange, their first pro nouncement since they were forced to reveal their talks 10 days ago. Abbey chairman, Lord Tugendhat, and his deputy Keith Woodley met BoS chairman Sir John Shaw with his deputy Sir Bob Reid and an "exchange of views" took place. "Further exchanges will now be considered by both parties," the banks said.

The statement appeared to indicate that little progress had been made, but the fact it was issued in both their names was said to be an indication that they were at least trying to soothe their tensions after an explosive start.

These differences have led to speculation that Lloyds TSB would find it impossible to resist bidding for one of the banks. Barclays is also seen as a potential bidder.

Royal Bank of Scotland yesterday appeared to rule itself out after chief executive Fred Goodwin said he would have liked to bid for a US bank but felt investors would be rattled by an acquisition so soon after its NatWest takeover.

webTitle: High street banks discover the semi-rich

fields.headline: High street banks discover the semi-rich
fields.standfirst:
Those who have £30,000-plus to spare can look forward to some serious schmoozing

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Those who have £30,000-plus to spare can look forward to some serious schmoozing.
fields.body:
It is the new buzz in the world of banking, a fresh battleground in a fiercely competitive sector. It is about tapping the "mass affluent." It might not trip off the tongue. It might even sound like a contradiction in terms. But Britain's big banks reckon one in 12 of the population falls into a mid-market wealthy category and they want a piece of it.

To qualify as a member of the "mass affluent," one has to have £50,000 or so of spare cash and a will to do something useful with it, but a lack of certainty about quite what.

Their ranks have no doubt been swollen by the dot.com rush, but bankers say such mid-market wealth is just as likely to have been amassed in the "old economy". As Tony Cohen, tax partner at Arthur Andersen, puts it, it is just that the advent of the e-era has awakened the financial industry to the trend. He claims his clients are more likely to be "serial entrepreneurs", creating companies and selling them on, in the old or new business world.

The sudden awareness of this wealthy breed, however, has set the hares running, and this week Abbey National joined the ranks of banks hoping to tap the market. Apparently, having decided that its brand lacked the cachet, Abbey is creating a new name, Inscape, to try to win their business. This unit is being formed despite the fact that Abbey already owns a traditional private bank catering for the well-off, Cater Allen.

The idea is to offer rather more than a regular current account, developing a deeper relationship and offering a broader range of services such as fund management.

To create the new image, Abbey chose the plush surroundings of Mayfair for the launch of Inscape, which will have a presence on the internet but will also have advice centres where "clients" - rather than boring, traditional "customers" - can speak to someone face to face.

Abbey's approach is one of many being tested by the banks, which have been forced by government to offer basic accounts for people on low incomes or those with poor credit ratings. They would much rather be wooing the growing numbers of people who have gained most from the years of economic growth, rising incomes and (until a few months ago) surging stock markets.

Barclays' attempt to reward its well-heeled customers with special deals, implemented this month, involves cutting personal loan rates for those with good track records in managing their finances. Such measures should have an impact much wider than Abbey's push for wealthy custom but demonstrates that there is a variety of approaches.

Royal Bank of Scotland is also making a fresh push through Coutts, the "Queen's bankers" which it acquired with NatWest this year. Even the most discreet and rarefied in the business of upmarket banking - the Swiss - are moving down-market a little to widen their client-base.

Crédit Suisse, Switzerland's second biggest bank, last week showed it was ready to tolerate less than uniformly blue blood by introducing an investment and banking service targeting a larger pool of people - the 7m Brits with £30,000-plus of "invested assets".

Crédit Suisse's Global Investor Portfolio account, which is predominantly seeking customers who are internet savvy, allows people to hold cash in up to four currencies, deal shares on 15 stock markets and buy unit trusts from an "investment supermarket". The seriously wealthy and reclusive superstar may not be all that excited - the minimum opening amount is a relatively modest £600.

Analysts believe the biggest impact in this contest will come from HSBC and its American partner Merrill Lynch, which in April pledged to launch a joint online banking and investment services venture.

But it is more a matter of promise than delivery because the industry is waiting for a name and a launch date. The two have set their entry level a little higher than Crédit Suisse, at "investable assets" of between £60,000 and £300,000, but there will also be a a network of "kiosk-style" branches across the country for the well-heeled to pop into.

It might feel like a throwback to the era when the local bank manager visited special treatment on his wealthier customers. But the oldest, truly blue-blooded names of the City are still suspicious of this mass-affluent crowd.

Andrew Sykes, for example, head of Schroder & Co, is differentiating his private banking push by setting his sights on those people with £250,000 of cash looking for a home. "Lots of organisations are part of something big. We have got something very niche to offer," Mr Sykes said.

Clients of Schroder & Co can expect more than a kiosk on the country's high streets. These are the people who can look forward to serious schmoozing.
