webTitle: My bosses are tearing me apart

fields.headline: My bosses are tearing me apart
fields.trailText: I'm in the middle of two bosses who don't talk to each other. They just send confusing messages through me. I want to leave.
fields.body:
The problem

I'm in the middle of two bosses who don't talk to each other. They just send confusing messages through me.

Besides, my salary and working conditions depress me and I want to leave. But I don't know if I should tell them or not.

Nadia Silva
Brasil

The Solution

Many people do face the same problem - or at least many people, especially secretaries and PAs, have to juggle the conflicting demands of more than one boss. When those bosses don't get on, life can be very awkward for the poor soul in the middle who often has to become referee, diplomat and peacemaker in addition to the roles required of the post.

If you wanted these extra duties, you would have joined the United Nations!

The best way to tackle two (or more) feuding bosses, is often to confront them. Whether you do this on an individual basis or get them when they are both together depends on the circumstances. If you confront them together, a slanging match could ensue, with each party blaming the other. On the other hand, confronting them separately might allow off loading of the blame onto the other, absent, boss. However you do it, you need to let them know that you are finding the situation intolerable. You need to establish some ground rules that both bosses understand. For example, you could make it clear that you will no longer allow confusing messages to go through you - ask them to each write down their message rather than have you deliver it yourself. Make it clear that you will not be dragged into their disputes and nor will you take sides. If this all sounds like how a mother might handle her feuding kids, you might be right, but then their behaviour is rather childish, isn't it?

As for your advising them about your intention to leave, I'd suggest you get a new job offer first, then give whatever notice is required in your contract.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

Advice given to this problem should only be regarded as a guide based on the limited information provided by the letter-writer. No responsibility can be taken by Dr Mann for any outcomes following advice given.

webTitle: EasyJet gets £850m shares lift

fields.headline: EasyJet gets £850m shares lift
fields.standfirst:
Low-cost carrier started five years ago with £5m is hit with investors

Special report: transport
fields.trailText: Stelios Haji-Ioannou, the founder and chairman of easyJet, yesterday saw the airline he started with a £5m loan from his father valued at more than £850m by the end of its first day as a quoted company.
fields.body:
Stelios Haji-Ioannou, the founder and chairman of easyJet, yesterday saw the airline he started with a £5m loan from his father valued at more than £850m by the end of its first day as a quoted company.

The 33-year-old easyJet chief, known simply as Stelios to his 1,400 staff, has sold 25% of the airline to outside shareholders. He has retained a 32% stake, worth some £275m at last night's closing share price.

EasyJet's flying start on the stockmarket contrasts sharply with its larger rival British Airways. It announced last week that it was pulling out of the no-frills airline business and putting its loss-making Go subsidiary up for sale.

EasyJet - which BA tried to buy just a year after it started flights from its Luton base - is one of the success stories of the skies. Last year it carried 5.6m passengers and made a profit of £22m. BA's Go carried 1.9m passengers last year and lost more than £21m.

The low cost carrier will use the money it raised from the stock market - about £200m - to buy more jets for its fleet, a move seen as a shot across the bows of its rivals.

With its trademark orange livery, easyJet has helped revolutionise short-haul travel for UK passengers. Passengers are given no food, no tickets and no pre-allocated seats, but they do enjoy much cheaper fares than on the traditional full service airlines.

When easyJet launched many questioned Mr Haji-Ioannou's philosophy, to which he pithily replied: "If you want a meal, go to a restaurant."

Eliminated

The airline industry had seen nothing like it since the days of Freddie Laker's Skytrain. Travel agents - and the commission they require for selling seats - were eliminated, with all bookings made direct. Nearly 80% of easyJet passengers now book on the internet.

In November 1995 Mr Haji-Ioannou had one plane, one route - London to Scotland - and a loudly trumpeted £29 fare, which was exactly one 10th of the price BA was demanding for the same journey.

Now he operates a fleet of 18 Boeing 737s, serving 28 routes, and has 32 new aircraft on order. As some planes are replaced easyJet plans to have a fleet of 44 aircraft by 2004.

It now has hubs in Liverpool and Geneva as well as Luton and is developing Amsterdam as a fourth hub.

However, it has no plans to move into low-cost long-haul flights, which would require different aircraft and the "expensive" business of putting two pilots on each flight.

The company - which Mr Haji-Ioannou started when he became bored with running a branch of the family shipping business in Athens - has doubled in size every year since its first flight in 1995 and its founder has become one of the UK's most high-profile businessmen.

In part this is thanks to his flair for publicity. He memorably took out full page adverts attacking Bob Ayling, the then boss of BA, and Barbara Cassani, who runs Go, as "the beauty and the beast".

More recently he has launched a campaign against Luton airport claiming that it was charging easyJet too much for the right to take off and land.

Again he loudly proclaimed to the media that Luton's big shareholder, Barclays, had placed a "£5 tax on passenger's tickets".

Despite his penchant for publicity the day-to-day running of easyJet is in the hands of chief executive Ray Webster, a former Air New Zealand executive. He has a 1% stake in the company now worth some £8m.

The shares began trading at 310p and quickly rose to 342p. Small investors were "locked out" of the flotation, but big City investors scrambled to buy the shares in the airline.

They were willing to buy nine times the number of shares on offer.

Mr Haji-Ioannou, whose brother and sister own 32% of the airline, said: "We are delighted by the high level of interest and support that institutional shareholders have shown."

All EasyJet's employees benefited from the float. Around 1,000 junior staff, including call centre operators and cabin crew, were given free packages of around 700 shares. Last night those packages were worth nearly £2,400.

But many senior staff and management have made much bigger gains on share options. The company's pilots were each given the right to buy around 25,000 shares at 182p each. Those options are now worth some £40,000. And several senior directors were given larger option packages which have turned them into paper millionaires.

The staff must keep their shares for between one and two years before they can take their profits.

Underdog who wins

Like Sir Richard Branson, Stelios Haji-Ioannou revels in being the underdog.

It is not the only similarity between the two. Like the Virgin chief, Mr Haji-Ioannou is a high-profile frontman. Behind both are deputies running their businesses, neither is frightened to march into court to protect his interests, and both have an eye for cheeky publicity stunts.

When British Airways launched its low-cost carrier, go, Mr Haji-Ioannou made a block booking on the inaugural flight - and he and his staff turned up in easyJet's trademark orange sweatshirts to take the limelight.

EasyJet is a dress-down operation. Ties are banned at the group's Luton base and Mr Haji-Ioannou has a desk in the vast open-plan office.

Virgin-style, he is now stretching the "easy" branding. There is easyRentacar and easyEverything, a chain of internet cafes.

Chasing the cheap flight millions

www.ryanair.com

Europe's biggest low-cost airline started flying in 1985 with one daily flight in a 15-seater from Waterford in Ireland to Gatwick. Today it carries some 7m passengers a year on 45 routes to destinations in 11 countries, and its staff number 1,400.

The company - started by the wealthy Ryan family - now is run by Michael O'Leary, an ebullient former accountant. Ryanair is listed on the Dublin stock exchange with a valuation of £2.1bn, about half the current value of British Airways.

The carrier has 35 Boeing 737s on order, to add to its fleet of 31. Last year it made a profit of IR£45.3m (£40.7m) while offering some of the cheapest fares.

www.easyJet.com

Started in 1995 by Stelios Haji-Ioannou with a £5m loan from his shipping magnate father.

The Luton-based carrier operates 18 with Boeing 737 airliners and has a further 32 on order. Last year easyJet's orange planes flew 5.6m passengers on 18 European routes and made a £22.1m profit.

Yesterday's float values the company at more than £850m - and the Haji-Ioannou family's 64% stake at more than£500m.

www.go-fly.com

The British Airways subsidiary, Go, was put up for sale last week.

It was started in 1998 in response to easyJet and Ryanair and is run by Bar-bara Cassani (above), a US-born former BA executive. The carrier operates Boeing 737s to 21 destinations and last year carried 1.9m passengers. It ran up losses of £22m.

www.buzzaway.com

Newest of the no-frills operators, Buzz is part of the Dutch KLM airline. Its first flights were in January this yuear and there have been no published passenger figures.

It operates eight BAe 146 aircraft and two Boeing 737s to 14 European destinations and flies into some of the major airports like Frankfurt, rather than secondary locations.

Its current best deals include Paris, Marseilles and Berlin for £29 one way.

All profiles: Julia Finch
